0.rationale:
USQ’s Strategic Plan, Educational Experience Plan (EEP), Operational and Resource Management Plans (e.g. ORMP, ICT Strategy/Portfolio of projects and the Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap) incorporate references to technological systems, processes, support, accessibility, digital and information fluency.

It was noted that some mechanisms to drive technology enhanced learning are still in development.
0.evidence:
• 2016 Operational Resource Management Plan (ORMP) – https://intranet.usq.edu.au/sbmi/Plans/Shared%20Documents/2016%20ORMP%20Final.pdf
    • The overall university operational plan includes key organisational priorities: ‘3. Build high quality 21st century learning environments’ by ‘Enhance the University's capacity and capability in online and blended learning, and technology-enhanced student support through the strategic deployment of information and communication technologies’. (2016 ORMP p 53)
    • Elements of the Academic Division Business Plan, relate to online learning and teaching standards development. The Academic Services Division Business Plan, points 1 and 2 specifically, include: ‘reducing barriers to, and providing tools and systems aimed at supporting improved performance ...‘ and ‘nurturing creativity and catalysing innovation in support of knowledge development and related systems’. (2016 ORMP)
  • Enterprise ICT Plan 2016 – 2020
  • Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap – https://lor.usq.edu.au/usq/items/1b057311-89af-489d-b3e0-c08751e4f144/0/LandT_Roadmap.pdf
  • Plans and reports – http://www.usq.edu.au/about-usq/about-us/plans-reports
  • Strategy at USQ – http://www.usq.edu.au/about-usq/about-us/plans-reports/strategic-plan
  • USQ Educational Experience Plan (EEP) – http://www.usq.edu.au/~/media/USQ/About-USQ/super-widgets/USQ%20Educational%20Experience%20Plan%20091215.pdf
    • Objective 1 of the Educational Experience Plan, states that: ‘All courses and educational services are designed to optimise learning opportunities through flexibility and personalisation enabled by online communication, digital media, and appropriate use of technology. This is true regardless of the nature of the learning environment. Delivery will be technology enhanced, mobile, personal, and media enabled’.
  • USQ Strategic Plan 2013-2015 – http://www.usq.edu.au/~/media/USQ/About-USQ/About%20us/12-1643_2013-15StratPlan1_0113_F_web.pdf
    • The Strategic Plan refers to student’s location of study, and not being a limitation. Page 8 states: ‘providing all students, regardless of location, enhanced access to student services and support’, in other words, the use of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL). The plan includes references to ‘emerging technologies’, ‘anticipate technological advances’, ‘engaging in highly digitalised manner’, ‘innovate and enhance delivery’ and includes a theme of ‘Personalised Learning’.
  • USQ Strategic Plan 2016 – 2020 – http://www.usq.edu.au/about-usq/about-us/plans-reports/strategic-plan
    • USQ’s vision includes ‘leadership in physical and digital higher education learning experiences geared to a diverse student constituency’ and education objectives which include, ‘Deploy learning environments that are student-centred, authentic, cooperative and engaging; and supported by an extended range of high quality resources, facilities and technologies.

1.rationale:
There appears to be a strategic alignment with a number of specific plans from the Academic, and Academic Services Divisions to enhance the quality of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL). However, anecdotal evidence suggests they are not well understood by coal face academic staff, not easy to locate or identify.

Relevant strategies include the continued streamlining of virtual learning environments, support for students’ ICT literacies and StudyDesk support for staff and students.

Under the Strategic Plan, the Educational Experience Plan (EEP) is designed to be aspirational, with what we are becoming, communicating important commitments, sparking the imagination, and leading the USQ community to important and practical investments in our educational experience.

Operational Plans encompass ORMP, ICT Strategy/Portfolio of projects and the Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap, all aligning to the strategy. The budget and project process attempts to align strategy with operations. The EEP – Educational Objective (EO) 1 is still in development with no procedure to date.
1.evidence:
• ORMP: Academic business plan – ‘establish related standards and guidelines, including, assessment hurdle and delivery mode definition standards. This will be in conjunction with Academic Services and Academic Board’ (p 63). ‘…deploy and continue to refine academic quality assurance framework…health checks for courses, programs…’ (p 64) This will include a review of the online learning environment, but is not explicit.
  • ORMP: Academic Services Division –
    • ‘Improvements in online learning and teaching capacity and experience including optimised: Staff development opportunities; Systems for students studying online; Systems for staff teaching online’ (p 68).
    • ‘To reduce barriers to and provide tools and systems aimed at supporting improved performance against the University’s strategic objectives’. Key strategies include: continued progress to improve learning content use and re-use, access and management including the eLearning Objects Repository (eLOR); renewal of library systems; recommendation of new systems capability (p 69).

2.rationale:
USQ clearly articulates Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) in Strategic and Operational plans, which points to these activities being Business As Usual (BAU), and therefore budgeted via the normal university budgeting processes.

The Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group reports to the ICT Services Committee, which is a check and balance into ICT Projects, services and strategy.
2.evidence:
• 2014 Council supported a proposal for additional ICT funding of $13 million over 5 years (Annual Report 2014).
  • 2015 USQ Annual Report – http://www.usq.edu.au/about-usq/about-us/plans-reports/annual-report
  • Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group (LTSAG)
  • One USQ Connectivity Project (1UCP) – Unified Communication
    • ‘The main focus of Unified Communication is on bringing together and supporting a suite of communication and collaboration tools to be offered as a Video Conference Service.’
  • Operational Resource Management Plan (ORMP)
    • Aligns tasks, budget and resourcing to the strategic plan and operations.
  • Various plans – https://intranet.usq.edu.au/sbmi/Plans/default.aspx

3.rationale:
There is limited specific policy or procedure around course and program level use of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL), beyond that all courses will use USQ’s Virtual Learning Environment (VLE). The Learning and Teaching Policy has a focus of online learning and pedagogy, and a blended learning model.

No official guidelines exist for TEL, but some are currently in draft form (e.g. StudyDesk Expectations and Good Practice Guidelines). Individual schools devise their own procedures, but this is limited. Information and Communication Technology (ICT) standards are related to service and use, rather than TEL.
3.evidence:
• Academic Programs and Courses Policy – http://policy.usq.edu.au/documents/13614PL
    • ‘Encompass the principles of best practice in curriculum design and utilize learning technologies and teaching approaches to provide for the broadest range of delivery modes.’
  • Good Practice Guidelines – Focus on online learning and the use of eLearning technologies. They reside in the eLearning Objects Repository (eLOR) and are available through sites such as Staff eLearning Environments (eLE).
  • ICT Standards – http://policy.usq.edu.au/polproc/category/Information%20and%20Records%20Management/ICT%20Standards
  • Learning and Teaching Policy – http://policy.usq.edu.au/documents/1348PL
    • ‘Staff and Student engagement and learning is enhanced through learning design, pedagogy, use of technology and aligned assessment strategies that are sustainable. This is achieved through a focus on online learning and pedagogy. On-campus Course offerings will normally use a Blended Delivery Model using the approved Virtual Learning Environment.’
    • ‘The approved Virtual Learning Environment will contribute to the personalisation of the Student Learning Journey. All Course offerings will involve use of the University's Virtual Learning Environment.’

4.rationale:
Currently, course and program quality is in pilot mode, and relevant guidelines are being raised for approval by the Senior Deputy Vice-Chancellor (SDVC). As such, it is difficult to provide much evidence of existing integration.

Guidelines in draft, include StudyDesk Expectations and Good Practice Guidelines, but currently, these are not integrated into processes and not well communicated.

Some schools have their own procedures, but this is limited and not well communicated.
4.evidence: • Good Practice Guidelines – Focus on online learning and the use of eLearning technologies. They reside in the eLearning Objects Repository (eLOR) and are available through sites such as Staff eLearning Environments (eLE).

5.rationale:
USQ committees include stakeholders from various areas of the university. There is some input from academics, but decisions and changes are decided by the technology, and its limitations.

The flow of information and communication is generally perceived as good. Committee minutes are accessible, and school forums provide an avenue for communication.
5.evidence:
• Academic Board – Faculty and School Groups
  • Academic Division Learning and Teaching Committee – Learning environment issues that affect teachers fall within scope.
  • ICT Governance Structure - http://www.usq.edu.au/ict/pmm
  • ICT Relationship meeting – Helps mediate systems-based issues.
  • ICT Services Committee – Oversees stakeholder satisfaction.
  • ICT Strategy Board – Governs and budgets for USQ’s systems. Three sub-committees with cross-department representation oversee the work.
  • Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group (LTSAG) – Reports to ICT Services Committee, and has sideways reporting to the Education Management Committee, if required.
  • Systems Operational Groups – Governance is mature and includes substantial stakeholders across each.

6.rationale:
USQ adopts a system of Product Custodians, Sponsors, and Managers which works well. However, these are not centrally publicised or promoted. There is confusion at times, particularly from an academic perspective, as to who is responsible for the technologies they use.

The Academic Services Division (ASD) provides operational management of technologies, and this is communicated through forums such as the IT Governance Structure, academic groups, School forums, and systems operational groups.

7.rationale:
The USQ, ICT Governance Framework (investment and innovation pipeline) is unclear about the selection criteria, other than alignment with USQ’s plan. The innovation pipeline has to be implemented through projects.

Operational management of technologies is provided by the Academic Services Division (ASD) and communicated through forums such as the IT Governance Structure, academic groups, school forums, and systems operational groups.

Communication and consultation with relevant stakeholders could be improved. The One USQ Connectivity Project – Unified Communication is an example of technologies being provided.

0.rationale:
Quality assurance processes are a work in progress with an ad hoc approach to the integration of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL), at both program and course level. Common guidelines, such as the StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form, programs of work via eLearning Development (eLD), program support projects, and Course Health Checks by the faculty, provide some consistency of approach and performance indicators.

Course and program quality is mediated by the Academic Division (AD), with the extent of TEL integration dependent on course and examiner requirements. The AD does have a level of expectation in relation to the services offered by Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services and Learning Environments and Media (LEM).

ICT undertake a staff satisfaction survey (2014 is most recent) to ensure their services are quality checked. The survey also includes questions related to the support of technologies, for a quality check on services provided by LEM. An email address (new.studydesk@usq.edu.au) has been established by LEM, for staff to submit, new ideas, change requests, satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the USQStudyDesk (Moodle).

A traffic light approach is not robust enough and accountability is limited. USQ’s online course environment will be the focus of a Course Quality Framework, and the implementation phase of the A-2, A-1 Program Quality Framework being piloted in 2016. Project Management methodologies for ICT Projects provides a clear focus on quality assurance, but this is not at a program and course level.
0.evidence:
• ICT Staff Survey 2014 – http://www.usq.edu.au/ict/ictsurveymetrics
  • Learning and Teaching and Academic Quality / Learning and Teaching – http://policy.usq.edu.au/policy/category/Learning%20and%20Teaching%20and%20Academic%20Quality/Learning%20and%20Teaching
  • Student Expectations and Responsibilities Policy – http://policy.usq.edu.au/documents/13446PL
    • The ‘Technology to support learning’ section.
  • StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form – https://lor.usq.edu.au/usq/items/1864d79c-8730-407d-9787-b5f503055c0b/0/Studydesk_Review_2015_3.docx
    • Good practice principles and indicators to use when reviewing a StudyDesk.
  • StudyDesk email – new.studydesk@usq.edu.au
    • Managed by Learning Environments and Media (LEM).

1.rationale:
When a new service is proposed, a rigorous evaluation process is applied and usually associated with a formal project. There is a collaborative approach between Academic Services Division (ASD), driven by Scholarly Information and Learning Services (SILS), and the Academic Division (AD), as multiple levels of approvals are required, particularly if the service has the potential to become a ‘core system’. For tools (plugins) associated with a core system, a trial phase and quality checks are instigated by Information and Communication Technology Services (ICT) Services and Learning Environments and Media (LEM). In some instances, limited user testing is undertaken due to time constraints.

The One USQ Experience Project (1UEP), Technology Demonstrator sub-project is identifying and trialling technologies, but this is not a mature process at this time.

ICT and LEM’s Learning Systems and Support (LSS) evaluate systems and support data to drive technology decision-making.
1.evidence:
• Enterprise ICT Plan 2016 – 2020
  • ICT Governance Structure - http://www.usq.edu.au/ict/pmm
  • ICT Strategy Board – Governs and budgets for USQ’s systems. Three sub-committees with cross-department representation oversee the work.
  • Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group (LTSAG) – Reports to ICT Services Committee, and has sideways reporting to the Education Management Committee.
  • Technology Demonstrators Showreel – https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4iNkCRnEccs&feature=youtu.be

2.rationale:
Regular scheduled updates and patches on core systems are planned for, and resourced from Business As Usual (BAU). Unless forming part of a project, innovation and major improvements are also resourced from BAU, which can put a strain on various departments. Some improvements tend to be ad hoc, or incremental, but not at a consistent pace.

Although infrastructure improvement is supported, there is often limited resourcing for professional development. It can be difficult to access staff resources with the expertise required, in a timely manner.
2.evidence: • USQ ICT Governance Framework FAQs – http://www.usq.edu.au/ict/pmm/ictgovframeworkfaqs

3.rationale:
The student course evaluation, using the MyOpinion system with limited technology-based questions, is a core component of the quality cycle at USQ. Access to view the course reports is limited (Academics teaching the course, Head of School, Executive Dean, Associate Dean Learning and Teaching, Senior Deputy Vice-Chancellor), so this can pose difficulty for departments to drive change.

Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services provide a client satisfaction survey for each staff and student incident they manage, to analyse and plan for continuous improvement.

A key objective in the Academic Services Division (ASD) business plan is: ‘To support the continuous improvement of learning and teaching outcomes for staff, students and other constituents’. (ORMP) This includes an outcome of improving systems for students studying, and staff teaching online. A link between KPIs in the ORMP business plans and forms of evaluation in this space are not clear.

KPIs exist in relation to performance uptime, however there is room to increase this aspect of our work at USQ. System data and information tends to be accessible across courses only, not programs, schools or faculties. For key support areas such a Learning Systems and Support (LSS), there is limited knowledge and access to reporting tools for the Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) modules.

A formal review of major core systems is scheduled in the Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap. A cross-institutional represented group is assembled to review current usage data. Typically a short satisfaction survey is circulated to gain input from end users.
3.evidence:
• 2016 Operational Resource Management Plan (ORMP) – https://intranet.usq.edu.au/sbmi/Plans/Shared%20Documents/2016%20ORMP%20Final.pdf
  • ICT Client Satisfaction Survey – http://usqassist.custhelp.com/ci/documents/detail/5/175/12/78d8afc90a0c25363c73ab4a921929fe41d69e40

  • Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap – https://lor.usq.edu.au/usq/items/1b057311-89af-489d-b3e0-c08751e4f144/0/LandT_Roadmap.pdf
  • Student Course Evaluation – http://www.usq.edu.au/sbmi/strategic-information/survey/student-course-evaluation
  • USQ Annual Report – http://www.usq.edu.au/about-usq/about-us/plans-reports/annual-report

4.rationale: Apart from USQ’s Annual Report, outcomes are generally reported to committees, with the Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group (LTSAG) one such committee. Those outside of committees rarely see results, unless invited to a school committee to share findings. A ‘climate of protectionism’ is perceived in relation to the inability to access academic course data. There is no systematic dissemination of data with a wider audience.
4.evidence:
• Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group (LTSAG)
  • USQ Annual Report – http://www.usq.edu.au/about-usq/about-us/plans-reports/annual-report

0.rationale:
The One USQ Experience Project (1UEP) is currently investigating options for a robust system, with Sustainable Business Management and Improvement (SMBI) working on a Learning and Teaching (L&T) Dashboard, although a solution is not imminent. A recently formed USQ analytics group, is working on a framework for the development and use of appropriate data and analytical methods.

Access to data, along with reporting capabilities is more readily available from USQ hosted core systems (e.g. Learning Management System (LMS) – Moodle), and limited access to others (e.g. Blackboard Collaborate Web Conferencing). RightNow (customer relationship management software) data is fed into the LMS and a learning analytics plug in provides data to teachers.

There is an ad hoc approach to data collection, usually when a specific need arises (e.g. lecture capture use, repository item status), and no reporting specialist to facilitate a systematic approach.
0.evidence:
• One USQ Experience Project (1UEP)
  • L&T Data Warehouse High-level Architecture

1.rationale:
The implementation of Ask USQ for Staff will aid in enhancing communication, but this is not a fully mature system yet. With the current Academic Services Division (ASD) structure, responsibilities and processes are fragmented, e.g. Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services and Learning Systems and Support (LSS).

Responsibilities are clearly outlined in ICT’s Maintenance Schedule, and Products and Services Catalogue, Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group’s (LTSAG) Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap (systems upgrade and decommission), and the Learning Systems and Support (LSS) Services Catalogue. It is less clear in relation to innovation, and there is a lack of flexibility.

Although stakeholder representatives attend committee and relationship meetings, information is not disseminated to all stakeholders. It is felt that processes and responsibilities are clearer within the ASD, as opposed to the Academic Division (AD). The ICT Governance Structure outlines the ICT Strategy Board with its three committees (Portfolio, Services and Standards Committees).

  • ICT Products and Services Catalogue – http://www.usq.edu.au/ict/prodserv
  • ICT Staff Service Catalogue – http://www.usq.edu.au/ict/servcat
  • Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group (LTSAG)
  • Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap – https://lor.usq.edu.au/usq/items/1b057311-89af-489d-b3e0-c08751e4f144/0/LandT_Roadmap.pdf

  • Maintenance Schedule – http://www.usq.edu.au/current-students/support/computing/maintenance-schedule
  • Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) reporting

2.rationale:
Although there is no policy defining support and training for staff and students in relation to Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) systems, there are clearly defined responsibilities and processes outlined during orientation activities, StaffEd presentations, School forums, ICT Training, and various USQ sites (e.g. Student Computing, USQStudyDesk Skills, Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services, and Learning Systems and Support (LSS) service catalogues). The platform for self-managed staff support delivery, starts with Ask USQ for Staff, leading into areas of the Staff Development Gateway, Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) and Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS).

In the past, student support with learning and teaching technologies was limited, but in recent years, support has increased substantially with the collaboration of ICT, LSS, Library, and Learning and Teaching Services (LTS). The platform for delivery of such support is Ask USQ, which houses the search and standardised view of the support framework, leading onto materials stored in central repositories.

Identification of contact points remains confusing to staff and students, with numerous specialised support teams across USQ.

The Academic Services Division (ASD) Professional Learning Working Group was established in 2015, to define responsibilities for training in systems, with an aim to align training to the Academic Calendar.

  • Computing (students mainly) – http://www.usq.edu.au/current-students/support/computing
  • ICT Staff Service Catalogue – http://www.usq.edu.au/ict/servcat
  • Learning Systems and Support (LSS) Services Catalogue – http://mystaffdesk.usq.edu.au/moodle2/mod/book/view.php?id=24504
  • Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS) – http://mystaffdesk.usq.edu.au/moodle2/mod/page/view.php?id=36792
  • Staff Development Gateway – http://mystaffdesk.usq.edu.au/moodle2/course/view.php?id=1602
  • StaffEd – http://www.usq.edu.au/learning-teaching/2016staffed
  • Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) – http://mystaffdesk.usq.edu.au/moodle2/mod/page/view.php?id=34699

3.rationale:
New services, and some major upgrades are usually delivered via formal projects, and are substantially resourced. USQ dedicates recurrent and strategic funding to Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) systems, with projects such as the Learning Management System (LMS) upgrade resourced with the Structural Adjustment Fund (SAF), Integrated StudyDesk, and the One USQ Connectivity Project (1UCP) – Unified Communication, aligning and supporting USQ’s Video Conference Service.

Resourcing challenges occur for mainstreaming systems after project completion and ongoing maintenance. With a lengthy timeline to decommission systems (mostly due to Queensland archiving rules), this can place a strain on resources for maintenance and support. Opportunities for investigation and extending the use of a product are restricted due to resourcing implications.
3.evidence:
• USQ Annual Report (SAF finalisation) – http://www.usq.edu.au/about-usq/about-us/plans-reports/annual-report
  • Enterprise ICT Plan 2016 – 2020
  • ICT Governance Structure – http://www.usq.edu.au/ict/pmm
  • One USQ Connectivity Project (1UCP) – Unified Communication

4.rationale:
USQ’s investment in the experimentation of new and emerging technologies has been limited. An initiative showing great promise in this space, is the One USQ Experience Project (1UEP), Technology Demonstrators sub-project. The project’s aim is to identify and trial technologies for learning and teaching, each in a limited timeframe. StaffEd presentations provide another arena to showcase ideas.

Requests for system improvement, innovation and new technology can be submitted to the Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group (LTSAG). However, there are limited procedures available, so this forum relies on word-of-mouth amongst colleagues. Sector scans and USQ’s Project Management Lifecycle are used to evaluate new technologies. Learning Environments and Media (LEM) maintains the Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap which incorporates formal review periods.

Some staff have been deterred from pursuing wide acceptance of alternative technologies, due to the time lag involved from initial request to implementation as a core system. It is however, important to have a robust process to mainstream tools to validate compatibility, security and support. eLearning Development (eLD) provide some support to academics in the use of alternative technologies when redeveloping courses.

5.rationale:
Staff are provided with opportunities, and encouraged to attend Professional Development (PD) when available. Some external opportunities may be limited due to budget constraints.

The ICT Training team, in conjunction with Learning Systems and Support (LSS), provide regular training on core systems. Biannual StaffEd presentations are conducted to keep staff abreast of core system updates, and deliver Academic Showcases. Teams, in varying degrees, incorporate PD in their Business As Usual (BAU) activities.

In relation to new and emerging technologies, this tends to be a mix of ad hoc, and planned internal or external activities. A small percentage of staff attend conferences such as MoodleMoot AU, ascilite, Equella Navigate, and EduTECH. A community of practice model exists, where those staff attending a conference are encouraged to present, then return to share their experience with colleagues.

6.rationale:
USQ has mature risk management initiatives, with the ICT Governance Structure, including the ICT Strategy Board and supported by three committees – Information Standards Committee, ICT Services Committee and ICT Portfolio Committee. Reporting is ultimately up to USQ Council.

IT Service Management (ITSM) software, which incorporates the Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) processes, is used by Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services, and Learning Systems and Support (LSS) to manage support incidents. Issues are highlighted through the ICT Service Desk and LSS then escalate to the appropriate team for a resolution as quickly as possible. Further usability improvements and system upgrades are handled by a software ticketing system called Gemini. This allows for proper release management and development cycles to be catered for.

Significant issues are also addressed via ICT Customer Relationship Meetings (CRM).

ICT adopts stringent security protocols around authentication, virus protection, backups, and digital rights management within repositories.

7.rationale:
There are numerous paths for staff to access technology support, but a lack of cohesion and clarity about the appropriate path is evident. The intention of the Staff Development Gateway, is to provide an avenue to access Academic Services Division staff support from one location, but this site has not been widely adopted.

Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services and Learning Systems and Support (LSS) have defined processes for support, including escalations, which are communicated, but not always followed.

Mechanisms provided for staff technology support include, ICT, LSS, LTS, Ask USQ for Staff, Staff eLE, PLAS, academic orientation, UConnect, Talk Nerdy (weekly videos), StaffEd presentations, Academic Info Bites (information session) and Learning and Teaching Communique. Communication about some of these pathways is ad hoc between departments and across USQ as a whole.

0.rationale:
There is a strong connection between Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL), and strategic plans and policies which express online learning as a hallmark of the university. The USQ Educational Experience Plan (EEP) principles include USQ’s approach to the use and deployment of technology and information systems. The application of technologies is implicit, with all course offerings involving the use of the Virtual Learning Environment (VLE), Moodle and associated tools (USQStudyDesk). This provides staff and students with the ability to use mobile technologies, communication tools, digital media and assessment tools.

The Associate Deans Learning and Teaching communicate with staff regularly at School forums and via a newsletter. Learning and Teaching Services (LTS) assist teachers to develop and review StudyDesk courses with the aid of eLearning projects, and course enhancement processes that use the StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form, which articulates good practice principles and indicators, including the use of technologies and online student engagement. The One USQ Experience Project (1UEP) outcomes will aid Learning and Teaching service application enhancement.

A key aim of the USQ Strategic plan is ‘leadership in physical and digital higher education learning experiences geared to a diverse student constituency’.

1.rationale:
At the course level, there has been a widespread application of the StudyDesk review criteria and indicators by the Academic Services Division (ASD), and Faculties which has led to some strengthening of the connection between Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) and pedagogy. This is currently applied on a relatively ad hoc basis by Schools, but will become increasingly systematised as the USQ strategic course quality system is enacted over time.

At the program level, there has been some use of the StudyDesk review criteria and indicators as part of re-accreditation and program development activities, but these function only at the course experience level. There is less connection between program design, TEL and online pedagogy. There are however, some good examples of whole-of-program implementation, for example, Bachelor of Midwifery, and the Masters of Project Management.

Learning and Teaching Services (LTS) apply good practice principles, and proactively identify issues for resolution during the review and enhancement of courses and programs as nominated by the Faculties. This review and redevelopment process has not been consistently adopted at either course or program level, and not evident that the recommended 5% course audit is being conducted. There is no approved template or set of expectations, that is enforced, about what is expected on StudyDesk, and pedagogical intent is largely left to the individual.

There is potential for improvement in this space with the A-2, A-1 Program Quality Framework being piloted in 2016, and Course Health Check which will be a systematic trigger for course and program enhancements.

2.rationale:
The StudyDesk review criteria and indicators, are based on sound educational research, legal guidelines, and accessibility guidelines (including Disability Standards for Education). Design principles and guidelines are promoted via avenues such as professional development and StaffEd presentations, but there is no evidence available as to how they are used. Although guidelines are available, it can be difficult locating them in a timely manner, and some are in need of a review and update.

To manage USQ’s legal obligations in relation to copyright compliance of digital objects, Digital Rights Management (DRM) is employed within USQ’s Equella repositories.

Resources and guidelines are not always evidence-based, but rather a sharing of practice. Sites such as Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) and Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS) provide a platform for staff to share their experiences with learning and teaching practices and technologies.

The USQ Salon Series and StaffEd presentations provide opportunities for knowledge sharing and conversation with internal and external experts.

4.rationale:
Learning and Teaching Services (LTS) dedicate 1 FTE academic staff and the eLearning Development (eLD) section to the development of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) pedagogies. eLD are upskilling from their previous role to provide greater support to academics in the review and development of their online courses. Ad hoc school-based attempts to improve pedagogical practice are ongoing with limited traction, and there are some communities of practice funded.

The Pro Vice-Chancellor (Scholarly Information and Learning Services) and Executive Director (ADFI) is an advocate for the competitive funding opportunities that are available, such as the 2015 USQ Learning and Teaching Grant (e.g. USQ Open Textbook initiative), and 2016 Open Educational Practice Grant. Projects such as the One USQ Experience Project (1UEP) provide a mechanism for technology development, with some alignment to plans such as the Educational Experience Plan (EEP).

5.rationale:
Sustainability is an explicit focus of eLearning tasks within Learning and Teaching Services (LTS), and component of a criterion in the StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form. Other opportunities to support sustainability of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL), include the Equella repositories, StaffEd presentations and Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS).

There is support with top-down funding, but there is a lack of direction around expectation and interpretation, so the application of pedagogy is inconsistent. Based largely on the technical ability of individual course examiners, some cases are sustainable and others completely unsustainable.

6.rationale:
The MyOpinion course evaluation collects data on all courses, with some questions in relation to pedagogical impact. However, uptake is varied and specific mention of technology enhanced learning is not undertaken. A review of the MyOpinion questions, and an update of platform is currently being conducted.

eLearning Development (eLD) utilise the StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form for course review and development, combined with a log of service for work completed on a StudyDesk. There is limited use of before and after review data at this stage. Ad hoc evaluations of support impact occur incidentally as part of Enrich and Promotion applications.

A Course Health Check and evaluation ‘dashboard’ approach to course evaluation is in its infancy, and yet to demonstrate impact. There has been a reliance on anecdotal evidence, though it is anticipated that the advent of the Course Health Check will improve this.

5.rationale:
USQ does aim to provide flexible staff development options which cater for differing skill levels. Training tends to be Toowoomba centric, via video conferencing or both. Staff development via video conferencing systems, needs to be facilitated well, and this is not always the case.

Professional development programs will usually focus more on technically challenged users, so power users may be overlooked. However, with the introduction of StaffEd, we are now showcasing the more experienced users and how they use the technology in an innovative way with their teaching and learning.

Increased engagement with the Academic Division for the delivery of online and physical induction and orientation programs, is proving to be successful.

Online resources are continually being developed and improved for just-in-time access. Talk Nerdy videos are delivered as short snippets of information. Whereas, Ask USQ for Staff provides more comprehensive how-to information, while Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS) and Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) are respectively focussed on pedagogical and contextual areas. StaffEd presentations are delivered face-to-face at the Toowoomba campus, but also incorporates Zoom for Toowoomba and other campus staff to participate.

Learning Systems and Support (LSS), eLearning Development (eLD), and Information and Communication (ICT) Services accommodate varied skill levels when delivering workshops, training or one-on-one assistance. The Equella repositories manage learning objects, and provides the ability to download objects for use offline.

Technical support is most definitely aligned and responsive, with the support provided by Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services and Learning Systems and Support (LSS). Media Services support audio, video, multimedia and graphics. The Library’s repository team provide user support for the Equella repository instances. eLearning Development (eLD) provide support for a small percentage of courses being reviewed, and LTS have, in the past, provided a range of education support, but this is lacking in 2016. Sites such as Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) and Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS) are further support mechanisms.

Zoom, cloud-based video conferencing technology, has recently been adopted by USQ for widespread use, with support from ICT and LSS. The One USQ Experience Project (1UEP), Technology Demonstrator sub-project is identifying and trialling technologies, but this is not a mature process at this time. A working party is being established to evaluate the use of tablets. At times, support of technologies appears to be more reactive than proactive, with expectations ever changing.

Information and Communication Technology (ICT) use Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) processes and implement evaluation of a client satisfaction survey on a regular basis, exit surveys from ICT professional development sessions, Ask USQ for Staff and the Talk Nerdy videos.

Regular Information Communication and Technology (ICT) relationship, and School meetings occur with representatives from support areas present, but these meetings are not solely focussed on support.

Ad hoc coordination occurs between Learning Systems and Support (LSS), ICT Training and the ICT Service Desk. Representatives visiting the Springfield and Ipswich campuses aid in coordination of support services. Learning and Teaching Services (LTS), Learning Systems and Support (LSS) and the Library coordinate individual consultations, orientation and referrals.

The Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group (LTSAG) provides coordination of relevant teams and individuals for systems related to learning and teaching. Attempts to create an Academic Services Division (ASD) Professional Development Group are ongoing. The StaffEd presentations require a coordinated effort across USQ twice a year.

Ad hoc extended hours are offered if required (e.g. support for out of hours Blackboard Collaborate Web Conferencing sessions). Learning and Teaching Services also provide some support for Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) and coordinate with teams such as ICT and LSS when required.

Support resources are accessible 24/7 via sites such as Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) and Ask USQ for staff.

LTS professionals work with faculty colleagues to influence, design, produce and deliver online and printed learning materials for OU students. This is a collaborative arrangement which engages our dedicated TEL, Development and Production, and Commissioning teams.

We also produce MOOCs for the FutureLearn platform, working closely with the Open Media Unit, and undertake a significant amount of OU corporate and commercial work.

We have an efficient warehouse and distribution operation for physical module items sent to students and support students through the Computing Helpdesk.

We are an enabler and incubator of innovative ideas adding value to academic module content, generating outputs efficiently and cost-effectively, and continually adapting to meet the pace of change required by the OU, impacted by globalisation, innovation and the changing nature of the HE sector.

0.rationale:
Positives: There are a wide variety of sources of analytical data to support decision making, and a number of projects focused specifically on this area such as Analytics for Action and Analytics for Student Success – this has raised the profile of the use of analytics over the last two years.  Data is available at institutional level where it feeds into the institutional dashboard. It is also available at module level and there is support to faculty staff from IET Data Wranglers and the LTS TEL Design Team for help with data interpretation.  The SAS Visual Analytics and Data Visualisation system provides on-demand data to support decision making at module level.  There are guidelines for using data to identify the need for interventions.

Negatives: Data and reports are generated across a number of units and sometimes there is overlap or gaps in coverage and distribution. There is not yet a systematic and effective process for ensuring the data is fed into the module production process. Awareness of the available data and associated guidance varies across the university, and there isn’t a clearly shared understanding about how staff in different roles can engage with and act upon data in addition to their existing responsibilities, therefore the extent to which data is used varies across units.
0.evidence: As above

1.rationale:
Positives: There are clear responsibilities and processes for implementing and maintaining TEL systems.  The roles and responsibilities are well understood between LTS who act as the business owners of the VLE and associated learning systems and tools, and the IT department who implement, monitor and maintain them.  There is an IT Operations Bridge that monitors systems and an IT Helpdesk that manages queries, incidents and issues around learning systems. Budget and resource to manage and maintain the University’s learning systems is ring-fenced within LTS and IT. Within LTS and IT there is a Systems Management Group and Systems Strategy Group for operational management and strategic governance, respectively. An established agile development method is in place with maintenance and project work being managed via an extensive product backlog.

Negatives: It was felt that while there are responsibilities and process for core learning systems, e.g. within the VLE, there is less control over external/proprietary systems such as OU Live and some Library systems. The processes for incident management are not well understood by departments outside IT and it is not always clear who to contact if there are issues with day to day system activities.  Also noted that although there are well established processes and responsibilities within business units and faculties, coordination between units could be improved.
1.evidence: As above

2.rationale:
Positives: Training and support for staff is largely via online guidance material such as the Online Learning Systems Guide, face-to-face via monthly drop in sessions, ad hoc induction sessions for new starters, and on-demand training sessions on request from LTS Learning Systems Service Administrators and the Online Services Team. There is a TEL in practice site for information and specific application of systems and tools.   Operational support for staff is via Online Services (first line, day-to-day support), and LTS Learning Systems (second line). Associate Lecturers have specific training for their role. Support for students is via online guidance material such as the Help Centre and Student Computing Guide and by telephone or email support from the Student Computing Helpdesk. Students are mainly supported with guidance material (both centralised and module-specific).

Negatives: The take up of training varies across the university and tends to be on an ad hoc/on-demand basis, rather than systematic. Not all staff are aware of what training is available or where to go to ask for it. Students are not offered routine training in using TEL systems, but there are some specific online live training sessions available from the Library from time to time.
2.evidence: As above

3.rationale:
Positives: There is a significant amount of dedicated resource within LTS and IT to implement and maintain the core learning systems and tools. This includes LTS Product Development Managers, who act as business owners on behalf of the university, Service Administrators, designers and analysts. In IT there are Technical Developers, Business Analysts, Scrum Masters and Solution Architects. There are also Interactive Media Designers within LTS who can develop bespoke module-specific TEL assets. In addition, there are dedicated teams for TEL Design, Online User Experience and Learning Innovation. There is dedicated ring-fenced budget for systems implementation and maintenance. The prioritisation of work is managed strategically via the Learning Systems Roadmap and Systems Strategy Group, and operationally via the IT TFS backlog.

Negatives: Although there is a substantial amount of resource and expertise is dedicated to TEL systems, there is also a significant backlog of work, balancing new strategic priorities against ongoing operational requirements. The prioritisation of this work is managed within LTS to ensure key deliverables are met within the finite budget of the university. It was felt that the university invests more in implementing new systems and tools than in maintaining existing systems and this is an issue because of the notable proportion of technical debt and legacy systems constraining some areas. For example, the university is sometimes too slow to take the decision to decommit from specific systems and tools. Within this context it was noted that student-facing systems are prioritised, unavoidably, over internal staff systems and tools.
3.evidence: As above

4.rationale:
Positives: There is a substantial amount of innovation and horizon scanning taking place across the university. There are dedicated teams and projects related to these areas in LTS, IET and KMI. Strategic funding for the cross-unit Minerva programme and the OpenCreate project to experiment with different technologies and processes are examples of strong encouragement and support from VC and PVC level. There are also subject/module-specific experiments and innovations, such as Open Science Lab and the various STEM lab initiatives. The specific objective relating to leadership in digital innovation in the new University Strategy was noted as a strong foundation for future opportunities.

Negatives: There were mixed views about the funding and resourcing for innovative projects.  A large number of experimental projects were quoted but there was also frustration expressed at the difficulty in securing funding for such projects. There is an appetite to do more in this area than can be achieved with current resourcing, and for more sharing of the learning from these projects so new ideas can be evaluated and adopted consistently. More generally, there was a feeling that the university is far too risk averse in its approach to experimentation and that current processes can hinder innovation.
4.evidence: As above

5.rationale:
Positives: Personal development is encouraged and all units have a training and development budget; the university has a process for identifying training needs as part of its appraisal system. There are regular drop-in sessions, special interest groups and VLE release briefings, but attendance is voluntary. Staff are expected to identify their own training needs and request training courses or attendance at conferences and these requests are usually signed off.

Negatives: The approach to training is more reactive than systematic and tends to favour existing systems and technologies over new and emerging ones. Making time in workloads to proactively attend training events or conferences was seen as a significant blocker, and a notable inconsistency with the fact that personal development is encouraged from senior management.
5.evidence: As above

6.rationale:
Positives: TEL risks are managed in the same way as other strategic and operational risks, through the University’s project management methodology, Unit-specific risk registers and associated governance. Risks and issues associated with new developments are identified within business cases and monitored via project/programme plans. IT has operational processes in place for support and escalation of issues with student/tutor-facing systems, both during and out of office hours. It also has a dedicated IT Security team. Both IT and LTS have technical testing teams who test software before it is released. IET carry out developmental and accessibility testing. The Online Student Experience team in LTS carry out UX and usability testing via external consultants.

Negatives: The University is regarded as risk averse and it is felt that this hampers experimentation with any new or emerging technologies. Not all risks associated with providing effective TEL systems are within the University’s control – students are responsible for providing their own internet connections, their own devices and for keeping their browsers and other software up to date. We provide guidance to students on minimum computing requirements for each module in the prospectus, and ongoing online technical support and guidance is offered via the Student Computing Guide and the Help Centre.
6.evidence: As above

7.rationale:
Positives: Support and pathways for assistance are well established and available. There are regular face-to-face and email communications such as drop-in sessions, release briefings and comms about guidance updates.  Comprehensive information is available online. One-to-one on-request support is available from Service Administrators, Product Development Managers and Senior TEL Designers.

Negatives: Not all staff are aware of the support available and not all staff engage with the communications.  There is a challenge in that there are so many systems and tools, and a perception of crossover of roles and responsibilities, for example between LTS, IET and IT, it is not always clear to all staff where they should go for support.
7.evidence: As above

0.rationale:
Positives: The use of TEL is at the core of the OU’s mission statement in terms of being open to people, places, methods and ideas, and leadership in digital innovation is embedded in the new Students First strategy. As our main delivery method is online, TEL is grounded in the institutional strategy and is included in unit and subunit business plans and objectives. Learning Design and TEL Design methods ensure that University learning and teaching strategies are brought into early TEL decision making, e.g. with regard to balance of learning activity types, TEL design and learning analytics for retention, student workload, principles of assessment and feedback (for example the use of formative iCMAs and collaborative tools for peer support and review). The translation of strategies into actions and activities for applying TEL are monitored by governance processes such as LTAG and LTSG.

Negatives: It was felt that the actual Learning and Teaching Strategy, Learning Now for the Future, is rather broad and high level and in practice, it is general and aspirational enough such and that any new initiative could be made to fit in within it. It was also noted that the current strategy could be communicated more widely to raise awareness of key strategic objectives – some stakeholders surveyed were not familiar with it. It was suggested there is a need for a specific digital strategy so that there is a clear policy for the blend between online and offline and to avoid the risk of technology driving teaching.
0.evidence: As above

1.rationale:
Positives: The overall feeling was that the pedagogic intent of the application of TEL services is better understood and more consistently applied at module level than at qualification level.

Negatives: As the university moves away from heavily print-based learning content to the affordances of digital content, there is still some debate as to the suitability of adding online activities and interaction in some subject areas; there is a risk that online learning is taken to mean simply putting text and books online. The application of TEL is inconsistent across the university, depending on the requirements of module teams and particular subjects, and the specific experience of academics, production staff and consultants involved. In some cases there are sophisticated and effective applications of TEL, but in others technology is perceived as a convenience and a cost reduction rather than the optimal method for delivering innovative learning.
1.evidence: As above

2.rationale:
Positives: There is comprehensive research to support teaching practice lead by IET. The evidence is available via special interest groups, the Scholarship Platform and the Evidence Hub.  There is a TEL in practice site with TEL exemplars and guidance on the learning systems and tools available to all staff, e.g. the Online Learning Systems Guide, Student Computing Guide, Structured Content website, IET Learning Design tools site, and Curriculum Management Guide. Compliance with legal obligations such as accessibility, copyright and the data protection act, and associated guidelines, are good and generally well understood. There are readily available guidelines and reference sites such as the SeGA website. Accessibility is carefully considered and tested for when designing activities and where appropriate alternative formats are provided. Legal copyright compliance is built into our production processes.

Negatives: It was felt that there are examples of good practice for using TEL but the relationship between student-facing application of TEL and any underlying research is not always clear. Quite often, institutional knowledge and experience of what has worked well in the past with regard to the pedagogical application of TEL is more compelling and accessible than published academic research. Some respondents felt that there is a lot of research but they were not sure how to access it, or if they did access it the research and recommendations are not always representative or applicable due to being on a small scale.
2.evidence: As above

3.rationale:
Positives: There are a large number of self-organising communities and special interest groups at the OU, dedicated to supporting the pedagogical application and innovation of TEL. These communities involve staff from a number of different units; examples include OU eLearning Community, Learning Systems monthly drop-in sessions and quarterly VLE release briefings, Learn About Fair, eSTEeM conference, Quality Enhancements seminar, Scholarship seminars, Assessment programme, TEL/Learning Design special interest group, Yammer groups and the JISC expert Group.

Negatives: It was noted that there is no obligation for anyone to attend or engage with any of the groups nor to implement anything they are recommending. There is a tendency for the same limited group of people to attend them and a perception from some that they could become quite insular. It was felt that the learning from these groups could be more widely communicated and could be of wider benefit. There is also some inherent overlap between the groups. It was noted that although such communities and good practice exist, faculties and individual module teams have the final say on what is implemented and are not obliged to take note of any TEL-related advice or evidence.
3.evidence: As above

4.rationale:
Positives: The creation of a new TEL subunit as part of last year’s LTS restructure demonstrates a clear commitment to resourcing TEL and TEL design/pedagogies. The TEL subunit includes TEL designers, a dedicated teams for learning innovation, learning systems and online student experience. IET, KMI and LTC also have specific resources for TEL development, and faculties have their own technology specialists. The teaching and learning strategy and SRA bidding process also support developments of strategic significance.

Negatives: It was reported that although there are resources available for TEL systems and tools, a lot of this capacity is taken up with maintaining what we already have; budget for investing in new innovations is a limited subset of business as usual effort. It was felt that the university tends to focus on incremental improvements to existing methods and tools rather than a step change, and accessing resources can be a bureaucratic process.
4.evidence: As above.

5.rationale:
Positives: We have successfully sustained the current VLE and associated tools for the last ten years and our TEL works at a greater scale than any other known VLE implementation. TEL capabilities are embedded in the University strategy and the business plans of various units. For example, there is funding for TEL in the annual LTS budget for the support and development of learning systems and for the effective application of TEL services via TEL designers working directly with module teams. Sustainability is always considered during the development of new modules as they are in presentation for up to ten years.

Negatives: It was reported that some TEL tools become neglected after release. It was felt that this is because the way that projects are funded and resourced means that when the original implementation team move on there is less focus on the development and maintenance.
5.evidence: As above.

6.rationale:
Positives: There are routine end of module reviews and the annual SeAM survey via IET, alongside more ad-hoc in-flight analytics. In addition, an objective of the Analytics for Action project is to measure the effectiveness of TEL. Evaluation tends to be more effective at module level than programme level because of the many combinations that can make up an OU qualification.

Negatives: There tends to be a lot of quantitative data on the use of the VLE and more subjective qualitative feedback on students attitudes towards it, but less evidence specifically on the pedagogic impact of TEL. The LTS TEL Design team intend to evaluate the impact of the modules they have been involved in, but as they are a relatively new team the modules that have gone through the formal TEL design process have yet to go into presentation so it is too early to do the full evaluation.
6.evidence: As above.

7.rationale:
Positives: Evidence for the impact of TEL being integrated into continuous improvement can be found in various high profile strategic projects, such as Minerva, Analytics for Action and OpenCreate. The impact of TEL will be included in the review of modules and programmes. In addition, in planning any new TEL systems requirements, enhancements to current capability in learning analytics are routinely considered – e.g. the new accessible VLE media player has new usage logging functionality, a significant improvement to the previous capabilities.

Negatives: It was noted that it is inherently difficult to distinguish between measures for good practice and positive student satisfaction and those that specifically relate to the application of TEL. It was also felt that the university funding model and maintenance processes for modules in presentation does not currently lend itself to continuous improvements. The current tendency is to make major updates at the midlife review, rather than make continuous improvements (annually or within presentation).
7.evidence: As above.

8.rationale:
Positives: There is a growing body of good practice examples, e.g. the TEL in practice website and various special interest and best practice groups. The LTS TEL designers are working across module teams which helps to share good practice. Best practice examples tend to be more at module level than at qualification level.

Negatives: It was observed that for good practice examples to be useful they need to be more widely communicated than they are at present. It is thought that individual faculties often have their own context-specific examples, but there could be more done to share examples between faculties. Also noted that there is very little evidence of good practice examples shared or compared with exemplars outside of the OU, and there was a strong feeling that this would be beneficial to the university.
8.evidence: As above.

1.evidence:
The ITDS Academic & Campus Experience (ACE) portfolio was set up in 2015. A PowerPoint lists 26 IT customer services with people responsible. These are not only in ITDS, but also include OPQ and the central BL team. Library services are not included in this framework.

Student and staff support and training for TEL is divided between ITDS, the Library and the Central Blended Learning Team.

Discipline-based

Academics support students in discipline specific technologies.

3.rationale:
ITDS rate this at 5 on both counts, and 5 overall.

A technology-enhanced learning experience is major part of the University's strategic plan for 2015-2020. So substantial funding has been made available to support this. This is evidenced in a number of areas:

  1. leadership - e.g. new PVC positions.
  2. major investments across the institution in providing mobile devices to students and staff, collaborative learning spaces, and campus IT infrastructure
  3. staffing to support key projects in ITDS, Library and various educational redesign initiatives.
3.evidence:
Leadership and prioritisation

The Senate Education Committee’s Learning and Teaching Technologies (LaTTe) advisory group reviews proposals for university-wide allocation of funds and resources for technology enhanced learning – a role supported by the Learning Technologies Policy. A new PVC (Digital Innovation and Learning Futures) position has been created to oversee this process, from July 2016.

Major services that have had funding in the last 3 years:

  • Provision of mobile devices to students and staff, with associated support (from 2013)
  • Expansion in network capacity and wifi coverage (ongoing)
  • Collaborative formal and informal learning spaces (from 2013)
  • Virtual face to face project, linking Zoom, learning space technologies and digital media management (from 2015)
  • 1PSQ prototypes (from late 2015 for implementation in 2017)

ITDS

ITDS has a team that processes licenses and procurement and a dedicated role for IT Strategic sourcing ensuring learning system services supplied by external vendors are monitored, clearly articulated contractually and strongly aligned to the university requirements.

Library

Library budget increased in 2016 to include a new team and service, Library Study Smart. The team is comprised of 1 coordinator, 1 academic integrity officer, 1 digital grammer pod producer and 5 literacy advisors.  

School view

No video content repository yet, apart from echo 360. Only have YouTube.

1PSQ prototypes - staff FB is that they don't work well. software problems, issues with wifi. Need to be updated. [I did point out that this is still a pilot and not a mainstream TEL facility!]

There have been some network issues with Zoom this year: freezes and drop-outs.

4.rationale:
There is support for encouraging and resourcing experimentation with new and emerging technologies. But the processes for linking the resourcing to academic priorities need more work. 

ITDS has money and control of major funding for projects. However, the Senate Committees, via LaTTe, should be making decisions on which innovations are adopted and promoted - based on academic priorities rather than technical ones. These processes are being established but they are not fully in place yet. Hence the discrepancy between ITDS and other scores on 'supported by procedure'.

The role of the new PVC (Digital Innovation and Learning Futures) should help.
4.evidence:
The Learning Technologies Policy also covers procedures for promoting and funding innovation.

LaTTe (reporting to Senate)

LaTTe’s role is to pick up academic ideas. The group has developed  a framework for acquisition, implementation and evaluation of technologies. The group has cross-university representation, and can pick up on duplication and growing needs to coordinate tools at program or School level. There is a form to apply for grants and previously the group has voted on funding for seed grants. However, no such funding was made available for 2016.

Examples

The 1PSQ prototype rooms are a specific example of how experimentation is encouraged and resourced. There is scaffolded support from ITDS and the central Blended Learning team.
ITDS has a focused innovation team and dedicated IT Relationship managers to underpin and support innovation, new and emerging technologies.

Another example is the introduction of Zoom. This was made available to staff first and then rolled out to students. It was funded as part of the virtual face-to-face initiative in ITDS.
A new PVC (Digital Innovation and Learning Futures) position will provide senior level support for new and emerging technologies.

ITDS

The ITDS strategic plan: Future Now; securing digital success 2015-2020 has 5 goals. One of these, ‘building digital capacity’, has as a measure of success a ‘risk management strategy that incorporates innovation’ and a ‘shift in ratio of spending from support to innovation’. Another goal, ‘powering up innovation’ also cites success measures in terms of shifting ratio of spending to encourage innovation.

ITDS has a focused innovation team and dedicated IT Relationship managers to underpin and support innovation, new and emerging technologies.

School view

Zoom and lecture recording have been introduced and promoted. But we still have nowhere to store the digital media.

For newer technologies there will always be gaps and catch-up to do. so it's regular but won't be comprehensive.

ITDS

This includes services that support learning such as identity and access management, network services, collaboration services, remote and on-campus desktop.

Library

In 2014, we mapped the TEL academic resources and support and strategies onto the three main objectives in the learning and teaching plan. There was central funding for a 3 year strategy involving placing teams in discipline-based Schools to support TEL development.

Now we have a new institutional strategic plan and a new Learning & Teaching Plan. The Securing Success strategic plan identifies Western Sydney as a distinctively student-centred University that provides flexibility and technology-enabled learning experiences.

Securing Success 2015-2020

University of Western Sydney Learning & Teaching Plan 2016-2020

Both of these documents put forward directions, goals and actions for TEL.

In 2016 the funding for blended learning support has been devolved to Schools, with contracts for a further 3 years. The local curriculum advisor roles are funded by the PVC LT area and are being clarified. Course Quality Officers now report to OPQ. So this has embedded a stronger and more consistent hub and spoke model for curriculum development, aligned with the institutional strategy.

BLA view:

The strategic documents have been helpful at school level for guiding practice and priorities in the discipline contexts.

There may not be such clear alignment bottom up, in that perhaps not all teaching practices on the ground are relating directly to these priorities. But rationale is there and is being used in curriculum development decisions and work.

Similarly, the TEL support services are there to support the implementation of the strategy, but they may not be used by everyone.

For example, the Blended Learning Advisors in SCEM are aligning use of the  advanced standards (for TEL design) with the Securing Success strategy, and they are using this in consultations with academics on curriculum development. At the Unit design level, they have been using the Unit Planning Sheet and have suggested updates to this.
0.rationale:
The Securing Success 2015-2020 strategic plan places the University as a student-centred institution that is seeking to provide flexible and technology-enabled learning experiences.

Discipline-based TEL support groups are able to refer to specific sections in the strategic plan in curriculum development work with academics. There are also eLearning guidelines and other design resources, aligned with the plan, that they can draw upon.

The new Western Sydney University Learning and Teaching Plan 2016-2020 has just been formally approved. This puts forward strategies and actions to expand fully online and blended study modes, in order to enhance flexibility.

The application of TEL services is 'substantially' rather than 'comprehensively' grounded in these strategies, because although the services are there and aligned strategically, they may not yet be used effectively in all teaching practices.

1.rationale:
The pedagogical (or rather andragogical) intent of the use of technology-enhanced learning is fully apparent to support staff, but perhaps not always to academic teaching staff. Directors of Academic Programs are likely to be more aware than individual teaching academics within their programs.

However, in centrally provided staff development and curriculum development support services, every effort has been made to integrate TEL methods with the design of learning activities and curricula.
1.evidence:
In 2014 we listed resources like the QILT site, SUNSET tool, curriculum development support in schools, etc. Then we said it was apparent but not consistently at program level.

In 2016 we have the following evidence that the pedagogical rationale for TEL is more apparent to teaching and support staff:

  • Staff interviews in 2013 and 2015 about their experiences with blended learning show a marked increase in awareness of and confidence with TEL.
  • We have a TEL Toolkit structured around pedagogical intent.
  •  Videos and case studies are available
  • There is a document on the 1PSQ learning spaces, with examples of learning activities (on Learning Transformations web pages).
  • BLADES activities (see BLA view below)
  • Curriculum mapping tool (CMT)
  • Roles of curriculum advisors and course quality officers, and use of CMT, all being clarified.

BLA view:

BLADES are still working more at unit than at program level. However, there is some work at program level. There is disparity in communication around program level work. BLAs are usually brought in afterwards on curriculum meetings.

For example,  BLADES have been involved in initial discussions on strategies for delivery of the BEng hons. program - part of a major curriculum review. It is intended that the new (School-based and centrally managed/funded) Curriculum Advisor roles will provide some leadership on this. So this is work in progress, which needs to be formalised better.

There are increasing calls from academics for support from the BLADE team, much more than in 2014. They can then have conversations about pedagogy. [But note preference for 'andragogy' in SCEM.]

Often academics ask for proof of value of TEL. So evaluation evidence is crucial.

2.rationale: There is plenty of guidance available at the institutional level, and this is based on research and best practice. But the guidelines, especially the more advanced complex ones, are not applied consistently. There is perhaps some work to do on interpreting and contextualising the various guidelines and standards, and in providing feedback to discipline groups on how they are being applied.
2.evidence:
In 2014 we cited the various guidelines and standards available, all based on research and best practice, such as the basic and advanced eLearning standards. For implementation we had the BL advisor roles.  Availability was good but consistent application less so.

In 2016 there has been some improvement.
Use of the Basic and advanced standards has exapnded. We do a consistency check twice a year, sampling 10% of UG units and are at 86% consistency with basic standards. We are aiming for 4% annual improvement.

The Advanced standards harder to measure, and are really just guidelines. All info on website and embedded in staff development like FULT and workshops on TEL. Workshop program.

BLA view:

The University has lots of guidelines for TEL, but some are hard to meet in practice. For example, in Echo360 captions are not available.

They use both basic and advanced eLearning standards. The basic standards easier to use and are taken up; the advanced standards less so.

Within SCEM, academics in the Engineering program are generally familiar with engineering education literature. BLADES would benefit from a library of this material too. [Is this another role for the Curriculum Advisor?]

Computing is not using BLADE services as much as Engineering program. Engineers tend to take up tools and quickly see educational applications for them.

Some people using videos but not very well integrated into activities.

10% of units are checked agains basic standards twice a year. But this is done by central BL team who may not fully appreciate the educational design rationale. e.g. size of small files may not be needed. More transparency is needed in these judgements - not just a total score for the School, so that they can identify how to improve. The School BL team would like to see some qualitative feedback on the designs. However, this is currently constrained by the need for anonymity.

3.evidence:
In 2014 we scored ourselves at 5 on this and the various activities have been maintained, and if anything expanded. As with PI 4.4, the Designing for Learning web pages list activities.

BLA view:

BLADE sessions and networking is well established. [But how many BLADE musters have there been this year?]

SSH is looking at job shadowing between Schools to share working practices.
3.rationale:
At the institutional level, there is a regular program of 'designing for learning' events, with monthly forums on different campuses where academics can share ideas on TEL practice, and an annual showcase.

The events are promoted widely and usually made available afterwards through online recordings.

Most of the discipline-based support groups organise similar events within Schools.

The support staff also have regular network events and other activities to share across disciplines.

4.evidence:
In 2014, we said this was well funded.

In 2016, there is continued funding for support staff, along with further investment in technology-enhanced learning spaces (1PSQ and informal spaces with provision for student use of technology).

The University has been maintaining and improving the hub and spoke model for supporting TEL. There is a central blended learning team and School-based Blended Learning Advisors and Designers – working alongside embedded curriculum advisors and course quality officers. See http://www.westernsydney.edu.au/qilt/qilt/support.

Projects around learning spaces, such as 1PSQ are funded as strategic priorities.

BL teams now embedded in schools and funded by Schools. the level of support varies between Schools but is generally good, with most Schools having everal team members.

BLA view:

BL roles funded until end of 2018. Some delays in funding within SCEM. Could do with one more person to cover the work. Management of the work is no longer funded separately through project coordinators for OFP.

Query about whether CQO role is integrated with School work rather than focusing on compliance. e.g. learning guide project.
4.rationale:
The funding set up for a 3 year TEL support strategy in 2013 has now been restructured and maintained, with support staff roles funded up to the end of 2018.

There has additional funding for strategic projects, such as the new 1PSQ Parramatta city campus. Pilots and evaluation of new high tech collaborative learning space designs are being combined with curriculum renewal.

However, the funding is limited by overall budget constraints and has to be prioritised tightly.

5.evidence:

We also have two new PVC positions, for Learning Transformations and for Digital Learning Futures. The BLADES are now funded by Schools and there are processes to embed other curriculum development support roles in Schools.

The BLADES are still on contract employment rather than continuing. But this is fairly usual in the sector.

BLA view:

Commitment for positions beyond 2018 is not sure. The TEL support is only sustainable if people available to work with academics (proactively) on the ground. Corridor stalking and tearoom talk, sparking discussions between academics is particularly useful, then organising showcasing of practice to share more widely.
5.rationale: Currently have sustainable support set-up, but funding is not set up longer term.

6.rationale:
The evaluation of TEL is now established at institutional level and there is a lot of data being collected and analysed. This is available through an institutional dashboard at various levels (School, campus, year, etc.). There is a summary report annually (established at the end of 2015) to the  Senate Education Committee.

At discipline and curriculum level the collection and use of TEL evaluation data is much more patchy. One challenge is to encourage more widespread use of the available institutional data within disciplines.

SFUs are used routinely.
6.evidence:

In 2016:
