Academic Compass

Academic Compass is an ongoing program of surveys to explore the needs, expectations and perceptions of CSU's academic staff.  Universities often focus on conducting surveys about their academics. Academic Compass seeks to redress this by providing a survey of academics about issues important to academic practice. The Compass aims to provide a mapping of current issues related to academic practice, in particular learning and teaching, and point the way forward as CSU charts new directions. Results from Academic Compass are provided back to our academic community to spark discussion and debate.  Summary reports from previous surveys are available to all staff.

·         Blackboard features and tools in Interact2 Survey (August 2015)

·         Promotions Survey (July 2015)

·         Learning Environments (virtual spaces) Survey (October 2014)

·         Learning Environments (physical spaces) Survey (October 2014)

·         Student EdTech Survey (September 2014)

 

 

Student EdTech Survey (September 2014)

The Division of Student Learning’s Education Technology Survey explores access, usage and experiences around educational technology among CSU students. The University seeks to better understand how students use technology especially in educational settings. The feedback gained through this survey enables the University to more effectively meet the diverse and changing needs of its students. The report form the survey is available to all staff and is promoted and was run in 2010, 2014 and 2016

 

The Pulse

The Pulse provides a picture of what is happening within CSU with regard to learning technologies and analytics to enhance our knowledge, challenge our thinking and stimulate conversation about the use of technology/analytics in learning and teaching.  The Pulse is published three times a year and each edition explores a particular theme. The statistics and analytics are drawn from a range of sources within CSU including systems reports, surveys and case studies. Trends in Learning Technologies and use of Learning Analytics outside CSU are also highlighted.

 

Smart Learning course design ensures data is gathered to inform the review process including student surveys (See section 4.1).

 

QLT Audit & Initiative

Faculty based, QLT Assessment and Online leads conducted audited subjects and highlighted the need for improvement in engagement in online environment and uptake of the Graduate learning outcomes as identified in subject learning outcomes. These audits have been used to inform priority courses and subjects requiring assistance in 2016.

Overall:

 

Initial recommendations for improvement

The followed areas have been identified for improvement;

4.3 The pedagogical application of technology enhanced learning is based on sound educational research and guidelines (including compliance with legal requirements, accessibility, and learning designs) are readily available to all teaching and support staff.

 

The OLM has filled a gap in good practice and as this initiative rolls out across the University a large number of courses/programs will adhere to the research based model. Another gap identified are learning designs. Examples of pedagogically sound learning designs are currently not available at CSU.

 

The following learning design resources are currently in development:

·         active lecture,

·         problem based learning,

·         scenario based learning

·         cooperative learning, and

·         ePortfolios and reflective practice.

 

The development of these learning design resources will encourage the use of research informed teaching practice and allow teaching staff to easily re-use the learning designs in subjects via the use of import/export function in Interact2.

 

Accessibility

Guidelines for the design of Interact2 sites are not readily available and is not evident that any guidelines are followed in design of subjects.

A number of landmark documents have evolved the technology mediated teaching and learning strategy at the University of Melbourne over the past 10 years.

We are now in a solid position in having an established framework for staff development, but are in a process of solidifying this more over the next few years.

 

The University of Melbourne's vision for online learning is clarifying and will be more transparent in the next few years.
0.evidence:
Creating Effective Websites for University Teaching: An educational framework (2008) is a guide that has been a foundational document for staff development at the University of Melbourne’s (UniMelb). Still relevant today. It is a great first starting point for staff embarking on technology enabled teaching at UniMelb. 

 

 

The eLearning Professional Development Framework (2013) outlines 14 PD opportunities available to staff at the University. From informal occasional Practical Pedagogy Seminars to formal study in the Graduate Certificate of University Teaching, many flexible options are offered to staff to accommodate something for everyone to advance their knowledge and experience in elearning.

This framework is being reviewed in 2016 to measure progress and assess applicability to the current educational climate. 

 

The Growing Esteem Strategy has evolved from the Melbourne Curriculum (previously the Melbourne Model) which was introduced in 2008. It has entered a second stage from the original Growing Esteem of 2010. The new stage is planned to take place from 2015-2020 and is outlined in a discussion paper. http://growingesteem.unimelb.edu.au/documents/UoM_Growing_Esteem_2014_GreenPaper.pdf

Chapter 3 contains a section titled ‘Embracing the online evolution’ which outlines some of the reasons why the University of Melbourne started providing MOOCs through Coursera. It also mentions the natural progression from this is to develop wholly online programs which has surfaced in the form of Graduate Online.

 

The UniMelb Digital Learning Strategy was updated in May 2015. This internal use only document outlines the

“key strategic and enabling priorities in the area of technology supported teaching, learning and assessment”

from the UniMelb elearning Strategy 2012-2014. It has three operational strands:

  1. Campus based eLearning: develop and integrate within a range of curricula, technology- based learning resources and applications to enhance the learning experiences of existing campus-based students;
  2. MOOCs: develop and deliver a portfolio of Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) in partnership with Coursera; and
  3. Graduate online learning (GO): develop a business plan followed by a suite of premium quality wholly online graduate courses.

To facilitate the first strand, all subjects must have a minimal presence in the LMS. Lecture capture is now opt-out, so most formal teaching space sessions are now recorded for students. This integrates eLearning into the curriculum at Melbourne. Staff are given a wide range of eLearning tools to use and support is available to assist them in the development of eLearning activities and artifacts.

To support development in the first strand, Learning and teaching Initiative (LTI) Grants have been offered each year to staff wishing to either redevelop their online course offerings, or to create some innovative educational offering to enhance the students learning. A review on the 2012-2013 LTI Grants is available here: http://melbourne-cshe.unimelb.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/1865938/UOM_LTI_Report_2014.pdf

UniMelb partnered with MOOC provider Coursera in 2012. In 2013 UniMelb delivered 7 MOOCs, enrolling 352,974 learners. 2014 saw 10 courses delivered with 291,964 enrolments. 2015 grew to 20 courses and 291,773 learner enrolments. As of 17th May 2016 9 courses have been delivered to 71,579 learners making over 1 million enrolments since the initial course. https://www.coursera.org/unimelb

Lessons learnt from the MOOCs have been folded into advice given to UniMelb staff to apply in their technology enabled learning classes within the University. Learning analytics from the Coursera platform on our learners study activities are being researched and published on. A University of Melbourne MOOC Data snapshots 2013-2014 is available at http://melbourne-cshe.unimelb.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0008/1761245/UOM-MOOC-report.pdf

Graduate Online (GO) offered its first course in term 2 of 2015. Currently there are 8 programs and 20 courses being offered. The portfolio of courses is being expanded over the coming years with programs that represent the broad mix and fields of strength across all faculties and schools of the University.

Digital Learning and Flexible Academic Programming - An overview of the UnIMelb Digital Learning Strategy is given on this page with mentions of the upcoming Flexible Academic Programming Project (FlexAP), the LTI grants and the key strategic focus areas for the University:

  •  Continued development of the Digital Learning Strategy
  • Innovation in academic program delivery
  • Quality and flexibility of the student experience
  • Use of physical and virtual infrastructure

 

Other contributing groups to UniMelb's framework:

The University's Library supports the framework in a number of ways.

LARC - Library and Academic Resources Committee- Improving digital literacy for Melbourne’s scholarly literacy framework. http://about.unimelb.edu.au/academicboard/committees/larc

Learning Environments (LE) is a central unit that provides support for enhancing teaching and learning through using educational systems and technologies, video production and event recording, and professional development and support services.

LE’s Vision: To support, enrich and extend academic achievement for Melbourne’s scholarly and learning community through the effective use of world-class learning environments, technologies and media.

LE’s Mission: Actively engage in the continual development and enhancement of learning, teaching and assessment capabilities for our academic community, by delivering high quality educational technologies, professional media production and responsive services.

The four work teams within LE are:

  • Academic and learning Systems Support (ALSS), made up of Blackboard and Echo 360 Lecture capture.
  • Video and Media Production (VAMP), producing high quality video and media production services for teaching and learning, promotions and events.
  • Interactive Technologies Team, comprised of graphic design, app and web development, software solutions.
  • Learning Design Team, managing the MOOC production for the University as well as assisting staff with learning design in their online educational developments and offering pedagogical advice, design and user interface direction.

LE provides a number of LMS workshops (see 5.6 for details) as well as a Practical Pedagogy series (see 5.6 for details) of lunchtime workshops to assit staff in the technical and pedagogical aspects of designing meaningful learning activities online.


Quality programmes are created using evidence based education and technical expertise. Learning designers have appropriate qualifications and have regular review meetings to robustly discuss the pedagogy employed in learning design.

Graduate Online offers personal and team staff development for technology enhanced learning to those academics who have programmes being delivered by them.

 Two examples of Faculty support are:

The Centre for Excellence in Learning and Teaching (CELT - formally TLU) sits within the Faculty of Business and Economics (FBE) and supports the delivery of an exceptional curriculum inclusive of diversity and innovation. Their staff work with teachers and students to provide world class learning experiences. They deliver workshops as well as provide one on one support around the effective use of technology enhanced learning.

 

Seth Paddle, the eLearning Coordinator for the Faculty of Veterinary and Agricultural Sciences reports:

We only do a little in the way of formal, structured professional development -- we occasionally run introductory LMS sessions on request for small groups of interns at Werribee, perhaps three or four times a year. These cover not just basic LMS usage, but specifically how to navigate and manage the complex year-long third- and fourth-year DVM subjects. These subjects have upwards of 70 different teaching staff at various times throughout the year, and so guidance on where to upload what file is important. I also meet with all newly commencing staff one-on-one to walk them through the basics of the LMS and locating their relevant subjects, files, and support.

I suppose we do a lot of ad hoc unstructured development when we respond to support requests. I rarely just fix the issue, mark the email read or close the ticket and move on. Unless the technology in question is very new, known to be buggy, requires advanced technical skills or high-level access, I'll almost always include step-by-step details of actions I took to resolve the issue, or demonstrate it in person, in case it comes up for the user again. Anecdotally, this is fairly successful, as I often won't hear about the issue again from that user for several years, until the technology is updated and the instructions aren't current.

4.rationale:

LTI grants come from chancellery are one way that innovation and creativity in creating new learning activites is supported.

Mr David Israel is Director, Online Education Busines & Curriculum Commercialisation.

We are also looking at how we can increase our offerings in educational technology focused staff development. This may be as a responce to new technology, or more importantly, finding ways to increase access to staff of these services to meet their development needs.
5.evidence:
Blackboard LMS workshops are offered on a regular basis throughout the year in a training room where staff have access to a computer and their courses. https://lms.unimelb.edu.au/support/events/

Topics include:

LMS - Essential Elements 2.5 hours Topics include: structure and design of your LMS subject, providing information and resources to students, staff and student management, subject availability and discovery of LMS self-help resources.

LMS - Tests and Surveys 80 minutes
Topics include: creating tests and surveys, question types, question management, setting test conditions, providing feedback and grades, and viewing test and survey data.


LMS - Assignments and Feedback 80 minutes
Topics include: providing an assignment submission area for students and groups, reviewing submissions, marking online and providing rich feedback to students.

LMS - Journals, Blogs, and Wikis 2 hours
Topics include: an overview of the similarities and differences between the three tools, and creating and managing the tools for subjects, communities, individuals and groups.


LMS - Grade Centre 90 minutes
Topics include: managing student grades, setting and using smart views, using weighted columns, student display options, Grade Centre history and grade statistics.


Turnitin and GradeMark 90 minutes
Topics include: options when creating assignments, discussion and review of originality reports, marking online and providing rich feedback to students.

Variations of the above workshops or more specific sessions around a specific part of the LMS are available as well through a Customised LMS staff development workshops programme.

LMS workshops, forums and events are now integrated with the Graduate Certificate in University Teaching (GCUT). GCUT participants are able to credit these events towards completion of the 'special topics' component of the first GCUT subject.

Practical Pedagogy is a series of lunchtime workshops that showcases the latest developments in teaching and learning with technology, within higher education and beyond.

These informal sessions provide practical demonstrations of innovative pedagogical tools in practice, as well as creating opportunities for discussion. The practical pedagogy sessions are presented by experts in designing, developing and delivering online and face-to-face courses.

Previous workshops have included these topics:

  • Applying lessons from MOOCs to inform future teaching practice 2015
  • A pragmatic approach to academic and learning activities 2015
  • Using social media to enhance teaching and learning 2014
  • Using blogs for reflective writing 2014
  • Making large lectures more interactive 2014

  • Teaching and learning using iPads 2014
  • Video and media production 2013

The University of Melbourne, along with other Australian Universities joined together and purchased the Epigeum online training materials in 2013. These have been reviewed by staff from LE and CSHE for their application to the University of Melbourne.

The six Epigeum modules are housed in an LMS Community that all staff have access to and include the following topics:

  1. Introduction to Teaching Online
  2. Mastering Online Pedagogy
  3. Designing and Developing your online course
  4. Being a successful online teacher
  5. Using technology tools for teaching online
  6. Studying online: A guide for students

Catherine Manning (LE) and Hero Macdonald (library) conducted a series of workshops with library staff to increase their awareness of online pedagogy as well as skill development in online course development. A report on their experience and its contribution of staff professional development is outlined in an Ascilite Conference paper available here:

Manning, C. & Macdonald. H. (2015). The three pillars to building staff capability to create digital learning experiences (2015). In T. Reiners, B.R. von Konsky, D. Gibson, V. Chang, L. Irving, & K. Clarke (Eds.), Globally connected, digitally enabled. Proceedings ascilite 2015 in Perth (pp. CP:150- CP:154).

http://www.2015conference.ascilite.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/ascilite-2015-proceedings.pdf


Pick IT Up online is a training resource for students to learn new skills online, and that can help them prepare for interviews, future employment and further professional learning.

The UniMelb Digital Learning Strategy (May 2015) revolved around three operational strands:

  1. Campus based eLearning: develop and integrate within a range of curricula, technology- based learning resources and applications to enhance the learning experiences of existing campus-based students;

  2. MOOCs: develop and deliver a portfolio of Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) in partnership with Coursera; and

  3. Graduate online learning: develop a business plan followed by a suite of premium quality wholly online graduate courses.

The first strand is supported but the ALSS (LMS) team within LE. Similar to other institutions LMS deployments the system is kept running with as minimal downtime as possible to allow staff and students to use pivotal learning portal for blended and online learning at the University.

Lecture Capture is available in approximately 120 teaching spaces around the Parkville campus with all spaces have audio and screen capture capacity. Three venues also have video capture of the presenter.

Learning design support and consultations are available from LE on an on-demand basis.

To support development in the first strand, Learning and teaching Initiative (LTI) Grants have been offered each year to staff wishing to either redevelop their online course offerings, or to create some innovative educational offering to enhance the students learning. A review on the 2012-2013 LTI Grants is available here: http://melbourne-cshe.unimelb.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/1865938/UOM_LTI_Report_2014.pdf

MOOCs are supported by a small team within LE along with members from the Video and Media production unit, the Copyright office and the teaching academics in each MOOC course. Lessons learnt from teaching online in the MOOCs are shared with the greater University teaching staff through a variety of channel, both face to face and electronically.

As mentioned previously, Graduate Online (GO) has a large team supporting the development and expansion of this new initiative for the University.

Turnitin is used for many online assessment submissions to reduce the incidence of plagerism and also for peer assessment tasks. it is integrated into the LMS and is supported by the ALSS team.

Zoom is supported through the Zoom conferencing portal website for help, as well as face to face training and support through the helpdesk.

Learning Environments Vision and Mission Statements

Vision - To support, enrich and extend academic achievement for Melbourne’s scholarly and learning community through the effective use of world-class learning environments, technologies and media.

Mission - Actively engage in the continual development and enhancement of learning, teaching and assessment capabilities for our academic community, by delivering high quality educational technologies, professional media production and responsive support services.

____________________

Digital Learning Strategy

Overview
The Digital Learning Strategy of the University is focussed on a balanced suite of initiatives, which together provide diverse student groups with exceptional learning experiences. The strategy responds to student demand for flexibility, while strengthening Melbourne's reputation for educational quality.

The original eLearning Strategy of the University (2012-2014) set out key strategic and enabling priorities in the area of technology supported teaching, learning and assessment. This strategy underpinned three operational strands which were:

Campus-based eLearning and mobile learning: develop and integrate within a range of curricula, technology based learning resources and applications to enhance the learning experiences of existing campus-based students;
MOOCs: develop and deliver a portfolio of Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) in partnership with Coursera; and
Graduate online learning: develop a suite of premium quality wholly online graduate courses.

____________________

Creating Effective Websites for University Teaching: An educational framework (2008) is a guide that has been a foundational document for staff development at the University of Melbourne’s (UniMelb). Still relevant today. It is a great first starting point for staff embarking on technology enabled teaching at UniMelb.

 ____________________

The eLearning Professional Development Framework (2013) Outlines 14 PD opportunities available to staff at the University. From informal occasional Practical Pedagogy Seminars to formal study in the Graduate Certificate of University Teaching, many flexible options are offered to staff to accommodate something for everyone to advance their knowledge and experience in elearning.

This framework is being reviewed in 2016 to measure progress and assess applicability to the current educational climate.

____________________

The Growing Esteem Strategy has evolved from the Melbourne Curriculum (previously the Melbourne Model) which was introduced in 2008. It has entered a second stage from the original Growing Esteem of 2010. The new stage is planned to take place from 2015-2020 and is outlined in a discussion paper. http://growingesteem.unimelb.edu.au/documents/UoM_Growing_Esteem_2014_GreenPaper.pdf

Chapter 3 contains a section titled ‘Embracing the online evolution’ which outlines some of the reasons why the University of Melbourne started providing MOOCs through Coursera. It also mentions the natural progression from this is to develop wholly online programs which has surfaced in the form of Graduate Online.

The UniMelb Digital Learning Strategy was updated in May 2015. This internal use only document outlines the

“key strategic and enabling priorities in the area of technology supported teaching, learning and assessment”

from the UniMelb elearning Strategy 2012-2014. It has three operational strands:

  1. Campus based eLearning: develop and integrate within a range of curricula, technology- based learning resources and applications to enhance the learning experiences of existing campus-based students;
  2. MOOCs: develop and deliver a portfolio of Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) in partnership with Coursera; and
  3. Graduate online learning (GO): develop a business plan followed by a suite of premium quality wholly online graduate courses.

To facilitate the first strand, all subjects must have a minimal presence in the LMS. Lecture capture is now opt-out, so most formal teaching space sessions are now recorded for students. This integrates eLearning into the curriculum at Melbourne. Staff are given a wide range of eLearning tools to use and support is available to assist them in the development of eLearning activities and artifacts.

To support development in the first strand, Learning and teaching Initiative (LTI) Grants have been offered each year to staff wishing to either redevelop their online course offerings, or to create some innovative educational offering to enhance the students learning. A review on the 2012-2013 LTI Grants is available here: http://melbourne-cshe.unimelb.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/1865938/UOM_LTI_Report_2014.pdf

UniMelb partnered with MOOC provider Coursera in 2012. In 2013 UniMelb delivered 7 MOOCs, enrolling 352,974 learners. 2014 saw 10 courses delivered with 291,964 enrolments. 2015 grew to 20 courses and 291,773 learner enrolments. As of 17th May 2016 9 courses have been delivered to 71,579 learners making over 1 million enrolments since the initial course. https://www.coursera.org/unimelb

Lessons learnt from the MOOCs have been folded into advice given to UniMelb staff to apply in their technology enabled learning classes within the University. Learning analytics from the Coursera platform on our learners study activities are being researched and published on. A University of Melbourne MOOC Data snapshots 2013-2014 is available at http://melbourne-cshe.unimelb.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0008/1761245/UOM-MOOC-report.pdf

Graduate Online (GO) offered its first course in term 2 of 2015. Currently there are 8 programs and 20 courses being offered. The portfolio of courses is being expanded over the coming years with programs that represent the broad mix and fields of strength across all faculties and schools of the University.

_____________________________________________

Digital Learning and Flexible Academic Programming - An overview of the UnIMelb Digital Learning Strategy is given on this page with mentions of the upcoming Flexible Academic Programming Project (FlexAP), the Learning and Teaching Inititive (LTI) grants and the key strategic focus areas for the University:

  • Continued development of the Digital Learning Strategy
  • Innovation in academic program delivery
  • Quality and flexibility of the student experience
  • Use of physical and virtual infrastructure

1.rationale:
Learning Environments deliver a range of staff development activites. These activities are reviewed regularly and updated as new tools are adopted/implemented, and as required by faculty staff. 

Following training and workshop sessions,  evaluation and feedback discussions are usually carried out to assess anticipated training needs in the future.

Staff are able to contact us to request individual assistance or to develop and deliver tailored training resources in a specific area that they want, or for a teaching team session customised to curriculum or delivery requirements (ie, moving from face to face teaching mode to blended/flipped classroom).

A formal six month survey and feedback cycle is currently being developed within Academic Sevices to enable Faculty staff to provide us with feedback on shared services.

Learning Environments will be included in this cycle, but for more specific teaching and learning feedback we will need to develop a more 'open mechanism' for informal feedback channels.

56e23d002761400d3e2716bd: TaLS is responsible for learning and teaching support. Our Academic Skills Office supports students. The Learning Resources team support staff through management of the VLE, learning media production, academic development and learning design.

0.rationale:
UNE has some systems are in place – the Automated Wellness Engine (AWE) and business intelligence reports through the Central Intelligence Unit (CIU), but processes regarding how to obtain and evaluate the data for decision making purposes are ad hoc and opague. The AWE utilises a range of data, including student access to systems and self reporting to determine recipients to support prompts – while this system could be used for certain kinds of decision making and investigation, little evidence suggests that this has been taken up from a learning technology point of view.  CIU also collects data from a range of systems, but reporting from this area is ad hoc and not broadly circulated, utilised or understood across the University. These systems generate data based on demographic and generalised trends rather than personal learner analytics which means that they are limited in assisting decision making at the unit or course level.

Learning analytics from the LMS are available in a range of comprehensive reports but these are not intuitive or practical to utilise for meaningful data at the unit level. There are tools available in the LMS which assist in monitoring student activity, but these require individual set up for each unit. Additional VLE systems generate analytics, but these are not always available to academic staff or students (some being limited to system administrators). Furthermore, no processes exist to triangulate this data with other institutional intelligence in order to make decision making robust. There is no provision for ‘dashboard’ analytics at the unit or course level for staff or students.

There are no frameworks in place related to use of learning and educational analytic data.
0.evidence:
• Automated Wellness Engine
  • Corporate Intelligence Unit
  • LMS usage data and trends including Blackboard service reports

1.rationale:
Processes and responsibilities vary across areas and informal processes are common. Implementation and maintenance of systems is generally working well, and this is enhanced by the small teams working with the learning systems across the institution more than by clearly articulated responsibilities and processes. Good communication, responsibility and a generally high sense of collegiality and professionalism has led to a healthy balance between formal and informal processes.

All learning systems are assigned business owners, however there is a lack of clarity with regard to the responsibilities.
Advisory and Operational groups are in place and are becoming more highly valued in the distributed model employed at UNE with regard to responsibilities related to technology enhanced learning systems but are not officially recognised in the institution. These include the Learning Environments Technology Advisory Group (LETAG), comprised of staff from ITD and TALS, monitors and oversees implementations, upgrades and maintenance issues. LTOPs acts as a forum for staff from Schools, TALS and ITD to share user experiences, requirements and issues, which are reported back to LETAG.
1.evidence:
• Assignment of Business Owners to core technologies
  • Cross-institution advisory groups – LETAG and LTOPs

2.rationale:
Students are supported in the use of technology enhanced learning systems through limited avenues and there are clearly defined responsibilities and processes in place for this. Students have access to Learning Online (re the LMS) (managed by TALS), online tutorials and support are provided through ITD, with all call and email support being channelled through a central service desk.

Just in time staff support and training is largely embedded in Schools with Learning Design teams. In addition, staff have access to a centralised service desk, specifically in place to manage staff issues with the VLE. ITD provide scheduled training sessions for the technological use of most core systems, which complements the pedagogical support and just in time training available in Schools. TALS also manage a staff portal (Teaching Online) which provides guides for use of various technologies including the LMS, lecture capture, virtual classroom and staff also have access to training materials and tutorials collated by ITD. Support and training for use of additional technologies is managed by user groups and learning design and support teams in the relevant area ie Maple is supported and training is provided by the School of Science and Technology.
2.evidence:
• Student support managed through ITD Service Desk. Online training resources available through ITD support pages and Learning Online (TALS managed portal for core learning technologies).
  • Staff support and training provided via Schools, ITD and TALS. Online support through ITD support pages and Teaching Online (TALS managed portal for core learning technologies).

3.rationale:
While large scale implementation is often supported by temporary teams, relatively small teams are assigned to ongoing maintenance and development of learning technologies in both ITD and TALS.

Resources are limited and a wide range of tasks are often spread across a small number of staff, which can lead to issues in cases where employee attrition or unanticipated leave occurs. For example, support for lecture capture is provided through TALS but backup resources are limited, leading to risk in the support of a significant system. Development work is often un-resourced.
3.evidence: • Relatively small teams exist in ITD and TALS with a focus on learning technologies.

4.rationale:
A lack of sponsorship for experimentation at higher levels exists and a bottom up approach is not encouraged or resourced. UNE tends to be risk averse. Adoption of technologies is limited by policy and IT capabilities to provide support both to staff and students.

A group has been established (UNE VITAL – Virtual Institute for Teaching and Learning) which will ‘promote collaborative research into more innovative and dynamic ways of integrating technology into tertiary education to the benefit of all our students’. This supports applications for funding but these must demonstrate a strong research component and the group has a focus on STEM.

Ongoing funding is a concern for academic staff who are interested in trialling new technologies as time spent developing learning objects may be wasted if these cannot be used following a trial.

UNE have no current procedures in place for the trial of new technologies, although some work is being done on this through LTOPs/ LETAG – to date this has been informal. UNE have no policies related to the use of learning technologies, other than the Learning Resources Policy (which references limitations to technologies to be used for assessment).
4.evidence:
• VITAL funding
  • Emergence of decentralised decisions to pilot new technologies independently
  • Lack of governance, policy or process regarding trialling new technologies

5.rationale: The range of technologies ITD are required to manage limits the potential for comprehensive PD to be supported for all systems in place. Online networks and training packages are increasingly used to upskill and remain abreast of changes to technologies as well as sharing updates/ workarounds in communities of practice. UNE professional staff have access to centralised PD funds, but this is allocated to individuals based on competitive application process.
5.evidence:
• PD program not evident in ITD or TALS
  • High level use of informal networks, online forums and communities of practice both external and within UNE

6.rationale: There was limited knowledge of University procedures, however we do have a centralised risk register in place where directorates identify risk and note the measures in place to mitigate this. Change management processes in ITD are clear and robust and this is important in managing risk associated with releases and upgrades on all technologies.
6.evidence:
• Centralised risk register
  • Change management processes in ITD

7.rationale: As we are a small institution, word of mouth communication is high and not all support paths are communicated officially. Semi-official communication is common, especially in terms of alerts to technical issues encountered on an ad hoc basis. Learning design teams located in Schools are generally the first point of call for staff and are well informed of key support contacts beyond Schools, including a centralised staff service desk which specifically provides support for learning technologies. Academic staff have reported a lack of understanding with respect to the different.
7.evidence:
• TALS and ITD each have a web presence with documented support paths of services offered to staff.

  • Learning design teams in Schools act as the first point of call and are able to direct/ redirect staff to the correct support area if required.

0.rationale: UNE currently does not have a strategic plan in place. There is a commitment to online teaching and learning and last year a distributed model for learning design support was implemented with learning design teams established in every School. This demonstrates commitment to improving services.
0.evidence:
• Lack of Strategic Plan
  • Learning design teams support technologies in Schools

1.rationale: The focus tends to be on the technology over the pedagogy and depends on individual interests and strengths of teaching staff. In some cases the technology is imposed, without pedagogical consideration. Application may be limited by individual interest areas and understanding of both academic and learning design staff. While evaluation on an individual level may consider the use of technologies, School and course reviews typically do not, which limits the effective use of learning technologies across a student’s learning experience.
1.evidence:
• Lack of systematic approach across UNE
  • Application of learning technologies not consistently considered in course mapping

2.rationale: Application is based on research in limited cases where expertise exists. Appointment of learning designers in Schools has the potential to enhance this, however there is some reluctance to defer to professional staff, and individual interests vary across a broad range of applications. Guidelines including compliance with legal requirements and accessibility are readily available through learning design teams as well as in online sites which support teaching (ie Teaching Online @ UNE, Dixson Library).
2.evidence:
• Lack of systematic approach with School learning design teams varying in approach and interests
  • Compliance evaluated across UNE with the AQF reviews in 2014/15. Awareness is high and guidelines readily available.

3.rationale: Several communities exist for School learning design teams, TALS and ITD staff involved in supporting technology enhanced learning systems. Some of these are more formal groups (LTOPS) with regular meetings and reporting lines to/ from advisory groups and senior staff. There are also informal groups – ADCOP / The Community blog, which are intended to focus more on innovation and pedagogy and sharing ideas within and beyond the learning design community. Academic communities are emerging and gaining exposure through coordination and promotion of events such as guest seminars.
3.evidence:
• Informal learning design communities are growing in reach and exposure
  • Additional groups are gaining reach incl. First year group and STEM practitioners

4.rationale: Budgets for learning technologies often include minimal funding for ongoing development. ITD traditionally manage budgets for all institutional technologies and any development funds available can often be diverted to non-learning technologies. VITAL supports projects with funding, but these do not include ongoing resources. Similarly, Schools often trial technologies, but with budgets being negotiated on an annual basis, no guarantees can be given on continuing to resource these.
4.evidence:
• Annual budget process (institutional development funding not allocated to specific technologies)
  • VITAL – single project funding opportunities

5.rationale: There is a tendency to support implementation extensively, but limit consideration of how services will be sustained. It is also the case that technology changes and shifts in pedagogical approaches alter the application of technologies (ie lecture capture). School learning design teams are sometimes required to support technologies that are not resourced at the institutional level which is not a highly sustainable approach. There has recently been a tendency to trial technologies, but the investment of time to run a pilot is seen by some as a fruitless impost with no guarantees that their efforts will be worthwhile. This means it becomes challenging to enlist willing participants in testing new approaches.
5.evidence:
• Limited resourcing in place post implementation for institutional technologies
  • Independent trials/ pilots occurring in Schools with limited planning and consideration of continuation strategies

6.rationale: While evaluation may occur, it is ad hoc and dependent on School strategies and approaches and individual interests. Processes in place that may include a review of use of learning technologies include unit evaluations/ monitoring processes (though this is not explicit in the questionnaire), PPDR processes (though may not be a focal point), internal informal processes which may be undertaken by learning design teams, use of analytics (evidence indicates that analytics use is limited and adhoc) and course and school reviews (though these generally have little focus on learning technologies). This is much more likely at the unit level, by academic staff with an interest in a particular aspect of teaching and learning. Unit reviews on a per trimester basis are likely to be conducted independent of other units, or of courses as a whole.
6.evidence:
• Limited evaluation is evidenced in ad hoc and informal practices
  • No systematic or detailed approaches are apparent

7.rationale: The University has school and institutional awards which require demonstration of continuous improvement cycles, so these contribute as evidencing the impact of TEL. These rarely have any impact on courses however, as they are commonly aimed at individual units. As mentioned above, evaluation is ad hoc and limited, and continuous improvement is often up to the individual academic staff member and/or the learning design teams located in Schools.
7.evidence:
• School and Institutional teaching awards
  • No systematic approaches are apparent

8.rationale: While UNE has attempted this in a range of iterations, there has not been a consistent longstanding approach which has gained traction. The latest development has been created by the learning design community with the intent of encouraging a sense of ownership and generating higher level of willingness to support and populate this. One issue is engaging academic staff to a) participate in development of these initiatives and b) to utilise them in practice. Workloads and rapid turnaround times between teaching periods work to prevent significant uptake of these initiatives. Some Schools have regular sessions to highlight a technology in use, and/or discuss online pedagogical approaches, but this is not consistent across the University.
8.evidence:
• Sushi menu/ EdShed/ The Community
  • Ad-hoc School ‘lunch and learn’ and showcase events

0.rationale: While we recognise that staff development is occurring, the University does not have a current Teaching and Learning Strategic Plan which aligns to the UNE Strategic Plan released this year. Substantial staff development work is being undertaken, despite the lack of a strategic plan, but no clear framework is currently in place.
0.evidence:
• Absence of a Teaching and Learning Plan
  • Development of frameworks underway in TALS
  • Staff development occurs across the University

1.rationale: Processes are in place and there is evidence of use in Schools and centralised support areas, but this is informal, inconsistent and staff needs may not always be addressed due to resourcing limitations. The learning design teams are tasked with staff development in Schools, but this is one of many duties and is more ad hoc than systematically planned.
1.evidence:
• Absence of formal process
  • Learning design teams identify needs in informal ways through business as usual interactions
  • Strategy in terms of technology enhanced learning is non-existent

2.rationale: There is no systematic process to identify staff development needs across UNE. Lack of resourcing also means that Schools have access to ≤ 1 Learning Designer for all academic staff members and the Learning Designers are tasked with a range of duties. Subject-matter expertise and technological knowledge appear to be privileged over educational expertise in some cases, although it is acknowledged that academic pedagogical content knowledge and experience is linked to disciplinary knowledge. Programs and resources at School level are somewhat dependent on the expertise of the learning design team. However, some programs and resources exist across UNE which have been developed with educational and/or technical expertise.
2.evidence:
• Programs and resources have been developed in some Schools through learning design teams which utilise both educational and technical expertise
  • Regular technical training sessions take place through ITD on core technologies used for teaching and learning
  • Teaching Online is an online portal with resources and guidelines for use of core technologies
  • Online Academic Development modules are in development to replace former model of workshops and formal courses

3.rationale: This is not systematic across UNE. It is reliant on professional networks to informally coordinate development activities. However, these informal processes result in reasonably good coordination. This is enhanced by the regular meetings and contact the School learning design teams have with TALS learning support and ITD training staff. There are a few gaps, however – including intersection between the Lecturer for Higher Education and the Learning Design teams.
3.evidence:
• Regular meetings and good communication occurs within informal groups (LTOPs and ADCOP)
  • School learning design teams provide just-in-time and at-desk training and provide regular feedback on centrally managed resources ie Teaching Online

4.rationale: The positioning of learning design teams in Schools has been a good step towards improved resourcing, however it is still limited and staff development is just one of the suite of tasks assigned to these staff. ITD has a full time trainer, who is able to provide development for learning technologies, but she is also tasked with covering development needs for all other technologies used at UNE. The academic development unit has been reduced from 4 staff to 1. Also, staff development is not included in workload calculations for academic staff, and casual staff may be disadvantaged significantly where staff development is concerned as they are typically not remunerated for development time.
4.evidence:
• Enterprise agreement
  • Staff ratios, both in Schools and across UNE

5.rationale:
UNE does not typically offer a range of programs that cover differing skill levels. Programs, as offered through ITD, are often beginner courses and further development is undertaken with ongoing use of the technology. Training sessions are scheduled, so flexibility in timing is limited, however there is scope to request special sessions (ie for a School or discipline, for example). School learning design teams typically deliver some development programs to staff, but these are limited as this is only one aspect of their role.  Ad hoc development is common in line with just-in-time and at-desk support.

Online guides have been developed by ITD and TALS and these are regularly updated, providing opportunities for individuals to up-skill.

Evaluation processes are not in place to inform staff development requirements.
5.evidence:
• Just-in-time staff development offered in Schools is flexible. More formal staff development sessions in Schools are likely to be aimed at a low-medium skill level and offered a limited number of times per trimester.
  • ITD training is face-to-face, timetabled, limited to one-two sessions per trimester.
  • TALS and ITD provide online guides which staff can work through independently

6.rationale: Informal evaluation occurs in Schools and across ITD and TALS, but this is not systematic across UNE. Some staff development is planned on a needs basis, however much is planned well in advance, is reliant on perceived needs and focused on UNE-supported learning technologies.
6.evidence:
No systematic process in place to evaluate staff development processes (see 1 and 2 above)

Informal evaluation may result in improvements, but this is inconsistent and reliant on professional networks and good communication rather than a feedback cycle which informs planning.

0.rationale: UNE has a focus on compliance and quality assurance. Use of emerging technologies is not aligned with workload implications, institutional policy limits and the change to a trimester model. Support for emerging technologies is more often provided in Schools, but learning design teams have extensive remits. Academic staff lack time to explore new technologies. ITD limit support provided to suite of identified UNE supported technologies. There is no formal mechanism in place to adjust the ‘supported’ list of technologies.
0.evidence:
• No official process for identifying/ employing new technologies
  • Historically ITD have resisted providing support for new technologies for teaching and learning
  • Learning design teams in Schools support both current and emerging technologies
  • Enterprise agreement/ workload policies

1.rationale:
PPDR, unit reviews, input from student representatives on approaches and use of technologies assist somewhat in identifying requirements.

If identifying equates to evaluating what is being done, some schools are asked to identify requirements in School Teaching and Learning Committees. Learning design teams use informal procedures to identify needs at the individual and team levels.
1.evidence:
• No systematic approach in place
  • Informal procedures in place in Schools addressing some individual and team support requirements

2.rationale: Evaluation of support services and resources is ad hoc rather than through a systematic approach. ITD evaluation takes place following service calls/ emails as an automated process. Informal feedback through learning design teams to TALS and ITD provides some evaluation, as does informal and reflection processes in Schools on what is working well and not so well.
2.evidence:
• Ad hoc procedures are common
  • ITD support services have automated evaluation processes

3.rationale: The learning design community is coordinated, particularly around communications to staff and having good understanding of support services available. The range of directorates involved in supporting various technologies and systems can cause issues however such as lack of transferability of student demographic data between student management system and the LMS; prescriptive terminology used by areas which does not assist in developing contemporary approaches to assessment. While support is generally good, there are overlaps and gaps, which makes it unclear and somewhat ineffective for academic staff.
3.evidence: • Regular meetings occur between TALS, ITD and School learning design teams, but this does not extend to areas which manage systems integrated with the VLE

4.rationale:
Support services are not available for extended hours, which does not align with requirements by academic staff. The University suggests flexibility for students, but this does not equate to extended hours for support (although the ITD Service Desk does have extended hours, their expertise is not in the learning technologies and support can be limited).

Working extended/ flexible hours is the ‘new normal’ – but this is not formally acknowledged.

Often support is provided flexibly through goodwill of learning design teams (and others) who monitor email out of hours and are willing to assist.

Online sites, developed by TALS and ITD, offer practical, step-by-step guides but these are used more for design and development than troubleshooting issues.
4.evidence:
• ITD Service Desk offer some extended support hours
  • Learning design teams often work outside office hours
  • Online sites provide some fully accessible guides

5.rationale:
There have been recent gains with employment of small learning design teams in each School. However, these are often considered to be inadequate for the size of the School. The University learning technologies support team for academic staff consists of two part time staff, and is constantly backlogged with requests.

Support services for learning technologies is not the only aspect when considering effective use in learning environments. Academic workloads, for example do not make any consideration of tie required to employing new technologies. Another ongoing issue is that academic staff are employed because of their subject matter expertise rather than experience in teaching, which means they often require considerable upskilling in working effectively in the online environment, using core technologies.

Tight turnaround between trimesters and challenges in managing teaching loads and employing casual staff can lead to a lack of ownership, with assignment of units often happening just prior to the teaching period and leaving little time for changes to revitalise units. Casual staff also require extra support and oversight by academic staff.
5.evidence:
• Learning design teams in Schools
  • uneonline (helpdesk for academic staff)
  • Limited resourcing and non-existent back up for staff in some areas
  • Workloads for academic staff

6.rationale: In some cases, the services available for technology enhanced learning support are promoted, but with little or inappropriate uptake. For instance, learning design teams are often promoted in Schools but they are generally under-resourced.
6.evidence:
• School learning design teams
  • UNE web pages direct staff to appropriate services

7.rationale: Decision regarding learning technologies are often made behind closed doors – there is a top down tendency with adoption of new technologies, with no consideration for post-implementation support requirements. Implementation of new technologies is often done poorly. Governance is also a concern, for example TALS is the business owner of the suite of learning technologies, but has not typically had any oversight into capabilities for further development, upgrades or reviews of alternatives.
7.evidence:
• Absence of clear governance of learning technologies especially with regard to TALS
  • Unclear support analyses in past implementations

8.evidence: No formal procedures in place other than automated feedback for ITD service desk
8.rationale: UNE has a decentralised model, with a large proportion of support being located in the School learning design teams. Learning design teams collect informal feedback, however this is often verbal and may or may not contribute to continuous improvement. It appears that there is no link between continuous improvements to progression for learning designers, so it may not be a focus for some. Evaluation data is collected on central support services, but this is feedback via an email submission form which simply asks if staff were happy with the service and to provide optional comments.

However, without clearly articulated QA processes, evaluation processes, and improvement plans, it’s unclear how relevant the outcomes that are being reported are, or how effective and efficient the reporting processes are at identifying areas of strength and improvement

0.rationale:
LTC PD Mapping conducted at the beginning of each year. From 2016, also includes alignment with Teaching Criteria and Standards Framework. However, the framework and how it aligns to the institution's learning & teaching strategy are not articulated and communicated to the wider ACU community. 

For example, the FLB states that, "There are a number of staff development opportunities with regard to technology enhanced learning (e.g. all the workshops run by LTC). However, they don’t present as a cohesive framework to help academic teaching staff themselves and faculty support staff assess what staff need and see how the PD they participate in might link to things such as the Teaching Criteria Framework"

1.rationale:
An ACU strategy specific for TEL has not existed for a while. Ways to identify staff development needs have largely been ad hoc, diverse and inconsistently managed.

There are some processes but no central place staff can capture and look at where people are in terms of their PD. Staff are not aware of any formal tools (checklists of skills required, minimum standards required etc) to help academic teaching staff and faculty support staff assess their needs.

2.rationale:
We have inadequate dedicated staff for the development and maintenance of TEL-related resources for staff development needs.

Many resources are out of date and incomplete when it comes to coverage of systems used.

We have very few resources developed for specific, targeted training needs for staff

3.rationale: There are formal places like eLAG meetings but these don’t happen frequently and there are too many other issues to cover to get into the detail required to know exactly what is going on across the institution

4.rationale:
Both LTC and Faculties need more staff to provide TEL-related PD support as well as L&T design expertise.

While LTC run a lot of workshops and there a various workshops run within faculties, many staff still fall through the cracks, especially sessional staff

5.rationale: LTC offerings are good and delivered in different modes. I agree that most of my time is also taken up helping people at a basic level. There are a range of delivery methods (webinars, f2f workshops, online resources) but these tend to be all at an introductory level

0.rationale: With LEO being ACU's enterprise system, then LEO Support provides comprehensive readily available technical support for staff. However, for emerging, or non-core technologies, that rely on support from external vendors, there is limited support available (e.g. for Adobe Connect and Kaltura).

2.rationale: Very little. We have procedures that measure support levels from service level agreement

3.rationale: Lots of verbal meetings, but no formal coordination. Very little is written down and carried forward, particularly when people leave

4.rationale:
LEO Support available extended hours. A report is generated monthly that shows how much the support is accessed by staff

With regards our LEO resources, w don't always track usage.

5.rationale:
Ratings by the Faculties - moderate: When it comes to LEO Support for core current technologies this is definitely true (5), but there is lack of resourcing for emerging technologies or resourcing that requires a staff member within the uni – staff on the ground (2) – so 3 as a result.

Rating by the LTC - Inadequate: LEO Support good. Lack of staff on the ground in the LTC and Faculties. Library support is available as well

6.rationale: A bit unclear about ownership of which support services. Lack of consistent approach to promotion. Sessional staff don't always get the message

7.rationale: Good or bad depending on the technology. Not always consistent. Core Moodle seems to be good but not always on the peripheral systems. Support resources aren't always there before. Don't always test all aspects of the technology. Technical specifications and functional specification documents aren't provided.

8.rationale: Need to separate out vendor support from our own support

Development of Content Layout Tool to allow for insertion of pre-designed elements into pages. All courses to have been touched by end of Semester 2, 2016.

  • Taking on new campus (from USQ) at Hervey Bay

  • Continuing to upskill teaching staff in digital technologies so appropriate technology use is seamless and enriching for students

0.rationale:
The University is in the third year of a three year strategy to embed blended learning as the core teaching methodology. A key outcome of the strategy is the implementation of a universal course design in Blackboard with good practice elements embedded in the course structure and menu.

There is no universal QA instrument applied to courses/programs from the blended learning perspective. Mapping projects have been done focusing on technology takeup, but not across the board.

Student Evaluation of Teaching and Courses (SETAC) is conducted each semester but this is currently under review.

Technology provision for teaching spaces is regularly evaluated and upgraded. There is good provision of facilities for general learning and teaching, such as wifi, classroom tech etc.

Systematic, longtitudinal instruments for quality assurance are lacking.

• Blended Learning Strategy 2014-2016
  • C~SALT Action Plan 2016-2018
  • Blackboard+ documentation including Core Elements framework
  • Blended learning mapping tool has been used and continues to be used in faculties
  • Staff development workshops
  • Implementation of standard Blackboard theme and menu structure in every course
  • Every academic school has an annual Blended Learning Action Plan is signed off by the HoS
  • BL Strategy overseen by BLS Steering Group chaired by Senior DVC with senior representation - Faculty Exec Deans, ADLTs etc.
  • SETAC
  • Course Impact Evaluations are required for new or substantially changed courses

1.rationale:
This depends on the scale of the rollout. Large systems are well scoped with good project management methodologies and project managers allocated. Resourcing has generally been adequate although budgets are tightening.

Smaller tech rollouts are less well defined. A process is in development to identify, investigate, evaluate, implement and evaluate post-implementation but there is a degree of ad hoccery at present.

The Educational Technologies Application Support Group monitors the operation of educational technologies through reports and updates, plans and schedules and approves system changes.
1.evidence:
• Educational Technologies Application Support Group
  • Course and Program Impact Statements

2.rationale:
There are regular cycles within ITS, Asset Management Services and C~SALT where technologies are regularly upgraded. This includes teaching space technology, large systems (Blackboard, Mediasite etc.), desktop computing applications, and these processes are resourced from within existing staff and sometimes with additional funds.

C~SALT is charged with monitoring the adequacy of these systems through its Educational Technologies and Environments team. Reviews lead to improvement and combined C~SALT and ITS resources are applied when needed. e.g. Annual Bb upgrades, Bb+ initiative. These activities all come from existing resources but are recognised as mainstream tasks.

Not all upgrade requests can be serviced, such as where needs are identified outside planning cycles.

  • Annual 'large system' upgrades that are 'routine' e.g. Blackboard

3.rationale: This is very poorly executed. KPIs are not generally identified and consolidated across different service areas. In the absence of defined KPIs there is no routine evaluation against them.
3.evidence: A practice vacuum.

4.rationale:
Reporting on technology enhanced learning occurs in pockets but is not integrated across cost centres or the University generally.

There is good reporting on the Blended Learning Strategy through regular meetings of the BL Academic Leads (on-ground academic advocates), School BL Action Plans and meetings of the BL Steering Group. Reporting varies within Schools as they have different reporting structures. C~SALT produces reports for Heads of School on the range of C~SALT engagements in their Schools including blended learning.

Student completion data is compiled by the Strategic Information and Analysis Unit so data on attrition/completion is created but is not widely circulated - (much of it is restricted). This data is used to identify priority courses that require attention from a learning and teaching perspective.

1.evidence:
There is a well documented calender of maintenance events for all systems, including annual major upgrades of the large systems; Blackboard and Mediasite. Processes are not always formally documented and not necessarily well shared. There are single points of failure where too much knowledge resides in individuals' heads at times.

There are clearly defined roles and responsibilities for teams within ITS and C~SALT. There is an Educational Technologies Application Support Group that considers a wide range of technologies and monitors, through monthly meetings, operations and system developments.
1.rationale:
Robust and reliable operation of learning systems is critical to the University's operations. This is well understood and supported.

Updates to major systems are well coordinated between ITS and C~SALT with project planning and execution tasks carefully coordinated. Similarly with scoping new systems and services.

2.evidence:
• Educational Technology Support for staff is provided through both C~SALT (learning and teaching use) and ITServicedesk (functional use) - both have job tracking and customer service ethos
  • Workshops and online resources are offered to staff but these are not as well developed or as comprehensive as they need to be. A work in progress.
  • ITS offers some workshops that focus on technical operation of equipment but the coverage is limited and not keeping pace with technology rollouts. (e.g. Office 365 implementation.)
  • Not good coordination across areas.
  • There is a slowly growing set of self-help resources for staff on intranet (MyUSC) but these have a way to go to be comprehensive.
2.rationale:
Student support is very limited. There is a Student IT Helpdesk with limited scope but no support beyond that. Student support for applied use of learning and teaching systems such as the LMS is devolved to academic staff with very mixed results. This has been a point of contention for some years.

Staff support is provided by the C~SALT team, focussing on the educational application of technologies. ITS deliver limited workshops in technology functionality, without the pedagogical overlay.

3.rationale: Generally, systems that are implemented are reasonably well supported by ITS.
3.evidence:
• Routine upgrades undertaken on rolling basis - technology lifecycles documented and generally followed
  • Poor support of innovative projects - unclear funding sources and governance of projects often lacking

4.rationale:
Broadly speaking, the University does not have a culture of bold exploration and innovation around technologies. Historically there has been considerable risk aversion at USC and this has been reflected in ITS' lack of willingness to support experimentation. This is now changing and in conjunction with C~SALT there is an improving culture of innovation.

Internal grants are another story and these have been provided for several years to enable academic staff to explore technologies in their practice. The processes to translate learnings from projects into production systems have been not been developed or formally established. Similarly with evaluation of technologies for integration with existing infrastructure.
4.evidence:
• Internal Grants and Awards - well defined submission, selection, evaluation processes
  • With the exception of Grants and Awards, there is no fund for technology exploration or to support innovation that staff can make submissions to for projects

5.rationale:
PD for staff involved with supporting services is provided on a routine basis and includes training events and conferences. This is particularly so for existing, established services and is more ad hoc for new services.

Conferences such as the annual Blackboard conference are routinely attended by several staff from ITS and C~SALT.

6.rationale: The University has robust risk assessment processes and a history of being risk-averse. This covers all areas of operation. ITS are audited regularly, by internal and external auditors.

7.rationale:
Support for staff for the educational use of learning technologies is generally understood to be the responsibility of the Centre for Support and Advancement of Learning and Teaching. This includes large systems, classroom technology and desktop educational tools.

Support for functional use of IT including basic infrastructure (desktop computing, wifi, productivity applications etc.) is the responsibility of IT Services. This is generally understood across the academic community.

1.rationale:
Identification of staff training needs in educational technologies is not undertaken systematically from any particular cost centre. HR have programs but they specifically avoid educational technologies and learning and teaching themes.

C~SALT identifies needs based on:

  • engagement with academic staff through a range of other activities
  • initiatives being driven from the Centre, e.g. Bb+
  • historical knowledge of training needs, e.g. Blackboard functionality etc.
  • rollout of new technologies, e.g. Bb Collaborate Ultra, SRS, Pebble

ITS provide training on core systems and software and as part of a change management process when new core technologies are rolled out.

  • Workshops to enable academic staff to 'bring and build' content and start on their courses
  • Offering open drop-ins at C~SALT for anyone wanting to call in, without appointment, to sort out issues

Engagement with academic staff results in intelligence around development needs that result in workshops and online resources such as:

2.rationale:
There are various activities that address professional development in blended learning. These vary from workshops to day-long sesssions, Learning and Teaching Week, and a course on University teaching.

Most of the content is developed by or vetted by Academic Developers to ensure it fits USC's core teaching philosophies.

C~SALT has technical staff with in-depth knowledge of our systems from desktop to enterprise systems and they develop and deliver professional development.
2.evidence:
• Foundations of University Teaching (optional course covering university teaching - theory and practice), with a strong emphasis on blended learning and delivered in a blended learning mode.
  • Sessional Staff Development Day - twice yearly day-long program focussed on needs of sessional staff.
  • Learning and Teaching Week - demonstrations of best practice at USC combined with visiting experts - with blended learning a key philosophy.
  • Peer Assisted Teaching Scheme (PATS) is offered to staff.

3.rationale: Coordination across cost centres is ad hoc. Individual areas tend to develop and deliver PD without reference to other areas. It is not always easy to identify who is offering what around the University.
3.evidence:
The evidence is that professional development opportunities is sometimes discovered after the fact. There are no coordinating mechanisms (such as a central training calendar) to expose all training being offered.

Promotion of professional development tends to be by 'all staff' emails out of individual cost centres. There is not yet an integrated training calender in our staff intranet.

4.rationale:
Resourcing for the provision of PD is reasonable and a core element of C~SALT's work. Capacity to develop and deliver PD is quite good.

However, support for academics to participate is within the domain of Schools, Disciplines and Program groups. One suspects this isn't an issue when there is no cost to participate but can become so if fees apply.

There is an ongoing problem for sessional staff who would not generally be paid to attend PD.

5.rationale:
C~SALT: Generally staff development is delivered face-to-face, both in groups and individually. The assumption is that facilitators will be faced with diverse skill levels and will accommodate them. Participatory learning is a fundamental approach and training is planned to be rich and engaging.

ITS: Training is provided in a relatively static format and appears to use a boilerplate approach. Presentation style tends to be 'stand and deliver'.
5.evidence: Evidence to come.

6.rationale: Evaluations of PD and training are undertaken and used to inform future delivery modes and themes. Continuous improvement is presumed and content of PD is reviewed prior to each delivery.
6.evidence: Programs and workshops run by C~SALT usually involve follow-up evaluations by email or online survey. Paper forms are used less as they are problematic.

0.rationale:
• The Minimum Standards for Online Presence procedure has recently been enacted which only governs the threshold use of approved technologies at Victoria University, and contains limited guidance on how to conduct quality assurance activities within this space.
  • Various Colleges at VU have established Learning and Teaching related meetings and reference groups that touch on the effective integration of technology enhanced learning into their courses however this is purely operational.
  • CCLT have developed a list of whitelist supported tools with support protocols and procedures around tools and systems that fall outside the scope of full support from the University.
  • There is a lack of University wide steering group that strategically oversees quality assurance aspects of technology enhanced learning platforms and processes across the numerous Colleges. Initial conversations are being held concerning the framework of this group.
  • VU Learning and Teaching Quality and Standards Framework loosely references the integration of technology enhanced learning in course design, delivery and evaluation.
  • VU Learning and Teaching Quality and Standards Policy does not reference blended learning, online learning, technology enhanced learning and what procedures are to be established in order to successfully undergo QA activities
  • Directors of Learning and Teaching across all Colleges have been given sufficient access to VU Collaborate (LMS), that enables them to conduct quality assurance activities.
  • Copyright audits by the Library department are conducted within VU Collaborate to ensure that staff and students comply with the Copyright Material (The Use Of) Policy.

• Learning and Teaching Quality and Standards Framework

1.rationale:
• Institutional processes have not been established at Victoria University however they are incorporated at an operational level within CCLT and the Colleges.
  • Establishment of the ‘Learning Environments working party group to support decision making and evaluation of the online learning environment.
  • The Learning Environments team utilise informal evaluation process and procedures in terms of effectiveness of TEL services.
  • Lack of initial checklist that informs Colleges on how to integrate new technology into their respective College
  • Lack of using data to inform decision making – high level reports are used but we are currently limited due to VU’s current data warehouse infrastructure.
  • Primarily only qualitative data has been used to validate successfulness of technology enhanced learning technologies however there is a strategic view to create and leverage data platforms that provide insight into the future implementation of online learning technologies.

2.rationale:
• An additional level of strategic management (PVCs) and Coordinators across the Colleges have been employed to assist with the planning for quality control and improvement concerning the University’s TEL services.
  • Employment 10 technology enhanced learning designers (TELD) to operationally execute key activities as part of the Blended Learning Project – this does not refer to planning but more so funds allocated to
  • Previously, a central enterprise value management department (EVM) controlled project direction which encompassed comprehensive support resource for planning. This department is no longer in operation due to continual political issues.
  • A centralised Community of Planning group has not been established and will need to be resourced.
  • Blended Learning Coordinators have been employed in some of the College to assist with planning for quality improvement concerning TEL services.

  • Blended Learning Strategy and Operational plan - outlines employment of 10 x Technology Enhanced Learning Designers and 1 Blended Learning Coordinator per College.

3.rationale:
• Basic evaluation cycles are in place through inter-departmental collaboration activities which include adoption and usage of the Learning Management System, categorised by College.
  • Regular stakeholder surveys are conducted to measure satisfaction with current TELS, with opportunities to provide constructive feedback that are fed back into the business. This is not institutionally recognised and has only generated limited traction.
  • Significant infrastructural limitations impinge VU’s ability to produce succinct and meaningful usage reports.
  • KPI’s relating to TELS have not been defined at the institutional level to support continuous improvement. This is only done at the operational level centrally within CCLT.
  • Through the initiation of the Blended Learning Project, key deliverables have been identified with the evaluation methodology documented accordingly.
  • Requests and Incidents handled by the ITS Service Desk are automatically categorised and reported on and fed back to CCLT to improve existing resources, professional development opportunities and limitations with existing TELS.

1.rationale:
• The existing framework for successfully integrating TEL is purely technical with limited pedagogical aspects for application included – this is ultimately left up to the Colleges with the assistance of CCLT.
  • College based discussions concerning the Minimum online standards and future direction of blended learning at VU indicate that a number of issues have surfaced and it’s unclear whether the technology dictates the pedagogical framework of teaching in a blended environment.
  • Recently approved micro projects conducted within the Colleges (known as Technology enhanced learning grants) have created a heightened awareness in small pockets in terms of understanding the pedagogical intent of TEL.
  • No unified strategy exists that documents the pedagogical intent of TEL (e.g. a Learning Technologies Strategy and Procedure). With no clear guidelines, this cannot be communicated institutionally to all teaching and support staff. Existing communicational efforts reside solely within CCLT, specific individuals within the Colleges and other support teams and are not shared freely amongst all staff.
