4.rationale:
The Portfolio of the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Education) (DVCE) has a communications strategy that relates to and reaches all academic staff and business unit directors. This includes:

The Learning at UC bulletin, a communication tool used by the DVCE to provide professional and academic staff with a range of information about teaching and learning. This includes innovations, technologies, policies, procedures, workshops and other related matters at the University.  Links to relevant resources and contacts for support/advice are included in the text.
Information sessions for academic staff and briefings of the Associate Deans of Education (ADE’s) by the DVCE, the Director of Teaching and Learning and/or other teaching and learning staff as necessary.
Briefings for new staff, as well as current UC staff who have been promoted to Professor.
Postings on Yammer, UC-Chat, UC-Teaching, Twitter, the DVCE Blog, Events Calendar, the Workshop registration system, the Library Facebook page, and various electronic screens located in public spaces.
The Policy database enables access to policy documents via text search or by browsing categories.  As noted above, new and revised policies are communicated to staff via Learning at UC, as well as email. 

The Staff Guide to Policies provides academic and professional staff with a quick reference resource document to help them find policy information.  It is updated annually and promulgated to staff via Learning at UC.

Minutes of Academic Board and its annual activity report to Council are available to all UC staff via the Academic Board web-site, and to members and relevant staff involved in governance processes via the Academic Board Moodle site.  The Academic Board Moodle site is a site designed to support staff involved with the approval processes for academic governance, including policies, curriculum documentation, resources for academics and communication associated with Academic Board.

Minutes of Academic Board standing committees, which include the University Education Committee (UEC) and its sub-committees (Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG) [refer to PI 6], and the Courses Sub-Committee), are available to all UC staff via the associated website. UEC monitors the quality of the University’s teaching and learning activities and academic program, and advises Academic Board and the Vice-Chancellor on polices related to education. As TEL is an inherent component of current teaching and learning activities any matters related to the procurement of the virtual learning environments are submitted to UEC by LEAG.

5.rationale:
A number of committees and groups have been established to provide oversight and responsibility in relation to the governance of TEL, these include:

Learning Environments Advisory Group
This group was established to evaluate and advise the University Education Committee (UEC) and the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Education) (DVCE) on existing, new and emerging technologies that could be used in teaching and learning to demonstrate innovation and improve student experience and learning outcomes, as well as ongoing implications for learning space design.  Its focus is at the infrastructure level.

The purpose and function of LEAG is to provide advice to UEC on the University’s virtual and physical learning environments, with its responsibilities set out as per below:  

Provide advice to University Education Committee on the nature, quality and fitness-for-purpose of UC’s virtual and physical learning environments.
Provide advice to UEC on existing, new and emerging technologies that could be used in teaching and learning to demonstrate innovation, and improve the student experience and learning outcomes.
Provide advice to UEC on the types of learning spaces, learning space design and furnishings needed now, soon or in the future to enable delivery to new and existing student cohorts
Lead and oversee the implementation of new or renewed learning environments.
Determine if any issues relating to learning environments require discussion by the UEC.
Undertake any other activities referred to it by the UEC.
Report annually to the UEC on its activities.

The group is chaired by an academic staff member appointed by UEC and should meet at least once before each UEC meeting, with representation from key stakeholders across the University community.  Membership includes:

Director, Teaching and Learning  
Manager, Learning Information and Environments  
Director, ITM or representative
Director, Estates Management or representative
Director, UCC or representative
Director, Student Engagement or representative
Two representatives from each faculty, nominated by the Dean, with alternates nominated by the Dean
Information Technologies Advisory Group (ITAG)
ITAG is an advisory group to the Vice President, Operations on Information and Technology Management matters. It is the primary ITM governance body of the University. Its composition is designed to ensure University business areas are represented and direct ITM resources and investments which enhance core business, including teaching, research and the student experience. ITAG prioritised IT projects against strategic criteria.  Membership includes:

Vice President, Operations (Chair)
Deputy Vice Chancellor, Education
Deputy Vice Chancellor, Research
Chair of Services Committee
Chair of Corporate Systems Working Group
Director, ITM

 

As detailed in PI 3, a new Capital Management Process is currently in discussion.
Change Advisory Board (CAB)
CAB is a cross-team group that meets weekly to review intended changes to UC’s IT systems that include a focus on possible downstream impacts and dependencies, and additional coordination or testing requirements.

Non-Standard Change Request Process (NSCR)
Changes to UC’s IT systems can be requested using the Non-Standard Change Request process.

For UC’s Virtual Learning Environment (VLE), NSCRs are reviewed weekly by the Scholarly Information Environments (SIE) team management group and prioritised against a set of criteria.

6.rationale:
Given the multi-dimensional nature of TEL within the University, some of the authorities and responsibilities for operational management of technologies cross a number of boundaries and are not clearly defined in documentation.  Technologies include corporate systems such as Office 365 with OneDrive and VLE tools and services, such as Moodle, Blackboard Collaborate, and Millenium. Key business units that support the operation of technologies include ITM and Teaching and Learning (SIE).  The purpose of the SIE team is to manage, coordinate and provide advice on the use of the University’s scholarly information environments, which include:

teaching and learning tools and services
scholarly information tools and services
third party content resources/packages, tools and services.
The Scholarly Information Environments document provides detailed information, including clear division of responsibilities for the range of VLE’s, to support staff in effectively using the University’s scholarly information environments to design and enable high quality student learning experiences and teaching and research innovation. 

The Teaching and Learning Plan, as discussed in PI 1, includes specific responsibility and accountability associated with each activity.  For example, the Manager of SIE is responsible for the ongoing provision, maintenance and improvement of all technologies supported by SIE.
6.evidence: Embedded in rationale...

7.rationale:
The Procurement Policy sets out principles that govern how goods and services, which include procurement of technology, are purchased for the University.  Supporting this policy is the Procurement Procedures Manual, which provides principles relating to procurement and information on carrying out procurement activities.  According to the Manual, all intending purchasers are responsible for identifying and planning their procurement processes.  The Financial Delegations Policy establishes a framework for delegating financial authority and sets out the responsibilities and associated value assigned to staff to enable them to take financial action on its behalf.  In terms of the procurement process, all computers (desktop computers, mobile computers, laptops etc.) regardless of price, must be obtained through ITM procurement.  Procurements relating to other technology such as learning management systems are processed according to the dollar value, and may require open tender.

Regarding the governance structure, the University has a number of advisory groups and/or committees that oversee discussion endorsement of and/or decision making around the adoption of new technologies.  These include:

Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG) (refer PI 6)
University Education Committee (refer PI 5 & 6)
Information and Technology Advisory Group (ITAG) (refer PI 6)

 

The Change Advisory Board (CAB) is a cross-team group that reviews change requests to UC’s IT systems (refer PI 6).  As part of the review they consider and determine possible impacts on other systems, as well as coordinating testing requirements.  Changes to systems require a non-standard change request (NSCR) form.  With regard to the Virtual Learning Environments, NSCR’s are submitted by the SIE team management group, Teaching and Learning.

0.rationale:
The University of Canberra has a distributed model of quality assurance and this is not specific to the technology-enhanced aspects of student learning. The ranking provided here does not properly reflect the range of quality assurance processes that are in place, but does reflect that many of these are silent on technology enhanced learning, although it may be implied. The University is in a transition in relation to the approach it is taking to quality assurance and is moving away from its existing reliance on a Unit Satisfaction Survey to a range of engagement and satisfaction metrics that provide a more faceted and immediate indication of students’ experiences.

The UC Breakthrough Strategic Plan objectives specifically include ‘Expand and enhance flexible learning’ which implies an increased and better use of technologies to support teaching practices and student learning. UC’s focus on and commitment to technology enhanced learning is demonstrated through the Education Plan (with targets for flexible delivery) and the Flexible Learning Implementation Plan which included the establishment of the Learning Environments Advisory Group.

The University is currently procuring a virtual learning environment (May 2016) which has included and extensive consultation process across the university community and the identification of the functional requirements from this consultation. The evaluation plan for this procurement focuses on the student and staff experience of the technology tools and services: simplification, integration, automation and function.

UC has a strong focus on supporting and encouraging the use of technology for teaching purposes, but less explicit mechanisms for quality assuring its use. Student engagement metrics are largely focused on the levels of online engagement as demonstrated through levels of touch of the TEL environments. Other demonstrations of engagement are more difficult to capture.

Institution-wide processes for quality assurance are in place and in use

  • Quality and Standards Framework
    • Quality and Improvements Advisory Group (QIAG)
  • Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG)
  • Course Quality Framework (CQF)
  • Information and Technology Management Strategy
  • Flexible Learning Implementation Plan (FLIP)
  • InterFace
  • Recognition and Advancement Strategy
    • Graduate Certificate in Tertiary Education
  • UC Digital Strategy

Quality and Standards Framework: At an institutional level UC has an overarching Quality and Standards Framework. This references the UC Course Experience Questionnaire (UCCEQ) and the Student Services Survey (2011, 2013 but not scheduled to run again). The UC Course Experience Survey does not mention the technology enhanced component specifically, but does reflect the responding students’ views about the quality of their learning experience. The Student Services Survey has only been conducted in 2011 and has not been repeated. The 2011 results suggested that key areas for improvement were access to computing equipment and IT Help and support, but does not relate these IT issues to their learning specifically.

Quality and Improvements Advisory Group (QAIT) – high level advisory group which meets 6 times per year and provides advice to the Vice-President Operations on quality and improvement matters related to the scholarly and professional areas of the university.

Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG): LEAG was established to evaluate and advise the UEC and the DVCE on existing, new and emerging technologies that could be used in teaching and learning to demonstrate innovation and improve student experience and learning outcomes, as well as ongoing implications for learning space design.

LEAG provides advice to the University Education Committee on the University’s virtual and physical learning environments. Its TOR are below. However, it is not clear that LEAG focuses on TEL at the course and program level. It is more at the broader tools and infrastructure level.

LEAG TOR

  1. Provide advice to University Education Committee on the nature, quality and fitness-for-purpose of UC’s virtual and physical learning environments.
  2. Provide advice to University Education Committee on on existing, new and emerging technologies that could be used in teaching and learning to demonstrate innovation and improve student experience and learning outcomes.
  3. Provide advice to University Education Committee on the types of learning spaces, learning space design and furnishings needed now, soon or in the future to enable delivery to new and existing student cohorts
  4. Lead and oversee the implementation of new or renewed learning environments.
  5. Determine if any issues relating to learning environments require discussion by the University Education Committee.
  6. Undertake any other activities referred to it by the University Education Committee.
  7. Report annually to the University Education Committee on its activities.

 

Course Quality Framework (CQF)

The CQF Statement of Principles includes:

  • Units and courses provide a high quality learning experience for students that employ best-practice teaching and learning methods and relevant learning technologies; and
  • Provide students with the opportunity for work integrated learning and international study experiences, and globally connected learning opportunities through technologies

The Dean of a faculty is responsible for the delivery and content quality of the courses offered by that faculty.

2016 implementation of the CQF has focused to date on the course development process by facilitating ‘quality assurance of course creation by determining market need, latest technologies and teaching practices by discipline’ (p.6). The course development process explicitly targets learning technologies by requiring proponents to address the principles of innovation and engagement, identified in UC’s Strategic Plan. A capacity statement supports, that explicitly requires proponents to consider ‘educational technology tools, creat[ing] diverse and effective online learning environments and experiences, and employ[ing] flexible pedagogies’. The UC’s Course Development Process has been fully operational since March 2016.

The CQF also requires course monitoring and Annual Course Reporting. This will manifest as an adaptive quality enhancement model predicated largely on online experience through integration with the InterFace dashboard and associated data and analytics. Technology enhanced learning and appropriate use of technology for learning is an integral part of this model.

Information and Technology Management Strategy

The ITM Strategy includes a goal of Transforming IT capability towards a borderless University taking a global position.

The Strategy includes ‘Develop and promote ITM services to facilitate engagement and experience through technology’ and ‘Develop ITM consulting services to provide advice and leadership on technology for teaching, learning and research’.

The Strategy does not include a focus on quality assurance in relation to teaching and learning, or a focus on integrating technology specifically at a program or course level (see below). However, ITM supports a range of technology services that support the teaching enterprise such as the student management system (Callista), the timetabling system (Syllabus+), the tutorial management system (Allocate), Office265 and OneDrive, and these are integrated to greater and lesser degrees with the students’ learning experiences of their units and courses through either MyUC and/or the learning management system.

integrate technology enhanced learning at both a program and course level

Flexible Learning Implementation Plan (FLIP)

The FLIP is a sub-plan of the University’s Education Plan. It is built on assumptions of flexibility, mobility and BYOD. It includes a range of planning and implementation activities to support the design, implementation, management and reporting of processes to update, replace and/or add educational technologies to enable and support learning and teaching innovation, quality student learning experiences, and proper administrative management of the business of education.

InterFace

InterFace is a web-based dashboard available to UC students and to unit conveners and other designated staff. It uses analytics to present students with real-time information about their progress towards completing their course and their progress and engagement with each unit in which they are enrolled. For unit conveners it can help build their understanding of the profile, performance and perceptions of students in their units. InterFace captures student engagement as expressed through their use of TEL environments, however, it does not explicit canvas their satisfaction with the TEL they experience. The questions they are asked are related to their satisfaction with their happiness, how well they think they have done, and the alignment of their unit with their career destination.

Recognition and Advancement Strategy

Teaching and Learning activities in staff development are designed to support the achievement of the UC Strategic Plan 2013-2017 and the associated Education Plan which have ambitious targets of growth via strategic partnerships nationally and internationally, and additional provision of flexible and online study opportunities for students.

It provides staff with advice, support, information sessions, online learning, and innovation showcases as well as opportunities for accredited study and support for international certification in the areas of learning design, curriculum design, policy development and implementation, library resources and technical and other support in the effective pedagogical use of our learning technologies.

The staff recognition and advancement activities are university-wide approaches to supporting the integration of technology into teaching and learning practice, and highlights the pedagogical applications of technology.

Staff Development for Teaching and Learning Program (the Program) includes:

  • Online courses provided by third party providers that UC has purchased (For example, Epigeum’s University and College Teaching modules, Blended Learning modules, open courses provided in MOOCs and/or OERu, Lynda.com resources),
  • Activities scheduled by Teaching and Learning to provide staff with the opportunity to develop skills in UC learning technologies (see https://www.canberra.edu.au/myuc-s/business-units/dvce/tl/staff-development-and-support/workshop-registration), and/or to extend the tools, techniques, strategies and approaches to their own teaching practice and curriculum renewal.

Graduate Certificate in Tertiary Education (GCTE)

The GCTE has been redeveloped for delivery to UC (and some partner staff) from mid-2016. One of the focus areas of the new GCTE is flexible learning environments. The use of educational technologies is embedded into every aspect of the course.

UC Digital Strategy

UC’s ITM Architecture Framework is supported and guided by the following Digital Principles:

  • Cloud First: cloud services should always be adopted when appropriate.
  • Mobile Friendly: an increasing percentage of our digital interactions are via mobile devices – therefore our services need to be mobile friendly.
  • Proactive Posturing: positioning the University to rapidly embrace new technologies and trends.
  • Borderless: supporting a model of users being able to work anytime, anywhere.
  • Embrace BYOE: acknowledging that users have services and devices that they want to use before and after their engagement with UC.
  • Review Strategy Frequently: ensuring alignment with emerging or disruptive trends.

Change Advisory Board (CAB)

Non-Standard Change Request Process

For UC’s Virtual Learning Environment, NSCRs are reviewed weekly by the SIE team management group and prioritised against a set of criteria.

Drop-in session review

The LearnOnline support team run drop-in sessions for staff Monday-Friday 1.30-3.30pm. The reason for the attendance is recorded to enable TL to identify trends in the use of the VLE tools and services and problems arising from that use for students and staff.

Weekly Remedy review

Remedy is the system by the University for management of tickets lodged with its ServiceDesk by staff and students. These tickets are generally IT-focused in nature. Those relating to VLE matters are referred to the LearnOnline team. Team leaders and the Deputy-Manager meet weekly to review Remedy tickets to assess a) number and type of tickets b) tickets that need escalation either from a business or a technical perspective c) review of trends and issues that need to be addressed through technical or user interface enhancements, renewal of online staff help or communications. This review process feeds into the evaluation of VLE tools and services.

Usage analysis

The University maintains and reviews statistical measures of VLE services usage to enable it to evaluate the cost and benefit of maintain that service and to evaluate its usefulness to the staff and students.

Requirements gathering/consultation for VLE procurement

The University is currently procuring tools and services that comprise its VLE. This include extensive consultation with stakeholder groups, detailed analysis of functional requirements, development of use cases, and an evaluation plan for the selection of the components. The evaluation panel for the VLE is comprised of stakeholders from across the university.
1.evidence: Evidence throughout rationale

2.rationale:
This is a hot topic at the highest level of university management, and there is a recognition that the current resourcing process is not adequate to ensure that resources are committed to enable longer term planning for TEL. At present ITAG is the body through which funds are allocated for strategic IT projects. However, this is done on a year by year basis and has largely excluded consideration of educational technologies. A Capital Investment Review is currently underway under the auspices of the Vice-President (Operations) and this will link consideration of the physical and virtual environments in the resource planning for the university. This change in approach is likely to support and enable a future focused planning process for TEL and better balance of resourcing between TEL systems and corporate systems.

The planning for quality improvement is a component of the position descriptions in different areas of the university, and in that sense it is resourced, though the PDs may not reference TEL directly.

Examples

Corporate Systems Administration Officer UC5: Contribute to the ongoing improvement of the Student Administration and Research Systems and other Corporate Systems as required.

Educational Designer/Technologist UC 6/7: Analyse the evaluation of courses and units delivered through blended delivery and online modes in order to develop and implement strategies to improve the quality of the student experience.

Given that most activities in the university are reliant on some technology or another, and rely on infrastructure such as the WiFi, the network, electricity for power etc, it is difficult to specify whether or not there is sufficient resourcing for the quality improvement of technology enhanced learning systems or not as a distinct and separate resourcing question.
2.evidence: Evidence throughtout rationale

3.rationale:
The Education Plan lists a number of key performance indicators linked to flexible learning provision for students, but not specifically related to quality or continuous improvement of the provision, nor the planning.

UC does not have a direct evaluation process for TEL components of student experience integrated into its planning for improvement, and the TEL evaluation tends to be focused around usage (quantitative statistics) rather than qualitative measures.

Technology Enhanced Learning is implied in the measures related to teaching performance and student satisfaction indicators and reporting such as:

Unit Satisfaction Survey (USS): the unit satisfaction survey has been a proxy measure for teaching quality, but does not specifically refer to TEL or the use of technology in teaching. Most units offered by the university are reliant on the Learning Management System for the provision of basic information such as the unit outline, submission of assignments, text matching, grading and submission of grades, and thus forms an important component of the student experience, but the student experience of this aspect of their learning is not explicitly included.

The USS is to be replaced from Semester 2, 2016. The replacement will include questions and feedback provided through InterFace, a web-based digital dashboard providing real-time information about student engagement and attitudes, as well as other qualitative metrics currently being considered.

Course and Teaching Evaluation and Improvement (CATEI) reporting: each faculty provides a report to the University Education Committee (UEC) about the performance in the preceding year of their courses and units, and associated action plans for units which are outside what is considered an acceptable range, based on USS percentages. This does not necessarily involved a review of the quality of TEL. CATEI will be replaced by a new ACR and Course Quality Portfolio process (as described in the Course Quality Framework) in 2017 with a pilot being run in 2016.

DVCE Reports to Council

The DVCE reports to Council in relation to usage of various components of the virtual learning environments, however, this does not necessarily relate to quality or planning for quality improvement.

Annual Course Report (ACR)

The Annual Course Report process is currently under review and will include a range of quality measures including InterFace data, benchmarking outcomes, QiLT results and other SAP data.

Reporting occurs at a range of levels on a number of different indicators but UC does not have specific reporting against TEL. It does have the following that are available to all level of the institution:

QILT data

  • Student Experience Survey (Learning Resources): includes Online learning materials/Computing IT resources/Library resources and facilities
  • Course Experience Questionnaire (Overall satisfaction/Good teaching/Generic Skills): not TEL specific
  • Graduate Destination Survey (not relevant to TEL)
  • Employer Satisfaction Survey (pilot only)

 

Reporting against the Education Plan KPIs

Teaching and Learning provides usage data for reporting against aspects of the Education Plan KPIs.

Student Administration and Planning provides data on mode of offerings for reporting against aspects of the Education Plan.

InterFace

InterFace provides students with the opportunity to provide feedback about how they feel about their unit and provide reponses to some questions about their experience. However, this is not TEL-specfic.

There was a range of responses to this question, reflecting a variation in views depending on the business unit's context and relationship with student learning. Technical alignment and technical integration are sometimes confused in designing and meeting student support expectations. The level of shared and common knowledge is assumed but at critical points the 'unknown' gaps become apparent and can cause significant confusion or delays in response. Our systems make some untested assumptions.

As 'flexible' services are rolled-out, user needs are differentiated and general solutions lose personal relevance. Personalisation has escalated the complexity of knotty problems. The University espouses and aspires to a strong focus on student support at multiple points of need. When problems arise there's a willingness to learn from mistakes and improve future practices; across the system.

The University has recently established a cross-area team (CAT) to coordinate better, more streamlined, solutions to identified systems and data issues impacting on matters of University administration; including student learning. This team is convened by Student Administration and includes staff from Teaching and Learning, ITM, marketing, partnerships and international. The ADEs are also members of the CAT. All members of CAT are encouraged to make the work of the CAT a priority when required, take direction from the team convener, be co-located together where possible, and be available after hours.

The cross-area team is tasked with the responsibility of:

  • Identifying and documenting immediate and medium-term solutions to current problems;
  • Establishing a rapid-response team to deal with student-system issues 24/7;
  • Provide advice on current governance and corporate processes that adversely affect student experience at UC.
  • Propose methods, budgets and timelines to address more difficult problems.
  • Provide regular reports and actions for the DVCE to escalate as required.

Documenting student experience expectations: The Office of the DVC(E) will use comparisons with other universities and student feedback to identify how UC’s processes and systems meet student expectations. This information is used to set KPIs and for the CAT to document progress. The Office of the DVCE will provide this information in regular reports to VCG.

For example, the current architecture of our course and unit website information is less user friendly than other universities. Edith Cowan University, also a Callista university, is an exemplar of what is possible (see http://www.ecu.edu.au/degrees/overview).

Rapid response to problems: The CAT will also be responsible for providing rapid response and resolution of issues before they can impact negatively on the student experience.  Response times should form part of the KPIs.

Timeframes for publication of information: The University should investigate the early publication of course and unit information, and the early announcement of timetabling information. The CAT will establish timeframes beyond which changes to this information occur only in exceptional circumstances, and only where the overall student experience is enhanced by such changes.

Revised governance arrangements: To ensure the efficient notification of important student information, the Office of the DVC(E) will review the University’s governance arrangements, policy and timelines for the approval of course and unit information. A revised new course approval process has begun operation, and it is timely to review the processes around approval on other types of course and unit changes.
0.evidence:
1: Support services tend to work in isolation. As independent solutions they are not integrated into other work practices. Staff providing training do not always know where they can refer students on to for support.

Example response 2: training occurs on and for university supported systems.

1.rationale:
The university maintains a focus on ongoing budget and technical support for UC’s existing services, and puts in place processes that continually update, replace and/or add educational technology to enable and support learning and teaching innovation, good quality student learning experiences, and proper administrative management of the business of education. Educational technology infrastructure requires regular review and enhancement to respond to changing and emerging needs of UC and its students.

The University has a reporting process where the educational technology ‘owner’ provides the Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG) with information about the educational technology. This information includes, as appropriate and meaningful for each of the technology the following:

  • usage in terms of student numbers;
  • usage in terms of integration of that technology by academics into their teaching practice;
  • usage in terms of its use for provision of UC Open or other community-facing initiatives;
  • budget for licensing, upgrades, enhancements and support;
  • impact of discontinuing the provision of the technology/service;
  • rationale for ongoing funding and support of the technology/service.

LEAG acts as a mechanism to recommend the purchase of educational technologies and provides input into the design of physical learning spaces that will be needed soon, or now, or in the future to enable delivery to new and existing student cohorts. LEAG’s Terms of Reference include formal and informal learning environments, physical and virtual spaces. Purchasing and implementation of educational technology oversee:

  • purchase and implementation of enabling and educational technologies to support the expansion and delivery of flexible learning at UC including for example:
  • developing and implementing a customer relations management system to support a consolidated approach to managing student engagement and support. 
  • implementing an Identity Management System that provides access management, identity and access monitoring, auditing and reporting for accountability and directory services such as identity data centralisation, discovery and reuse.
  • acquiring mobile learning applications to develop a student-friendly mobile platform accessible to both students and staff and that covers mobile corporate services including:
  • enrolment and course progression;
  • PC room availability;
  • integration with LearnOnline;
  • mobile UC search functionality;
  • personalised information based on location.
  • creating a webinar/virtual classroom capability and virtual classrooms to provide:
  • tutorial-size virtual classroom teaching environment
  • softphone capability
  • ability to share screen, desktop and applications
  • lab-style teaching, including online interaction, whiteboard sharing and raising hands to ask questions for students logging in remotely.
  • enhanced lecture-streaming capability including live interaction;
  • persistence of sessions to be replayed afterwards.
  • upgrading Moodle capability including digital resource management and Mahara ePortfolio integration.
  • participation in the conceptualisation of, and decisions around, learning space design and furnishing.
1.evidence: Some responses stated that staff were being asked to provide support outside of their area of expertise, other responses stated that support services were well-resources.

2.rationale:
In the main, student pathways towards defined solutions are promoted but students can be overwhelmed. Promotion of the pathways are multi-modal and derived from either local or central initiatives (e.g. Interface dashboard, Study Help Moodle site accessible via all Moodle pages) and cross-promoted on some unit Moodle sites.

The common first year unit (Foundations of Professional Planning - FPP) aims to help students transition to university and plan for their career through a student centred approach.  The unit helps students connect with the university via common approaches and supportive activities, recognise the relevance of their study and non-curricular activities in professional planning (improves retention and engagement) and plan for their career via a five year plan (leads to better employment outcomes).  The FPP unit is intended to benefit all commencing undergraduate students across the university. During FPP studies, students are introduced to a variety of support services at the point of need, rather than simply at the start of the academic year during orientation. As students require help with certain technological tools for their assessment, they are also directed to appropriate support services.

3.rationale:
With regard to student access to timely and actionable information about their learning achievements and progress towards course completion the University of Canberra has made great strides over the past two years. Through the creation of three nested digital dashboards; students, staff (and soon the executive) have access to dynamic data intended to drive feedback loops, promote engagement and increase retention rates.

InterFace (the name of UC’s dashboard project) is an innovative product that does more than simply assemble centralised learning analytics. InterFace includes progressive achievement data and perception feedback to provide staff and students with an overview of course achievements (by semester) with daily updates on unit performance indicators. The InterFace web-page uses responsive design to deliver content according to four themes that inform learning and teaching partnerships:

  • Student Details: extracted from Systems of Record, includes: address, email contacts, HECS status, census dates, transcript requests, etc.
  • Course Achievements: extracted from the Student Management System; includes: course history, credit points, minors and majors.
  • Unit Performance: extracted from data warehouse and learning management datasets; includes: unit by unit learner analytics in graphic dashboard arrangements.
  • Perception Data: sourced from three forms of feedback, University Word Cloud, Unit Satisfaction Indicator and ISEQ, that reveal formative changes in mood and satisfaction.
  • The InterFace dashboard is our ‘big data’ portal. Still in development the figures are impressive:
  • 800,000 student sessions on interface
  • 200,000 staff sessions on interface (totalling 1 million sessions!)
  • 4,960 students have used interface to provide feedback (around 30%)
  • 49,877 individual pieces of feedback have been recorded
  • 1,000 additional students to have used it during this semester (probably closer to 1500 as you can see the spike just before the term starts).
  • Many students have provided feedback across multiple different ‘channels’, as well as providing repeat feedback.
  • Worldwide there's a growing interest in using learning analytics to personalise students' study experiences. In response to InterFace students have appreciated convenient access to information they can use to monitor and adjust their own engagement. As learning environments become more flexible and learning partnerships become more open the need for a digital dashboard becomes more obvious. Profiling student data with UC's InterFace dashboard is proving to be a simple, usable and accessible service solution.. We are responding to:
  • increased expectations – making better use of learner analytics to personalise students' study experiences;
  • stories of early adoption - providing insights from international (Horizon Report) and national (OLT) reviews and reports;
  • technological enhancements – improving the educational design of online teaching and learning partnerships.
  • It’s early days, but the development of a Learning Analytics mind-set is opening up opportunities to:
  • improve pedagogies – alongside new educational technologies
  • empower students – with digital solutions that encourage self-help study habits
  • promote active learning – on ever advancing Learning Management Systems (LMS)
  • support students - according to personalised profiles of learning characteristics and needs.

4.rationale:
As noted in BM1 & BM2, at the highest level of university management there is recognition that the current resourcing process is not adequate to ensure that resources are committed to enable longer term planning for TEL. At present ITAG is the body through which funds are allocated for strategic IT projects. However, this is done on a year by year basis and has largely excluded consideration of educational technologies. A Capital Investment Review is currently underway under the auspices of the Vice-President (Operations) and this will link consideration of the physical and virtual environments in the resource planning for the university. This change in approach is likely to support and enable a future focused planning process for TEL and better balance of resourcing between TEL systems and corporate systems.

The planning for quality improvement is a component of the position descriptions in different areas of the university, and in that sense it is resourced, though the PDs may not reference TEL directly:

  • Corporate Systems Administration Officer UC5: Contribute to the ongoing improvement of the Student Administration and Research Systems and other Corporate Systems as required.
  • Educational Designer/Technologist UC 6/7: Analyse the evaluation of courses and units delivered through blended delivery and online modes in order to develop and implement strategies to improve the quality of the student experience.

Given that most activities in the university are reliant on some technology or another, and rely on infrastructure such as the WiFi, the network, electricity for power etc, it is difficult to specify whether or not there is sufficient resourcing for the quality improvement of technology enhanced learning systems or not as a distinct and separate resourcing question.

As expenditure relates to the ‘student experience’ business units prioritise spending on Technologically Enhanced Learning against strategic and operational priorities. The overall coordination of resourcing is a managed process. Some components of the existing educational technology infrastructure were put in place as part of the SAFFIRE project.

The core of the existing educational technology infrastructure, the learning management system (LMS - currently under review) has been in place for many years with significant expansion as part of the SAFFIRE project. The university maintains a focus on ongoing budget and technical support for UC’s existing services, and  puts in place processes that continually update, replace and/or add educational technology to enable and support learning and teaching innovation, good quality student learning experiences, and proper administrative management of the business of education. 5.rationale:
As reported in BM2, the University of Canberra has a distributed model of quality assurance and this is not specific to the technology-enhanced aspects of student learning. It notes that many evaluation processes are silent on technology enhanced learning. The University is in a transition in relation to the approach it is taking to quality assurance and is moving away from its existing reliance on a Unit Satisfaction Survey to a range of engagement and satisfaction metrics that provide a more faceted and immediate indication of students’ experiences.

The UC Breakthrough Strategic Plan objectives specifically include ‘Expand and enhance flexible learning’ which implies an increased and better use of technologies to support teaching practices and student learning. UC’s focus on and commitment to technology enhanced learning is demonstrated through the Education Plan (with targets for flexible delivery) and the Flexible Learning Implementation Plan which included the establishment of the Learning Environments Advisory Group.

The University is currently procuring a virtual learning environment (May 2016) which has included and extensive consultation process across the university community and the identification of the functional requirements from this consultation. The evaluation plan for this procurement focuses on the student and staff experience of the technology tools and services: simplification, integration, automation and function.

UC has a strong focus on supporting and encouraging the use of technology for teaching purposes, but less explicit mechanisms for quality assuring its use. Student engagement metrics are largely focused on the levels of online engagement as demonstrated through levels of touch of the TEL environments. Other demonstrations of engagement are more difficult to capture.

At an institutional level UC has an overarching Quality and Standards Framework. This references the UC Course Experience Questionnaire (UCCEQ) and the Student Services Survey (2011, 2013 but not scheduled to run again). The UC Course Experience Survey does not mention the technology enhanced component specifically, but does reflect the responding students’ views about the quality of their learning experience. The Student Services Survey has only been conducted in 2011 and has not been repeated. The 2011 results suggested that key areas for improvement were access to computing equipment and IT Help and support, but does not relate these IT issues to their learning specifically.

Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG) was established to evaluate and advise the UEC and the DVCE on existing, new and emerging technologies that could be used in teaching and learning to demonstrate innovation and improve student experience and learning outcomes, as well as ongoing implications for learning space design. LEAG provides advice to the University Education Committee on the University’s virtual and physical learning environments. However, it is not clear that LEAG focuses on TEL at the course and program level. It is more at the broader tools and infrastructure level.

LEAG TOR

  1. Provide advice to University Education Committee on the nature, quality and fitness-for-purpose of UC’s virtual and physical learning environments.
  2. Provide advice to University Education Committee on on existing, new and emerging technologies that could be used in teaching and learning to demonstrate innovation and improve student experience and learning outcomes.
  3. Provide advice to University Education Committee on the types of learning spaces, learning space design and furnishings needed now, soon or in the future to enable delivery to new and existing student cohorts
  4. Lead and oversee the implementation of new or renewed learning environments.
  5. Determine if any issues relating to learning environments require discussion by the University Education Committee.
  6. Undertake any other activities referred to it by the University Education Committee.
  7. Report annually to the University Education Committee on its activities.

 

The CQF Statement of Principles includes: Units and courses provide a high quality learning experience for students that employ best-practice teaching and learning methods and relevant learning technologies; and Provide students with the opportunity for work integrated learning and international study experiences, and globally connected learning opportunities through technologies

The course development process explicitly targets learning technologies by requiring proponents to address the principles of innovation and engagement, identified in UC’s Strategic Plan. A capacity statement supports, that explicitly requires proponents to consider ‘educational technology tools, creating diverse and effective online learning environments and experiences, and employing flexible pedagogies’. The UC’s Course Development Process has been fully operational since March 2016.

The CQF also requires course monitoring and Annual Course Reporting. This will manifest as an adaptive quality enhancement model predicated largely on online experience through integration with the InterFace dashboard and associated data and analytics. Technology enhanced learning and appropriate use of technology for learning is an integral part of this model.

The ITM Strategy includes a goal of Transforming IT capability towards a borderless University taking a global position. The Strategy includes ‘Develop and promote ITM services to facilitate engagement and experience through technology’ and ‘Develop ITM consulting services to provide advice and leadership on technology for teaching, learning and research’.  The Strategy does not include a focus on quality assurance in relation to teaching and learning, or a focus on integrating technology specifically at a program or course level (see below). However, ITM supports a range of technology services that support the teaching enterprise such as the student management system (Callista), the timetabling system (Syllabus+), the tutorial management system (Allocate), Office265 and OneDrive, and these are integrated to greater and lesser degrees with the students’ learning experiences of their units and courses through either MyUC and/or the learning management system.

6.evidence: See above.

7.rationale:
At the beginning of most recent strategic cycle (2014 – 2017) the University of Canberra repositioned itself to focus on consolidating and embedding initiatives and projects that take advantage of opportunities emerging in a globally competitive tertiary environment. The DVCE’s portfolio identifies actions that will reposition the University’s teaching, learning and support efforts to provide students with more access, choice and flexibility in how, when and where they use our services. This repositioning established a new learning and teaching context designed to:

  • develop, implement and embed information and communication technologies that enable more online, distance and flexible learning opportunities that meet the strategic goals of the faculties and the needs of their student markets;
  • provide targeted student support services and academic services online through new initiatives and third party services, using educational analytics to assist in identifying where support is needed and directing students to that support;
  • provide technology infrastructure to better track student interactions through their university lifecycle and to facilitate better information about staff roles through identity management;
  • implement engagement strategies to assist students to engage broadly with the University, other students, and university staff and see themselves as a part of the UC community;
  • reviewing and streamlining policies and procedures to enable the University to become more adaptable and agile in a fast moving environment;
  • support staff as they develop and grow their capability and enthusiasm for innovation in teaching and learning; and
  • ensure quality of the University’s courses through multiple mechanisms including course reaccreditation, timely internal reporting, national benchmarking, and action plans for ongoing improvement.
  • To ensure students have equitable access to technological learning resources and services the University supports their needs through the Student Engagement Directorate. Study Skills is part of the Student Engagement directorate and provides a range of face-to-face and online study help programs for UC and UCC students. These programs include drop-in study help sessions, peer learning programs, interactive online study programs, and in-unit support.

The Study Skills & Study Help drop-in sessions invite students to bring assignments and other work where staff are available to help with:

  • professional and academic writing skills
  • understanding and structuring assessment tasks
  • finding journal articles and other information resources
  • referencing and avoiding plagiarism
  • time management and exam preparation

 

Through the University’s Digital Strategy we have constructed a map of our ICT ecosystem ‘driven by the convergence of four interdependent trends: social interaction, mobility, cloud, and information. Matched to the highest level outcomes there are four digital KPI’s; in particular KPI3 suggests we remove technology barriers and provide a seamless IT experience on and off campus for all members of the university.’ ITM’s Operational Plan includes five improvement themes: prioritise domestic and international students’ digital experience; enable easy and open access to measurement reporting and analytics; remove barriers to enable secure and easy of university systems when and where required; lead innovation through technology within the university; and create stronger engagement with core university stakeholders; including:

  • Establish a yearly ‘techfest’ to engage with students to help solve University problems in creative ways.
  • Trial the appointment of a service delivery liaison officer within ITM. Each liaison will focus on the three core stakeholders of students, faculties and business units.

While the university has in place some specific student training initiatives, it’s clear the future lies in the creation of an adaptive ecosystem; open and accessible to all. Such a learning environment promotes self-enabling agency built upon agreed themes and principles including cloud first; mobile friendly, proactive posturing, borderless and BYOD:

  • Pull back from detailed hand-holding; provide configuration settings and let users work it out for popular services. Supports flexibility of access, reduces cost and effort, empowers users.

8.rationale:
The University has a variety of evaluation processes in place to support decisions relating to the implementation of technology enhanced learning services. Different business units at UC implement software that supports technology enhanced learning.

    • This includes corporate systems such as: Allocate; Syllabus + and Office 365 with OneDrive
    • VLE tools and services such as: Moodle, Mahara, Blackboard Collaborate and Millennium
  • System Processes such as:

 

  • Learning Environments Advisory Group (see above)
  • Information Technologies Advisory Group (ITAG)
  • Change Advisory Board
  • Non-Standard Change Request process
  • Remedy Review
  • Drop in session review
  • Usage analysis
  • Requirements gathering/consultation for VLE procurement

 

The LearnOnline support team run drop-in sessions for staff Monday-Friday 1.30-3.30pm. The reason for the attendance is recorded to enable TL to identify trends in the use of the VLE tools and services and problems arising from that use for students and staff.

Weekly Remedy review: Remedy is the system by the University for management of tickets lodged with its ServiceDesk by staff and students. These tickets are generally IT-focused in nature. Those relating to VLE matters are referred to the LearnOnline team. Team leaders and the Deputy-Manager meet weekly to review Remedy tickets to assess a) number and type of tickets b) tickets that need escalation either from a business or a technical perspective c) review of trends and issues that need to be addressed through technical or user interface enhancements, renewal of online staff help or communications. This review process feeds into the evaluation of VLE tools and services.

Usage analysis: The University maintains and reviews statistical measures of VLE services usage to enable it to evaluate the cost and benefit of maintain that service and to evaluate its usefulness to the staff and students.

Requirements gathering/consultation for VLE procurement: The University is currently procuring tools and services that comprise its VLE. This include extensive consultation with stakeholder groups, detailed analysis of functional requirements, development of use cases, and an evaluation plan for the selection of the components. The evaluation panel for the VLE is comprised of stakeholders from across the university.

Under LEAG’s Terms of Reference the Committee meets a minimum of four times per year. Through LEAG’s auspices, a rolling three-year learning technology road-map for enterprise eLearning systems will respond to demands arising from more flexible delivery, open units and courses, and new technologies and applications coming onto the market.

Through LEAG, the renewal of policies and procedures are kept at pace with the changing technology environment. Implementation and dissemination processes are standardised to ensure that staff are aware of changes to policy and the implications for them. This is facilitated through:

  • development of standardised implementation processes for implementation of additional educational technologies infrastructure;
  • development of standard implementation processes/staff training/promotion for new educational technologies;
  • regular review of policies and procedures against reality, and against emerging needs.
8.evidence: Nil reported

9.rationale:
At all layers of the University’s strategic and operational activity there are reporting mechanisms in place designed to evaluate an initiative’s effectiveness, efficiency and equity. In the context of Technologically Enhanced Learning initiatives the driving strategies obligate some form of evaluation against key performance indicators.

The University’s Digital Strategy is explicit in its demands for high quality review of resource allocation and service delivery. To contribute to the University’s three principles (education, internationalisation and research) ITM’s operational objectives establish improvement measures under regular review:

  • Prioritise domestic and international student's digital experience through:

 

 

  • Improving self-help material available to students relating to IT issues.

 

 

  • Increased engagement with the student body through focus groups to better understand their needs and wants.

 

 

  • Ensure student facing applications and sites are optimised for mobile devices and slow internet speeds.

 

 

  • Enable easy and open access to measurement reporting and analytics through:

 

 

  • Successful delivery of the 2015 analytics and reporting projects.

 

 

  • Increased focus on internal and vendor relationships pertaining to reporting and analytics.

 

 

  • Remove technology barriers to enable secure and easy use of University systems when and where they are required through:

 

 

  • Increasing focus on the connections between UC and partner organisations such as Tafe Queensland.

 

 

  • Ensure new systems that are deployed provide secure and easy off site access wherever possible.

 

 

  • Continuous evolution of the UC Technology Road Map to ensure we are ahead of key technology changes in the industry.

 

 

  • Lead innovation through technology within the University through:

 

 

  • Remaining open to and seeking our strategic partnerships with industry leaders that may lead to innovative and exiting ways to work and study at UC.

 

 

  • Continue to develop and explore a more strategic partnership with our existing partners and suppliers such as Wipro, Microsoft and Intersect.

 

 

  • Establish a yearly 'techfest' to engage with students to help solve University problems in creative ways.

 

 

  • Stronger engagement with core university stakeholders:

 

 

  • Trial the appointment of a service delivery liaison officers within ITM. Each liaison will focus on the three core stakeholder groups, students, faculties and the business units.

 

 

Through the Learning Environment Advisory Group (LEAG) the University has a strategy for ongoing ‘over the horizon’ technology planning and implementation. LEAG’s focus on the future and educational technologies that may have, do have, or will have important uses in higher education, as well as a focus on the implications of the use of this technology for learning space design, and the impacts on broader technology-enabling infrastructure.

LEAG is positioned to evaluate and advise UEC and the DVCE on existing, new and emerging technology that could be used in teaching and learning to innovate and improve student experience and learning outcomes, as well as ongoing implications for learning space design. Further, LEAG takes the position that there should be no assumption made that existing educational technology will continue to be supported if it is superseded by better or more appropriate options. LEAG receives reports from the technology owners and makes recommendations to UEC and the DVCE about existing educational technology.

The aim of LEAG is to ensure that UC develops a ‘pilot and evaluate’ culture, where UC regularly interrogates its own assumptions about the educational technology provided for students’ use.

LEAG provides advice to UEC on the types of learning spaces, learning space design and furnishings required to enable and enhance flexible learning.

Requirements gathering/consultation for VLE procurement: The University is currently procuring tools and services that comprise its VLE. This include extensive consultation with stakeholder groups, detailed analysis of functional requirements, development of use cases, and an evaluation plan for the selection of the components. The evaluation panel for the VLE is comprised of stakeholders from across the university.

0.rationale:
Strategic goals to drive the University’s growth and rankings through technological advancements and innovative practices is implicitly stated in the University of Canberra’s (UC’s) Strategic Plan 2013-2017 (Breakthrough).  Technology enhanced learning (TEL) is a requirement in order for the University to achieve Objective 1 of the Strategic Plan, which is “To ensure UC is competitive within Australia through improved attractiveness to students nationally and strengthened course viability”. The expansion and improvement of flexible learning through TEL sits under this objective.

The UC 2016-2018 Operational Plan to Achieve Breakthrough Objectives serves as a link between the Strategic Plan, leadership and senior management.  It assembles each of the 13 UC Portfolio Operational Plan submissions into a single unifying document, which is designed to provide UC leadership, managers and staff with a clear and detailed list of priorities and intended key results that align with the Breakthrough goals.  A number of intended key results support the incorporation of TEL into teaching and learning.  Embedded within this Operational Plan is an enabling objective related to infrastructure with an intended result of planning and managing the University’s IT capability to realise operational efficiency and effectiveness on campus, nationally and internationally.

The primary theme that forms the basis of the Information Technology Management Operational Plan is leading innovation through technology, which explicitly supports the use of technology to achieve the strategic goals of the University.

The Education Plan 2013-2017 is more explicit in its promotion of TEL.  It was designed to support the various goals of the Strategic Plan, and includes in its guiding principles a statement referring to the implementation of a student-centred focus, choice, and flexibility across the University’s coursework offerings. These primary course design elements encompass the following dimensions:

location (in Canberra, regional study centres, interstate, internationally, online)
time (asynchronous, weekends, after hours, hour long classes through to full-day blocks)
pathways (credit packages, formal articulation, non-award, MOOCs, short courses)
intensity (winter term, block intensives, self-paced)
modes of delivery (face-to-face, blended, online only, online supported, intensive, work integrated learning)

These principles are embedded within course design, aligning with the teaching and learning aspects of the Strategic Plan.  Integral to the Education Plan is the implementation or renewed organisation of the University’s enterprise systems and teaching and learning technologies, to create integrated systems across the whole UC group.  The aim of this is to facilitate and support the new teaching and learning models detailed above.

Underpinning and supporting the goals of the Education Plan is the Teaching and Learning Operational Plan 2016-2017, which incorporates activities that are fundamental to the inclusion of TEL, such as working with faculties to identify new and existing courses for flexible, online, distance and/or partnership study and implement creative curriculum structures around these.

1.rationale:
The Flexible Learning and Implementation Plan (FLIP) is a sub-plan of the University’s Education Plan, which provides line-of sight leadership and management actions relevant to University operations, linking them with the strategic goals of the University.  FLIP was built on assumptions of flexibility, mobility and BYOD. It includes planning and implementation activities to support the design, implementation, management and reporting of processes to update, replace and/or add educational technologies to enable and support learning and teaching innovation thereby providing quality student learning experiences.

The Learning Environment Plan 2015-2016 provides an overview of the current situation at UC including a recent evaluation and a roadmap for 2015 to 2016, aligning with and aiming to support the achievement of the University’s strategic goals.  The Plan considers future developments in any decision that UC make with reference to learning management systems, noting the emerging trends in the sector, such as the increase in content curation, BYOD and mobility, assessment, social media, digital literacy and learner analytics. 

The University also has a number of approved strategies and frameworks in place that relate to the use of TEL.  This includes the Information and Technology Management Strategy (ITM Strategy), the Digital Strategy and the Course Quality Framework:

ITM Strategy - this includes provision for the provision of leadership on technology for teaching and learning, and research.  Key principles underlying the ITM Strategy include engagement/experience, relationships/partnerships, transformation and optimisation, agility and empowerment. 
Digital Strategy - this incorporates a number of digital principles that align with and support the achievement of the objectives of the University’s Strategic Plan, and its sub-plans.  These include principles that encourage flexibility and adoption of new technologies.  Recognition of mobile devices and the embracing of BYOD are key principles, aiming towards a ‘borderless campus’ that supports the flexibility to work anytime, anywhere and in a seamless way. 
Course Quality Framework - this focuses on aligning courses with the University’s overarching priorities through implementation of strategies and actions to ensure ongoing course quality enhancement. The framework includes principles related to flexible learning and provision of a high quality learning experience for students through employment of relevant learning technologies including providing them opportunity for globally connected learning opportunities through such technologies.
Disability Action Plan 2014-2017 – this plan supports the Strategic Plan’s goal of providing ‘transformative educational experiences accessible to everyone, whatever your stage of life or background.’  In terms of technology, this plan includes direct actions to ensure that the University ITM infrastructure reflects and meets accessibility standards and that ITM plans, (including plans for technology deployment in teaching spaces), consider the needs of people with a disability and/or health condition(s).

Capital expenditure (CAPEX) is the University’s spend on capital assets to create benefit, which includes information and technology systems.  The UC Financial Delegation Policy details the financial authority and delegations that may be exercised by staff of the University.  Recommendations for expenditure related to information and technology systems come through the Information and Technology Advisory Group (ITAG), which reports to the Vice-President (Operations).   

ITAG is an advisory group that advise on information and technology management matters. It is the primary ITM governance body of the University; the composition is designed to ensure University business areas are represented and direct ITM resources and investments which enhance core business, including teaching, research and the student experience. Business cases are submitted for consideration to ITAG.  The membership is as follows:

A new Capital Management Process for evaluating technology bids is currently under discussion, which includes the formation of a Capital Planning Expenditure Committee.  Membership would include the Vice-President (Operations) (VPO), Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Education) (DVCE), Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Research) (DVCR), Chief Information Officer (CIO), and the Chief Financial Officer (CFO).

3.rationale:
Current policy and procedures make reference to specific technologies however they do not provide a solid nor detailed framework for how technology enhanced learning should be used at the course or program level.  There are some examples scattered through policy that make reference to the use of technology, such as the Assessment Policy and Procedures, which states that ‘(Assessment) Feedback is provided in a variety of ways, including: …. via the University’s learning management system (Moodle)’.  The Assessment Policy and Procedures also reference the use of social media in teaching and assessment activities, which includes a more detailed account of how it should be used within delivery of courses and units.

The assessment and grading process has been increasingly supported by TEL. For example, a requirement to submit all assessment items electronically via the Learning Management System (LMS) gradebook for the recording of grades and marks, with a transfer system enabling the final marks and grades to be entered into the Student Management System (SMS), Callista.

The Attributes of UC Graduates (Coursework Students) Policy makes reference to outcomes that those graduating from UC can ‘make creative use of technology in their learning and professional lives’, and that they can ‘evaluate and adopt new technology’, inferring that TEL is a primary facilitator used in teaching and learning at the course and unit level.  Additionally the Generic Skills and Attributes of UC Graduates from Higher Degree by Research Courses also refers to graduating students that will be able to ‘select and apply appropriate digital tools to support the conduct and management of research’, which also implies the use of TEL in learning. Although these documents provide a framework that implies the use of TEL, it is an overarching framework rather than specifying how the technology should be used at a course or program level.

As detailed in PI 2, the ITM Strategy and the Digital Strategy provide principles and strategies that support incorporation of TEL.  These documents are related to high level infrastructure components, the elements of which cascade down to the course level.  The ITM Policy Manual also provides principles related to TEL in terms of overarching design principles, as well detail regarding security and staff obligations when using the University network.

The University is undergoing a process of policy renewal and has a developed a new Course Policy, which is currently being considered by central committees as per  the approval process.  The Policy has been drafted to specifically provide flexibility and opportunity to meet the University’s future needs and directions, affording a range of learning experiences and encouraging innovation in the delivery of courses.

One of its key principles relates to using innovative technologies for student engagement and assessment; using student centred learning and teaching approaches, including the offer of flexible modes of learning; to not only meet the learning expectations, but also to meet the needs of an increasingly diverse student body.

Additionally, a new policy is currently under development that will inform teaching and learning at the University.  It is envisioned that this, the Teaching and Learning Policy, will include references to TEL and will have a number of sub-procedures that support the implementation of the policy.

In lieu of guidelines per se, Teaching and Learning provides a range of sources and information on how to use various technologies, including self-help resources (e.g. tutorials), workshops and drop-in sessions.  Self-help resources include frequently asked questions about technology enhanced learning and a variety of resources related to understanding and how to use Moodle, Mahara, Urkund, Echo360, Blackboard Collaborate, Scenario Based Learning Interactive, learning spaces (support resources for the effective and technology enabled use of physical/on-campus) and Respondus (a tool for creating and managing exams).

In addition the University will commence offering the Graduate Certificate in Tertiary Education in 2016, a professional development course designed for new or experienced teachers and teaching and learning support professionals, which specifically addresses appropriate and effective use of flexible learning environments.

4.rationale:
The Portfolio of the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Education) (DVCE) has a communications strategy that relates to and reaches all academic staff and business unit directors. This includes:

The Learning at UC bulletin, a communication tool used by the DVCE to provide professional and academic staff with a range of information about teaching and learning. This includes innovations, technologies, policies, procedures, workshops and other related matters at the University.  Links to relevant resources and contacts for support/advice are included in the text.
Information sessions for academic staff and briefings of the Associate Deans of Education (ADE’s) by the DVCE, the Director of Teaching and Learning and/or other teaching and learning staff as necessary.
Briefings for new staff, as well as current UC staff who have been promoted to Professor.
Postings on Yammer, UC-Chat, UC-Teaching, Twitter, the DVCE Blog, Events Calendar, the Workshop registration system, the Library Facebook page, and various electronic screens located in public spaces.
The Policy database enables access to policy documents via text search or by browsing categories.  As noted above, new and revised policies are communicated to staff via Learning at UC, as well as email. 

The Staff Guide to Policies provides academic and professional staff with a quick reference resource document to help them find policy information.  It is updated annually and promulgated to staff via Learning at UC.

Minutes of Academic Board and its annual activity report to Council are available to all UC staff via the Academic Board web-site, and to members and relevant staff involved in governance processes via the Academic Board Moodle site.  The Academic Board Moodle site is a site designed to support staff involved with the approval processes for academic governance, including policies, curriculum documentation, resources for academics and communication associated with Academic Board.

Minutes of Academic Board standing committees, which include the University Education Committee (UEC) and its sub-committees (Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG) [refer to PI 6], and the Courses Sub-Committee), are available to all UC staff via the associated website. UEC monitors the quality of the University’s teaching and learning activities and academic program, and advises Academic Board and the Vice-Chancellor on polices related to education. As TEL is an inherent component of current teaching and learning activities any matters related to the procurement of the virtual learning environments are submitted to UEC by LEAG.

5.rationale:
A number of committees and groups have been established to provide oversight and responsibility in relation to the governance of TEL, these include:

Learning Environments Advisory Group
This group was established to evaluate and advise the University Education Committee (UEC) and the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Education) (DVCE) on existing, new and emerging technologies that could be used in teaching and learning to demonstrate innovation and improve student experience and learning outcomes, as well as ongoing implications for learning space design.  Its focus is at the infrastructure level.

The purpose and function of LEAG is to provide advice to UEC on the University’s virtual and physical learning environments, with its responsibilities set out as per below:  

Provide advice to University Education Committee on the nature, quality and fitness-for-purpose of UC’s virtual and physical learning environments.

Information Technologies Advisory Group (ITAG)

As detailed in PI 3, a new Capital Management Process is currently in discussion.

Given the multi-dimensional nature of TEL within the University, some of the authorities and responsibilities for operational management of technologies cross a number of boundaries and are not clearly defined in documentation.  Technologies include corporate systems such as Office 365 with OneDrive and VLE tools and services, such as Moodle, Blackboard Collaborate, and Millenium. Key business units that support the operation of technologies include ITM and Teaching and Learning (SIE).  The purpose of the SIE team is to manage, coordinate and provide advice on the use of the University’s scholarly information environments, which include:

teaching and learning tools and services

7.rationale:
The Procurement Policy sets out principles that govern how goods and services, which include procurement of technology, are purchased for the University.  Supporting this policy is the Procurement Procedures Manual, which provides principles relating to procurement and information on carrying out procurement activities.  According to the Manual, all intending purchasers are responsible for identifying and planning their procurement processes.  The Financial Delegations Policy establishes a framework for delegating financial authority and sets out the responsibilities and associated value assigned to staff to enable them to take financial action on its behalf.  In terms of the procurement process, all computers (desktop computers, mobile computers, laptops etc.) regardless of price, must be obtained through ITM procurement.  Procurements relating to other technology such as learning management systems are processed according to the dollar value, and may require open tender.

Regarding the governance structure, the University has a number of advisory groups and/or committees that oversee discussion endorsement of and/or decision making around the adoption of new technologies.  These include:
