The Change Advisory Board (CAB) is a cross-team group that reviews change requests to UC’s IT systems (refer PI 6).  As part of the review they consider and determine possible impacts on other systems, as well as coordinating testing requirements.  Changes to systems require a non-standard change request (NSCR) form.  With regard to the Virtual Learning Environments, NSCR’s are submitted by the SIE team management group, Teaching and Learning.

0.rationale:
The University’s strategic intent expresses strong support for establishing  robust and flexible learning and teaching platforms and environments. Providing student-centred access and choice across our coursework offerings; including flexibility in location of study, times of delivery, pathways to UC programs, study intensity and modes of delivery. To make the most of this diverse offering students require complimentary study skills. As identified in the ‘digital strategy’ the University is embedding into its programs self-help strategies that enable students to resolve issues using online resources with only light touch technical support.

 The seamless integration of technology into an expanding array of learning experiences requires a training mind-set that maintains a focus on the educational purpose of the support provided. Currently, the expanding diversity of teaching approaches is not always known to the groups providing the training and therefore the training is sometimes overly focused on the technologies used at the institution rather than on the teaching approaches underpinning them.
0.evidence: Embedded in Rationale

1.rationale:
As identified in the University’s ‘Digital Strategy’ UC ‘has realised a fundamental shift in the education ICT ecosystem, driven by the convergence of four interdependent trends: social interaction, mobility, cloud and information drivers: These forces are contributing to a flood of information as more of our lives are lived “online”. Both in structured forms from student and learning management systems, and unstructured forms such as social media. Resourcing this new learning landscape requires an extensive understanding of aligned purposes that bring together effective technological and educational collaborations.

Through organisational and structural adaptation UC has positioned itself to make better use of available funds to meet the changing needs of contemporary learners. There’s been a transformation in the provision of support to better meet students’ personalised learning needs. Through adaptive practices Business Units have made operational changes to ensure enough training and resources are available to meet demand. That being said, if strategic and operational purposes are to maintain a common purpose communication channels will need to engage with and act upon review and evaluation findings to ensure funds are directed at continuous improvement strategies… ensuring resources are always kept up-to-date and to proactively create new resources
1.evidence: Embedded in rationale

2.rationale:
At all layers of the University’s strategic and operational activity there are reporting mechanisms in place designed to evaluate an initiative’s effectiveness, efficiency and equity. In the context of Technologically Enhanced Learning initiatives, the driving strategies require some form of evaluation against key performance indicators.

The university maintains a focus on ongoing budget and technical support for UC’s existing services, and  puts in place processes that continually update, replace and/or add educational technology to enable and support learning and teaching innovation, good quality student learning experiences, and proper administrative management of the business of education. Educational technology infrastructure requires regular review and enhancement to respond to changing and emerging needs of UC and its students.

Through the Learning Environment Advisory Group (LEAG) the University has a strategy for ongoing ‘over the horizon’ technology planning and implementation. LEAG’s focus on the future and  educational technologies that may have, do have, or will have important uses in higher education, as well as a focus on the implications of the use of this technology for learning space design, and the impacts on broader technology-enabling infrastructure.

At the project level, general practice ensures resources and training are locally evaluated at the end of each semester – some formative evaluation with user testing of online resources is often implemented prior to issue.
2.evidence: Embedded in rationale

3.rationale:
The University has recently established a cross-area team to coordinate better, more streamlined, solutions to identified systems and data issues impacting on matters of University administration; including student learning. This team is convened by Student Administration and includes staff from Teaching and Learning, ITM, marketing, partnerships and international.  The ADEs are also members of the CAT. All members of CAT are encouraged to make the work of the CAT a priority when required, take direction from the team convener,  co-locate  where possible, and be available after hours.

 The cross-area team is tasked with the responsibility of: Identifying and documenting immediate and medium-term solutions to current problems; Establishing a rapid-response team to deal with student-system issues 24/7; Provide advice on current governance and corporate processes that adversely affect student experience at UC; propose methods, budgets and timelines to address more difficult problems; and provide regular reports and actions for the DVCE to escalate as required.

Documenting student experience expectations: The Office of the DVC(E) will use comparisons with other universities and student feedback to identify how UC’s processes and systems meet student expectations. This information is used to set KPIs and for the CAT to document progress. The Office of the DVCE will provide this information in regular reports to VCG.

As described, better higher-level communication regarding TEL  is in train. And so it can be said that coordination exists between and across some central services. However, at a critical point in the chain lack of coordination often occurs between training performed in-class by unit convenors and central training services.
3.evidence: Embedded in rationale

4.rationale:
The Study Help Moodle site allows students to access online training in a range of study skills including digital literacy skills . It contains a number of self-paced, interactive modules and informative resources to help students. Many of the interactive modules are at introductory level, however there are varying levels of difficulty for some of the technology platforms, such as EndNote and Mahara. The content for the Study Help Moodle site is developed by the Study Skills team who also run a face-to-face drop-in service on weekdays on the library where students can access study skills support tailored to their individual needs from introductory to advanced level. The Study Skills team can also create tailored interactive modules for unit convenors to add to their online unit materials to support the study skills needs of their student cohorts.

In addition to this the peer learning study skills program, the Study Skills Rovers, offer 20 minute one-on-one consultations in a face-to-face drop-in model daily in the library (including weekends and public holidays). The Study Skills Rovers are students trained to help their peers with general study and digital literacy skills required to succeed in their studies and can tailor the session to the need of the students from introductory to intermediate level. The Rovers assist with assignment writing, information searching, referencing, Moodle and are specifically trained to offer Mahara support from basic to advanced level.  They also offer this service online through phone and computer consultations on Mondays-Thursdays from 4.30-6.30pm.

5.rationale:
The common first year unit (Foundations of Professional Planning - FPP) aims to help students transition to university and plan for their career through a student centred approach.  The unit helps students connect with the university via common approaches and supportive activities, recognise the relevance of their study and non-curricular activities in professional planning (improves retention and engagement) and plan for their career via a five year plan (leads to better employment outcomes). 

The FPP unit is intended to benefit all commencing undergraduate students across the university. During FPP studies, students are introduced to and provided training with technological tools such as Moodle, Mahara, Twitter, etc. They examine the implications of the use of technologies such as social media not only in relation to their academic studies but also on into their professional careers. This ensures students understand the value of ethical use of such technologies, through understanding the long term implications of their digital footprint.

The Assessment Policy and Procedures gives advice to staff in the use of social media for learning purposes. This includes alerting students to the same and ethical use of social media. Unit outlines also give a standard warning text about the use of social media for units/assessment items that require their use. Students are reminded that use of social media is a public domain and that their online behaviour should mimic that of the ethics expected in their face-to-face behaviour. As such, online behaviours deemed to breach student conduct rules will be dealt with in the same manner.
5.evidence: Evidence embedded in rationale

6.rationale:
The University has high-level processes in place for procurement (LEAG) and the ongoing allocation of funds supporting TEL; furthermore, for determining value for money on the basis of Key Performance Indicators (Digital Strategy). Reporting channels are clearly described and as such maintain regular reporting routines; facilitating communication and review as part of the University’s continuous improvement of student development processes.

Where TEL related programs are under development (or redevelopment) and broadly engaging resources and/or stakeholders from across the University the motivation to review and evaluate is embedded in project management strategies, two examples include:

Through the Information Technology Advisory Group (ITAG) digital dashboards for students, staff and the executive are under development. This large and heavily resourced Learner Analytics project has been phased-in over two years and has included extensive forms of review and evaluation as the technology is brought online and socialised.


Through the DVCE’s portfolio, a Common First Year Unit (Foundations of professional Planning - FPP) has been developed and implemented over the last three years. FPP represents a very contemporary educational design and initiates first-year students in many of the University’s online learning strategies. To ensure its ongoing improvement this whole of University initiative is comprehensively reviewed through regular scrutiny of a representative steering group working to an explicit set of Terms of Reference.

Smaller sub-projects, operationally managed within Business Units, undergo less formal review and evaluation. In most cases these programs establish their own success criteria, keep their own forms of evidence and adjust as needs be to contextual circumstances. By nature, these small programs have ‘only limited or ad hoc integration’.

Some services collect ongoing evaluation data and use this to inform new resources, but not all services do this.
6.evidence: Embedded in rationale

7.rationale:
Pathways clear and accessible, but staff are not always knowledgeable of the training they can recommend to their students – central communication difficult.

Study Help site was designed as a one-stop-shop for online training resources to prevent students needing to access a number of different sites, however not all services that provide training use this site for delivery.

0.rationale:
The University of Canberra has a distributed model of quality assurance and this is not specific to the technology-enhanced aspects of student learning. The ranking provided here does not properly reflect the range of quality assurance processes that are in place, but does reflect that many of these are silent on technology enhanced learning, although it may be implied. The University is in a transition in relation to the approach it is taking to quality assurance and is moving away from its existing reliance on a Unit Satisfaction Survey to a range of engagement and satisfaction metrics that provide a more faceted and immediate indication of students’ experiences.

The UC Breakthrough Strategic Plan objectives specifically include ‘Expand and enhance flexible learning’ which implies an increased and better use of technologies to support teaching practices and student learning. UC’s focus on and commitment to technology enhanced learning is demonstrated through the Education Plan (with targets for flexible delivery) and the Flexible Learning Implementation Plan which included the establishment of the Learning Environments Advisory Group.

The University is currently procuring a virtual learning environment (May 2016) which has included and extensive consultation process across the university community and the identification of the functional requirements from this consultation. The evaluation plan for this procurement focuses on the student and staff experience of the technology tools and services: simplification, integration, automation and function.

UC has a strong focus on supporting and encouraging the use of technology for teaching purposes, but less explicit mechanisms for quality assuring its use. Student engagement metrics are largely focused on the levels of online engagement as demonstrated through levels of touch of the TEL environments. Other demonstrations of engagement are more difficult to capture.

Institution-wide processes for quality assurance are in place and in use

  • Quality and Standards Framework
    • Quality and Improvements Advisory Group (QIAG)
  • Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG)
  • Course Quality Framework (CQF)
  • Information and Technology Management Strategy
  • Flexible Learning Implementation Plan (FLIP)
  • InterFace
  • Recognition and Advancement Strategy
    • Graduate Certificate in Tertiary Education
  • UC Digital Strategy

Quality and Standards Framework: At an institutional level UC has an overarching Quality and Standards Framework. This references the UC Course Experience Questionnaire (UCCEQ) and the Student Services Survey (2011, 2013 but not scheduled to run again). The UC Course Experience Survey does not mention the technology enhanced component specifically, but does reflect the responding students’ views about the quality of their learning experience. The Student Services Survey has only been conducted in 2011 and has not been repeated. The 2011 results suggested that key areas for improvement were access to computing equipment and IT Help and support, but does not relate these IT issues to their learning specifically.

Quality and Improvements Advisory Group (QAIT) – high level advisory group which meets 6 times per year and provides advice to the Vice-President Operations on quality and improvement matters related to the scholarly and professional areas of the university.

Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG): LEAG was established to evaluate and advise the UEC and the DVCE on existing, new and emerging technologies that could be used in teaching and learning to demonstrate innovation and improve student experience and learning outcomes, as well as ongoing implications for learning space design.

LEAG provides advice to the University Education Committee on the University’s virtual and physical learning environments. Its TOR are below. However, it is not clear that LEAG focuses on TEL at the course and program level. It is more at the broader tools and infrastructure level.

LEAG TOR

  1. Provide advice to University Education Committee on the nature, quality and fitness-for-purpose of UC’s virtual and physical learning environments.
  2. Provide advice to University Education Committee on on existing, new and emerging technologies that could be used in teaching and learning to demonstrate innovation and improve student experience and learning outcomes.
  3. Provide advice to University Education Committee on the types of learning spaces, learning space design and furnishings needed now, soon or in the future to enable delivery to new and existing student cohorts
  4. Lead and oversee the implementation of new or renewed learning environments.
  5. Determine if any issues relating to learning environments require discussion by the University Education Committee.
  6. Undertake any other activities referred to it by the University Education Committee.
  7. Report annually to the University Education Committee on its activities.

 

Course Quality Framework (CQF)

The CQF Statement of Principles includes:

  • Units and courses provide a high quality learning experience for students that employ best-practice teaching and learning methods and relevant learning technologies; and
  • Provide students with the opportunity for work integrated learning and international study experiences, and globally connected learning opportunities through technologies

The Dean of a faculty is responsible for the delivery and content quality of the courses offered by that faculty.

2016 implementation of the CQF has focused to date on the course development process by facilitating ‘quality assurance of course creation by determining market need, latest technologies and teaching practices by discipline’ (p.6). The course development process explicitly targets learning technologies by requiring proponents to address the principles of innovation and engagement, identified in UC’s Strategic Plan. A capacity statement supports, that explicitly requires proponents to consider ‘educational technology tools, creat[ing] diverse and effective online learning environments and experiences, and employ[ing] flexible pedagogies’. The UC’s Course Development Process has been fully operational since March 2016.

The CQF also requires course monitoring and Annual Course Reporting. This will manifest as an adaptive quality enhancement model predicated largely on online experience through integration with the InterFace dashboard and associated data and analytics. Technology enhanced learning and appropriate use of technology for learning is an integral part of this model.

Information and Technology Management Strategy

The ITM Strategy includes a goal of Transforming IT capability towards a borderless University taking a global position.

The Strategy includes ‘Develop and promote ITM services to facilitate engagement and experience through technology’ and ‘Develop ITM consulting services to provide advice and leadership on technology for teaching, learning and research’.

The Strategy does not include a focus on quality assurance in relation to teaching and learning, or a focus on integrating technology specifically at a program or course level (see below). However, ITM supports a range of technology services that support the teaching enterprise such as the student management system (Callista), the timetabling system (Syllabus+), the tutorial management system (Allocate), Office265 and OneDrive, and these are integrated to greater and lesser degrees with the students’ learning experiences of their units and courses through either MyUC and/or the learning management system.

integrate technology enhanced learning at both a program and course level

Flexible Learning Implementation Plan (FLIP)

The FLIP is a sub-plan of the University’s Education Plan. It is built on assumptions of flexibility, mobility and BYOD. It includes a range of planning and implementation activities to support the design, implementation, management and reporting of processes to update, replace and/or add educational technologies to enable and support learning and teaching innovation, quality student learning experiences, and proper administrative management of the business of education.

InterFace

InterFace is a web-based dashboard available to UC students and to unit conveners and other designated staff. It uses analytics to present students with real-time information about their progress towards completing their course and their progress and engagement with each unit in which they are enrolled. For unit conveners it can help build their understanding of the profile, performance and perceptions of students in their units. InterFace captures student engagement as expressed through their use of TEL environments, however, it does not explicit canvas their satisfaction with the TEL they experience. The questions they are asked are related to their satisfaction with their happiness, how well they think they have done, and the alignment of their unit with their career destination.

Recognition and Advancement Strategy

Teaching and Learning activities in staff development are designed to support the achievement of the UC Strategic Plan 2013-2017 and the associated Education Plan which have ambitious targets of growth via strategic partnerships nationally and internationally, and additional provision of flexible and online study opportunities for students.

It provides staff with advice, support, information sessions, online learning, and innovation showcases as well as opportunities for accredited study and support for international certification in the areas of learning design, curriculum design, policy development and implementation, library resources and technical and other support in the effective pedagogical use of our learning technologies.

The staff recognition and advancement activities are university-wide approaches to supporting the integration of technology into teaching and learning practice, and highlights the pedagogical applications of technology.

Staff Development for Teaching and Learning Program (the Program) includes:

  • Online courses provided by third party providers that UC has purchased (For example, Epigeum’s University and College Teaching modules, Blended Learning modules, open courses provided in MOOCs and/or OERu, Lynda.com resources),
  • Activities scheduled by Teaching and Learning to provide staff with the opportunity to develop skills in UC learning technologies (see https://www.canberra.edu.au/myuc-s/business-units/dvce/tl/staff-development-and-support/workshop-registration), and/or to extend the tools, techniques, strategies and approaches to their own teaching practice and curriculum renewal.

Graduate Certificate in Tertiary Education (GCTE)

The GCTE has been redeveloped for delivery to UC (and some partner staff) from mid-2016. One of the focus areas of the new GCTE is flexible learning environments. The use of educational technologies is embedded into every aspect of the course.

UC Digital Strategy

UC’s ITM Architecture Framework is supported and guided by the following Digital Principles:

  • Cloud First: cloud services should always be adopted when appropriate.
  • Mobile Friendly: an increasing percentage of our digital interactions are via mobile devices – therefore our services need to be mobile friendly.
  • Proactive Posturing: positioning the University to rapidly embrace new technologies and trends.
  • Borderless: supporting a model of users being able to work anytime, anywhere.
  • Embrace BYOE: acknowledging that users have services and devices that they want to use before and after their engagement with UC.
  • Review Strategy Frequently: ensuring alignment with emerging or disruptive trends.

1.rationale:
The University has comprehensive evaluation processes in place to support decisions relating to the implementation of technology enhanced learning services.

Evaluation

Different business units at UC implement software that supports technology enhanced learning. This includes corporate systems such as:

  • Allocate
  • Syllabus +
  • Office 365 with OneDrive

VLE tools and services such as:

  • Moodle
  • Mahara
  • Blackboard Collaborate
  • Millennium

Processes

  • Learning Environments Advisory Group (see above)
  • Information Technologies Advisory Group (ITAG)
  • Change Advisory Board
  • Non-Standard Change Request process
  • Remedy Review
  • Drop in session review
  • Usage analysis
  • Requirements gathering/consultation for VLE procurement

 

Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG)

(see above)

Information Technologies Advisory Group (ITAG)

ITAG is an advisory group to the Vice President, Operations on Information and Technology Management matters. It is the primary ITM governance body of the University. Its composition is designed to ensure University business areas are represented and direct ITM resources and investments which enhance core business, including teaching, research and the student experience. ITAG prioritised IT projects against strategic criteria.

Membership:

Vice President, Operations (Chair)

Deputy Vice Chancellor, Education

Deputy Vice Chancellor, Research

Chair of Services Committee

Chair of Corporate Systems Working Group

Director, ITM

Secretary provided by the Office of the Vice President, Operations

Note that this process is being replaced by a new Capital Management Process.

Change Advisory Board (CAB)

CAB is a cross-team group that meets weekly to review intended changes to UC’s IT systems with a focus on possible downstream impacts and dependencies, and additional coordination or testing requirements.

Non-Standard Change Request Process

Changes to UC’s IT systems can be requested using the Non-Standard Change Request process.

 

For UC’s Virtual Learning Environment, NSCRs are reviewed weekly by the SIE team management group and prioritised against a set of criteria.

Drop-in session review

The LearnOnline support team run drop-in sessions for staff Monday-Friday 1.30-3.30pm. The reason for the attendance is recorded to enable TL to identify trends in the use of the VLE tools and services and problems arising from that use for students and staff.

Weekly Remedy review

Remedy is the system by the University for management of tickets lodged with its ServiceDesk by staff and students. These tickets are generally IT-focused in nature. Those relating to VLE matters are referred to the LearnOnline team. Team leaders and the Deputy-Manager meet weekly to review Remedy tickets to assess a) number and type of tickets b) tickets that need escalation either from a business or a technical perspective c) review of trends and issues that need to be addressed through technical or user interface enhancements, renewal of online staff help or communications. This review process feeds into the evaluation of VLE tools and services.

Usage analysis

The University maintains and reviews statistical measures of VLE services usage to enable it to evaluate the cost and benefit of maintain that service and to evaluate its usefulness to the staff and students.

Requirements gathering/consultation for VLE procurement

The University is currently procuring tools and services that comprise its VLE. This include extensive consultation with stakeholder groups, detailed analysis of functional requirements, development of use cases, and an evaluation plan for the selection of the components. The evaluation panel for the VLE is comprised of stakeholders from across the university.
1.evidence: Evidence throughout rationale

2.rationale:
This is a hot topic at the highest level of university management, and there is a recognition that the current resourcing process is not adequate to ensure that resources are committed to enable longer term planning for TEL. At present ITAG is the body through which funds are allocated for strategic IT projects. However, this is done on a year by year basis and has largely excluded consideration of educational technologies. A Capital Investment Review is currently underway under the auspices of the Vice-President (Operations) and this will link consideration of the physical and virtual environments in the resource planning for the university. This change in approach is likely to support and enable a future focused planning process for TEL and better balance of resourcing between TEL systems and corporate systems.

The planning for quality improvement is a component of the position descriptions in different areas of the university, and in that sense it is resourced, though the PDs may not reference TEL directly.

Examples

Corporate Systems Administration Officer UC5: Contribute to the ongoing improvement of the Student Administration and Research Systems and other Corporate Systems as required.

Educational Designer/Technologist UC 6/7: Analyse the evaluation of courses and units delivered through blended delivery and online modes in order to develop and implement strategies to improve the quality of the student experience.

Given that most activities in the university are reliant on some technology or another, and rely on infrastructure such as the WiFi, the network, electricity for power etc, it is difficult to specify whether or not there is sufficient resourcing for the quality improvement of technology enhanced learning systems or not as a distinct and separate resourcing question.
2.evidence: Evidence throughout text

3.rationale:
The Education Plan lists a number of key performance indicators linked to flexible learning provision for students, but not specifically related to quality or continuous improvement of the provision, nor the planning.

UC does not have a direct evaluation process for TEL components of student experience integrated into its planning for improvement, and the TEL evaluation tends to be focused around usage (quantitative statistics) rather than qualitative measures.

Technology Enhanced Learning is implied in the measures related to teaching performance and student satisfaction indicators and reporting such as:

Unit Satisfaction Survey (USS): the unit satisfaction survey has been a proxy measure for teaching quality, but does not specifically refer to TEL or the use of technology in teaching. Most units offered by the university are reliant on the Learning Management System for the provision of basic information such as the unit outline, submission of assignments, text matching, grading and submission of grades, and thus forms an important component of the student experience, but the student experience of this aspect of their learning is not explicitly included.

The USS is to be replaced from Semester 2, 2016. The replacement will include questions and feedback provided through InterFace, a web-based digital dashboard providing real-time information about student engagement and attitudes, as well as other qualitative metrics currently being considered.

Course and Teaching Evaluation and Improvement (CATEI) reporting: each faculty provides a report to the University Education Committee (UEC) about the performance in the preceding year of their courses and units, and associated action plans for units which are outside what is considered an acceptable range, based on USS percentages. This does not necessarily involved a review of the quality of TEL. CATEI will be replaced by a new ACR and Course Quality Portfolio process (as described in the Course Quality Framework) in 2017 with a pilot being run in 2016.

DVCE Reports to Council

The DVCE reports to Council in relation to usage of various components of the virtual learning environments, however, this does not necessarily relate to quality or planning for quality improvement.

Annual Course Report (ACR)

The Annual Course Report process is currently under review and will include a range of quality measures including InterFace data, benchmarking outcomes, QiLT results and other SAP data.
3.evidence: Evidence throughout rationale

4.rationale:
Reporting occurs at a range of levels on a number of different indicators but UC does not have specific reporting against TEL. It does have the following that are available to all level of the institution:

QILT data

  • Student Experience Survey (Learning Resources): includes Online learning materials/Computing IT resources/Library resources and facilities
  • Course Experience Questionnaire (Overall satisfaction/Good teaching/Generic Skills): not TEL specific
  • Graduate Destination Survey (not relevant to TEL)
  • Employer Satisfaction Survey (pilot only)

 

Reporting against the Education Plan KPIs

Teaching and Learning provides usage data for reporting against aspects of the Education Plan KPIs.

Student Administration and Planning provides data on mode of offerings for reporting against aspects of the Education Plan.

InterFace

InterFace provides students with the opportunity to provide feedback about how they feel about their unit and provide reponses to some questions about their experience. However, this is not TEL-specfic.
4.evidence: Evidence throughout rationale

56e23d002761400d3e2716bd: The main responsibility of the Learning Innovation Hub is to implement elements of the Learning and Teaching Strategic Framework at Macquarie University. This includes: building communities of practice across the university, developing professional development and quality standards frameworks in conjunction with faculty based learning and teaching teams, developing and implementing the learning technologies and spaces roadmap, and providing media and other educational technology resources and services to the university.
56e23d002761400d3e2716be: Macquarie University is currently in the process of developing a learning technology and spaces roadmap for the next 5 years. As a result, this is a time of transition and exploration to ascertain the appropriate and pedagogically driven technologies that will best serve the learning and teaching community.
56e23d002761400d3e2716bf: One challenge currently faced is an inconsistent wireless network. In order  to adequately support any changes or additional implementation of learning technologies, it if first important to address the infrastructure, building it sufficiently to support the needs of the 30,000+ students that will be using it.
56e23d002761400d3e2716c0: The Learning Innovation Hub is composed of a 28-member team in charge of the Learning Technology Services and a 7-person strategy team charged with the implementation and support of the Learning and Teaching Strategic Framework.
56e23d002761400d3e2716c1: Currently, LTS works with IT to ensure that the technical support is coordinated. The Stategy Team works collaboratively with the library on a number of projects, including the campus-wide implementation of Lynda.com and a project called Connected Literacies that looks at developing shared online resources across the university.

1.evidence:
The annual PDR process would appear to be the natural starting point. In my view, this process is only partly used to set specific development goals. Most importantly, I am not aware of resources that are dedicated to individual and tailored development programs, similar to targeted research training. I also believe that there are likely to be many programs and resources available that we are not aware of.

The PDR process provides an avenue for conversation. I'm not sure if these are collected at departmental, faculty, or institutional level to inform needs and programs. Training can occur at vendor/program levels as in "how to use". Programs like FiLT work at the individual level. FPP has previously provided skills and support for library staff in these areas.

2.rationale:
Again, there seem to have been quite a few cutbacks and there is not as much support as one would like in developing in this area, especially with the technical side. The educational side is good in terms of working out pedagogy, but in terms of finding and applying the technology, I have found that it is quite limited.

It is sometimes difficult to identify who has the experise, adn once you do they are normally overworked or overcommitted and only able to provide limited assistance (because everyone else is going to the same person. As a result, it is sometimes required to look externally for support, or develop a home grown approach.

1.rationale:
There are big variations in how apparent pedagogical intent and affordances of various technologies/tools is to teaching staff. Some convenors understand the pedagogical intent well, while others are not aware of (i) the existing services/tools or (ii) pedagogical principles behind good use of these tools. 

We do note that overall the use and understanding of technology has risen substantially across the University through a combination of universal adoption of aprticular technologies and projects and intitiatives to support their use in a meaningful way.
1.evidence:
Many convenors ovet look the pedagogical intent of tools, such as Turnitin and Unit Guides and view them as 'administrative'.

There are also big variations in how tools are used. Some convenors use a wide variety of tools and have a sound pedagogical intent using these tools, but many use iLearn spaces as 'adminstrative spaces' (repositories for content/assignment submission), and do not take advantage of the pedagogical portntial of many tools.

2.rationale: Most convenors seem to have a limited knowledge of research on techology-enhanced teaching and do not take the full advantage of the affordances ofthe learning technolgies. Support staff also needs further education/training on such aspects as legal compliance, accessibility, and recent research on education technologies.
2.evidence: Most convenors use technology for basic rather than enriching purposes (e.g. for distributing contrent rather than encouraging collaboration and reflection). There is a good number of technical guides on various tools; however, they tend not to include pedagogical recommendations/reserach findings/best pedagogical practices. This information is available elsewhere (teche, webpages), but there is not systematic approach and a lot of pedagogical informaiton is abstract rather than practical.

3.rationale: Communities of practice that consist of 'average practitioners' seem to be rare and/or irregular. There are some programs/courses that are more engaged and conneted, but it does appear that investing time in learning technologies is low on most convenors' priority list.
3.evidence:
There are some communites that share practice around learning technology tools (e.g. Matt Bower's technology in education group or former iLearn Exchange), but they consist of predominately L&T staff and very few convenors (who tended to have participated in Fculty Partnership Programs). 

The key reason why many convenors do nto tend to invest time/effort in such communities is the lack of motivation, as currently there sees to be no real benefit for academics to engage in learning technologies (unless it is directly related to their research area). The 'worth' of most academics tends to be measured by research outputs.

4.rationale:
Macquarie learning technologies are not allocated resources to develop the existing tools (only to maintain them).

Some resources (mostly Learning and Teaching grants) are allocated to the development of technology enhanced language pedagogies; however, these grants tend not to be scalable or sustainable, as the development tends to finish once the funds run out.
4.evidence:
There is limited uptake of the grants' findings among the wider community as there is limited incentive (recognition) for teaching staff to engage in the ongoing development of techology-enhanced learning pedagogies. It is not in convenors' workload models, and it takes away from research time - against which all academic careers are assessed. What is more, online teaching is allocated less workload than face-to-face for the same number os students.

Therefore, just increasing the funding (e.g. number of grants) or hiring more L&T staff many not have the desired effect. Potentially, the introduction of the new Promotion Policy might bring some changes to convenors' perceptions fo a relative worth of investing into pedagogies.

Another potential positive influence of ongoing devleopment is the burgeoning focus on program design and a more integrated approach to learning across courses.

5.rationale: There are issues with sustainability both on the institutional and individual unit level.
5.evidence:
On the institutional level, changes such as the move to Office365 from Google or the disestablishing of iLab impaces the sustainability of the pedagogical practices. On the individual level, the practices of different convenors vary greatly. Many busy convenors struggle with the administrative demands of running iLearn spaces, and do not feel that the recommended use of iLearn spaces is sustainable in the light of their workloads. Those convenors who do introduce innovations tend to do it individually and the sustainability of their practices is not considered.

Other examples include the FPP model and training workshops. With the FPP model (project work with individual convenors), pedagogical application was most sustainable, as the project team worked on embedding pedagogies/tools in individual units. Therefore, individual convenors were likely to continue using these pedagogies/innovations. One downside of that model, however, was a 'low coverage' as only a handful of academics took part.

Training workshops (eg Echo screen recording/Zoom, etc) reach more academics. However, empirically it appears taht only a few of those attending the workshops implement tools in their practice. It might be partically because workshops tend to be 'technical' and do not provide academics with pedagogical ideas/case studies or ask participants to plan how to apply the technologies to their practice.

6.rationale: There is very limited evaluation of technology enhanced learning services. Evaluation tends to be mostly on unit (not program) level with convenors on the effectiveness of their approach/tools. These reflections are not currently collected.
6.evidence:
There was an 'iLearn survey' last year, the results of which started being developed into actionable items, but this project stopped due to the loss of key staff.

Few aspects of learning technologies get evaluated by TEDS, but it's marginal and not sufficiently in-depth. The evaluation is ad hoc and not systematic, which makes it difficult to get an overview of all units in a semester.

Some convenors choose to add specific questions to their TEDS surveys or conduct their own surveys, but it tends to be a rare practice.

7.rationale: As there is limited evaluation of the pedagogical impact, there is limited 'hard evidence' that could be incorporated in planning/improvement. There is no systematic process for improvement. The HOD reports tends to be too high level.
7.evidence:
Invididual convenors may seek feedback from their students and incorporate this feedback in their units, but it is at the discretion of individual convenors. 

There are few anecdotal accounts that make great stories, and they do get incorporated in planning by some departments/faculties, but this process could be improved on to make it more objective and evidence-based.

8.rationale: Some (limited) sharing happens on a unit or deparment level, but varies widely and is not common/systematic.
8.evidence: Some good practice examples are showcased in the learning and teaching blog and in previous intitiatives, such as iLearn Exchange and Learning and Teaching Week, but a lot more work needs to be done to showcase good practice examples and reach more convenors.

0.rationale:
* L&T Strategic Framework has strong statements promoting the use of TEL and embedding TEL in program design

* Difficult to answer overall because operational plans are at best in development/ emergent rather than in place/ being implemented. However, these are being consciously aligned with the Strategic Framework and hence clearly recognise, promote and support TEL

* Faculty operational plans are in development, with some more advanced than others – e.g. FoA plan and “scorecard” completed, others under consultation.

* Even Faculty operational plans are still fairly high level, but are well aligned to the Strategic Framework (because that’s the basis of their design).

* Operational plans are needed at different levels and need to be expressed in the language of practice for the various groups and levels i.e. academics, tech support staff, systems, admin.

* Learning & Teaching Strategic Framework

* Faculty Learning & Teaching Plans (add links as completed)

1.rationale:
* As above, difficult to answer in current context because operational plans are in development at all levels of the institution; general consensus that although planning below institutional level is incomplete, as and where it’s being done, it’s well aligned with institutional strategy and any broader operational plans. Lack of operational plans in place lowers the overall score.

* Also general agreement that in areas where the institutional L&T Strategic Framework is vague or poorly defined, operational and other lower-level plans are similarly vague.

* Specific Learning Technologies Policy/Procedure due for review May 2016, will need re-alignment with the L&T Strategic Framework.

* Implementation is the real challenge – whether plans align “on paper” or not. What does the strategy mean at operational level where people actually do the work? e.g. flipped classroom is not scalable. Principles can be agreed but how do they work.

* L&T Strategic Framework aligns with broader University strategic directions (Framing of Futures).
1.evidence:
* Learning & Teaching Strategic Framework

* Faculty Learning & Teaching Plans (add links as completed)

* Review process for Learning Technologies Policy/Procedure

* University overall strategy (Framing of Futures)

2.rationale:
* Participants expressed a great deal of frustration and disappointment about the University’s performance on this indicator.

* Participants related a number of issues with budgets, from lack of transparency of allocations to lack of budget allocation to the real cost of Learning Technologies. For example:

o Many ongoing technology needs (e.g. development, support, training, maintenance and upgrade) are being met from grant funding, which is insecure and unpredictable.

o No relationship between introduction of new technologies and the funding for support for them (the iLearn transition was an exception - run as a funded project under the DVC-A).

o Budgets generally don’t include funding for support and management of cultural change around adoption of new learning technologies (iLearn transition an exception).

o No longer have access to CAPEX for upgrades/maintenance and this funding has not replaced with operational funding – so there is essentially no funding for upgrades.

* TEL support budget has been cut by approx. 50% with the carve-up of the LTC budget.

* Staff with responsibility for ensuring that TEL is supported and that teaching staff receive professional development for TEL are not privy to budgets and have no input into or influence over allocations to TEL or TEL support.

* Participants noted that foreshadowed changes to the budget process are expected to bring about improvements, but were not sure about the current status or details of this. It appears that under the new funding model, faculty budgets will be treated differently from central budgets, with the latter fixed and not taking technology costs into account. Faculties expect central units to supply technology and support but central units are not funded for this.

* The process of forming Faculty operational plans provides an opportunity to align budget allocations with L&T Strategy but the extent to which this is happening currently is not clear.
2.evidence:
* Little evidence available due to lack of transparency in budgeting processes and consequent lack of knowledge of alignment between TEL operations and budgets even at quite senior levels of L&T leadership and management.

* Anecdotal evidence of budget discussions but a lack of concrete evidence of commitment of funds.

* Faculty of Arts L&T plan includes commitment to investment in TEL.

* Specific (limited) funding for improvements/enhancements of MLTP (where is this documented?)

3.rationale:
* There are policies, procedures and guidelines that guide use of TEL at some levels of unit and program design, but these tend to be relatively high level, compliance focused and lacking in operational detail and guidance.

* More practical guidance is provided by learning & teaching and curriculum development & design resources devised by faculties and the former Learning and Teaching Centre. However, these don’t have formal status as institutional policies and are development focused; as such they don’t provide a formal framework for use of TEL at either program or unit level.

* There are minimum standards for use of learning technologies at unit level (unit guides, iLearn standards, deadlines etc) but these provide a “floor” for compliance purposes, not guidance for excellence. Similarly, there are minimum requirements for approval of both units and programs but these don’t provide much practical guidance for effective use of TEL; more a compliance tool.

* Program-level design and use of TEL strong elements of L&T Strategic Framework but not yet fully realised in either policy or operations. Program level design itself is in such an early stage that there is inconsistent engagement of program level drivers with TEL and so there is little use of technology enhanced learning integrated across programs. This is a work in progress with the implementation of the new L&T Strategy.

* The framework is there (in the combination of unit/program approval guides and developmental resources) but implementation/application is focused on minimum standards of compliance for

approvals and LMS use so doesn’t necessarily provide a good framework for excellence. We are good on compliance but not on excellence or quality; there is no clear link between them. The focus on compliance with minimum requirements means that in practice the majority of units (and programs, where applicable) only meet the minimum and go no further.

* On a more positive note, although there are few explicit statements in policies, the overall culture is stronger in support of implementing new technologies (workload permitting). Emerging Faculty L&T plans and Scorecards are expected to focus more explicitly on the practical application of TEL in units and programs (particularly the latter, in accordance with the L&T Strategic Framework).

* The Curriculum Standards Framework currently in development is aimed to set out a very high level statement of expected standards for curriculum design and organisation. It is focused more on compliance than development of curriculum, teaching or TEL. The Curriculum Standards Framework combined with a range of policies, procedures, guidelines and resources currently in development provide a potential pathway to a formal framework for TEL. These include: Program Review Policy and Procedure; Assessment Procedures (Faculty level); review of the Learning Technologies Policy and Procedure; Learning Technologies and Spaces Roadmap, and resources supporting implementation of the L&T Strategic Framework.
3.evidence:
* Faculty L&T Plans and Scorecards [need links to these]

* Learning Technologies Policy/Procedure (due for review May 2016)

* Unit level guidelines and policies (e.g. Unit Guide, use of LMS)

* Faculty Guideline (for unit and program approvals) – mainly compliance advice, little specific on TEL other than former LTC sign-off and specification of learning tech usage intended.

4.rationale:
* Communication involves both sending and receiving – while there is extensive messaging on policies, procedures and guidelines generally (including those relating to TEL, curriculum, L&T strategy and assessment) using a range of communication channels, it appears that many staff are not really receiving, interpreting and applying the information being disseminated. Policies, procedures and guidelines are all on policy central and resources are on the L&T website but it’s difficult to know whether, or the extent to which, these actually influence or direct staff behaviours.

* In relation to adoption of new technologies, communication in faculties tends to be limited and/or intermittent and while there is some constructive collaboration that integrates policies, procedures, guidelines and curriculum design & development, this not systemic but largely ad hoc and poorly disseminated. We’re not a very “connected learning community” in the TEL area.

* Apart from iLearn help and resources, there is little communication about use of TEL unless staff seek it out. The TEL enthusiasts know and learn a lot about it but it doesn’t tend to touch others, who tend to comply with the minimum iLearn standards but don’t seek to expand their TEL use. We still haven’t moved much beyond the compliance model.

* There is an opportunity to improve communication and integration of TEL p/p/g into processes and systems with the review of the Learning Technologies Policy, revival of the Learning Technologies and Spaces Committee (replacing the iLearn Steering Committee) and the implementation of the L&T Strategic Framework.

* Some areas work very consciously (and conscientiously) to communicate information on TEL to staff (e.g. Faculty of Arts) but there is still mixed response in terms of integration in practice.

* Participants returned to the problem of the compliance focus, with further discussion of their view that compliance burns out the most creative and innovative teachers – this is a casualty of standardisation. Standardisation treats the best teachers as poor performers subject to compliance. Branding is another factor in creating and maintaining a compliance and standardisation focus – why should all units, programs, iLearn sites, presentations look the same? How does this promote creativity and innovation?

* Clearly TEL p/p/g are not well integrated into processes and systems because people get away with a fair bit of non-compliance, even to minimum standards – this should not be possible. Participants saw integration in terms of alignment with values and ideals as being very poor. Again little attention is paid to the cultural change aspects of promoting the use of TEL.

* There is always a time lag between communication of strategy and the integration of strategic activities into practice at faculty and department level. It is particularly difficult to penetrate the unit level where practices are long-established. More resources and discipline-specific support are needed “on the ground”.
4.evidence:
* Faculty L&T plans and Scorecards [links needed]

* Learning Technologies Policy/Procedure (due for review May 2016)

* L&T Week Programs (previously); L&T Exchange/Colloquium Program (proposed)

* L&T communications strategy (in development)

* Communication of plans and information – websites, notices (This Week), Teche, Faculty comms – examples of communication channels being used;

* Use of iLearn resources and support, curriculum resources (ex LTC) [analytics?]

* Committee minutes? (FLTC, SLTC, iLearn Steering Committee)

5.rationale:
Key discussion points/rationale

* This was one of the more contentious and interesting discussions, as participants delved into the meaning of governance and the diverse levels of knowledge of current governance structures within the participant group. This is unsurprising, as they were selected precisely because of their diverse perspectives. See below under “Interpretation issues” for more detail on this discussion – it is important because it goes to the heart of the governance failures at Macquarie (not just in TEL).

* Taking the narrower, “values free” interpretation of governance, the responses to the component measures are a fairly straightforward matter of looking at our governance structures and governing body membership under University By-Laws and Rules. In terms of the latter, we have a comprehensive set of governance bodies, from the Council and Academic Senate and their subcommittees through to Faculty Boards and Committees, accompanied by a clear and accessible policy framework. Membership of the academic governance bodies is inclusive of academic staff at all levels as well as management and administration in relevant academic and service areas.

* There is an established institutional mechanism with stakeholder representation for the governance of TEL in particular, although this is spread over a number of bodies, from the former iLearn Steering Committee (replaced by the Learning Technologies and spaces committee) to the Senate Learning & Teaching Committee, Quality & Standards Committee and Senate itself, as well as the Finance & Facilities Committee of University Council (in relation to budgets). Faculty level governance for L&T is reasonably well established and this includes some aspects of local governance of TEL.

* However, there were very mixed views amongst participants as to the effectiveness or impact of these mechanisms and structures, ranging from lack of knowledge of their existence and/or role in relation to TEL, to neutral or negative views of their effectiveness in the governance of TEL.

* Governance was rated as “maturing” due to the current reshaping of TEL subcommittees, including the replacement of the iLearn Steering Committee by a revitalised Learning Technologies and Spaces Committee with updated terms of reference, connecting practice to development. Some participants stated that governance on the technical side is quite good (apart from budget issues), as there is now one committee on TEL that is a subcommittee of SLTC. Some participants pointed out that LT&SC is not really a governance committee but an advisory body (SLTC is the governance body). Faculty Boards and Committees are also relatively new structures and operate differently in different faculties.

* Some participants noted that although a range of stakeholders are “represented” on governance bodies and committees, staff as a stakeholder group tend to be fairly muted in discussion and in reality have little influence on decision-making, strategic directions and policy in relation to TEL.

* There was also some critical questioning of the meaning and scope of the term “governance” in relation to TEL. To some participants, the boundary between governance and management roles in relation to TEL is very blurred and somewhat contested between those responsible for central decision-making, service provision, strategic leadership, budgeting and implementation functions. Individuals using TEL find the structures confusing at best and lacking in transparency at worst.
5.evidence:
* Senate and Faculty Rules, Senate Subcommittee and other committee ToRs and membership.

* New L&T support structures – central and faculty levels.

* Learning and Teaching Strategic Framework

* iLearn Steering Committee now Learning Technologies and Spaces Committee – Membership and ToR.

6.rationale:
* Authority is clear for technology management for TEL but overall/general authority over and responsibility for technology outside iLearn (LMS), for the adoption of new technology, and for use of technology etc. at any level is not so clear. Learning technologies other than those included in the MLTP remain unsupported and essentially without operational management (or governance, for that matter).

* Some participants at faculty and office levels were unaware of the management structure for Learning Technologies and of the existence of the LTS group (formerly LTSS in LTC, now in LIH). This indicates insufficient articulation of the operational structure at some levels (although faculty staff with TEL support roles are generally likely to have good knowledge of LTS as many of them either previously worked in LTC or had regular working relationships with those who did.

* Where people are familiar with the work of the Learning Technologies unit (pre and post restructure) they generally see reporting lines and delegations as clear although not necessarily well could be better articulated.

* At Faculty level, operational management of technologies for TEL is collaborative in the sense that the authority and responsibility involves Associate Dean of Learning and Teaching, Arts IT and the centrally located Learning and Teaching Services.

* Some participants felt that policy and structures for operational management of TEL technologies (if supported) are clear; some agreed but stated that they appear to have little bearing on behaviours in relation to use of TEL; others felt that control, authority and responsibility are clear in practice but not articulated clearly in documentation.
6.evidence:
* Learning Technologies Policy and Procedures

* New L&T support structures, org charts, position descriptions – central and faculty levels.

* Executive, PVC, Executive Dean, Associate Dean and HoD portfolio summaries, org charts, position descriptions (+KPIs)?

* Delegations Policy, Procedures and associated formal delegations

* Committee/Subcommittee minutes

7.rationale:
* Our lowest rating item and a source of some frustration and dismay. There is essentially no policy framework or standard process (documented or practice-based) for the introduction of new technologies. Recent examples of large-scale introduction of new technology (e.g. the key elements of the MLTP and the adoption of student feedback software) were the subject of specific “one-off” projects with their own internal processes (needs analysis, consultation, showcases, pilots etc) rather than following a process governed by policy and procedures.

* The reason for the variation in initial data collection was largely due to varying perspectives and assumptions that when new technologies are adopted, this has been in accordance with a policy framework and standard process. In discussion, participants from the different areas of the University shared their knowledge about this (or, more specifically, the lack of it) and realised that much of what appears to be following a process is in fact ad hoc, although generally managed well by the Learning Technologies group and faculty teams. There is some good practice at faculty level but this is not set out formally in policy or procedures. On the other hand, there is a perception at faculty level that decisions on the adoption of new technologies is “top-down”, arbitrary and lacking in consultation. Following this exchange of views, the group collectively came to the conclusion that the lowest rating is appropriate for all PMs associated with this PI.

* Several participants expressed their frustration at the slow process of adopting technology – this was explained by others as reflecting the lack of clear framework and procedure coupled with the poor alignment to budgets (see PI3).

* An operational initiative to remedy this situation following the restructure of L&T support currently under way, with Learning Technologies Services establishing a process for requesting new technology that includes consultation between LIH, LTS and Faculty L&T teams. On the governance side, participants expected that development of a policy framework and associated procedures and guidelines for adoption of new technologies would be a priority for the Learning Technologies and Spaces Committee. Some participants felt that these processes would become clearer (and would need to do so) with the implementation of the L&T Strategic Framework.
7.evidence:
* This may be a case in which absence of evidence is indeed evidence of absence. The Learning Technologies Policy and Procedure are inadequate in this area and currently under review.

* Learning Technologies and Spaces Committee ToR.

56e23d002761400d3e2716bd:
Distance Learning, as a unit, is responsible for strategic leadership and high-level planning, facilitation and co-ordination of Distance Learning at the University of Otago.

Major objectives include:

 - To provide strategic leadership and high-level planning, enablement and co-ordination of the future development of the University of Otago’s Distance Learning Programme

 - To take a leadership role in the development and management of good practice systems for supporting Distance teachers, administrators and learners

 - To provide leadership in facilitating and expediting research into Distance Learning

 - To consolidate and co-ordinate the dissemination of expertise in Distance teaching and learning across the University

 - To provide direction in relevant market research and in identifying market and partnership opportunities, noting the significant changes that are occurring in the Distance Learning sector

- To develop, in collaboration with Marketing and Communications, promotional plans, and to co-ordinate an integrated approach to Distance Learning publications

comments from survey respondents:

  • On a programme level in both scenerios I would say the integration of TEL is low. 
  • A Learning and Teaching Technologies Review resulted in adoption of a new LMS. The implementation of CANVAS was managed as a central project and the new system was rolled out across the University. While there are minimum requirements to a course set up there are few processes in place to assure the quality of the student experience. Faculty have a large degree of autonomy and the student experience is highly dependent on how the staff member uses the tools. Initiatives are largely uncoordinated and there are no specific QA processes/guidelines. 
  • Platforms, software and capability is now emerging with canvas, and other related tools. The main issue is the need for the development of applications in specific contexts and how technology can be integrated more deeply into programmes in this way, and maintained. 
  • There are a number of examples of more advanced use of TEL within the Faculty of Law. But on the whole there is no widespread of sytematic use of TEL beyond CANVAS and other basic practices such as power point. This ussage is monitored in the usual way through the SET process. The Associate Dean (Academic) also ensures that collegues use and publish their CANVAS sites. As a result the Faculty of Law had one of the highest CANVAS usage figures within the university in the last semster. There are no procedures in place for more systematic or deep monitoring of TEL which is separate from the overall monitoring of teaching at faculty level. 
  • Mechanisms are in place, and education of staff to include technology-enhanced teaching is underway.

1.rationale:
Nothing explicitly identified in existing documentation (below). This does happen for large ticket items and packages with high strategic value. But after a project implementation go-live date there is normally poor followup and evaluation of the tool from the users.

*Provide positive message around how the trajectory and success of recent LMS evaluation project and process (specifically oriented to eval of project management team processes and outcomes) bodes well for the future approach to comprehensive evaluation but the success of the LMS evaluation project must be supported by user evaluations after the new LMS has been deployed and then again after it has been "bedded in."
1.evidence:
Programme review guidelines  (p11) - https://www.auckland.ac.nz/en/about/learning-and-teaching/strategies-goals-and-plans/learning-and-teaching-quality-assurance/programme-reviews.html

Information literacy guidelines and principles - https://www.auckland.ac.nz/en/about/the-university/how-university-works/policy-and-administration/teaching-and-learning/general/information-literacy-guidelines-and-principles.html

 

comments from survey respondents:

  • Evaluation processes are not generally implemented IF TEL is in evidence. The course builder formative evaluation tool is an example of poor evaluation from its use and more feedback needed to be given. I find this to be a general trend - if you try something, very often it is up to your own evaluation processes to implement change and improvement. 
  • Large university-wide projects such as the adoption of the new LMS are well managed and there are mechanisms for regular feedback and evaluation. The evaluation processes tend to be less systematic for any more local initiatives. 
  • Technology enhanced learning is occurring in the faculty at a nascent level. However, the evaluation of systems is not common practice at the moment. 
  • Beyond CANVAS and TALIS which is mandatory, the use of TEL is is left to discretion of individual academics. 
  • Evaluation teams and mechanisms do not always recognise input from teaching staff.

2.rationale: In addition to move to new Canvas LMS and Talis tools, how do we ensure this can also happen for smaller projects. There is a set financial point where the overall cost of a project will tip it over to a centrally managed project and where support from Uni project & change management office is automatic. There is good planning for systems and technology that are centrally adopted and supported via BAU processes.
2.evidence:
If a TEL system doesn’t meet the strategic threshold set by the university, how do we ensure that the context specific TEL needs of a faculty are supported and resourced at the same high level ?

 

comments from survey respondents:

  • One of the major factors that will stymy meaningful integration is the fact that many of the administrative processes tied to quality assurance and the basic runnings of the courses are themselves technologically backward. It is no use trying to instigate a culture of change around TEL if the administrative processes are still paper-based. An example of this is the trouble the EDSW had when scraping examination data from Canvas. We have been automating this system for two years and with the transition to Canvas, this data gathering had to be done manually. Comprehensive teaching pedagogical change can only happen when the structures with which that teaching occurs are themselves up to date and technologically advanced. 
  • At the University level adequate resources were made available to support the adoption and implementation of CANVAS. More resources are required to support faculty in developing the capabilities required to use the system more effectively. 
  • In my perception it is not yet resourced. There may be plans afoot, but these are not clearly visible or integrated into regular teaching practices. 
  • Beyond some support for the Law Library to create TALIS reading lists and for CANVAS training there are no additional resources directed towards quality improvements of TEL systems. 
  • Substantial resources but not always available at the coal face. time cost to teaching staff taken a little for granted.

3.rationale:
This is done well for IT and tech infrastructure but not for Teaching & Learning.

Internal Uni continual improvement processes (end of course surveys) are focused on overall quality of staff teaching, which is is currently seen to be individually-focused on staff (popularity contest? and skewed because of low participation rates by students). The questions in these summative surveys do not included questions explicitly linked to TEL issues.

External audits/reviews for professional organisations or AQA process does not drill down specifically to course level and is not routine enough to support effective continual improvement within the uni

Team consolidation comment: need to be careful in crafting the internal writeup for this item.
3.evidence:
AQA Cycle 4 audit (2014) identifies on p10-12 of the report is fairly concise in its identification of issues and quite pointed with its recommendations. The same issues regarding TEL were surfaced in the previous Cycle 3 audit for the Uni (2009).

AQA Recommendation: The Panel recommends that in order to provide a high-quality learning and teaching environment across the institution, the University gives urgent attention to implementing a coherent strategy to develop digital technologies and to promote and support staff use of these, including prioritising and developing timelines for the Actions outlined in Section 6 of the 2013-2016 Learning and Teaching Plan. 

 

2014 Learning and Technologies review by DVCA’s office - https://www.auckland.ac.nz/en/about/learning-and-teaching/community-news/2014-learning-and-teaching-projects.html

 

comments from survey respondents:

  • This has not been well thought out in terms of an elongated, sustainable approach. 
  • There is a wide range of levels of faculty engagement with technology. Clear KPIs need to be agreed as part of the next phase. 
  • There are key issues in NICAI faculty regarding some stakeholders not having a clear fit with new evaluation systems. This has been discussed at the faculty level and beyond. There is a need to have a more flexible evaluation system for creative and one to one teaching situations, which by their very nature require more tailored approaches. 
  • Beyond looking at SET evaluations there are no specific KPIs on integrated planning model in relation to TEL. There is however regular consultation with student stakeholders through the twice a semester meeting of the Staff Student Consultative Committee regular meetings between the Dean and the executive of AULSS. The Associate Dean regularly meets with student representatives who also sit on the Faculty Academic, Teaching and Learning Committee (*). There is an opportunity for TEL related issues are raised in all these forums. Academic stakeholders can raise TEL related issues through the Faculty Academic, Teaching and Learning Committee.

4.rationale: University and Faculty Teaching & Learning Quality Committees provide framework and opportunity for reporting outcomes, this is the ideal process. However, since there is no specific requirement for evaluation of the quality or value of TEL integration in courses/programmes these outcomes cannot be reported except possibly as ad-hoc exemplars (typically positive stories).

responses from survey respondents:

  • Outcomes are reported. It's the next step that is not well implemented. What we do with information should be integrated into a long term strategy of support and innovation.

  • Outcomes are reported at senior levels. The first iteration of online evaluation has just occurred, so a review of "reporting" is still something that will need to happen, to see what level of compliance is there at the classroom, and APR level. Course review compliance is something that is being looked at in the faculty, this will be integrated with online student evaluation reporting . 
  • Outcomes are reported through the Academic, Teaching and Learning Committee and where appropriate Department. Issues of this sort may where relevant be raised through the Annual Survey Round process.

responses by survey participants:

  • We try, but it is more about shifting a culture that is very paper based and cumbersome. 
  • The use of a 24/7 CSL system is well established. (*clarification needed here)
  • This is beginning to emerge. However, given that technological systems for pedagogy can be designed to be flexible and attend to specific needs and differences, there are problems still with the level of flexibility attained by TEL. A generic, rigid, systems type technological approach (one size fits all) has value only for higher level quality assurance needs, and does not always filter down to pedagogical action, and content differences. 
  • The use of TEL is grounded within the context of wider university strategy for example in the use of CANVAS. The use of TEL was one element of the Teaching and Learning component of the report produced to inform the recent Faculty Review process.

1.evidence:
comments from survey respondents:

  • This is a major pitfall in many cases. Pedagogical intent must always be first, and the fancy bells and whistles must only ever be in service of the learning intention. If sustainable change is the aim, then much more comprehensive staff training, support services and wider institutional support need to be implemented. CreATE is our learning support in this regard and they are a very skilled bunch of people who know about the complexities of blended learning and integrating technology into teaching. Each faculty should have this kind of support (and it needs to consist of people who are cognisant and active in this area of Higher Ed pedagogy).

Feedback suggests that some cases courses have not been designed and developed to take advantage of the use of technologies as staff are not familiar with how this might be used to increase levels of engagement in the learning process. 
  • more visibility of potential required. 
  • Because the use of TEL is left to the discretion of individual lecturers there is no overall pedagogical strategy at programme level. In individual cases the use of TEL by individual academics is built upon pedagogical literature and research.

56e23d002761400d3e2716bd:
IML is the academic development unit of the University. It is in the division of the DVC (Education and students and comprises three areas of support and development:

1. The Teaching and Learning Group

Consists of:

Six academic staff, each with a faculty liaison role and other roles including strategic project work and teaching in graduate certificate and foundations programs. In their faculty roles, they support the associate dean (teaching and learning or equivalent) in their respective faculties, including advising on and contributing to course review, renewal and reaccreditation and; 

Eight learning technologist staff who provide support for teaching staff in developing and integrating online learning strategies and resources into students’ learning experiences. Each learning technologist is assigned to a faculty and also has one or more specialist areas of expertise

2. The Academic and Professional Communications Group collaborates with Faculty academics to embed academic literacies across the UTS curriculum. We work with course and subject teams to develop discipline specific approaches to teaching academic language and literacies. These approaches can include curriculum development, co-design of subjects and tutorials that focus on language and literacy, guest lectures on academic language and literacy and some team teaching.

3. The Academic Programs Office is responsible for overall curriculum data management. This area supports the administrative side of course review, renewal and reaccreditation, including advising course leaders on the University's curriculum policies, curriculum management processes, maintaining curriculum systems and supporting central institutional approval committees.
