0.rationale:
T&L sessions and events aim to generate enthusiasm and confidence in innovative teaching approaches with an integrated use of technology. Events are clearly geared towards the institution’s t&l strategy, (learning.futures) and the UTS model of learning. As such it is part of an articulated framework.

A challenge is the decrease in staff ‘downtime’ from teaching to focus on educational development. This can tend to cause a reactive rather than planned approach to staff development around using educational technology based on pedagogical principles. As a development process, just-in-time approaches can be less considered and strategic. We are working now more towards a scaled and staged approach that staff can plug into to gain and build on skills, especially the underpinning skills around software and hardware integration in learning and teaching best practices.

There may be a risk that development resources are directed towards new initiatives and less towards maintenance of established good practices.

  • Learning Technologist do some on the ground identification of needs by responding to enquiries from staff and reviewing most common types of service requests
1.rationale: The UTS t&l strategy (learning.futures) incorporates team-based implementation strategies. Feedback data from these teams are used to identify staff development needs that may not have previously been apparent and to look at needs in terms of the overall strategy, rather than individual requirements. As these teams meet regularly, the cycles of feedback also occurs regularly, rather than relying on annual staff surveys alone.

2.rationale: IML runs a number of well-planned events aimed at exposing the University community to trends and pilots in educational approaches, including uses of educational technology. The design and facilitation of these events draws on the expertise from the t&l group, library, AVS, ITD and teachers from within faculties and schools.  However those attending can sometimes be the same interested group. Sharing of expertise also occurs at some events like the flipped learning action group is where teachers and technologists meet regularly. This group also puts forward proposals for the development of further educational technology resources, but funding is limited. While we have recently increased the number of people in the t&l group who are themselves a resource for staff development, we are beginning to increase the number of stand-alone resources for staff to access. There appears to be limited technical resources at an institutional level to implement wider and more targeted programs.

There are additional resources for students presented inside an LMS unit called "Getting Started with MyLO"
0.rationale:
The primary online services utilised by students are email, eStudent Cemtre, Library, and the learning management system; MyLO. All of these services are available on and off campus. They can be accessed remotely via internet services or mobile devices. Online access is available at the Library computer labs or within faculties and students can connect their own devices via the wireless network on all three campuses. A VPN service can be utilised to access files remotely.

The IT support provided aligns with these services. There is a main IT Service Desk that links to information about accessing MyLO, email, mobile devices, and connecting to VPN and mobile devices. As well as the external support for MyLO through the Service Desk, there are three Help sections embedded within the learning management system. There is Student Help, Library Help, and IT Help. These link to services external to MyLO as well as resources embedded within MyLO.  The eStudent Centre also has a Help section within that system that provides details about managing enrolments online. The IT Help services in the Library focuses on providing all support services in the online environment that are accessed traditionally face-to-face. The Library also links to a general Q&A service, Ask Us. All the services are made available to all students regardless of their mode of study. This aligns with the adoption of the Blended Learning model (TELT White Paper) and does not privilege students studying via any particular study mode. However, no direct action has been taken to implement the Blended Learning Model consistently across the University.

It has been a goal of the University to have an online presence in all units offered. This has been difficult to achieve from both educational and technological perspectives. In relation to the technology, when the LMS was first introduced in 2012/3 the implementation was successful due to strong project coordination between UTAS and the LMS developers, and adequate resourcing for infrastructure and staff training. Since then there has been staff losses, staff turnover, and a change in the administrative structures of the University that has impacted on the ability to maintain the connectedness among various University departments that is required to ensure the LMS platform is maintained, updated, and resourced. There have been inadequate change management strategies put in place to support the application and evolution of the LMS, which needs to occur for it to keep abreast with students’ use of new technologies and learning needs. The reduction in resources has had a negative impact on the alignment of the support services with the learning technologies over the past few years. That said, all of the essential services are covered but coordination and clear responsibility for some service provision are lacking.

We used to be better at this than we currently are.  When we first implemented the current LMS in 2102/3 there was strong project coordination and adequalte resource. Since then there has been staff loss, staff turnover and a change in the relationship between sections.

That said, we cover all of the necessary bases but coordination and clear responsibility for some service provision is lacking.

  • First Steps for New Students:  http://www.utas.edu.au/students/first-steps
1.rationale:
The technology enhanced learning support resources that students access online are numerous. This would suggest that there has been quite an investment made in setting up these services. Students’ main point of entry is via Current Students. As expected the portal links directly to academic services, such as the Library, eStudent, webmail, student administration, and course information as well as specific learning support services, such as Student Advisers and Online Computer Skills tutorials.

Another element of the Student Support services provided online are related to beginning students’ transition into university study, which are put in place to foster student resilience with the aim of enabling them to progress through an academic degree successfully. There are links to a Student Advisers, First Year Facebook page, Student Life, Starting at University, and First Steps for New Students.

Support for these students’ services are provided through the Ask Us portal. The support is offered as an email contact service as well as a personal phone contact service. Both offerings of the service are understaffed. Typically, contact by phone is greeted by a “all the operators are busy” message and the option to wait or provide contact details, be placed in a queue, and receive a call back is given. When the call back selection was chosen, the call was returned but it took two hours for the call to reach the top of the cue. An email sent at the same time as the phone call was made was not answered within one working day.

It should be acknowledged that academic staff are often a student’s first port of call for all manner of problems and support in relation to TELT. Occasionally this is useful such as where there is a problem with a LMS unit that can be passed on to the relevant lecturer. This is often unseen workload and not necessarily part of the contacted person’s roles and responsibilities. Some Faculties have dedicated Educational Developers responsible for supporting staff to deliver learning experiences online. For example, the Faculty of Education have a Senior Academic eLearning Pedagogue. In some faculties the Educational Developers support students directly (e.g., Faculty of Health, Understanding Dementia MOOC). They usually help a teaching staff member resolve issues but the teaching staff member communicates the possible solutions to the students (this is the case in Tasmanian School of Business and Economics).

The main source of support for students using the LMS is the Service Desk. Problems arise, however, when the Service Desk staff do not have knowledge of or experience with MyLO to provide sufficient support students. The Service Desk staff are not given access to units at Support/Lecturer level so are limited in their ability to address or resolve problems encountered by students in a timely manner. Embedded in the LMS are learning objects that link to advice about the LMS functions. Similarly, the eStudent Centre has embedded Help links but as is the case with the LMS, the links are external to service and do not always open up in a new browser tab. This can make trouble shooting issues faced within the service quite difficult.

2.evidence:
See 8.1 for detail of services.

Pathways to Service Desk are widely, clearly and consistently communicated.  This should provide triage to other tier 2 support as needed.

There are links to a range of coreresources and support services for LMS, ITS, Library and Learning Support designed into the LMS template - these have recently been reviewed and refined.

FAQs are delivered via AskUS - http://askus.utas.edu.au/ although this is a relatively new offshoot of the CRMS project and not yet fully integrated with other services

Access to other support can sometimes be a little more opaque, or there are apparently multiple pathways to the same or apparently the same services.
2.rationale:
The dominant way that the IT support services and learning support services are conveyed to students is via the internet. This is achieved implicitly. The Library, IT Service Desk, and the Student Support webpages have links to multiple services and in some cases, the same service can be accessed from multiple places. For example, Ask Us can be accessed from the Library page as well as the Student Support page. This has the advantage of students being able to access services without having to always work back to and from the one place but there is also the disadvantage that students do not always know from where they have accessed a service and find it difficult to return to that service in an efficient manner.   

Pathways to the IT Service Desk are widely, clearly and consistently communicated. Regular updates about IT Services are conveyed through email contact and advice about contacting IT Services is often attached to queries responded to by email. Requests for assistance can be made through the Log a Service Desk Job link on the IT Services homepage. The link takes students and staff alike, to a Service Portal that has four main options to choose from: Report an Issue; Request Something; Find Answers; and Other Services. Although useful, difficulties in navigating fluidly between the Service Portal and the Service Desk arise. For example, the Report an Issue link sends students to an external Service Portal via an email and password authentication process. Details about problems encountered can be added to a template and forwarded to the IT Services Support Team. The problem arises when the request is completed and the students try to return to the Service Desk. Instead, they are forwarded to an individualised Self Service Portal. It is then necessary to open a new browser tab to return to where they started. The Request Something option on the Service Portal is multi-layered. At first, a selection must be made from three options: Dell Services; Apple Devices; and Service Request. The problem arises when the options at the next level do not cover the problem sought to be answered. For example, a request to upload software is not one of the options under the Service Request option. Although not an issue as such, a request to upload software can only be requested via the Report an Issue option. The Service Request option would benefit from a contact template such as the one in the Report an Issue option. The Find Answers option leads to a FAQ list, which can be searched. Like all other FAQ services, it is only useful if the question pursued has been answered previously and there is the potential for the process to be time consuming and frustrating as users search for the relevant questions that provides the appropriate answers for their problems. Services like the FAQ list are usually provided to avoid answering the same question multiple times and their provision is used to justify reduced resourcing. However, decisions made for economic reasons do not always translate to positive experiences for students and staff.

3.evidence:
Core learning services such as LMS, media, web conferencing, etc are at least partly mobile friendly. Design practices of individual teachers can limit useful mobile access to learning resources and activities.

University WCMS is responsive but suitable templates are only applied 2-3 navigation layers deep in places.

Despite acknowledging its importance, there was relatively little awareness about any requirement for services to be mobile accessible among the benchamrking team.

The Service Desk keep service ticket stats, manily for the purpose of tracking their volume of work.  Stats are too broadly grouped to allow useful analytics, although improvements are currently planned. 

The AskUS team regularly review the rating of FAQ answers and modifies them as a result.

As far as the team were awere there are few stats collected on usage and none appear to be published
3.rationale:
Technology usage surveys are conducted regularly at the University and learning analytics are collected via the LMS. There is, however, no evidence of systematic analysis and reporting of technology support issues. Detailed learning analytics offer the potential to collect rich data on student use of technologies as a means of identifying potential issues. Using analytics in this manner would require collection of detailed information and specific reporting, which are not currently apparent. The University currently has no systematic monitoring or analysis of student technical skills and knowledge. The TELT Action Plan 2011-2013 included as one of its proposed actions the creation of a “diagnostic digital literacy skills audit for all incoming students,” which was intended to inform and support the provision of skills development and support activities. To date, this has not been funded.

Core learning services such as the LMS, MyMedia (Echo 360), and web conferencing are partly mobile friendly. Support to connect mobile devices is located on the IT Services web website, however, the usability of the devices is often limited by the learning design practices of individual lecturers. Often the assumption is made that successful presentation in the online medium will translate directly to mobile technologies. This is not always the case. Promotion of and advocacy for implementing learning strategies compatible with mobile technologies across the university is needed. Indeed, despite acknowledging its importance, the benchmarking team demonstrated relatively little awareness of any requirement for services to be mobile accessible.

The IT Service Desk keeps service ticket statistics, which are used mainly for the purpose of tracking their volume of work and allocating personnel to service “peak hour traffic.”  Although improvements are currently planned, the data collected are too broadly grouped to produce useful analytics that could inform the development of IT Services, from a strategic perspective, that is responsive to students’ particular needs.

The Ask Us support team regularly review the users’ perceptions of the FAQ answers. Individual questions and answers have a feedback tab - “Is this answer helpful? Yes or No.” The feedback is compiled monthly and reported at a Knowledge Based User Group meeting. Based on the feedback, modifications are made to the answers when information is reported as not useful and identification of popular searches are used to instigate communication campaigns. As far as the benchmarking team were aware there are few statistics collected on the usage of the FAQs and none appear to be published. It is also unclear what level or density of responses for particular FAQs stimulates modifications to be made.

4.evidence:
Responsibility for the maintenance of student support resources for TELT systems is less clearly defined than it used to be.

eValuate (unit and teacher evaluations) surveys do not directly measure issues around TELT

There is some feedback from online students contained in the SES, but this has only recently come to light and little use has been made of this data.

Teaching staff frequenlty get feedback from studets but there is on formal way to capture this. There are firm plans to establish a TELT user group and this should act as a forum fpr such information.
4.rationale:
Responsibility for the maintenance of student support resources for Technology Enhanced Learning and Teaching services is less clearly defined than it used to be.

Unit and teacher evaluations (eVALUate surveys) are used to gather data that can be used to review, improve and enhance the student learning experience in individual units. They do not, however, provide data about access to or use of technological resources and services that support student learning. The statements that students respond to on the eVALUate surveys are phrased generally. For example, “The learning resources in this unit help me to achieve the learning outcomes.” The answers to this question are likely to be influenced by students’ experiences with the technology and associated services but that assumption cannot be made when analysing the data. Considering eVALUate is administered to every unit in every semester, it provides a prime opportunity for gathering data about students’ experiences with the technology and the way in which it supported their learning. The addition of three questions to a relatively short survey, as it stands, would yield data that could inform the development and prioritisation of IT Services and resources. This would be a relatively inexpensive and cost effective way to collect data. Feedback from online students is gathered in the Student Experience Survey completed upon graduation but this has only recently come to light and little use has been made of the data. Although useful, data from the SES would be retrospective and likely to be related to “old technologies,” whereas, collection of data via eVALUate surveys would provide “just in time data” that are directly relevant to the current students’ learning experience and application of “current technologies.”

Teaching staff frequently get feedback from students but there is no formal way to capture that data. There are firm plans to establish a TELT user group and this should act as a forum for the collection and collation of such information.

5.evidence:
The benchmarking team were not aware of data regularly being used to inform decision-making or resource allocation.

In the past university-wide surveys on the use of technology were conducted and had significant impact ion decision-making but hese have not been done since 2013.  There was a past proposal to participate in the ECAR survey.

There is some feedback from online students contained in the SES, but this has only recently come to light and little use has been made of this data.

5.rationale:
The benchmarking team were not aware of data being used regularly to inform decision-making about the allocation of resources, provision of services, and development of student learning and support resources. There is some feedback from online students contained in the SES, but this has only recently come to light and little use has been made of this data.

In the past university-wide surveys on the use of technology were conducted and had significant impacts on decision-making but these have not been administered since 2013.  In the past, there was a proposal to participate in the Educause Centre for Analysis and Research survey about information technology in higher education, which is used to understand the role of IT in universities. Revisiting this idea may be useful.

IT Service Quality Benchmark via systemsthinking.com.au was conducted in 2015. The benchmarking is in relation to the evaluation of and cataloguing of Self-Service initiatives. The relatively poor ranking in comparison with other universities in 2015 fed into a range of strategies in 2016. The development of self-service activities, such as the Student Support Services Ask Us and the IT Services Find Answers FAQs, are examples of how UTAS are utilising the notion of self-service to free up technical staff for higher value work. This places an emphasis on IT service delivery that focus on the presentation of knowledge for student consumption and interpretation.

Available immediately, is research conducted at UTAS that is directly related to the use of learning technologies. Although it does not involve large scale survey data, the findings could inform areas of need and give direction to future research that could inform decision-making about the role of IT at UTAS, specifically.

Another source of data is the University of Tasmania Student Matters Forum hosted each year since its launch in 2013. At the 2014 Students Matter Forum a workshop focused on gathering students’ perceptions of their learning experiences.

The focus of this workshop is to gain insights into student expectations and perceptions about the nature and quality of student service delivery at the University of Tasmania. What examples of good service have students experienced, and what examples can they provide of where service delivery could be improved?

Many of the responses provided at the workshop were related to online learning and IT services. It is not evident how the results from the forum informed decision making about those services or how the findings from the forum were disseminated other than making them available on the Students Matters website. As yet, the 2015 report is not available.

The University also hosts a “We are Listening” web page where students can give feedback on their experiences. Feedback categories are linked to e-mails to the Head of the service responsible for that area and also centrally collated. Complementing this initiative is the “We’ve Listened” web page that lists the feedback provided and the action taken in response to the feedback. Of the three sets of feedback and actions listed, two are directly related to IT services. Although these initiatives appear to be positive ways of garnering feedback and communicating the responses to the feedback, no links to those web pages could be found on the Student Support Services web page.

6.evidence:
Some Coordination occurs - a specific function of Online Learninng Environment Advisory Group to coorcination between ITS, TILT and Student Services.

There is a Facebook group that supports coordniation between ITS and faculty-based educational developers and technologists. 

Most coordination, information sharing and problem-solving happens through personal connections

There are firm plans for a TELT User Group which will support coordination.
6.rationale:
Some Coordination occurs - a specific function of the Online Learning Environment Advisory Group is to coordinate activities among IT Services, Tasmanian Institute of Learning and Teaching, and Student Services.

There is a Facebook group that supports coordination between IT Services and faculty-based educational developers and technologists. The extent to which this resource captures the issues and experiences of learning online across the University is unknown. https://www.facebook.com/groups/Building.eLearning/ 

For the most part, coordination, information sharing and problem-solving occurs through personal connections and communications. One of the roles of the proposed TELT User Group will be to support coordination of services and activities as well as facilitate the dissemination of information.

7.rationale:
We found this one a little difficult to understand.

There is no mandatory training in usage of TELT for students and therefore no section of the university with this responsibility.

There are several foundation or entry pathway programs that introduce students generally to the TELT learning environment. Support for developing computer literacy skills are the focus of UniStart and the University Preparation Program units. These units provide specialised support for beginning and non-traditional students in their first year of study. Lacking is ongoing support that acknowledges the need to provide more than just advice on file management, say, as students become more exposed to learning environments that utilise IT as a delivery platform as well as a way of working and learning.

8.evidence:
A new TELT governance is being implemented and there will be student representation on the TELT Governance Group and the TELT User Group. Determining student support needs is in the TOR of each group.

There is student representation on all key committees; however, student support needs with regard to TELT are rarely on agendas.

To date, there is no evidence that teaching staff have been approached regarding their thoughts about support requirements of students. The assumption can be made that some teachers design the online delivery of units based on their knowledge of their students as well as their knowledge of their discipline, therefore, are a resource that could provide invaluable insights into the way in which students engage in the online learning space and with the educational technologies utilised in learning experiences.

9.evidence:
ITS have comprehensive procurement and change management procedures and a range of policies on risk, security, etc.

Large systems implementation projects have student representation on the project board and user group.

The new TELT Governance structure will establish clear responsibility for evaluation of new systems and services.
9.rationale: Implementation of new systems and services generally occurs through funded projects.  The bidding process, followed by project management methodology druing implementation demands that a Project Board and a User Group be established.  There ar some frameworks to guide the determination of user requirements, systems integration standards, etc, but none specifically adress student support requirements.

0.rationale:
The primary online services utilised by students are email, eStudent Cemtre, Library, and the learning management system; MyLO. All of these services are available on and off campus. They can be accessed remotely via internet services or mobile devices. Online access is available at the Library computer labs or within faculties and students can connect their own devices via the wireless network on all three campuses. A VPN service can be utilised to access files remotely.

The IT support provided aligns with these services. There is a main IT Service Desk that links to information about accessing MyLO, email, mobile devices, and connecting to VPN and mobile devices. As well as the external support for MyLO through the Service Desk, there are three Help sections embedded within the learning management system. There is Student Help, Library Help, and IT Help. These link to services external to MyLO as well as resources embedded within MyLO.  The eStudent Centre also has a Help section within that system that provides details about managing enrolments online. The IT Help services in the Library focuses on providing all support services in the online environment that are accessed traditionally face-to-face. The Library also links to a general Q&A service, Ask Us. All the services are made available to all students regardless of their mode of study. This aligns with the adoption of the Blended Learning model (TELT White Paper) and does not privilege students studying via any particular study mode. However, no direct action has been taken to implement the Blended Learning Model consistently across the University.

It has been a goal of the University to have an online presence in all units offered. This has been difficult to achieve from both educational and technological perspectives. In relation to the technology, when the LMS was first introduced in 2012/3 the implementation was successful due to strong project coordination between UTAS and the LMS developers, and adequate resourcing for infrastructure and staff training. Since then there has been staff losses, staff turnover, and a change in the administrative structures of the University that has impacted on the ability to maintain the connectedness among various University departments that is required to ensure the LMS platform is maintained, updated, and resourced. There have been inadequate change management strategies put in place to support the application and evolution of the LMS, which needs to occur for it to keep abreast with students’ use of new technologies and learning needs. The reduction in resources has had a negative impact on the alignment of the support services with the learning technologies over the past few years. That said, all of the essential services are covered but coordination and clear responsibility for some service provision are lacking.

We used to be better at this than we currently are.  When we first implemented the current LMS in 2102/3 there was strong project coordination and adequalte resource. Since then there has been staff loss, staff turnover and a change in the relationship between sections.

That said, we cover all of the necessary bases but coordination and clear responsibility for some service provision is lacking.

Often the assumption is made that successful presentation in the online medium will translate directly to mobile technologies. This is not always the case. Promotion of and advocacy for implementing learning strategies compatible with mobile technologies across the university is needed. Indeed, despite acknowledging its importance, the benchmarking team demonstrated relatively little awareness of any requirement for services to be mobile accessible.

The IT Service Desk keeps service ticket statistics, which are used mainly for the purpose of tracking their volume of work and allocating personnel to service “peak hour traffic.”  Although improvements are currently planned, the data collected are too broadly grouped to produce useful analytics that could inform the development of IT Services, from a strategic perspective, that is responsive to students’ particular needs.

The Ask Us support team regularly review the users’ perceptions of the FAQ answers. Individual questions and answers have a feedback tab - “Is this answer helpful? Yes or No.” The feedback is compiled monthly and reported at a Knowledge Based User Group meeting. Based on the feedback, modifications are made to the answers when information is reported as not useful and identification of popular searches are used to instigate communication campaigns. As far as the benchmarking team were aware there are few statistics collected on the usage of the FAQs and none appear to be published. It is also unclear what level or density of responses for particular FAQs stimulates modifications to be made.

4.rationale:
Responsibility for the maintenance of student support resources for Technology Enhanced Learning and Teaching services is less clearly defined than it used to be.

Unit and teacher evaluations (eVALUate surveys) are used to gather data that can be used to review, improve and enhance the student learning experience in individual units. They do not, however, provide data about access to or use of technological resources and services that support student learning. The statements that students respond to on the eVALUate surveys are phrased generally. For example, “The learning resources in this unit help me to achieve the learning outcomes.” The answers to this question are likely to be influenced by students’ experiences with the technology and associated services but that assumption cannot be made when analysing the data. Considering eVALUate is administered to every unit in every semester, it provides a prime opportunity for gathering data about students’ experiences with the technology and the way in which it supported their learning. The addition of three questions to a relatively short survey, as it stands, would yield data that could inform the development and prioritisation of IT Services and resources. This would be a relatively inexpensive and cost effective way to collect data. Feedback from online students is gathered in the Student Experience Survey completed upon graduation but this has only recently come to light and little use has been made of the data. Although useful, data from the SES would be retrospective and likely to be related to “old technologies,” whereas, collection of data via eVALUate surveys would provide “just in time data” that are directly relevant to the current students’ learning experience and application of “current technologies.”

Teaching staff frequently get feedback from students but there is no formal way to capture that data. There are firm plans to establish a TELT user group and this should act as a forum for the collection and collation of such information.

5.rationale:
The benchmarking team were not aware of data being used regularly to inform decision-making about the allocation of resources, provision of services, and development of student learning and support resources. There is some feedback from online students contained in the SES, but this has only recently come to light and little use has been made of this data.

In the past university-wide surveys on the use of technology were conducted and had significant impacts on decision-making but these have not been administered since 2013.  In the past, there was a proposal to participate in the Educause Centre for Analysis and Research survey about information technology in higher education, which is used to understand the role of IT in universities. Revisiting this idea may be useful.

IT Service Quality Benchmark via systemsthinking.com.au was conducted in 2015. The benchmarking is in relation to the evaluation of and cataloguing of Self-Service initiatives. The relatively poor ranking in comparison with other universities in 2015 fed into a range of strategies in 2016. The development of self-service activities, such as the Student Support Services Ask Us and the IT Services Find Answers FAQs, are examples of how UTAS are utilising the notion of self-service to free up technical staff for higher value work. This places an emphasis on IT service delivery that focus on the presentation of knowledge for student consumption and interpretation.

Available immediately, is research conducted at UTAS that is directly related to the use of learning technologies. Although it does not involve large scale survey data, the findings could inform areas of need and give direction to future research that could inform decision-making about the role of IT at UTAS, specifically.

Another source of data is the University of Tasmania Student Matters Forum hosted each year since its launch in 2013. At the 2014 Students Matter Forum a workshop focused on gathering students’ perceptions of their learning experiences.

The focus of this workshop is to gain insights into student expectations and perceptions about the nature and quality of student service delivery at the University of Tasmania. What examples of good service have students experienced, and what examples can they provide of where service delivery could be improved?

Many of the responses provided at the workshop were related to online learning and IT services. It is not evident how the results from the forum informed decision making about those services or how the findings from the forum were disseminated other than making them available on the Students Matters website. As yet, the 2015 report is not available.

The University also hosts a “We are Listening” web page where students can give feedback on their experiences. Feedback categories are linked to e-mails to the Head of the service responsible for that area and also centrally collated. Complementing this initiative is the “We’ve Listened” web page that lists the feedback provided and the action taken in response to the feedback. Of the three sets of feedback and actions listed, two are directly related to IT services. Although these initiatives appear to be positive ways of garnering feedback and communicating the responses to the feedback, no links to those web pages could be found on the Student Support Services web page.

0.rationale:
The University of Tasmania Open to Talent: Strategic Plan 2012–Onwards, emphasises the University’s aspirations as a leading research university. There is no explicit mention of technology enhanced learning and teaching, or blended learning in Open to Talent: Strategic Plan 2012–Onwards, although there is a recognition of the need for infrastructure such as broadband “Early rollout of the National Broadband Network in Tasmania positions us to embrace technology as a key component of the learning experience, and to deliver curriculum with the flexibility required by students who may be restricted by geography or the demands of work” and a general reference to technology as a whole “The implementation of innovative design and technology will complement an organisational culture which promotes sustainable practices through all of our endeavours”.

A clearer emphasis on technology enhanced (or blended) learning appeared in the Open to Talent strategies sub-document (University of Tasmania Open To Talent: Strategies 2012–Onwards) as one of eighteen student-related actions (S3.6): “[To develop a renewed curriculum which] Embraces technology as a key component of the learning experience and delivers curriculum with the flexibility required by students” …which was reflected in the Learning and Teaching Strategic Plan 2012-14 (2015 Extension) noted in the vision “Our approaches promote innovation and use technology that enhances learning and teaching”. Technology appears in objectives 1.3, 3.1 and (most strongly) 3.3 of the plan “Objective 3.3: Curricula support student learning across a diverse range of student and course profiles and use innovative applications of technology and blended learning approaches”. A clear emphasis is placed on the role that technology can play in supporting flexible learning for students with diverse needs and in a variety of locations, … but is otherwise a very high-level strategy dominated by actions that are common to all modern universities.

Online education is positioned as a means for increasing enrolments at the University by raising its profile and providing new pathways for students to transition to formal study. There is also a clear recognition of the need to provide a comprehensive set of online courses for formal study following on from the open initiatives and partnerships so that the students experience coherent study pathways.

All other strategic plans (post-dated 2014) refer to the central Technology Enhanced Learning and Teaching ‘TELT’ White Paper 2014-2018, an ambitious plan endorsed by the Academic Senate in November 2013, it provides a very strategic, comprehensive and ambitious vision, strategy and outline of operational priorities for blended and e-learning at the University via 12 principles and their 33 enablers, and 67 pages affecting virtually every aspect of the University's operations. It was complemented by the UTAS Blended Learning Model 1‐5 Framework (2015). A full list of principles, and a more detailed discussion of the paper, is given in Performance Measure 1.2 below. Of key relevance to benchmark 1.1 would be “Principle 9: UTAS Will Clearly Define Strategic Directions and Imperatives for Technology Enhanced Learning and Teaching, that are Informed by High Level Strategy Documents and Regular Environmental Scanning”. The University is currently going through a process of High Level Curriculum Renewal focussing on the needs of students in 2025.

All other strategic documents such as the Student Experience Strategy (2016-2020) refer to the TELT White Paper and TELT to a greater or lesser extent, such as “Increasingly, students expect access to comprehensive and quality support services and innovative and flexible learning spaces, irrespective of whether their mode of study includes campus, blended learning and/or fully online experiences; further, the extent to which their time at university leads to desirable graduate outcomes is becoming a strong measure of the performance of an institution” on page 4.

The Teaching Performance Expectations are mapped to the UK Professional Standards Framework and outline what staff need to achieve, at different grades, to meet their performance expectations.

1.1 Initial recommendations for improvement

  • There is a need for a ‘one stop shop’ list of clearly dated strategic documents (including those that are no longer current).
  • There is a wide range of language used in the different policies and increased consistency would be helpful.
  • High level plans could better reflect each other (cross referencing).
  • There is a need for greater reflection of the high level strategies, using the same language, in other Faculty/Institute strategic plans.
  • Anecdotal awareness of, for example, the TELT White Paper, indicates that many staff are unfamiliar with the detail. Where they have read it, many of the concepts are high level and difficult for individuals to undertake.

1.rationale:
The TELT White Paper 2014-2018 actions include a focus on establishing high impact student learning environments, infrastructure, flexibility and modern learning spaces, open practice, resourcing, surveying experience and a detailed analysis of the changes the University will need to enact if the White Paper's vision is to be realised over the next five years (see the 12 principles copied below).  It outlines an approach to blended learning framed by interactive and high quality learning experiences and identifies the need for consistent access to a range of administrative and support facilities integrated into the MyLO LMS system and easily accessible by students irrespective of the mode of study. The TELT White Paper specifically notes the need for the development of system roadmaps (enabler 11.1).

The TELT White Paper defines ‘high impact learning experiences’ in relation to Kuh’s (2008) ‘high impact educational practices’[1] as “a meta- analysis of these yields key characteristics that can be incorporated in all teaching.

·        Critical inquiry, questioning and systematic investigation  

·        Collaborative learning  

·        Development of student intellectual competencies in areas such as writing, information literacy, oral communication and quantitative reasoning  

·        Experiential learning  

·        Application of learning in real world settings  

·        Connecting learning beyond the classroom  

·        Exploring diverse perspectives.”  

It should be noted that these are based on good pedagogic practice (not good technology) and there is a need for disciplines to interpret these in the context of best practice in their own discipline (see below).

The TELT White Paper is based on a comprehensive review of the modern e-learning literature and a careful consideration of the University's context and broad strategic priorities, and it identifies a vision of leadership in blended learning and outlines a set of actions that are intended to realise that vision. The White Paper explicitly engages with the geographical isolation of the University and outlines how technology can promote research, teaching and service activities beyond the local context.

Online education is positioned as a means for increasing enrolments at the University by raising its profile and providing new pathways for students to transition to formal study. There is also a clear recognition of the need to provide a comprehensive set of online courses for formal study following on from the open initiatives and partnerships so that the students experience coherent study pathways.

The TELT White Paper states: “At UTAS we use technology in learning and teaching for eight key purposes. To:

  • Improve the quality of the learning environment and student learning outcomes;  
  • Access the best quality resources from around the world;  
  • Connect students to each other, their teachers and to the world;  
  • Prepare students to thrive in a technology rich environment;  
  • Improve access to, and flexibility of, university study for students;  
  • Build UTAS reputation and brand in a global education market;  
  • Increase student enrolments through targeting new groups of students; and  
  • Meet the service expectations of students, staff and stakeholders.”  

Support functions are provided by the University’s Information Technology Service (ITS) who have responsibility for all of the institutional technology services, and published the University of Tasmania Information Technology Strategy: Connecting people, information, content and knowledge (2014-2024) which listed five objectives:

1.   Quality information for strategic enhancement

2.    Supporting Quality Learning and Teaching

3.   Supporting Excellence in Research

4.   Governing Improved Value and Outcomes

5.   High standard infrastructure

The ITS together with the Tasmanian Institute of Learning and Teaching, Division of the Deputy Vice-chancellor (Students and Education) (TILT), have responsibility for the support functions and staff development for TELT. The ITS manages a ‘helpdesk’ and supports the day to day functions of the online learning environment. The ITS leads the implementation of new IT projects and the maintenance of existing ones.   

The Faculty of Health Strategic Plan (2015-19) references the TELT White Paper and TELT, especially 3.1 (3.1.5), 3.2, 3.3 (3.3.16 and 3.3.17); 4.1.1, 4.1.4, 4.1.5, 4.2.3, 4.2.15 and 5.1.1. It has also approved a Faculty Digital Education/TELT Strategic Plan (2016) which interprets the TELT White Paper into specific action lines for implementation. These include implementing the UTAS Blended Learning Model 1‐5 Framework (2015), and processes to support the vision, such as achieving access for staff to the learning environment (as many clinical teaching staff are employed by the health services) and staff development. This level of granularity is relatively uncommon, many of the Faculty documents mention the TELT White Paper by name but not the individual principles or recommendations. Other Faculty documents were requested but not available for this exercise.

A new TELT governance committee structure has been proposed specifically to better support integration of the TELT White Paper into practice.


[1]     Kuh, George D., 2008, High-impact educational practices: What they are, who has access to them, and why they matter.  

1.2 Initial recommendations for improvement

  • Faculty/Institute plans better reflect the detail of the high level strategy particularly discipline-based ‘high impact learning experiences’ in the TELT White Paper.
  • Influence HR and wider suite of plans (including the TPEs) to consolidate the language and core messages around online learning.
  • Strategies are broken down into achievable operational plans, resourced, and clearly communicated.

2.rationale:
The focus for the past 18 months is the roll out of new student management systems to support enrolment and finance which, while not technically ‘learning’ infrastructure, essential to the success of the organisation. The earlier investment in e-learning has been dominated by the establishment of the LMS facilities (2012) involving an online learning environment (MyLO) comprising Brightspace and a suite of linked tools such as MyMedia. Capital investment is managed through the Capital Investment Committee (CIC) who have supported projects such as video conferencing installed strategically to support inter-campus communication. Support functions provided by the University’s Information Technology Service (ITS) and TILT are budgeted centrally.

The Schools and Divisions within the Faculties and Institutes represent the spending units and are able to make contributions to the local implementation of TELT, such as supporting professional staff to assist academic staff, local projects and staff development activities. It is likely that all aspects of the University are expending resource on additional extras particular to the needs of their students, for example, the Faculties of Health and Education have recently invested $500K on a new student placement management system (with many learning support features).  

The endorsement of the TELT White Paper should have seen a substantial investment in online learning and resourcing criteria aligned to the principles, however funding support for teaching in the institution has been cut overall (for example in the area of student support advisors) and with it the commitment to further investment (other than via specific projects and the CIC). The TELT White Paper should have been translated into operational plans addressing the relative priorities of specific enablers, the resources needed to address them, and assigning responsibility to key groups.

Currently resources are allocated primarily in support of the central e-learning tools with additional support provided on request by TILT staff on an ad-hoc basis. The University does not, as yet, have a mechanism that is investing in a targeted manner in the improvement of unit e-learning design or delivery, beyond the imperative that MyLO will be used. The institution is Quality Matters accredited and this is reflected in the  Blended Learning Model 1-5 Framework where all provision (whether fully online or not) is expected to meet ‘level 3’.

The actions around development of open practice in the TELT White Paper has been picked up in the development of Breadth Units (since the runaway success of the MOOC in Dementia Care leading to the Bachelor in Dementia Care). The open platform is funded by the ITS however there are limits on the number of students that can be supported on non-units (such as CPD) on the open platform.

Technology use at the University of Tasmania is governed by a set of clear policies designed to ensure that the infrastructure can be integrated, managed and sustained by the IT Services group using the available resources. Investment to date has created a solid set of basic services, particularly the newly redeveloped MyLO LMS. The existing policies have a strongly infrastructural focus, seen in the assessment of capability in the Delivery dimension.

Technology use at the University of Tasmania is governed by a set of clear policies designed to ensure that the infrastructure can be integrated, managed and sustained by the (newly renamed) IT Services group using the available resources. Investment to date has created a solid set of basic services, particularly the newly redeveloped MyLO LMS. The existing policies have a strongly infrastructural focus, seen in the assessment of capability in the Delivery dimension.

1.3 Initial recommendations for improvement

  • The development of detailed operational plans with allocated resources, measures and specific outcomes.  
  • Allocate funding to support implementation of the TELT White Paper recommendations.
  • Development of the roadmaps outlined in the White Paper need be undertaken and used to both inform the engagement plan with the University and to provide a mechanism for soliciting feedback and ongoing maintenance of the roadmaps. A formal lifecycle for the roadmap should be developed in parallel that provides a mechanism for early involvement of a wide range of stakeholders in identifying future directions and setting priorities. This will greatly assist coordination across service, support and academic groups throughout the University.

3.evidence:
The following strategic documents were consulted as part of this exercise (some links may go to internal access only).

Evidence + Commentary on relevance to 1.4

  • The UTAS Blended Learning Model 1‐5 Framework (2015); High relevance. 
  • Graduate Certificate in University Learning and Teaching especially Unit ELT506.
  • Online tutorials and getting started guides, and staff training materials in the Learning Object Repository (https://mylo.utas.edu.au/d2l/lor/search/search_results.d2l?ou=6607&lrepos=1042) (internal access only) - 145 ‘how to’ and other resources available for staff in the LOR. 
  • Faculty of Health ‘Digital Education’ TELT Strategy (2016) - As an example of Faculty/Institute Plans
3.rationale:
The TELT White Paper 2014-2018 makes clear that open and online courses need to be developed in response to comprehensive business plans and in line with the overall strategic objectives of the University. This should see an improvement in capability, particularly if such an approach is influential on planning for technology use within all units. The ongoing focus on the requirements of the Higher Education Standards Panel’s (HESP) Learning Outcomes (Coursework) standard mandated by TEQSA is also likely to encourage coordinated planning in all aspects of unit and course design and implementation.

The Student Experience Strategy 2016-20 outlines five “Pillars” (copied below), none of which explicitly refers to online, blended or flexible learning, but which might be inferred through reference to “high quality environments” and “experiences” with much of the detail left to the TELT White Paper. The Blended Learning Model 1-5 Framework is much more explicit about use of specific tools in the learning environment, such as discussion, rubrics and gradebook, without being prescriptive. It also refers to “high impact learning experiences” without teasing out what this means . Possibly as this will vary, discipline by discipline. There is a predominantly ad-hoc approach to any course or unit developments.

Staff at the University of Tasmania are supported in the use of technology in a variety of ways. In addition to a network of faculty-based educational designers, staff have access to on-demand support provided by the staff of the TILT. Support from TILT is a combination of one-on-one assistance, workshops and online resources including the ELT506 unit and the “Planning Your Online Unit” document.

There are also online tutorials for “Getting Started in MyLO” and “Teaching Online in MyLO” available to all staff (https://mylo.utas.edu.au/), although these are in need of update as many links are broken and pages fail to load. The “Planning Your Online Unit” materials provide a useful framework but they are focused primarily on decisions within a single unit, rather than helping staff engage collectively in their use of technology within entire courses and qualifications. The Quality Matters framework also has the potential to raise awareness of how technology use can be planned for systematically in relation to online learning.

The TILT website provides a range of materials on technology use but these are currently dominated by the technical and administrative aspects, with some discussion of pedagogical implications and options. A particular strength is the alignment of the Quality Matters rubric items into the standard academic performance management systems through Teaching Performance Expectations exemplars, and the resulting systematic encouragement to use technology well within individual units. There is a clear sense that the support currently provided is in the process of being redesigned and redeveloped. The TELT White Paper 2014-2018 notes the importance of digital literacy for staff (enabler 1.4) and outlines a set of competencies expected of staff. The implementation of the Quality Matters framework is also stimulating awareness by teaching staff of the ways by which technology can support learning by providing examples of effective online units. Learning Technologists (professional staff) run ad-hoc sessions on technology (and some pedagogy) in schools. More often staff (particularly sessional staff) are helped by colleagues.

The White Paper also includes an action regarding recognition of staff engaging in digital scholarship (enabler 5.3) but it is unclear what this means in practice and when it might be enacted. As the various initiatives identified above mature and are integrated more extensively into the University’s management systems they will likely provide information on the capability of the staff to engage in e-learning, which can be used to further prioritise investment of support resources. Such systems are currently lacking and so many of the initiatives lack evidence of the current quality of staff engagement with e-learning and are informed primarily by anecdote.

Many of the initiatives lack evidence of the current quality of staff engagement with e-learning and are informed primarily by anecdote. There is a need for more systematic approach to staff support, both in terms of utilisation of technology and high quality pedagogy in order to maximise return on investment.

The Quality Matters framework currently being deployed at the University is an excellent ‘standards’ document that will provide the staff with a model and encourage a renormalisation of expectations around learning design and the use of technology to support learning. The “Planning Your Online Unit” materials provide a form of standards-like guidance as well. Both of these are relatively recent and so are yet to been fully engaged with across the University and integrated with other policies, systems and processes. Technical IT aspects are covered by the various IT policies and standards (processes D5 and D6) but these do not address pedagogical aspects of technology use. The only technical standard apparent is the expectation that the new MyLO LMS will be used.

 

1.4 Initial recommendations for improvement

  • More support is required for operationalizing the recommendations in the TELT White Paper. For example, it talks about delivering a ‘High Impact Learning Experience’ however what this would look like in the different disciplines is not described in detail.
  • Disciplines identify what constitutes ‘high impact learning experiences’ in their own context, using the international educational literature and other sources as a base for innovation.
  • Update all support materials (such as “Getting Started in MyLO”, “Teaching Online in MyLO” and possibly “Planning Your Online Unit”) as many links are broken and many pages fail to load rendering them unusable. Videos are also out of date.
  • Initiate comprehensive staff development and support in order to communicate best practice and achieve maximum return on investment.

Evidence + Commentary on relevance to 1.5

  • University Governance/Committee structure - High
4.rationale:
The University Governance/Committee structure is the primary method of communication of strategic advice. There is good representation of key stakeholders (Heads of Schools, Deans, representatives of staff and students) on key committees such as Academic Senate. Most minutes are papers are available to staff to review, following sign-off. Documentation is uploaded to the University website (usually publicly available) for wider information. News bulletins to staff, students and alumni may carry information about new strategic documents. The Vice Chancellor’s road shows share latest strategic developments. ITS has held road shows to communicate, for example, the ten-year strategic plan. Communication events are usually video conferenced to distant sites.

Staff are encouraged to review documentation and attend road shows but there is no active dissemination strategy.  

It is unclear at this stage what measures of success or feedback will be used to demonstrate the impact the various initiatives will have on staff and students.

TELT White Paper Principle 11: UTAS will position decision-making and funding for TELT at an appropriate level to ensure stability, support and innovation.

1.5 Initial recommendations for improvement

  • All strategic documentation is announced (on publication) via news and other feeds to all staff in the institution.
  • A ‘one stop shop’ site for links to all current (and expired) policies is established and maintained. This should include HR and finance policies as well as strategic policies. It should include Faculty/Institute strategic plans (and ideally operational plans).

  • Draft proposals for new TELT governance reporting to University Learning and Teaching Committee
  • Learning Technology_map_governance_May2015.docx in evidence folder - Was for created for communication and planning purposes only – never had formal status.
5.rationale:
The TELT White Paper enabler 1 states that the institution will form a high-level TELT group to discuss and review TELT strategy in university-level strategy and planning documents once a year to ensure that an annual process of environmental scanning informs the next cycle of documents.

Several committees such as the Strategic ICT Committee consisting of ITS, TILT, academic and educational developers  currently exist (such as the strategic ICT committee, academic reference group and the MyLO User Group) to generally support communication in relation to the implementation of the TELT White Paper and other eLearning initiatives (but are not necessarily governance committees per se). Faculties variously have similar committees with communication as a primary objective. For example, Faculty of Health has a TELT Group (reporting to Faculty Learning and Teaching Committee) [others?].

These are being replaced through proposals to establish a new TELT Governance Group (and two sub committees TELT Users Group and TELT Platforms Management Group), reporting to University Learning and Teaching Committee.

TELT is relatively fast moving and the need for governance may be overtaken by the establishment of new facilities. All new projects have a new committee feeding in as appropriate.

TELT White Paper Enabler 9.1 states that the University should “conduct a regular survey of staff and students about the state of TELT and the future of TELT at UTAS in order to evaluate progress and inform future directions.” A survey instrument has yet to be developed and the impact will hinge on the extent of participation and the ways in which the analysis drives outcomes valued by staff and students.

The current presumption appears to be that staff will raise TELT issues on an individual basis through existing management channels (Schools, Faculties, etc.). University policies on evaluation and review are silent on the benefits of staff perspectives on their experience of e-learning technologies and pedagogies. There is also the issue that, absent any encouragement to engage with specific pedagogical models for the use of technology, staff will be commenting on the basis of existing models and many will not be seeking tools that extend or transform their teaching.

1.6 Initial recommendations for improvement

  • Continue with plans for reform according to current draft proposals for a new Governance Committee and relevant sub-committees.

6.rationale:
The authority and responsibly of the operational management of the TELT White Paper are articulated through the ITS ten year plan. While the provision of a learning environment is clearly laid out the connection with online pedagogy is less clear.

The new governance committee needs to deal with privacy principles, legal framework, use of cloud, etc.

1.7 Initial recommendations for improvement

  • Articulation of the entire operational process for supporting online learning and teaching needs to be clearer including how Faculty/Institutional support relates to the central strategy.

ANU Online Governance

Terms of reference and membership for the following groups are listed below

  • ANU Online Steering Committee
  • Wattle Reference Group
  • Wattle User Group

ANU Online Steering Group

The ANU Online Steering Group will support the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Academic) in assessing and developing strategic directions and high-level resourcing recommendations regarding the provision of online education at ANU.

The Steering Committee will:

  1.  Identify ongoing market opportunities in online education for ANU, on the basis of national and international evidence;
  2. Ensure that business requirements and models for online education align with the strategic directions of ANU, as articulated in ANU by 2020;
  3. Make high-level resourcing recommendations regarding the provision of online education at ANU, including platforms;
  4. Maintain executive oversight of the significant risks and their mitigation strategies in relation to online education at ANU;
  5. Ensure sufficient and early engagement with proposed new business/enterprise solutions in other areas that may impact on ANU Online activities; and
  6. Advise on public communication concerning online education at ANU.

Members

  • The Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Academic) as chair
  • The Chief Information Officer
  • Two College Heads or Education Deans
  • ANU Online Lead

Wattle Reference Group

The Wattle Reference Group is a sub-committee of the ANU Online Steering Group which itself advises the delegate – the DVC(A). It does not, therefore, make decisions; rather it is authorised only to make recommendations to the Steering Group.

Wattle Reference Group will:

  1. Consider, seek feedback on and report back to ANU Online Steering Committee recommendations concerning opportunities to expand and improve online education at ANU;
  2. Propose, monitor and review University policies and procedures designed to enhance online education at ANU;
  3. Monitor issues affecting student and staff experiences of online education at ANU and make recommendations to address them;
  4. Advise the ANU Online Steering Group on national and international developments in the enhancement of online education that align with University strategy; and
  5. Liaise with Colleges to coordinate enhancements to staff and students experiences of online education at ANU

Members

  • Chair
  • One staff member and one alternate, with expertise in the area, from each ANU
  • College nominated by the ANU College Head (may be either academic or professional staff)
  • ANU Online Lead
  • BSG Manager or nominee
  • One staff member from CHELT with expertise in the area, nominated by the CHELT director
  • Registrar or nominee (invited as needed)
  • CIO or nominee
  • Two members appointed by the Chair, for their expertise and/or observers invited as needed
  • Two student members, nominated by the President of ANUSA and the President of PARSA
  • Secretariat support provided by BSG

Reports/Makes Recommendations to: ANU Online Steering Group

Wattle User Group

Terms of Reference

  • Provide a community of practice for senior educational technologists and eLearningpractitioners from all Colleges and from CHELT
    • Standing items for consideration:
    • Current issues and operations
  • Non-Moodle components of Wattle (DLD, Adobe Connect)
  • Provide support and training for people who are operating the system, for example:
    • Train-the-trainer
    • Problem solving
    • Workarounds
    • Sharing best practice
    • Applications
    • Testing
  • Report to the Wattle Reference Group on operation of Wattle, issues, risks

Reports/Makes Recommendations to: Wattle Reference Group

ANU Online provides a range of learning environment services.
Under the direction of the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Academic), and in partnership with the Information Technology Services Division, the ANU Online Program is responsible for the enterprise-wide implementation of a technology platform to enhance teaching and learning across the University. 

With Moodle as its platform, ANU Online will deliver the following Online Learning Environment elements:

Learning Management System
Ethical Treatment of Academic Materials
Lecture Capture
Content Repository for Education
Learning Analytics
Community Creation and Sustainability.

DIGITAL FUTURE: LA TROBE’S DIGITAL LEARNING STRATEGY (2015–2017) 

  • Digital Future describes the goals and strategies by which La Trobe University will use technology to provide transformative high quality degrees that will equip students to fulfill their full potential through the pursuit of interesting and rewarding lives and careers. The five overarching goals of Digital Future are: 
  • Goal 1: Create high quality contemporary online and blended learning experiences 
  • Goal 2: Improve student success, satisfaction and retention through the strategic use of intelligent technologies 
  • Goal 3: Enable effective and equitable teaching delivery to regional and isolated students 
  • Goal 4: Facilitate learning through the provision of integrated, flexible and intuitive online and physical environments 
  • Goal 5: Nurture productive relationships with internal and external partners and expert groups 

Innovation Grants are part of the Digital Learning Strategy (DLS) 2016. These grants are designed to encourage innovative, future-oriented teaching practices that will improve the learning experiences of our students in the digital age. In 2015 we awarded 26 Innovation Grants across four categories. This year, we will be awarding up to 4 Major Grants (ranging from $80,000 to $120,000) and up to 10 Minor Grants (up to $15,000), across four categories.

DIGITAL FUTURE: LA TROBE’S DIGITAL LEARNING STRATEGY (2015–2017) 

  • Digital Future describes the goals and strategies by which La Trobe University will use technology to provide transformative high quality degrees that will equip students to fulfill their full potential through the pursuit of interesting and rewarding lives and careers. The five overarching goals of Digital Future are: 
  • Goal 1: Create high quality contemporary online and blended learning experiences 
  • Goal 2: Improve student success, satisfaction and retention through the strategic use of intelligent technologies 
  • Goal 3: Enable effective and equitable teaching delivery to regional and isolated students 
  • Goal 4: Facilitate learning through the provision of integrated, flexible and intuitive online and physical environments 
  • Goal 5: Nurture productive relationships with internal and external partners and expert groups 
  • Innovation Grants are part of the Digital Learning Strategy (DLS) 2016. These grants are designed to encourage innovative, future-oriented teaching practices that will improve the learning experiences of our students in the digital age. In 2015 we awarded 26 Innovation Grants across four categories. This year, we will be awarding up to 4 Major Grants (ranging from $80,000 to $120,000) and up to 10 Minor Grants (up to $15,000), across four categories.

Swinburne positions itself strongly as a technology University and TEL is a key pillar of this positioning. Therefore there is considerable alignment.

There is a Technology Roadmap that provides a process for identification and adoption of emerging technologies.

There are constant learning opportunities provided for staff re using our LMS, Blackboard, including weekly drop in sessions, individualised technical support and a range of short ( 2 or 3 hour) training sessions offered at strategic points in the academic calendar, such as when Blackboard sites have to be set up or when results have to be entered in Gradebook.

As we move into implementing our new Blended Learning Standards Framework in the second half of 2016 we are designing a range of training sessions with online resources being created to support them.

1.rationale:
The Learning and Teaching Strategy (2014) articulated our 2020 Learning and Teaching Vision as 'quality, personalised, innovative and flexible education'. As Swinburne positions itself strongly as a 'technology university' these pillars are commonly interpreted as sitting within the TEL domain.

Procedures are in place and many such needs are identified.

However, it is of concern that the same people use multiple services and resources, rather than such use being spread in a more equitable way across a greater number of staff.

In particular, we need to get better at creating opportunities to include sessional and OUA staff and getting better at meeting their support needs.

Communities of Practice are currently being established to better identify staff needs and to offer the opportunity for staff to share practice, talk and get quick answers to their immediate needs. For instance, we have offered one day learning design  workshops for years to integrate blended learning into unit design and teaching practice but we have, up until now, not had any idea of what happens in these units once the teachers leave the workshops. The COP will allow staff to share what worked well and what didn't ,work so well with what they learnt.

COPs are also being  established for OUA teaching staff.

2.rationale: There are no coherent and wholistic evaluation frameworks in place. While individual support and professional development activities are briefly evaluated at the end of each session and attendance numbers are recorded, there is no systematic analysis of this data, nor rigorous inclusion of it in continuous quality improvement processes.

3.rationale:
Coordination happens between the Faculties and the central Learning Transformations Unit (LTU), and is fairly regular and robust. The Associate Deans Learning Innovation are the key points of communication. GIven that 2/3 of these roles have very new incumbents at the moment, we are currently in a process of re-establishing expectations and responsibilities across these relationships.

The LTU and Library and ITS work closely together and there are more projects underway with Student Advancement and Academic Services in 2016.

4.rationale:
There are good aspects to accessibility - staff make very good use of the technical support available through the Learning Transformations Unit (LTU) via drop in sessions and telephone support. The learning design workshops are also well known and attended. They are regularly publicised through a newsletter, which results in a spike of inquiries every time it is distributed.

There are particular issues for OUA teaching staff who work outside of, and in addition to, the two semester University academic calendar. The Learning Transformations Unit has an internal website that houses electronic resources Which is the portal for 24/7 resources but people would rather overall to call and speak to a person, who is only available 9.00-5.00.

5.rationale:
Swinburne positions itself as a technology Univeristy. As a dual sector institution with a strong focus on enhancing its digital capacity as one of the four pillars of its 2020 there is a recognition that resources are needed to support this. 

When putting a technology project forward we need to create a business case that includes not only the cost of the technology but the cost of supporting and embedding use of new technology adoption amongst the staff.

6.rationale:
We have an excellent suite of programs, training sessions and electronic support tools that are housed on The LTU internal site on the intranet. We have recently relocated where we house all these resources from a hard to find internal wiki to an internal webpage for our centre, that staff can more easily find.

There is a regular and well read newsletter that advertises what is offered to the university teaching community. Previously this only went to those people who had used our services or training sessions before, so wasn't reaching the staff (in particular OUA and sessional staff) who didn't know who we were or what we offered.

The core functions of the Centre for Learning and Teaching span the following broad areas:

Academic and Professional Development that promotes scholarship, adoption of innovative learning technologies and builds capacity.

Curriculum Support that promotes learning and teaching excellence and innovation, aligns with University strategies such as those in the Teaching and Learning Functional Plan, complies with requirements of TEQSA and AQF and is strongly informed by School based needs.

Learning Support for our students that provides academic skills support that is embedded in schools’ curricula, provides strong underpinnings in academic literacy and English language proficiency and provides academics with resources to promote student success.

University’s Teaching and Learning Functional Plan mentions TEL however:

  • It's scope in terms of the meaning of TEL is limited to online learning, flipped learning, flexibility, and communications technologies.
  • Despite the potential direct influence of TEL on all five goals expressed in the plan, there is no explicit reference within goal 3 (PD and SoLT) and goal 5 (assuring quality learning outcomes)
