University’s Teaching and Learning Functional Plan mentions TEL as follows:

Goal 1: To provide a relevant and engaged curriculum

  • ACTIONS
    • 1.2 Engagement and Employability
      • Embed e-portfolios within relevant undergraduate and postgraduate programs to enhance students' employability and to provide evidence of their achievement
    • PERFORMANCE MEASURES
      • 80% of u/g courses using e-portfolios

Goal 2: To provide quality learning experiences for all students

  • ACTIONS
    • 2.1 Increase student access to online courses
      • Develop a distinct online learning strategy to expand ECU provision of online courses
      • Improve staff capability for designing and delivering quality learning online
      • Online development of targetted courses for online delivery across all Schools
      • Review and update online courses to provide engaged learning for all students
      • Explore opportunities for MOOCs and other innovative online approaches to support learning
    • PERFORMANCE MEASURES
      • All online courses meeting ECU minimum standards
      • 10% increase in students enrolled in online units/courses
      • All staff teaching online having completed PDC114 (Online Teaching and Learning)
      • Online students' UTEI overall satisfaction equivalent to on-campus students

2.3 Broadened technology support for student learning

  • ACTIONS
    • Enhance students' learning experiences through increased applications of flipped learning approaches
    • Provide increased levels of flexible learning opportunities across all courses through technology and course design
    • Develop infrastructure and resources to support increased use of communications technologies for specialist learning and teaching i.e. video and synchronous communications
    • PERFORMANCE MEASURES
      • All Schools demonstrating instances of flipped learning as an alternative learning design
      • 90% u/g courses providing flexible learning opportunities through Blackboard sites
      • Video-conferencing and asynchronous communication being used in targeted u/g course offerings

Goal 4: To enhance student support services

  • ACTIONS
    • 4.1 Implement strong firtst year support activities across all courses
      • Use of analytics data to target support services to students in need with transition to university
    • PERFORMANCE MEASURES
      • Blackboard Analytics provided to all Schools to support student learning and transition
    • 4.3 Learning Spaces
      • Technology infrastructure supporting ubiquitous student learning on campus with portable devices
    • PERFORMANCE MEASURES
      • Wireless connectivity available to all students across all campuses

1.rationale:
Many activities are ad-hoc and opportunistic, often in response to either rumoured or confirmed TEQSA priorities at any given time.

Where specific plans are put in place  they are, however, almost always directly aligned with strategic and operational plans.

3.rationale:
• ECU’s policies relating to TEL are quite generic and inherently soft.
  • Don’t really provide a strong framework for the way forward, e.g. will use Blackboard but no real indication of quality of use.
  • At both the strategic and operational level the requirement to use such technologies is not worded strongly enough – uptake of such technologies is recommended, not mandated.
  • At the executive level the schools are seen as culpable for not targeting strategic plans for TEL with actions and targets
  • At the School level it is felt that the strategic plans lack clarity, primarily around where the university sits as an online institution (no clear institutional value proposition, plan or resourcing beyond short term initiatives)
  • Operationally it is felt there are too many institutional IT roadblocks to achieve the strategic vision. E.g. IT will not support externally hosted learning technologies like PebblePad and Learning Catalytics and it is left to the meagre resources of CLT to find work arounds and to support them.
  • Clear and comprehensive quality assurance guidelines which contain significant guidance and examples have been developed that reflect sound pedagogy and best practice, but neither mandated nor backed by course and program delivery policies (which contain quite weak minimum requirements).
  • https://intranet.ecu.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0011/660890/ECU-Quality-Assurance-Guidelines.pdf
  •  The attention paid to pedagogy, training, infrastructure and support in the Course and Unit Delivery and Assessment Policy is significantly weakened by a lack of substance within the minimum requirements
3.evidence:
ECU's Curriculum Framework specifically refers to the use of technologies to support and enhance learning as one of many attributes that will form an integral part of course and unit delivery.

ECU's Course and Unit Delivery and Assessment  Policy contains the following items:

5.6.1 E-LEARNING

The use of ICT in learning and teaching affords many opportunities and advantages when applied in an informed and strategic fashion and linked to fundamental teaching and learning principles. 

  • 5.6.1.1 ICT will be used to support quality learning and teaching in all courses delivered at Edith Cowan University.
  • 5.6.1.2 Where possible and practical, ICT will be used to provide flexible learning options for students. 
  • 5.6.1.3 All courses will develop and support the capability of students to use ICT effectively and efficiently in their learning and development.
  • 5.6.1.4 The University will provide appropriate forms and levels of ICT infrastructure and support for e-learning in all courses.
  • 5.6.1.5 The University will provide and maintain a learning management system as one form of online support for all courses. 
  • 5.6.1.6 Students will be provided with flexible access to library services.
  • 5.6.1.7 Evidence-based decision making will inform the adoption of ICT-based learning and teaching ideas and activities.
  • 5.6.1.8 Professional development opportunities will be provided to enable all teaching staff to develop the capability to use learning technologies efficiently and effectively in their context
  • 5.6.1.9 The University will share and disseminate models of good practice in e-learning among teaching staff.
  • 5.6.1.10 Due attention will be paid to ensuring the use of ICT in learning and teaching does not restrict the educational opportunities of students with limited personal access to ICT and/or particular technologies.
  • 5.6.1.11 Guidelines describing the minimum requirements for the use of ICT to be demonstrated in units across all courses are shown in Attachment 3 to this policy.
  • 5.6.1.12 Guidelines describing the requirements for units designated as online are shown in Attachment 4 to this policy.

MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS

Attachment 3

Minimum Requirement for use of ICT in ECU Courses and Units

1. Online support for Courses and Units

* Each unit will have an online presence in the University LMS which will include as a minimum the unit outline and the unit plan. Where possible, electronic forms of all the resources distributed in class will be included.

* The Unit Outline should be a copy of the current approved outline in the Course Management System.

* The Unit Plan should include a list of the timetabled classes with times and rooms, a schedule of the learning and teaching program, full descriptions of all assessment items, including assessment marking criteria, lecturer and tutor contact details, staff consultation times, and other relevant details relating to the delivery of the unit.

* Important notices and relevant resources should be made available electronically within two working days of distribution in class.

* E-mail and electronic messages sent to teaching staff by students should be answered within two working days.

* Electronic communications with students will be through students' official ECU email addresses.

* Where possible and practical, students should be able to submit assessment items electronically. If electronic submission is not a standard element of a unit, students wishing to submit electronically should be able to communicate with the lecturer to organise how this will be done.

Attachment 4

Any ECU unit designated as available online shall provide students with the following elements:
* A personal introduction from the unit coordinator and tutor with details on how communication with and between students will be facilitated during the unit offering;
* The Unit Outline from CMS;
* The Unit Plan including all assessment requirements and marking criteria;
* Students are guided through the various resources and learning activities across the teaching period.
* An online textbook or reader or online course materials, or web-based resources e.g. online access to lecture notes, PowerPoint presentations, video and/or audio versions of relevant classes;
* E-Reserve for materials with copyright constraints;
* Comprehensive learning activities to engage students with course content/materials, including some collaborative activities;
* Tutor-moderated online supports e.g. discussion boards, blogs, wikis;
* A discussion board to facilitate social contact among students;
* Online submission of assignments and receipt of feedback;
* Access to tutor through email.
* When the same Blackboard site is being used for both on-campus and online students, care must be taken to ensure:
o The requirements of the different cohorts are clearly described; and
o There is equivalence in the learning opportunities provided for the cohorts.

4.rationale:
• Policies, procedures and guidelines poorly communicated – Many staff unaware even of the minimum requirements for TEL stated in policy
  • At best policy describes technologies to support learning but not a lot of energy and enthusiasm directed towards how to enhance student learning
4.evidence: ECU's Quality Assurance Guidelines for Online Delivery focus on enhancing student learning through evidence-based practices, sound pedagogoy, and examples of good practice, however they are communicated on an irregular and ad-hoc basis and cannot be found by searching the ECU intranet.

5.rationale:
• Strong governance of the use of IT networks, security etc., but little governance of learning and teaching quality at institutional level.
  • IT focus is on restricting rather than enabling technology enhanced learning
  • Problematic relationship between IT and CLT – IT communicate poorly and often exclude CLT from decision-making processes. CLT often unaware of new technology purchases which they could be promoting heavily.
  • ITSC believes technology governance process does engage all key stakeholders and fully enables prioritisation of technology enhanced learning initiatives.
  • Business Initiative Groups established but unsuccessful
5.evidence:
Technology Governance until recently included committees called Business Initiative Groups (BIGs). The objective of each BIG was to make certain that initiatives for the relative business area had sound business oversight and appropriate ECU wide technology governance applied. The members of each BIG were typically key stakeholders relvent to the area.

It was the role of each BIG to consider IT project proposals and escalate concept briefs to the IT Governance Committee for approval. 

Many teaching and learning stakeholders found the BIG process to be a “talk to the hand” experience, i.e, that the teaching and learning BIG would escalate what they considered worthy projects, only to have them rejected by the ITGC.

While the BIGs were in operation, all of the concept briefs prepared by the Centre for Learning and Development were rejected by IT.

The BIGs are no longer in existence and appear to have been replaced by informal processes.

6.rationale: While it is clearly articulated that the Centre for Learning and Teaching has responsibility for the operational management of all learning technologies, with the Head of Centre as the Business Manager of the appropriate systems, it is commonly reported that the Head of CLT is denied any actual management, decision-making or control of the relevant systems.

7.rationale:
ECU's Strategic Technology Governance and Planning Cycle Process defines the decision-making rights and controls that take place between the business idea and the decision to fund and initiate a project. Project proposals must go through a 5-stage process of approvals. Approved projects are then subject to a priority ranking by the ITGC.

There was a strong feeling amongst respondents that key stakeholders are allowed little input into this process, especially since the failure of the Business Initiative Groups.

It was also therefore felt that ITSC alone decides which technologies to adopt according to their own priorities, with very little trialling or review from stakeholders, and then work with CLT and ADTLs to to try to ensure adoption, regardless of the appropriateness of the technology for ECU's teaching and learning priorities or needs.
7.evidence:
ECU has a very strong IT governance structure - so strong that it typically takes several years to get any actions on ideas or innovations leading to adoption of new technologies (e.g PebblePad, Bb Learning Analytics).

CLT staff, as high-end users and promoters of learning technologies, have on repeated occasions been asked to trial products and systems post-purchase, only to find them unsuitable for the types of users or teaching approaches at ECU. A recent case in point is WebEx.

Recently set up an ICT Working Party that reports to our Curriculum Teaching and Learning Committee to represent TEL issues and needs to the IT governance committee. If this mechanism of feeding requirements from the schools upwards is successful, we might hope to see a maturing of this area.

56e23d002761400d3e2716bd:
1. Strategic University Teaching and Learning Initiatives


In collaboration with SEG, Academic Board and the DVC (E), the EI team works on university-initiated and other funded (e.g. DEEWR) strategic projects involving university teaching and learning, including the application of educational technologies in teaching and learning. These projects include:

  • University Planning
  • Teaching Standards
  • Inclusive Teaching & Widening Participation
  • Engaged Enquiry
  • The Sydney Graduate
  • Curriculum Renewal
  • Academic Honesty & Text Matching Software
  • Standards Based Assessment


2. Professional Development for University Teachers


The EI team provides the University’s mandated professional development programs on teaching for university academic staff. It also convenes a range of other voluntary professional development activities and networks for university teachers, often in collaboration with colleagues in faculties and other central units.

2.1 Sessions for new Academic Staff

New staff general orientation program (through learning solutions)
Information on teaching at Sydney for all new academics
Teaching induction program for all new academics Principles and Practice of University Teaching (P&P). This two-day program is a formal probationary requirement for new academic staff.


2.2 Courses and Formal Qualifications for University Teachers

  • A one year, part time formal qualification in university teaching and learning, Graduate Certificate in Educational Studies (Higher Education), is available to staff. Completion of this course is a condition of appointment in some faculties.

  • Additional units of study in eLearning and Research Student Supervision can be undertaken to Masters level. The EI team also supervises students studying for their PhD in Higher Education or Academic Development.

  • Professional development for eLearning is an aspect of all EI programs however in addition to this a series of introductory and extension eLearning workshops are available during the year.

  • The Foundations of Research Supervision, is a short, online, independent study program for staff new to research higher degree supervision. It is a policy requirement that staff complete the program before undertaking supervision of their first students.


2.3 Faculty-based teaching development

The EI team works with Deans and Associate Deans (L&T) to jointly offer faculty workshops and other activities to support teaching development and curriculum planning on request.

2.4 University Teaching Scholars Networks

The EI team works to bring together members of the university community around shared areas of teaching interest and expertise, particularly those engaged in shared endeavours funded by the University. The aim of these networks is to support the further development of expertise amongst members and provide direct EI support for projects funded by internal University teaching grants. These networks include:

  • Engaged Enquiry Scholars Network
  • Widening Participation Scholars Network


3. Recognising and Rewarding Teaching


The EI team supports members of the University community who are competing for national and university, grants and awards for teaching. It also supports applicants for promotion to prepare their teaching case.

The EI team assists the University to promote the recognition of quality teaching, and the dissemination of quality teaching practice, through EI team publications and events.

4. Teaching Quality Assurance and Enhancement


The EI team works closely with the Quality and Analytics team to coordinate the University’s central data collection and quality assurance processes for university teaching. This includes collecting and reporting student feedback on teaching and the quality of courses and units of study for staff and students, for university planning and performance management, and for government quality assurance purposes.

56e23d002761400d3e2716bf:
While there are institutional resources to support learning technologies including the LMS (blackboard); IT Department; an applications administrator; learning technologies developers and some School based resources such as lecture and screen capture software; learning technologies that describe the importance of 'flexible approaches to educational delivery' have only been recently described in the Institutional and Learning and Teaching Strategic Plans. This has meant an inconsistent adoption of learning technologies to date. In addition, given that one of the Objects of Notre Dame is the provision of pastoral care (which Notre Dame sees as differentiating itself within the sector) there has been a reticence from staff to take up blended learning, believing it diminishes their ability to provide pastoral care.

As we prepared for the summit we asked ourselves the question ‘could Notre Dame decide to maintain the status quo in relation to learning technologies? We had the following response: 'What is the risk of not resourcing technology enhanced learning and how do we mitigate the risk?'

The risk

(1) students will most probably expect to have access to learning technologies and our pastoral care mandate expects us to respond to their expectations

(2) the sector, as evidenced by the new HESF; CEQ and QILT expect the presence of technology enhanced learning

Mitigation

(1)     The recommendations made as a result of participating in this benchmarking summit.

The University of Notre Dame e-Learning Advisory Group – Blended Learning Survey September 2015.

Summary

The aim of the survey was to gain a general understanding of the ICT tools available to and used by academics in the last two years. A total of 114 academics across the three campuses completed the survey (n = 110; 21% response rate). Importantly, the survey was completed by both early adopters of technology and those who do not currently use technology in their learning and teaching. Thirty-five per cent of respondents were using technology delivery options for their f2f students while 53% did not use ‘technological delivery options’. Most of the academics using ICT to deliver teaching (84%) were teaching in an undergraduate degree program. Thirty-one per cent of respondents reported using technology in the delivery of a postgraduate degree. The largest proportion of respondents used technology to create ‘online’ or beyond the classroom learning activities. Online activities were also used to support ‘independent study’ (62%).

Analysis of the free comment responses regarding how academics encourage independent learning through the use of ICT tools can be categorised into four groups. From highest to lowest: driven through formative and/or summative assessment; social interaction; provision of resources; and delivery mode of the course (e.g. compressed). Linked to assessment 95% of respondents were aware of Bb rubrics and 79% reported using rubrics.

The survey found that a high proportion of respondents (88%) were using standard communication tools (e.g. Outlook and Bb) and while most respondents knew of social media, very few were users. Similarly, albeit fewer respondents, academics were using tools to share knowledge. However, when asked about the use of tools to curate knowledge, there were fewer respondents across a range of pre-identified tools.

In the creative space most academics were using standard tools such as word and PowerPoint and 66% were using mind mapping tools. Less than 40% of the respondents reported using a screen capture tool. However, over 50% of respondents used some kind of recording tool to deliver lectures (voice: 18%; voice and image: 30%; streaming: 19%). Fourteen per cent and 27% were using ‘Echo 360” and ‘Bb collaborate’ respectively. One respondent noted that while they did not record their lectures, students captured the lectures on their personal devices.

It is clear from this survey that academics are seeking professional development in this space. Eighty-five per cent of respondents want to develop their skills in Blended Learning strategies and 79% want to hear about ‘great ideas’ for activities. Importantly, respondents want technical support (74%). Respondents also reported that support must be ongoing and flexible given the time demands on academic staff, staff turnover and changes in technology.

There are regular cycles within ITS, Asset Management Services and C~SALT where technologies are regularly upgraded. This includes teaching space technology, large systems (Blackboard, Mediasite etc.), desktop computing applications, and these processes are resourced from within existing staff and sometimes with additional funds.

C~SALT is charged with monitoring the adequacy of these systems through its Educational Technologies and Environments team. Reviews lead to improvement and combined C~SALT and ITS resources are applied when needed. e.g. Annual Bb upgrades, Bb+ initiative. These activities all come from existing resources but are recognised as mainstream tasks.

Not all upgrade requests can be serviced, such as where needs are identified outside planning cycles.
2.evidence:
• Scheduled equipment upgrades that fall within funding cycles. Managed through ITS
  • Annual 'large system' upgrades that are 'routine' e.g. Blackboard

3.rationale: This is very poorly executed. KPIs are not generally identified and consolidated across different service areas. In the absence of defined KPIs there is no routine evaluation against them.
3.evidence: A practice vacuum.

4.rationale:
Reporting on technology enhanced learning occurs in pockets but is not integrated across cost centres or the University generally.

There is good reporting on the Blended Learning Strategy through regular meetings of the BL Academic Leads (on-ground academic advocates), School BL Action Plans and meetings of the BL Steering Group. Reporting varies within Schools as they have different reporting structures. C~SALT produces reports for Heads of School on the range of C~SALT engagements in their Schools including blended learning.
4.evidence:
• Blended Learning Action Plans for each School that are reported to BLS Steering Group
  • Reporting by Blended Learning Academic Leads in their Schools
  • Blended Learning Strategy Working Group meetings
  • Blended Learning Strategy Steering Group meetings
  • Some collaborative activity across Schools/Faculties e.g. eMagazine 'Transitions'
  • No high level, consolidated reporting outside those directly involved, e.g. to other Cost Centres, via staff intranet
  • Some reporting to Faculty L&T Committees and School meetings

0.rationale:
Currently no systematic data analysis is performed on learning and educational data from an educational technology systems basis. There is no dedicated data analytics being performed based on LMS data or similar. Reporting is limited and ad hoc.

We do not have a 'Learning Analytics' system or planned project. A Business Intelligence/Data Warehousing project is underway but this is not expected to produce useful data on learning for some time.

Student completion data is compiled by the Strategic Information and Analysis Unit so data on attrition/completion is created but is not widely circulated - (much of it is restricted). This data is used to identify priority courses that require attention from a learning and teaching perspective.
0.evidence: • SIAU data

1.evidence:
There is a well documented calender of maintenance events for all systems, including annual major upgrades of the large systems; Blackboard and Mediasite. Processes are not always formally documented and not necessarily well shared. There are single points of failure where too much knowledge resides in individuals' heads at times.

There are clearly defined roles and responsibilities for teams within ITS and C~SALT. There is an Educational Technologies Application Support Group that considers a wide range of technologies and monitors, through monthly meetings, operations and system developments.
1.rationale:
Robust and reliable operation of learning systems is critical to the University's operations. This is well understood and supported.

Updates to major systems are well coordinated between ITS and C~SALT with project planning and execution tasks carefully coordinated. Similarly with scoping new systems and services.

2.evidence:
• Educational Technology Support for staff is provided through both C~SALT (learning and teaching use) and ITServicedesk (functional use) - both have job tracking and customer service ethos
  • Workshops and online resources are offered to staff but these are not as well developed or as comprehensive as they need to be. A work in progress.
  • ITS offers some workshops that focus on technical operation of equipment but the coverage is limited and not keeping pace with technology rollouts. (e.g. Office 365 implementation.)
  • Not good coordination across areas.
  • There is a slowly growing set of self-help resources for staff on intranet (MyUSC) but these have a way to go to be comprehensive.
2.rationale:
Student support is very limited. There is a Student IT Helpdesk with limited scope but no support beyond that. Student support for applied use of learning and teaching systems such as the LMS is devolved to academic staff with very mixed results. This has been a point of contention for some years.

Staff support is provided by the C~SALT team, focussing on the educational application of technologies. ITS deliver limited workshops in technology functionality, without the pedagogical overlay.

3.rationale: Generally, systems that are implemented are reasonably well supported by ITS.
3.evidence:
• Routine upgrades undertaken on rolling basis - technology lifecycles documented and generally followed
  • Poor support of innovative projects - unclear funding sources and governance of projects often lacking

4.rationale:
Broadly speaking, the University does not have a culture of bold exploration and innovation around technologies. Historically there has been considerable risk aversion at USC and this has been reflected in ITS' lack of willingness to support experimentation. This is now changing and in conjunction with C~SALT there is an improving culture of innovation.

Internal grants are another story and these have been provided for several years to enable academic staff to explore technologies in their practice. The processes to translate learnings from projects into production systems have been not been developed or formally established. Similarly with evaluation of technologies for integration with existing infrastructure.
4.evidence:
• Internal Grants and Awards - well defined submission, selection, evaluation processes
  • With the exception of Grants and Awards, there is no fund for technology exploration or to support innovation that staff can make submissions to for projects

5.rationale:
PD for staff involved with supporting services is provided on a routine basis and includes training events and conferences. This is particularly so for existing, established services and is more ad hoc for new services.

Conferences such as the annual Blackboard conference are routinely attended by several staff from ITS and C~SALT.
5.evidence:
• Performance, Planning and Review (PPR) processes often include agreed PD
  • Conference and training attendances

6.rationale: The University has robust risk assessment processes and a history of being risk-averse. This covers all areas of operation. ITS are audited regularly, by internal and external auditors.
6.evidence:
• Risk in the IT space is overseen by the ICT Governance Group and its associated Application Support Groups.
  • The project methodology used for all ICT projects includes formal risk assessment in the design and monitoring of projects.
  • Where risk is identified, mitigation strategies need to be defined.
  • Risk in terms of business system owner staff leaving or becoming ill not documented and no mitigation strategies in place

7.rationale:
Support for staff for the educational use of learning technologies is generally understood to be the responsibility of the Centre for Support and Advancement of Learning and Teaching. This includes large systems, classroom technology and desktop educational tools.

Support for functional use of IT including basic infrastructure (desktop computing, wifi, productivity applications etc.) is the responsibility of IT Services. This is generally understood across the academic community.
7.evidence:
• ET Support (Educational Technology Support within C~SALT) is widely promoted as the support centre for Blackboard, Mediasite and related learning technologies.
  • The ITServicedesk is promoted as the support centre for straight technical issues.
  • Many support resources are provided on the intranet (MyUSC) and these clearly differentiate the support offered by the respective centres.

0.rationale: The University has two major and related activities designed to provide professional development in educational technologies for staff. These are the Blended Learning Strategy 2014-2016 and Blackboard+. These set out a number of deliverables and outcomes for blended learning and course improvement in the LMS. The initiatives are supported by backfill of academic positions and various PD activities.
0.evidence:

  • Various formal programs are delivered (see 5.3 below).

1.rationale:
Identification of staff training needs in educational technologies is not undertaken systematically from any particular cost centre. HR have programs but they specifically avoid educational technologies and learning and teaching themes.

C~SALT identifies needs based on:

  • engagement with academic staff through a range of other activities
  • initiatives being driven from the Centre, e.g. Bb+
  • historical knowledge of training needs, e.g. Blackboard functionality etc.
  • rollout of new technologies, e.g. Bb Collaborate Ultra, SRS, Pebble

ITS provide training on core systems and software and as part of a change management process when new core technologies are rolled out.
1.evidence:
There have been a range of activities offered around the Blackboard+ initiative. These include:

  • Workshops with program groups to consolidate agreed pedagogies and course design
  • Workshops to enable academic staff to 'bring and build' content and start on their courses
  • Offering open drop-ins at C~SALT for anyone wanting to call in, without appointment, to sort out issues

Engagement with academic staff results in intelligence around development needs that result in workshops and online resources such as:

  • Collaborate Ultra workshops/online content

2.rationale:
There are various activities that address professional development in blended learning. These vary from workshops to day-long sesssions, Learning and Teaching Week, and a course on University teaching.

Most of the content is developed by or vetted by Academic Developers to ensure it fits USC's core teaching philosophies.

C~SALT has technical staff with in-depth knowledge of our systems from desktop to enterprise systems and they develop and deliver professional development.
2.evidence:
• Foundations of University Teaching (optional course covering university teaching - theory and practice), with a strong emphasis on blended learning and delivered in a blended learning mode.
  • Sessional Staff Development Day - twice yearly day-long program focussed on needs of sessional staff.
  • Learning and Teaching Week - demonstrations of best practice at USC combined with visiting experts - with blended learning a key philosophy.
  • Peer Assisted Teaching Scheme (PATS) is offered to staff.

3.rationale: Coordination across cost centres is ad hoc. Individual areas tend to develop and deliver PD without reference to other areas. It is not always easy to identify who is offering what around the University.
3.evidence:
The evidence is that professional development opportunities is sometimes discovered after the fact. There are no coordinating mechanisms (such as a central training calendar) to expose all training being offered.

Promotion of professional development tends to be by 'all staff' emails out of individual cost centres. There is not yet an integrated training calender in our staff intranet.

4.rationale:
Resourcing for the provision of PD is reasonable and a core element of C~SALT's work. Capacity to develop and deliver PD is quite good.

However, support for academics to participate is within the domain of Schools, Disciplines and Program groups. One suspects this isn't an issue when there is no cost to participate but can become so if fees apply.

There is an ongoing problem for sessional staff who would not generally be paid to attend PD.

5.rationale:
C~SALT: Generally staff development is delivered face-to-face, both in groups and individually. The assumption is that facilitators will be faced with diverse skill levels and will accommodate them. Participatory learning is a fundamental approach and training is planned to be rich and engaging.

ITS: Training is provided in a relatively static format and appears to use a boilerplate approach. Presentation style tends to be 'stand and deliver'.
5.evidence: Evidence to come.

6.rationale: Evaluations of PD and training are undertaken and used to inform future delivery modes and themes. Continuous improvement is presumed and content of PD is reviewed prior to each delivery.
6.evidence: Programs and workshops run by C~SALT usually involve follow-up evaluations by email or online survey. Paper forms are used less as they are problematic.

Terms of reference and membership for the following groups are listed below

  • ANU Online Steering Committee
  • Wattle Reference Group
  • Wattle User Group

ANU Online Steering Group

The ANU Online Steering Group will support the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Academic) in assessing and developing strategic directions and high-level resourcing recommendations regarding the provision of online education at ANU.

The Steering Committee will:

  1.  Identify ongoing market opportunities in online education for ANU, on the basis of national and international evidence;
  2. Ensure that business requirements and models for online education align with the strategic directions of ANU, as articulated in ANU by 2020;
  3. Make high-level resourcing recommendations regarding the provision of online education at ANU, including platforms;
  4. Maintain executive oversight of the significant risks and their mitigation strategies in relation to online education at ANU;
  5. Ensure sufficient and early engagement with proposed new business/enterprise solutions in other areas that may impact on ANU Online activities; and
  6. Advise on public communication concerning online education at ANU.

Members

  • The Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Academic) as chair
  • The Chief Information Officer
  • Two College Heads or Education Deans
  • ANU Online Lead

Wattle Reference Group

The Wattle Reference Group is a sub-committee of the ANU Online Steering Group which itself advises the delegate – the DVC(A). It does not, therefore, make decisions; rather it is authorised only to make recommendations to the Steering Group.

Wattle Reference Group will:

  1. Consider, seek feedback on and report back to ANU Online Steering Committee recommendations concerning opportunities to expand and improve online education at ANU;
  2. Propose, monitor and review University policies and procedures designed to enhance online education at ANU;
  3. Monitor issues affecting student and staff experiences of online education at ANU and make recommendations to address them;
  4. Advise the ANU Online Steering Group on national and international developments in the enhancement of online education that align with University strategy; and
  5. Liaise with Colleges to coordinate enhancements to staff and students experiences of online education at ANU

Members

  • Chair
  • One staff member and one alternate, with expertise in the area, from each ANU
  • College nominated by the ANU College Head (may be either academic or professional staff)
  • ANU Online Lead
  • BSG Manager or nominee
  • One staff member from CHELT with expertise in the area, nominated by the CHELT director
  • Registrar or nominee (invited as needed)
  • CIO or nominee
  • Two members appointed by the Chair, for their expertise and/or observers invited as needed
  • Two student members, nominated by the President of ANUSA and the President of PARSA
  • Secretariat support provided by BSG

Reports/Makes Recommendations to: ANU Online Steering Group

Wattle User Group

Terms of Reference

  • Provide a community of practice for senior educational technologists and eLearningpractitioners from all Colleges and from CHELT
    • Standing items for consideration:
    • Current issues and operations
  • Non-Moodle components of Wattle (DLD, Adobe Connect)
  • Provide support and training for people who are operating the system, for example:
    • Train-the-trainer
    • Problem solving
    • Workarounds
    • Sharing best practice
    • Applications
    • Testing
  • Report to the Wattle Reference Group on operation of Wattle, issues, risks

Reports/Makes Recommendations to: Wattle Reference Group

ANU Online provides a range of learning environment services.
Under the direction of the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Academic), and in partnership with the Information Technology Services Division, the ANU Online Program is responsible for the enterprise-wide implementation of a technology platform to enhance teaching and learning across the University. 

With Moodle as its platform, ANU Online will deliver the following Online Learning Environment elements:

Learning Management System
Ethical Treatment of Academic Materials
Lecture Capture
Content Repository for Education
Learning Analytics
Community Creation and Sustainability.

1. Strategic University Teaching and Learning Initiatives


In collaboration with SEG, Academic Board and the DVC (E), the EI team works on university-initiated and other funded (e.g. DEEWR) strategic projects involving university teaching and learning, including the application of educational technologies in teaching and learning. These projects include:

  • University Planning
  • Teaching Standards
  • Inclusive Teaching & Widening Participation
  • Engaged Enquiry
  • The Sydney Graduate
  • Curriculum Renewal
  • Academic Honesty & Text Matching Software
  • Standards Based Assessment


2. Professional Development for University Teachers


The EI team provides the University’s mandated professional development programs on teaching for university academic staff. It also convenes a range of other voluntary professional development activities and networks for university teachers, often in collaboration with colleagues in faculties and other central units.

2.1 Sessions for new Academic Staff

New staff general orientation program (through learning solutions)
Information on teaching at Sydney for all new academics
Teaching induction program for all new academics Principles and Practice of University Teaching (P&P). This two-day program is a formal probationary requirement for new academic staff.


2.2 Courses and Formal Qualifications for University Teachers

  • A one year, part time formal qualification in university teaching and learning, Graduate Certificate in Educational Studies (Higher Education), is available to staff. Completion of this course is a condition of appointment in some faculties.

  • Additional units of study in eLearning and Research Student Supervision can be undertaken to Masters level. The EI team also supervises students studying for their PhD in Higher Education or Academic Development.

  • Professional development for eLearning is an aspect of all EI programs however in addition to this a series of introductory and extension eLearning workshops are available during the year.

  • The Foundations of Research Supervision, is a short, online, independent study program for staff new to research higher degree supervision. It is a policy requirement that staff complete the program before undertaking supervision of their first students.


2.3 Faculty-based teaching development

The EI team works with Deans and Associate Deans (L&T) to jointly offer faculty workshops and other activities to support teaching development and curriculum planning on request.

2.4 University Teaching Scholars Networks

The EI team works to bring together members of the university community around shared areas of teaching interest and expertise, particularly those engaged in shared endeavours funded by the University. The aim of these networks is to support the further development of expertise amongst members and provide direct EI support for projects funded by internal University teaching grants. These networks include:

  • Engaged Enquiry Scholars Network
  • Widening Participation Scholars Network


3. Recognising and Rewarding Teaching


The EI team supports members of the University community who are competing for national and university, grants and awards for teaching. It also supports applicants for promotion to prepare their teaching case.

The EI team assists the University to promote the recognition of quality teaching, and the dissemination of quality teaching practice, through EI team publications and events.

4. Teaching Quality Assurance and Enhancement


The EI team works closely with the Quality and Analytics team to coordinate the University’s central data collection and quality assurance processes for university teaching. This includes collecting and reporting student feedback on teaching and the quality of courses and units of study for staff and students, for university planning and performance management, and for government quality assurance purposes.

0.rationale:
Swinburne positions itself strongly as a technology University and TEL is a key pillar of this positioning. Therefore there is considerable alignment.

There is a Technology Roadmap that provides a process for identification and adoption of emerging technologies.

There are constant learning opportunities provided for staff re using our LMS, Blackboard, including weekly drop in sessions, individualised technical support and a range of short ( 2 or 3 hour) training sessions offered at strategic points in the academic calendar, such as when Blackboard sites have to be set up or when results have to be entered in Gradebook.

As we move into implementing our new Blended Learning Standards Framework in the second half of 2016 we are designing a range of training sessions with online resources being created to support them.

1.rationale:
The Learning and Teaching Strategy (2014) articulated our 2020 Learning and Teaching Vision as 'quality, personalised, innovative and flexible education'. As Swinburne positions itself strongly as a 'technology university' these pillars are commonly interpreted as sitting within the TEL domain.

Procedures are in place and many such needs are identified.

However, it is of concern that the same people use multiple services and resources, rather than such use being spread in a more equitable way across a greater number of staff.

In particular, we need to get better at creating opportunities to include sessional and OUA staff and getting better at meeting their support needs.

Communities of Practice are currently being established to better identify staff needs and to offer the opportunity for staff to share practice, talk and get quick answers to their immediate needs. For instance, we have offered one day learning design  workshops for years to integrate blended learning into unit design and teaching practice but we have, up until now, not had any idea of what happens in these units once the teachers leave the workshops. The COP will allow staff to share what worked well and what didn't ,work so well with what they learnt.

COPs are also being  established for OUA teaching staff.

2.rationale: There are no coherent and wholistic evaluation frameworks in place. While individual support and professional development activities are briefly evaluated at the end of each session and attendance numbers are recorded, there is no systematic analysis of this data, nor rigorous inclusion of it in continuous quality improvement processes.

3.rationale:
Coordination happens between the Faculties and the central Learning Transformations Unit (LTU), and is fairly regular and robust. The Associate Deans Learning Innovation are the key points of communication. GIven that 2/3 of these roles have very new incumbents at the moment, we are currently in a process of re-establishing expectations and responsibilities across these relationships.

The LTU and Library and ITS work closely together and there are more projects underway with Student Advancement and Academic Services in 2016.

4.rationale:
There are good aspects to accessibility - staff make very good use of the technical support available through the Learning Transformations Unit (LTU) via drop in sessions and telephone support. The learning design workshops are also well known and attended. They are regularly publicised through a newsletter, which results in a spike of inquiries every time it is distributed.

There are particular issues for OUA teaching staff who work outside of, and in addition to, the two semester University academic calendar. The Learning Transformations Unit has an internal website that houses electronic resources Which is the portal for 24/7 resources but people would rather overall to call and speak to a person, who is only available 9.00-5.00.

5.rationale:
Swinburne positions itself as a technology Univeristy. As a dual sector institution with a strong focus on enhancing its digital capacity as one of the four pillars of its 2020 there is a recognition that resources are needed to support this. 

When putting a technology project forward we need to create a business case that includes not only the cost of the technology but the cost of supporting and embedding use of new technology adoption amongst the staff.

6.rationale:
We have an excellent suite of programs, training sessions and electronic support tools that are housed on The LTU internal site on the intranet. We have recently relocated where we house all these resources from a hard to find internal wiki to an internal webpage for our centre, that staff can more easily find.

There is a regular and well read newsletter that advertises what is offered to the university teaching community. Previously this only went to those people who had used our services or training sessions before, so wasn't reaching the staff (in particular OUA and sessional staff) who didn't know who we were or what we offered.

8.rationale:
Need to get much better at this, there are very ad-hoc and inconsistently used approaches to evaluating learning design and technology interventions.

The new Learning Analytics project currently being piloted should also really enhance this capacity.

The new Blended Learning Standards framework is being rolled out in semester two, 2016 and there is a strategic approach to identifying what professional development will need to be offered in support of this.

0.rationale: Victoria has a clearly framed Vision and Strategy for Digital Learning and Teaching at Victoria (http://www.victoria.ac.nz/learning-teaching/academic-development/digital-vision/DigitalVisionStrategy.pdf). This includes an action plan outlining specific operational objectives supporting and promoting the use of technology to support learning and teaching.

1.evidence:
Operational plans for support groups including CAD and ITS include clear and specific linkages to this strategy. Plans for investment in major capital works similarly are aligned to the Vision and Strategy for Digital Learning and Teaching at Victoria.

In 2014 the ITS Operational Plan refocused service delivery to be in line with the Strategic Plan.

This defined a shift from delivering traditional corporate IT services to the university to expanding its services to support the strategic goals of the university, specifically in the areas of research, teaching and learning and enhancing the student experience.

For Learning and Teaching this has led to a change in delivery model to working one on one with academics in the development of teaching and learning technology services and solutions in support of the digital vision strategy.

2.rationale: Specific budget proposal aligned to the process. Institutional lifecycles for ongoing investment and development of technology to support learning and teaching are in development. Lifecycle for Learning Spaces has been created and is being refined through experience in its application. Other lifecycles are planned for development including applications.

3.rationale:
The University does not have a unifying pedagogical framework that must be applied. The Vision and Strategy for Digital Learning and Teaching at Victoria emphasise that the role of technology at Victoria is primarily as an enhancement of a face to face education and that technology should be applied to this end. No specific requirements are imposed at either course or program level.


A series of support materials including case studies and pedagogical advice are in active development on the University Innovation Incubator (http://hub.vicinnovate.ac.nz/) and Digital Learning Hub (http://learning.vicinnovate.ac.nz/).

4.rationale:
The University does not have formal processes and systems relating to technology that must be applied in the design, development and delivery of learning.


A series of support materials including case studies and pedagogical advice are in active development on the University Innovation Incubator (http://hub.vicinnovate.ac.nz/) and Digital Learning Hub (http://learning.vicinnovate.ac.nz/). These are intended to be used by support staff and linked to systems where possible.

5.rationale: Vision and Strategy for Digital Learning and Teaching at Victoria Governance Group has been constituted and includes membership of both of the Vice-Provosts (Learning and Equity, and Research) as well as the Faculty Associate Deans with learning and teaching responsibility. Group has not yet commenced pending appointment of the AVC Digital Futures.

6.rationale:
Victoria has in place a model “the Virtual CSU” with a shared responsibility for technology support between multiple groups including CAD, ITS, Campus Services, the Library and Student Learning.

This model is based on a high trust and engagement model of work which is not formalised into operational processes, but is clearly apparent particularly in the operational coordination between ITS and CAD. Most communication of the model is focused on ensuring supported staff know how to engage with support staff.

7.rationale: ITS has in place a formal project process for new investments and there are expectations made through the budget process. Application lifecycle has been identified but not yet promulgated.

0.rationale:
Through the Centre for Academic Development (CAD), Victoria provides both Peer and Student focused improvement and quality assurance processes for implementing and reflecting on the success of integrating technology into the learning experience for students. These processes include:

 

Student Teacher and Course Feedback process. Used for the post-review of courses including options for additional questions eveluating technology use: http://www.cad.vuw.ac.nz/wiki/index.php/Student_Feedback
Peer Observation between CAD staff and teachers for the observation, reflection and mentoring on technology use in class. Peer observation can also be attributed towards academic promotion: http://www.utdc.vuw.ac.nz/resources/guidelines/PeerObservation.pdf
Curriculum design support and consultation for learning outcome, activity and assessment change when planning the integration of technology into programmes or courses:  http://www.cad.vuw.ac.nz/wiki/index.php/Curriculum_redesign

A current project, the minimum course presence project, is defining the required level of online interaction by all courses at Victoria. An overview of the recommendations can be found in the new programme and course design handbook:  


http://www.victoria.ac.nz/documents/policy/governance/programme-and-course-design-handbook.pdf - Page 17, Section 3.9.


The application of these quality assurance processes for programmes is reactive and generally based on organisational, faculty or school based changes e.g. dependencies for multi-campus delivery or shift to full online offering. There is no cyclic programme review process around technology integration. At a course level, reactive requests from individual academics are common and based on engagement with professional development or a change in the mode of delivery of the course.

1.rationale:
Victoria University has multiple levels of governance over the evaluation, selection and implementation of learning technology. The level of governance is defined by the cost of implementation of the learning technology service.


For major investment ($100,000NZD and above) the evaluation and selection processes are defined by the University procurement policy:

http://www.victoria.ac.nz/documents/policy/facilities-management/procurement-policy.pdf


Before an open tender is released for a major learning technology project, requirements will be created and accepted by the following groups -


Final approval for release: University CAPEX Committee
Review of RFI: ITSOC (Information Technology Strategic Oversight Committee) This group is chaired by the COO and includes leadership membership from both the academic and professional arms of the university.     
Academic acceptance of requirements: DVOAG (Digital Vision Operational Advisory Group) This group is focused on the advancement of digital learning and teaching at Victoria. This group will soon be chaired by the AVC Digital Futures and includes membership from each Faculty and key support units.   
Creation of requirements: Academically focused requirements from cross disciplinary project teams and projects created by DVOAG and also from Faculty, Service Unit and individual academic projects.

All requests for information or pricing that are realeased via the open tender process will be distributed on the NZ Government eTendering Service (GETS): https://www.gets.govt.nz/ExternalIndex.htm


Major projects will then select pilot courses and programmes to trial learning technology before an enterprise roll out.


While these processes are defined by financial requirements, input into the functional requirements for the implementation of learning technology services are the responsibility of the DVOAG and Digital Vision strategy working group. This includes the discussion and review of services as they reach end of life.


This review and implementation of lifecycle processes are in the process of being developed to support the digital vision and also to enable technology decision making with core university learning, teaching and research strategies. The first of the lifecycles for physical space has been drafted:

 

While these evaluation and decision making groups enable some cohesion in technology enhanced learning services, there is still a level of autonomy within support units and faculty to fund and implement services based on their own needs and unit strategies.

2.rationale:
In response to the Digital Vision Strategy, ‘The Virtual CSU’ approach for planning improvement and support was developed to provide a shared responsibility approach across support units.


While developed for increasing academic support, the expertise in the leadership layer of the virtual csu has worked to focus on the quality improvement of technology enhanced learning systems (including physical and virtual learning environments), support and guidelines:

 

 


The Virtual CSU is made of staff from across multiple support units including CAD, ITS, LIbrary, Research Office. Planning and improvement initiatives developed by the Virtual CSU include:


Creation of the Digital Vision Strategic working group to plan and deliver on the key improvement action points within the digital vision strategy
Creation of the Organisational Development Steering group to plan and align university professional development
Development of lifecycles strategically highlighted in the Digital Vision. Physical space lifecycle is active when spaces are planned for upgrading with application and operating  environment lifecycles being planned
Planning of academic professional development as a cohesive programme across support units
Student Learning developing a student digital support strategy
A major programme of improvement is in place to improve student management systems and data integrity. This is an ongoing project called the Student Services Improvement Programme (SSIP)

While planning is being delivered across the organisation, delivery of planned improvements for academic staff and support units is still performed with a small increase in support resources over the last five years.


The SSIP programme is well funded and resourced for project management and delivery but leverages shared resources for technical delivery.


Another area limiting planning and implementation is lack of accountability and responsibility to implement planned outcomes across the organisation. There is still no drive to change, or be rewarded for change, at the individual academic, course or programme level.

3.rationale:
The are limited formal KPIs for technology enhanced learning environments. Current formal KPI’s agreed between service units are based on infrastructure, systems management and front end support targets. These KPI’s are visible within service level agreements. These KPI’s are used to identify improvement in infrastructure and support, but not the fundamental focus or outcomes of the service. These KPI’s are:


Performance Measure
Performance Target
Quality Standard
Incident Management
Ø  Agreed service level response times are met

 
Ø  Incidents managed in accordance with Section 5 of this document

Ø  Agreed escalation procedures are followed
Service Availability

 
Ø  ≥ 99.5% availability
Ø  All outages are pre-planned and within agreed change windows or agreed to by the business owner

Ø  Systems perform to agreed standards

 
Change Management
Ø  All system changes are implemented successfully

Ø  All changes are documented and signed-off at the appropriate level
Ø  Formal change management process followed in accordance with ITS’s Change Management process

Ø  Change management process is auditable
Systems Maintenance

 
Ø  System version,  fixes/patches up to date

 

 
Ø  All fixes/patches assessed in terms of relevance and applied as appropriate

Ø  Formal change management process followed

 
Backup & Restore

 

 
Ø  Full back-up performed once a fortnight

Ø  Incremental back-up  performed every other day
Ø  Data is able to be recovered when requested

 

Service improvement and service planning are generally based around product roadmaps for specific learning and teaching services and infrastructure.


The Digital Vision working group are planning to create an application lifecycle for learning and teaching application services to match the current physical space lifecycle planning.

4.rationale:
Since the University appointed a new Chancellor and Vice Chancellor in the last two years, there has been an increase in the strategic importance and oversight in digital learning and research environments at Victoria. The term ‘Digital Victoria’ is now commonly used at SLT level to explain a desired future state. The importance of Digital Victoria has also been highlighted in the creation of a new Associate Vice-Chancellor Digital Futures role at Victoria to lead the shift to digital learning, teaching and research methodologies. This role is focused on understanding the impact and possibilities of the SLT portfolios and ensuring that data driven decision making on digital initiatives and change is presented to SLT in a meaningful manner.   


Due to this focus, reporting on the utilisation, implementation and successful use of digital learning services is now delivered to SLT and Council. The Digital Victoria report, ITS Quarterly operational reports and programme funding reports / requests are overseen by Council.   

 

Reports include the progress of strategic initiatives (such as the Digital Vision and eResearch Capability report), professional development targets, programme progress and operational targets, Organisational units also develop unit plans for delivery to SLT.


The increase of data and information to SLT and Council recently instigated a strategic statement on digital capability at Victoria drafted by the Vice-Chancellor. This instigated a council workshop where selected staff from across faculty and support units were invited to an open debate in regards to digital change.


At the mid-tier governance level, the Information Technology Strategic Oversight Committee (ITSOC) also receives and develops relevant reporting into university digital services.


While the importance of reporting into the progress of Digital Victoria is seen by Council, SLT and individual support units, there is still limited visibility of reporting into Faculty strategic groups such as Learning and Teaching Committees, Research Committees and Faculty Management Teams.

0.rationale:
The application of various technologies including Blackboard, VStream, Turnitin, Zoom etc. into individual courses is done primarily for operational and administrative reasons rather than reflecting a comprehensive and systematic application of technologies aligned to the overall strategies. There are a growing number of strategic projects and implementations but these are still in a minority.

University learning and teaching strategy in redevelopment, current version four years out of date.

1.rationale: As with 4.1, there are examples where there is a clear pedagogical intent for the use of technology but these are still in the minority. Specific examples include programmes operated by SIM, Education and LALS.

2.rationale: Research evidence available through CAD websites and the HELT programme. CATS are increasingly able to draw on research evidence in their work as well. Set of case studies with strong research linkages are in preparation but are not yet widely available. Summaries have started to be published in VicNews on a monthly basis.

3.rationale: VicTeach is an excellent community that is clearly supporting the effective use of technology. While VicTeach is an excellent example, there are problems with cross campus engagement and bringing in new members into the community - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ie36XgkB8b0

4.rationale: Resources for CAD e-learning staff, CATS being expanded year over year, Teaching development grants. Issue is continuing to grow support in line with growing demand for it - ability to sustain the needs.

5.rationale: Projects typically have capital budgets but no operational allocation for support. Ongoing issues engaging with staff in advance of major deployments and changes. CATS are starting to address this but clearly room for improvement.

6.rationale: Evaluations typically only occur if individual staff are particularly engaged. Many staff discouraged from extensive evaluations as these are not valued under the PBRF.

7.rationale: Apparent in specific programmes that are explicitly prioritising the use of technology - SIM, Education.

8.rationale: Case studies of good practice in active development.

0.rationale:
In 2011 the University realised a need for governance and vision around the application and support for technology for teaching, learning and research at the university. This initiated the development of the Digital vision and strategy for learning and teaching. Within this strategy a number of key areas of focus were outlined. These includes specific actions in support structure definition, reprovisioning of technology application and faculty specific identification of technology needs. In articulating the vision of the university with regards to Digital adoption there have been a number of changes to the strategic and operational plans within ITS, including the creation of a Learning and Research Technology Team which is responsible for building training support to closely align technology adoption and pedagogy practice.  Within this team there are key staff (CATs) tasked with collaborating directly with faculty staff to develop capabilities for technology use, there is also specific support for research capabilities and Workplace productivity skills. With the establishment of this group and the close collaboration with the Centre for Academic Development (CAD) more online capability resources are being created for staff to freely access.

 

 


eResearch capability report - link and evidence

http://www.victoria.ac.nz/its/staff-services/eresearch-capabilities


ITS’ strategic and operational plans link to the Digital Vision with regards to establishing a support team which can respond and develop activities with regards to the specific goals outlined in the Digital Vision document. These include specific Faculty support for technology use based on their distinctive identity, development of a roadmap for technology investment, physical support for innovation and individualised technology support.

 

University Staff Capability Strategy was drawn up in 2012 and sets out the University vision for capability Development and support across the board (not just regards to technology within Teaching and Learning). This strategy defines how the University sees capability development holistically and defines responsibilities and objectives. The document attempts to set out the high-level vision for staff development but does not cover the specifics of application.


However, the digital strategy is not necessarily well known across all staff in relation to staff development.

1.rationale:
Specific support structures and tools are available and being used in order to collect capability development needs and allow staff to request support.  A limited amount of proactive identification of future needs for staff occurs and should be part of the PDCP process. However anecdotally we know that this process is problematic and sporadic in its application.

Facilities established to respond to staff needs and request:

Staff embedded in faculties with explicit role to identify needs - CATs
https://vuw.sharepoint.com/sites/virtualcsuteaching/_layouts/15/guestaccess.aspx?guestaccesstoken=xSUWXkgDo6g86TW14ZzMy10V%2fIG%2b0eeC53ll1tnr3xo%3d&docid=2_17a8e2b8e97e24c07bafacc7ba28cb531
PDCP Process with manager support and training -
https://www.victoria.ac.nz/staff/human-resources/performance/career-planning/academic-staff/academic-staff-pdcp-process-guide.pdf
https://www.victoria.ac.nz/staff/human-resources/performance/career-planning/general-staff
Yammer and VicTeach (CoP) soliciting needs - provision of channels for staff to both find out about possibilities for technology PD and express interest.
ITS Helpdesk call analysis
Also call resolution process - this includes recording any resolution actions from problems or training done as part of troubleshooting.
ITS Capability Developer use of call data to prioritise training
Responsive planning for training based on data from CATs and helpdesk
ITS internal training for support staff to ensure able to identify needs

There are areas that are currently being developed further to encourage and reinforce the ability of staff to actively plan their own development and understand the scope and purpose of any technology adoption. These include:

Capability pathways plan
Staff self audit tool to record current capabilities and highlight future needs
Better links into PDCP process (richer range of activities) this needs to be addressed with improvement management of the process and higher priority placed on continual improvement of career and skills development - this might include a specific technology goal?
More uptake of HELT programme by academic staff. A greater understanding amongst staff regarding the pedagogical drivers and implications of adopting technology within teaching practice would result in greater awareness and improved engagement with technology support. (we second that)

However, there is not a clear message from the SLT to use technology in teaching. Ongoing development is “encouraged” not “expected”.

2.rationale:
The initial creation of the innovation incubator worked to address this need. It brought together resources information and support on both technical and pedagogical fronts. IT’s information is limited and not particularly well structures. Many staff are unaware of the resource and therefore its value is limited.  We are in the process of addressing this with the creation of the Learning Hub which brings a more structured approach to making available technical support information in several different media together with pedagicial commentary, perspectives, application guidelines and case study examples. In the future we may also have a Research, Workplace and Leadership streams of resource hubs.

Innovation Incubator

Learning Hub

3.rationale:
With the development of the Virtual CSU and the Learning and Research Technology Team within ITS the collaboration between ITS and CAD has grown. Training support and consultation is now often offering in conjunction with staff from both teams facilitating training or advising. Continual communication between these two CSUs allows for support calls to be responded to far more quickly.

Professional development of these these teams internally through the HELT programme also extends the improvement of this support structure and ensures technology and pedagogy are supported concurrently. Since 2015, the learning and research team in ITS has undertaken HELT papers as professional development to bring together the pedagogical and technological support to all staff members.

4.rationale:

0.rationale:
There is considerable alignment between the student training with the technology used, as the purpose of the training is to enable the students to use the technology independently. For example, during orientation (before the start of trimester 1 and trimester 2) there are IT orientation sessions managed by Student Academic Services. This includes an overview of all student systems follow by a hands on learning session for one on one tailored help from the Student Systems trainer and student orientation workers. Topics covered include signing in for the first time, Blackboard, myVictoria, Printing, myQual, Library myVictoria tab, Student Records, myAllocator, the CliqueIn App and onsite wifi. The Library also runs training sessions for students on how to use the Library catalogue, database and reference management software. These are usually done from about week 3 tailored towards the first assignment. These sessions are advertised through the Library’s workshop website, and runs for 4-6 weeks, three times a week. At times course coordinators request a librarian to run a training session for students, and librarian may also advertise pop-up training sessions for students advertised through Blackboard for a particular course.


Self-paced training for a number of applications commonly used at university are available through Microsoft Imagine Academy which is covered by the site license for Microsoft. People living in Wellington who have a Wellington City Library Card (which students may have) also have access to self-paced training for a large number of applications through Lynda.com.


Postgraduate students have access to some specific training/ orientation workshops organised by the Faculty of Graduate Research and these include data management and data analysis tools such as R and Python and software

1.rationale:
The student training for technology enhanced learning can be considered as inadequately resourced in terms of staff available to deliver training. Because different units of the university deliver different types of training, the availability of staff to deliver training varies widely. For example, Disability Services have a dedicated Adaptive Technology Specialist who is available full time to deliver 1-on-1 training for students with disability status.On the other hand, a Student Management Systems trainer is allocated to train the students for one week before trimester 1 starts, and 2 days before trimester 2 starts.


It should be noted, however, that the need for training may not always be considered high for some systems. The majority of students may not need in-depth training on the use of BlackBoard as the use of the different features of BlackBoard depends on which features the relevant course coordinators select for their courses. So an introductory training may be sufficient for most students, and some students may be able to make sense of the system without any training at all. However, the use of adaptive technology may require a more intensive training ranging from 1 hour of 1-on-1 training (for Read Write Gold, OpenBook and Kurzweill) to 10 hours of 1-on-1 training for Dragon Naturally Speaking.


Student Learning, another unit of the university, have a couple of staff who are able to assist students with the use of technology as needed. But the availability of training run by Student Learning is very much ad-hoc.


There are a number of self-help resources available for students to digest at their own time, but the availability of these are not always obvious. Examples of these are the ITS website for students (http://www.victoria.ac.nz/its/student-services),  and link to Blackboard help resources on the Blackboard login page, repeated again in the Support tab on the BlackBoard landing portal.


Some tools are not resources sufficiently (eg. NVivo).

2.rationale:
No formal evaluation occurs (ad hoc). Anecdotal comments may be received from students but there are no formal ways of recording these.


Library has an evaluation framework for the training that they do (still ad hoc).

3.rationale:

For example, Student Learning may refer  students who may fall under the DS equity group to talk to their technology specialist for training using specialised applications for DS students (Read Write Gold), or a particular librarian may refer a postgraduate student to Student Learning for training on how to use NVivo, or how to manage long documents in Word.

56e23d002761400d3e2716be:
Victoria has chosen to prioritise the use of technology for learning and teaching and for research. We have a substantial number of initiatives underway under the overall University Strategy (http://www.victoria.ac.nz/about/governance/strategic-plan) and also the Digital Vision and Strategy for Learning and Teaching (http://www.victoria.ac.nz/learning-teaching/academic-development/digital-vision). The University is also in the process of appointing an Assistant Vice-Chancellor Digital Futures who will lead ongoing strategic development in this area.

Large Scale ICT project initiatives at Victoria:

• Project to upgrade/replace Echo360 Lecture Recording and Video Management facilities

• Talis course content management and reporting system

• New teaching and learning spaces in two new buildings (approx 60 spaces including double tiered lecture theatre and teaching laboratories)

• Office365 deployment for all staff and students including a review of support for online collaboration and publishing associated with teaching, research and administration.

• Research data management
