0.rationale:
Victoria has a clearly framed Vision and Strategy for Digital Learning and Teaching at Victoria (http://www.victoria.ac.nz/learning-teaching/academic-development/digital-vision/DigitalVisionStrategy.pdf). This includes an action plan outlining specific operational objectives supporting and promoting the use of technology to support learning and teaching.


Vision

Technology is a fundamental contributor to modern life and key to a challenging and stimulating educational experiences for students in the 21st Century. Victoria students will experience a professional, supportive and enabling digital learning technology environment aimed at ensuring our students succeed in the modern world. This environment will enhance and extend student learning experiences through participation in a lively, innovative and scholarly community, both physically and online. Technology will be used to facilitate the engagement of students through their experience of:


1. Programmes of study designed to maximise the positive impact of technology on students’ critical engagement, motivation and creativity. Innovative digital technologies extending the impact of formally scheduled face to face contact by preparing, informing and framing the student’s learning and enquiry, enabled and enhanced in partnership with staff and other students; and


2. An efficient, seamless and professional service, administration and learning environment designed to support individual student’s engagement with their studies and ensure that students are able to focus their energy and attention on learning.


In the Victoria University Strategic Plan, the following areas highlight and champion technology enhanced learning:


Primary Strategy 3: Provide a holistic learning, teaching and student experience  that is second to none - The University’s research-enriched learning culture will be characterised by professional course and programme design that fosters a high level of student engagement, by excellent learning opportunities and facilities and by effective use of digital technologies for learning and teaching. Teaching practices will be inclusive and continually refreshed by attention to evolving methodologies and technologies.


Enabling Strategy 3: Optimise the University’s organisation, processes,  facilities and use of resources - Ongoing, carefully planned campus development and modernisation of equipment and information technology will enhance research, teaching, the student experience and administrative efficiency.

1.rationale:
Operational plans for support groups including CAD and ITS include clear and specific linkages to this strategy. Plans for investment in major capital works similarly are aligned to the Vision and Strategy for Digital Learning and Teaching at Victoria.

In 2014 the ITS Operational Plan refocused service delivery to be in line with the Strategic Plan.

This defined a shift from delivering traditional corporate IT services to the university to expanding its services to support the strategic goals of the university, specifically in the areas of research, teaching and learning and enhancing the student experience. The following graph illustrates the required shift in delivery:  

 

For Learning and Teaching this has led to a change in delivery model to working one on one with academics in the development of teaching and learning technology services and solutions in support of the digital vision strategy.

2.rationale: Specific budget proposal aligned to the process. Institutional lifecycles for ongoing investment and development of technology to support learning and teaching are in development. Lifecycle for Learning Spaces has been created and is being refined through experience in its application. Other lifecycles are planned for development including applications.

3.rationale:
The University does not have a unifying pedagogical framework that must be applied. The Vision and Strategy for Digital Learning and Teaching at Victoria emphasise that the role of technology at Victoria is primarily as an enhancement of a face to face education and that technology should be applied to this end. No specific requirements are imposed at either course or program level.


A series of support materials including case studies and pedagogical advice are in active development on the University Innovation Incubator (http://hub.vicinnovate.ac.nz/) and Digital Learning Hub (http://learning.vicinnovate.ac.nz/).

4.rationale:
The University does not have formal processes and systems relating to technology that must be applied in the design, development and delivery of learning.


A series of support materials including case studies and pedagogical advice are in active development on the University Innovation Incubator (http://hub.vicinnovate.ac.nz/) and Digital Learning Hub (http://learning.vicinnovate.ac.nz/). These are intended to be used by support staff and linked to systems where possible.

5.rationale: Vision and Strategy for Digital Learning and Teaching at Victoria Governance Group has been constituted and includes membership of both of the Vice-Provosts (Learning and Equity, and Research) as well as the Faculty Associate Deans with learning and teaching responsibility. Group has not yet commenced pending appointment of the AVC Digital Futures

6.rationale:
Victoria has in place a model “the Virtual CSU” with a shared responsibility for technology support between multiple groups including CAD, ITS, Campus Services, the Library and Student Learning.

This model is based on a high trust and engagement model of work which is not formalised into operational processes, but is clearly apparent particularly in the operational coordination between ITS and CAD. Most communication of the model is focused on ensuring supported staff know how to engage with support staff.

7.rationale: ITS has in place a formal project process for new investments and there are expectations made through the budget process. Application lifecycle has been identified but not yet promulgated.

0.rationale:
Through the Centre for Academic Development (CAD), Victoria provides both Peer and Student focused improvement and quality assurance processes for implementing and reflecting on the success of integrating technology into the learning experience for students. These processes include:

 

Student Teacher and Course Feedback process. Used for the post-review of courses including options for additional questions eveluating technology use: http://www.cad.vuw.ac.nz/wiki/index.php/Student_Feedback
Peer Observation between CAD staff and teachers for the observation, reflection and mentoring on technology use in class. Peer observation can also be attributed towards academic promotion: http://www.utdc.vuw.ac.nz/resources/guidelines/PeerObservation.pdf
Curriculum design support and consultation for learning outcome, activity and assessment change when planning the integration of technology into programmes or courses:  http://www.cad.vuw.ac.nz/wiki/index.php/Curriculum_redesign

A current project, the minimum course presence project, is defining the required level of online interaction by all courses at Victoria. An overview of the recommendations can be found in the new programme and course design handbook:  


http://www.victoria.ac.nz/documents/policy/governance/programme-and-course-design-handbook.pdf - Page 17, Section 3.9.


The application of these quality assurance processes for programmes is reactive and generally based on organisational, faculty or school based changes e.g. dependencies for multi-campus delivery or shift to full online offering. There is no cyclic programme review process around technology integration. At a course level, reactive requests from individual academics are common and based on engagement with professional development or a change in the mode of delivery of the course.

1.rationale:
Victoria University has multiple levels of governance over the evaluation, selection and implementation of learning technology. The level of governance is defined by the cost of implementation of the learning technology service.


For major investment ($100,000NZD and above) the evaluation and selection processes are defined by the University procurement policy:

http://www.victoria.ac.nz/documents/policy/facilities-management/procurement-policy.pdf


Before an open tender is released for a major learning technology project, requirements will be created and accepted by the following groups -


Final approval for release: University CAPEX Committee
Review of RFI: ITSOC (Information Technology Strategic Oversight Committee) This group is chaired by the COO and includes leadership membership from both the academic and professional arms of the university.     
Academic acceptance of requirements: DVOAG (Digital Vision Operational Advisory Group) This group is focused on the advancement of digital learning and teaching at Victoria. This group will soon be chaired by the AVC Digital Futures and includes membership from each Faculty and key support units.   
Creation of requirements: Academically focused requirements from cross disciplinary project teams and projects created by DVOAG and also from Faculty, Service Unit and individual academic projects.

All requests for information or pricing that are realeased via the open tender process will be distributed on the NZ Government eTendering Service (GETS): https://www.gets.govt.nz/ExternalIndex.htm


Major projects will then select pilot courses and programmes to trial learning technology before an enterprise roll out.


While these processes are defined by financial requirements, input into the functional requirements for the implementation of learning technology services are the responsibility of the DVOAG and Digital Vision strategy working group. This includes the discussion and review of services as they reach end of life.


This review and implementation of lifecycle processes are in the process of being developed to support the digital vision and also to enable technology decision making with core university learning, teaching and research strategies. The first of the lifecycles for physical space has been drafted:

 

While these evaluation and decision making groups enable some cohesion in technology enhanced learning services, there is still a level of autonomy within support units and faculty to fund and implement services based on their own needs and unit strategies.

2.rationale:
In response to the Digital Vision Strategy, ‘The Virtual CSU’ approach for planning improvement and support was developed to provide a shared responsibility approach across support units.


While developed for increasing academic support, the expertise in the leadership layer of the virtual csu has worked to focus on the quality improvement of technology enhanced learning systems (including physical and virtual learning environments), support and guidelines:

 

 


The Virtual CSU is made of staff from across multiple support units including CAD, ITS, LIbrary, Research Office. Planning and improvement initiatives developed by the Virtual CSU include:


Creation of the Digital Vision Strategic working group to plan and deliver on the key improvement action points within the digital vision strategy
Creation of the Organisational Development Steering group to plan and align university professional development
Development of lifecycles strategically highlighted in the Digital Vision. Physical space lifecycle is active when spaces are planned for upgrading with application and operating  environment lifecycles being planned
Planning of academic professional development as a cohesive programme across support units
Student Learning developing a student digital support strategy
A major programme of improvement is in place to improve student management systems and data integrity. This is an ongoing project called the Student Services Improvement Programme (SSIP)

While planning is being delivered across the organisation, delivery of planned improvements for academic staff and support units is still performed with a small increase in support resources over the last five years.


The SSIP programme is well funded and resourced for project management and delivery but leverages shared resources for technical delivery.


Another area limiting planning and implementation is lack of accountability and responsibility to implement planned outcomes across the organisation. There is still no drive to change, or be rewarded for change, at the individual academic, course or programme level.

3.rationale:
The are limited formal KPIs for technology enhanced learning environments. Current formal KPI’s agreed between service units are based on infrastructure, systems management and front end support targets. These KPI’s are visible within service level agreements. These KPI’s are used to identify improvement in infrastructure and support, but not the fundamental focus or outcomes of the service.

Service improvement and service planning are generally based around product roadmaps for specific learning and teaching services and infrastructure.


The Digital Vision working group are planning to create an application lifecycle for learning and teaching application services to match the current physical space lifecycle planning.

4.rationale:
Since the University appointed a new Chancellor and Vice Chancellor in the last two years, there has been an increase in the strategic importance and oversight in digital learning and research environments at Victoria. The term ‘Digital Victoria’ is now commonly used at SLT level to explain a desired future state. The importance of Digital Victoria has also been highlighted in the creation of a new Associate Vice-Chancellor Digital Futures role at Victoria to lead the shift to digital learning, teaching and research methodologies. This role is focused on understanding the impact and possibilities of the SLT portfolios and ensuring that data driven decision making on digital initiatives and change is presented to SLT in a meaningful manner.   


Due to this focus, reporting on the utilisation, implementation and successful use of digital learning services is now delivered to SLT and Council. The Digital Victoria report, ITS Quarterly operational reports and programme funding reports / requests are overseen by Council.  

Reports include the progress of strategic initiatives (such as the Digital Vision and eResearch Capability report), professional development targets, programme progress and operational targets, Organisational units also develop unit plans for delivery to SLT.


The increase of data and information to SLT and Council recently instigated a strategic statement on digital capability at Victoria drafted by the Vice-Chancellor. This instigated a council workshop where selected staff from across faculty and support units were invited to an open debate in regards to digital change.


At the mid-tier governance level, the Information Technology Strategic Oversight Committee (ITSOC) also receives and develops relevant reporting into university digital services.


While the importance of reporting into the progress of Digital Victoria is seen by Council, SLT and individual support units, there is still limited visibility of reporting into Faculty strategic groups such as Learning and Teaching Committees, Research Committees and Faculty Management Teams.

1.rationale: As with 4.1, there are examples where there is a clear pedagogical intent for the use of technology but these are still in the minority. Specific examples include programmes operated by SIM, Education and LALS.

2.rationale: Research evidence available through CAD websites and the HELT programme. CATS are increasingly able to draw on research evidence in their work as well. Set of case studies with strong research linkages are in preparation but are not yet widely available. Summaries have started to be published in VicNews on a monthly basis.

3.rationale: VicTeach is an excellent community that is clearly supporting the effective use of technology. While VicTeach is an excellent example, there are problems with cross campus engagement and bringing in new members into the community - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ie36XgkB8b0

4.rationale: Resources for CAD e-learning staff, CATS being expanded year over year, Teaching development grants. Issue is continuing to grow support in line with growing demand for it - ability to sustain the needs.

5.rationale: Projects typically have capital budgets but no operational allocation for support. Ongoing issues engaging with staff in advance of major deployments and changes. CATS are starting to address this but clearly room for improvement.

6.rationale: Evaluations typically only occur if individual staff are particularly engaged. Many staff discouraged from extensive evaluations as these are not valued under the PBRF.

1.rationale:
The student training for technology enhanced learning can be considered as inadequately resourced in terms of staff available to deliver training. Because different units of the university deliver different types of training, the availability of staff to deliver training varies widely. For example, Disability Services have a dedicated Adaptive Technology Specialist who is available full time to deliver 1-on-1 training for students with disability status.On the other hand, a Student Management Systems trainer is allocated to train the students for one week before trimester 1 starts, and 2 days before trimester 2 starts.


It should be noted, however, that the need for training may not always be considered high for some systems. The majority of students may not need in-depth training on the use of BlackBoard as the use of the different features of BlackBoard depends on which features the relevant course coordinators select for their courses. So an introductory training may be sufficient for most students, and some students may be able to make sense of the system without any training at all. However, the use of adaptive technology may require a more intensive training ranging from 1 hour of 1-on-1 training (for Read Write Gold, OpenBook and Kurzweill) to 10 hours of 1-on-1 training for Dragon Naturally Speaking.


Student Learning, another unit of the university, have a couple of staff who are able to assist students with the use of technology as needed. But the availability of training run by Student Learning is very much ad-hoc.


There are a number of self-help resources available for students to digest at their own time, but the availability of these are not always obvious. 0.evidence:
CSU has developed a Business Intelligence Strategy and a Learning Analytics Strategy.  The University has undertaken significant development with regard to its data warehousing and the reporting to stakeholders in Faculties and administrative divisions of accurate and timely learning and teaching data.  The Course Health Check dashboard has been a key initiative in this space and supports the University’s formal course/school review processes.  Other learning and teaching-related dashboards includes:

·         the Subject Experience Survey Dashboard – providing access to subject evaluation results for students and staff;

·         the Responsiveness to Students Dashboard – detailing performance on key learning and teaching standards; and

·         the Learning Technologies Dashboard – provide insights on the use of learning technologies across CSU.

 

The University has also developed a Priority Contact List – an analytics-enabled report on students “flagged” as at risk of attrition based on a predictive model built on extensive data mining processes.  The report is provided the University’s Student Outreach Team to enable targeted communication with students on the list.  Monitoring, evaluation and improvements processes with regard to the predictive model and associated student communication activities are in place.

 

CSU has also recently implemented Blackboard Analytics to provide a system for the collection and reporting of analytics from within its Learning Management System (LMS).  Blackboard Analytics provides a data warehouse for LMS analytics, with reports readily available to teaching staff in their subject sites and the capacity to develop bespoke reports/dashboards using Pyramid.  To date, bespoke dashboards developed by CSU include:

·         Educational Designers Dashboard; and

·         Faculty Admin Staff Dashboard.

 

CSU has established a data feed from the Blackboard Analytics warehouse to appropriate databases within the institution to facilitate future development.

 

CSU recently launched a Learning Analytics Code of Practice, which governs the use of Learning Analytics at the institution.  It is a formal policy of the University and is reflected in other key policies/processes (e.g. admissions, subject outlines, etc).
0.rationale:
We have progressed well in this field.

 

Opportunities:

 

The key gaps for CSU with regard to learning and educational analytics to support decision-making include:

1.       Establishment of processes and expectations around the use of analytics by teaching staff to support at-risk students

2.       Continued data integration and report development to support management of learning and teaching quality standards

3.       Continued enhancement of technology/data infrastructure to enable the integration of a wider array of learning analytics sources

4.       Ongoing training and organisational engagement activities to build capability and culture around the use of data/analytics in learning and teaching

1.evidence:
The responsibility for approval, funding and prioritisation of large scale technology implementations is centrally managed via the Initiatives and Strategy Implementation Plan (ISIP) and supporting processes.

 

The ISIP process calls for proposals for technology implementation projects to be made during publicised periods each year. The process includes a template outlining required proposal information along with guidelines on expectations of the content. Support is provided to proposers to assist them in their proposal development with particular focus on optimal alignment with strategy and in gathering accurate information for cost benefits analysis and implementation resource costing estimations.

 

Large scale technology implementation activities are managed as projects. A centralised Project Management Office provide and support a customised CSU project management framework which outlines the roles and responsibilities of project members and governance roles. The central team also provide key staffing roles to projects (e.g. Project Managers) to drive project execution.

 

The Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) framework is used as the foundation of the CSU change, incident and problem management processes used in the support of technology implementation and maintenance. Staff with roles relating to technology implementation are trained in the ITIL framework, a governing group is in place to consider change proposals and gateways and checkpoints are in place to ensure appropriate review of incoming changes.

 

Key documents:

•             How DIT Practices ITIL

•             Change Management User Guide

•             Change Management – LANDesk Process

•             Project Management methodology

•             ISIP Process

•             ISIP Governance Committee Terms of Reference
1.rationale:
A range of the activities below.

 

Opportunities:

 

While the processes for implementation of learning technologies is, on the whole, quite well defined there are nonetheless some gaps in the definition of responsibilities of the various stakeholders.

 

Improvements could be made in defining the responsibilities of stakeholders in managing technology once it has been implemented and in particular, in regards to forward planning of technologies. Some work has been done to define the key roles (e.g. application custodian) but these aren’t well understood across the organisation and could benefit from greater specificity and socialisation.

 

In conjunction with the above there would be benefit in further developing and communicating the process for maintenance of technologies. These processes are defined and are operating effectively but they are not well documented and haven’t been broadly socialised beyond core stakeholders of the ISIP processes.

2.evidence: Consistent with the institution’s Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) framework, for all learning technologies a system custodian is nominated.  The custodian’s role is to manage (including monitoring, responding to and evaluating): a) performance of the technology, b) user support/training (including help resources), and c) upgrades.  The custodian may manage staff who deliver user support services or may manage support arrangements via the relevant vendor or another part of University.  The custodian has responsibility for the development, maintenance and delivery of support/training processes, programs and resources, including the professional development of staff and student-facing support staff.  The latter includes the provision of Knowledge Base Articles and other documentation that address key issues and escalation processes.  For example, to support Service Desk operations, the Division of Information Technology (DIT) and Division of Student Learning (DSL) maintain a register of learning technologies which identifies over 100 inquiry categories, provides guidance for response and/or escalation (including identifying responsible individuals), and defines the response/resolution timeframe.
2.rationale:
Doing a comprehensive set of activities in this dimension.

 

Opportunities:

 

An issue for CSU is the “decentralised” management of support processes.  That is, different custodians may implement differing approaches to user support/training – for example, some may require users to formally log requests via one of the University’s two service request systems, while others prioritise a support email account (which may or may not have formal procedures/requirements for monitoring and response timelines) and/or other mechanisms (e.g. personal email account).  The same variability in approaches/processes can apply to the training provided for staff and students. Furthermore, support and training process may operate with little formal evaluation/review, or with evaluation/review processes that only address responsiveness to support requests once they enter a formal service request systems (which may not reflect the totality of support needs).

 

There may be an opportunity for CSU to:

·         create a formal register of the support and training arrangements for each institutionally-support learning technology (with a view to co-ordinating arrangements), including:

o   custodian;

o   support access points (where/how staff and students can access help);

o   request management processes (e.g. roles/responsibilities, escalation processes, timeframes, etc);

3.rationale:
On the whole, resource allocation for technology implementation and maintenance is well handled at CSU.

 

Opportunities:

An area where some gap exists is in the planning of application maintenance. The ISIP Backlog Maintenance process is a good first step towards improving this area but it is not yet fully articulated and/or broadly communicated.

 

A second area of opportunity is in having firmer processes for ensuring the appropriate prioritisation of BAU activity. It can be a challenge to resource BAU work when it is competing against larger, often centrally funded, activities. While it is not always as obviously aligned with strategy as large activities, the continuous improvement of technology services through BAU work is an important maintenance requirement.
3.evidence:
Large scale technology implementations are resourced through the ISIP processes wherein an annual budget is allocated for ISIP approved activities. The ISIP Governance Committee, a cross-organisational group of senior divisional and faculty staff, approves financial allocations from the ISIP budget. The extent of the budget varies each year but will typically be sufficient to support a small number of 1-3 large projects (greater 12 months implementation time) and 5-10 medium to small projects in a given year.

 

Medium scale (4 weeks to 6 months implementation time) technology implementation activities occur through the ICT Significant Work Register (ICT-SWR). The work of the ICT-SWR is typically funded by IT budgets and approvals are governed by a committee of relevant IT stakeholders. The committee meets fortnightly and a process and supporting artefacts (e.g. proposal template) exist to support submissions. 

 

The allocation of human resources to key project team roles is centrally managed. A Resource Analyst within IT is responsible for receiving requests from project managers and for facilitating the allocation of resources. The allocations are governed by a stakeholder group from IT.

 

Outside of ISIP substantive sectional budgets can also be used to support technology implementation. Activities that are funded in this way are typically managed using the standard CSU project methodology but are resourced from outside the ISIP funding pool.

 

Smaller scale technology implementations and maintenance (<4 weeks) is classed as business as usual (BAU) activity and is resourced from within divisional (predominantly DIT) budgets. Prioritisation of BAU work is done by relevant line managers within the divisions.

 

The timely execution of application maintenance is the responsibility of the Application Custodian. The Custodian works with the Division of IT and/or the external vendor to plan for application updates and upgrades and for ensuring use of the appropriate delivery channel (e.g. ISIP or ICT-SWR etc.) to secure funding, access to necessary resources and to manage risk (e.g. technical dependencies).

 

The ISIP process currently includes a mechanism for dedicating between 10-15% from the funding pool for allocation towards exceptional maintenance activities. Activities that are funded from this allocation are typically high risk and/or high complexity changes and often involve multiple key stakeholder groups. Proposals for use of the maintenance funding are made to the ISIP Governance Committee from DIT based on analysis of the age and health of applications across the portfolio.

 

Key documents:

•             Initiatives and Strategy Implementation Plan (ISIP)

•             ICT Significant Works Register (ICT-SWR)

•             Resource request and prioritisation processes used in the CSU project methodology

•             Budgeting process

4.evidence:
The core processes for proposing and funding technology investigation and implementation exist within the ISIP processes but these are generally focused on larger scale implementations of relatively well known technologies used in support of core business processes.

 

Academic and general staff are encouraged to consider innovative use of new and experimental learning technologies within the university, however, outside of the ISIP context there is limited access to resources (both human and financial) to support this. The processes for securing resources to support technology experimentation aren’t clear.

 

The area where technology experimentation has been most successful is uImagine, a group with a core mandate and accompany budget to work in identifying and supporting innovation in learning and learning technologies. The uImagine grant process is clearly defined and has been successful in driving experimentation with a number of new technologies. The uImagine budget is, however, limited when compared to the overall university spend on technology and as such resources are, on average, relatively scarce.

 

Support of those activities that are successful in securing experimentation funding will occurs through the Approval of New Learning Technologies Policy that is being developed. This policy outlines a support process to provide a pathway from experimentation through to implementation and provides guidance on support and risk management strategies applicable during experimentation periods.

 

The External Educational Technologies Policy also supports experimentation with learning technologies. This policy provides guidance on the use of external (i.e. not managed or controlled by CSU) technologies. Successful trials and pilots of external educational technologies feed their outcomes into the Approval of New Learning Technologies processes or ISIP processes for larger scale (i.e. post pilot) implementation.

 

Key documents:

•             uImagine grant process

•             External Educational Technologies Policy

•             Approval of New Learning Technologies Policy (Draft)
4.rationale:
Doing average re new and emerging technologies.

 

Opportunities:

 

While the university is supportive of experimentation with learning technologies there are, in reality, insufficient resources available to faculties and divisions to do so outside of specialised vehicles such as uImagine.

 

With funding it could be possible to direct effort towards identifying means of supporting additional technology experimentation across the organisation more broadly. For example additional funding might allow staff a small time allocation to be quarantined for experimentation with technology.

5.evidence:
For new and emerging technologies, the training of the system custodian and key technical staff is an essential part of the release management and must be reflected in the implementation plan.  Professional development (PD) is typically delivered by the vendor/systems provider to the custodian/systems staff in the first instance and then cascaded as appropriate to others who play a role in supporting the application of the technology (e.g. Educational Designers and Educational Support Co-ordinators, Student Central staff, DIT Service Desk staff, etc).  This “second-level” PD may be delivered by the vendor or the CSU system custodian and can consist of formal training through to the simple provision of Knowledge Base Articles or other documentation.  Requirements for all new technologies include the provision of training/user resources, such as manuals, how-to videos, etc, to underpin initial training activities.

 

Once a technology has transitioned into standard operating mode, PD occurs at the request/initiation of the custodian – typically related to a) upgrades, b) new user groups to support (i.e. new use cases), and/or c) exploration of new functionality/new ways of using the system.  Such PD may range from informal discussions with the vendor and knowledge sharing via user groups through to vendor conferences, webinars and/or structured training programs.  Budget can often be a constraint upon access to PD for system custodians.

 

For new system support staff working with existing core services, PD is generally delivered via “shadowing” of and coaching from the existing custodian/technical support staff, and reference to relevant system documentation and resources.
5.rationale:
Doing average in this area.

Opportunities:

 

As mentioned under Performance Measure 3, the creation of a formal register of learning technology support processes that includes identification of PD needs for systems support staff may enhance the PD practices in this space by providing visibility and accountability for the maintenance and enhancement of skills among such staff.

6.evidence:
A centralised Risk Management Framework and associated Risk Management Policy drive the risk management processes and procedures at CSU. The framework outlines risk management governance arrangements, planning requirements and provides guidance on the execution of risk management practices.

 

The Risk Management Policy requires an annual (or better) Strategic Risk Assessment be conducted by the University Auditor. Each section of the university is required to maintain a risk register that is annually reviewed. The risk register is required to include a Business Continuity (BC) Plan. The Risk Registers and BC Plans are centrally stored in a secure Section Planning Portal.

 

Technology implementation projects are required to adhere to risk management practices and to develop and maintain a risk register during execution. Projects are required to consider the service availability and recovery times necessary to support business continuity requirements. A list of agreed service response times is centrally maintained.

 

A Critical Incident Review (CIR) process is defined to provide a structured means of assessing high impact technology failures in order to inform risk management practices and requirements.

 

An IT Security Policy document is in final draft form and will be submitted to the senior executive staff for approval in the coming weeks. This policy

 

Key documents:

•             Risk Management Framework

•             Risk Management Policy

•             Strategy Risk Assessment

•             Section Planning Portal (Restricted Access)

•             Critical Incident Review (CIR) Process

•             IT Service Recovery and Availability Register

•             Security Policy (Draft)
6.rationale:
Doing average re communication of risk processes.

 

Opportunities:

The university has quite a rigorous and comprehensive approach to risk management. A top-down approach has been instilled which clearly denotes the responsibilities across the organisation and regular audits and reporting ensure ongoing compliance with requirements. However, this information isn’t well known across all areas of the organisation.

 

 

 

The average rating for this indicator across stakeholders was “moderate” with most individuals being able to cite an element of risk management they were involved in. The bulk of the evidence on the full extent of risk management process that is in place was received from a small number of senior staff, and more specifically those with nominated responsibilities for risk management.

 

An opportunity exists to more broadly communicate the Risk Framework and Risk Management Policy to give a broader cross-section of the organisation improved awareness of the processes and responsibilities that exist.

7.evidence:
Support for all learning technologies may be accessed via the Division of Student Learning (DSL) Service Request System and/or the Division of Information Technology (DIT) Service Desk, with underlying processes generally enabling the efficient assignment of service requests to the appropriate custodian.  Thus, at one level, staff only need to know that the efficient pathway for assistance is via the respective service desks.

 

However, while the existence of the service desks is communicated, this is problematised by a range of factors that act as deterrents to the use of the service desks:

·         a comparatively low-level of communication on the DSL Service Request System compared with the DIT Service Desk, and little communication on the relationship of the two service desks.  The latter can create confusion around where to “log a request”. Indeed, some help resources for DSL-supported learning technologies direct staff to the DIT Service Desk or prioritise other support email addresses.  The DSL Learning Technologies website identifies 7 channels via which staff may access support for learning technologies. This all adds to the potential for confusion and/or lack of awareness of the DSL Service Request System;

·         existing patterns of behavior, where staff would go direct to a particular custodian/systems support person, leading to a less than 100% awareness of role/availability of the service desks (e.g. staff don’t engage with communications because they have their own way of getting what they need … until arrangements change).  Thus, the importance for staff to use the service desks is a message that could be better sold; and

·         lack of familiarity with the service request systems and/or not being clear how to “log a request” to get it to the right support person.  Recent staff surveys reveal this is particularly true for sessional academics.

 

All learning technologies also provide access to “in place” help.  That is, links within the technology to help resources.  Such resources may be (generic) vendor provided or, preferably, tailored CSU resources which also include links to appropriate service request systems.  CSU’s LMS (Interact2) and the assessment submission/return system (EASTS) are examples where extensive tailored “in place” resources are provided.
7.rationale:
Doing well re communicating opportunities for assistance.

 

Opportunities:

 

The Division of Student Learning is in the process of upgrading its Service Request System (to reflect an expansion and redefining of the services it covers), which will be implemented along with increased communication, improved accessibility (e.g. desktop icon on CSU computers), and improved help resources for users.  It will be critical for communications to clearly define the role of each service system (DSL vs DIT).  Activity and stakeholder feedback should be monitored.

The Division of Student Learning (DSL) works in partnership with faculties and schools to enhance the quality of student learning at CSU. DSL staff work with Schools and Faculties to design curricula and to develop effective online resources for blended and flexible learning environments. DSL is guided by the Curriculum, Learning and Teaching Framework within the context of the CSU Strategic Plan. These provide frameworks in which to promote excellence within the CSU degrees.

 

The Curriculum Learning and Teaching Framework (CLT Framework)
The framework illustrates how strategy and policy support the three elements of curriculum, learning and teaching come together to produce CSU Graduates. It demonstrates how the large amount of change we are under-going at CSU works together to supports our primary goal of graduating capable professionals.

 

Curriculum, Learning and Teaching sub plan 2015  

The Curriculum, Learning & Teaching Sub-Plan has set in place outcomes to be achieved from the Curriculum Learning & Teaching Framework.  The CLT sub-plan has as a stated outcome that CSU will be the national leader in the provision of high quality online learning and as such has a number of strategies/priorities to achieve this.

 

CLT Sub-Plan Outcomes

·         OC1 - Significant improvements in course and teaching quality and delivery as well as enhanced student engagement

·         OC3 - The national leader in the provision of high quality online learning

 

Outputs

·         Destination 2020: A Road Map for CSU's Online Future  (Distance Education Strategy)

Distance Education Strategy outlines a strategic vision for CSU to develop a distinctive model of online learning with student engagement, connectedness and workplace learning at the core.

 

·         The CSU Online Learning and Teaching Model

CSU Online Learning & Teaching Model was developed to foster engagement, connectedness and student interaction as these elements collectively contribute to improved teaching and learning processes and outcomes. The intention is to engender a holistic student experience, including achievement of discipline specific graduate outcomes as well as broader social and emotional development.

 

·         CSU Quality Learning & Teaching Standards

CSU quality learning & teaching standards were developed as an outcome of the Curriculum, Learning and Teaching Framework in achieving significant improvements in course and teaching quality

 

Educational Frameworks and Plans grounded in CSU Strategic Plan and CLT Framework

CSU Learning Technologies Framework

The CSU Learning Technology Framework guides the governance, policy and practice needs for learning technology at Charles Sturt University (CSU) and defines the provision, use and application of learning technology at CSU. The Framework provides a structure through which planning and goal-setting will occur to guide future development; that is, it aims to provide a strategic and operational pathway for development to follow.

 

The Framework aligns with the CSU Strategy and the University plans including the Curriculum, Learning and Teaching Plan. The organisational design of CSU needs to support and respond to the key tenets of the Framework, for instance in the formulation of position descriptions and the way that work is organised.

 

The CSU Learning Technologies Plan

The CSU Learning Technologies Plan embodies from 2015 to 2016 the principles espoused in the CSU Learning Technologies Framework. The Plan aligns with the Strategy Reload and the University plans especially the Curriculum, Learning and Teaching Plan.  The Plan is revised annually and covers a two year period. Policy is reviewed and appropriate resources allocated to ensure that the key tenets of the Framework are implemented through the Plan. The plan further reflects the funding decisions of the Initiatives and Strategy Implementation Plan (ISIP).

 

Learning technologies plan (2016) aims to support the following key university developments and initiatives:

·         The service improvement program and common support model;

·         CSU has fully transferred to Interact2 in 2015;

·         New course design processes are being rolled out;

·         Institution-wide approaches to Adaptive Learning and Teaching (data-informed practice, personalised support and personalised learning) are required;

·         Indigenous education strategy;

·         Transitions project;

·         Student success as per the Student Experience Program and aspiring to the Student Experience Project Objectives;

·         Professional and Practice-Based Education Model;

·         The Curriculum Renewal/Degree Initiative includes course mapping software, digital object management systems (DOMS) strategy for digital learning objects, ePortfolios, Assessment tools, interactive resources and collaboration technologies;

·         The CSU Learning Analytics Model, including the mapping of the drivers of student success with respect to learning environments;

·         Increased accessibility in regional areas, for students with low socioeconomic status (LSES), and general accessibility.

 

CSU Course Design Process

Course Design at CSU is a collaborative process between Course Directors, their course teams and the Division of Student Learning. Whether a course or degree is brand new or selected for review, the design process follows a standardised, university-wide, phased process.

 

The Curriculum, Learning and Teaching Sub Plan commits the Faculties and the Division of Student Learning to completing the design and implementation phases of Smart Learning.  The Smart Learning Course Design Team has been working closely with the Course Directors to guide them through the process and the Learning Design Unit has allocated extra Educational Designer time to meet these goals. 

The design process is enabled and supported by the bespoke software developed at CSU, CourseSpace. Course teams use the software to design and record their decisions and specifications of course, subject, assessment and module design. Integrated into the course design process is the philosophy of online by design. The course design process aligns with the first element of the Curriculum, Learning and Teaching Framework, Degrees designed for graduate outcomes.

This Framework guides the governance, policy and practice needs for learning technology at Charles Sturt University (CSU) and defines the provision, use and application of learning technology at CSU. External Educational Technologies for Learning and Teaching Guidelines
This document describes Charles Sturt University's guidelines for the use of External Educational Technologies (EETs) for learning and teaching in the context of existing University policies and principles. They are informed by the External Educational Technologies Policy and include advice and helpful hints for staff on the effective use of EETs in learning and teaching to minimise risks and ensure that students will have a positive learning experience. The Guidelines expand on the common-sense Social Media Guidelines or generic online activities.

 

UImagine OLM

The Online Learning and Teaching Model is underpinned by Moore’s (1989) model of Distance Education engagement and the key interactive elements of engaged student learning which incorporates learner-teacher, learner-learner and learner-content interaction. One element that of teacher presence or learner-teacher interactivity has also been identified and highlighted as effective by many authors including Chickering, & Gamson (1987) in the seven principles that can help to improve undergraduate education. Garrison, and Anderson & Archer (2000) also have identified teacher presence in their conceptual framework of elements that are crucial prerequisites for a successful higher educational experience.  It is recognised that 30 years of empirical research has consistently shown that high levels of engagement result in improved learning experiences.

 

 

Pedagogy project

A large number of resources that provide pedagogical application of technology enhanced learning guidelines and video tutorials are available on this website.  These guides are based on sound educational research are available to all staff on the CSU Interact2 website, including:

 

Teaching with Interact2 for the first time? This ten-page pdf guide summarises considerations relating to:
-accessing and finding your way around Interact2
-preparing subject sites, including the Subject Outline
-a start of semester checklist

Learning Academy

The Learning Academy promotes academic development, reward and recognition for teaching, peer review of educational practice, scholarship of teaching and learning, educational leadership development, and plays a key role in supporting the implementation of the CSU Institutional Cultural Competency Program.

 

Graduate Certificate in Learning & Teaching in Higher Education
The Graduate Certificate in Learning and Teaching in Higher Education offers a formal qualification in learning and teaching in higher education that will provide opportunities to strengthen learning and teaching theory and practice. This course is only available to academic staff of Charles Sturt University.

Participants in the course will engage in critical examination of their roles and responsibilities in view of issues confronting learning and teaching in higher education nationally and internationally, their disciplines and professional practice. These include issues of particular relevance to learning and teaching at CSU such as blended and flexible learning, and professional and practice-based education.
Graduates will demonstrate a commitment to continuous improvement in tertiary learning and teaching and a deep level of knowledge, understanding and integration into their practice of:

·         issues confronting learning and teaching at their organisation including its location and student intake, approach to learning and teaching, institutional strategy, curriculum principles and good practice guidelines

·         issues confronting learning and teaching in higher education in light of contemporary research in the area, their perspectives on learning and teaching, and discipline and professional practice based imperatives

·         professional and practice based education and the integration of PBE principles into course and subject design and development processes

·         pedagogical content knowledge and educational technology affordances in the development of their scholarship in learning and teaching.

 

Learning &Teaching standards

The Learning & Teaching standards provide guidelines for teaching staff in the delivery of subjects and include the incorporation of a landing page in subject sites, provisioning of subject outlines 14 days prior to the commencement of each session, adherence to Faculty policies for exams, marks and grades, cancellation of classes and inclusion of elements of the OLM.

 

Australian Qualification Framework (AQF)

An essential consideration during course mapping and analysis is the The Australian Qualifications Framework (AQF). The AQF is the national policy for regulated qualifications in Australian education and training. It incorporates the qualifications from each education and training sector into a single comprehensive national qualifications framework.

The AQF is a key national policy instrument. Implementation of the AQF requirements commenced on 1 July 2011. All AQF requirements were to be met from 1 January 2015.

For each level of award (Diploma, Associate Degree, Degree) the AQF defines:

·         Purpose

·         Knowledge

·         Skills application and knowledge of skills

·         Volume of learning

·         Learning and Teaching Academic Standards

In 2010 the Australian Government charged the ALTC in the facilitation and the coordination of discipline communities' definition of academic standards as the higher education sector prepared for the new regulatory environment of the Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency (TEQSA). These standards were developed as part of a demonstration project funded by the Australian Government in 2010 and facilitated by the Australian Learning and Teaching Council. Academic institutions and teachers, professional bodies, accreditation bodies, employers and graduates participated in the development of minimum threshold learning outcomes for the discipline.

 

CSU Website Accessibility Guidelines

Charles Sturt University is committed to providing timely, accurate and accessible administrative and online learning environment resources to all students, regardless of age, ethnicity or disability.

The aim of these guidelines is to:

·         Ensure staff and students with a disability have equal access to CSU website and learning environment resources.

·         Ensure the University meets it’s legal and moral requirements regarding accessibility for people with a disability.

Compliance is an ongoing initiative at CSU and subject to continual improvement and feedback. Some of the material accessed through the CSU website is third party content and the University cannot guarantee that every page will be accessibly to students or staff with a disability. The University will, however, ensure CSU staff are aware of the need to select materials that are accessible and assist users to get access to alternate accessible versions when required.

 

External Educational Technologies for Learning and Teaching Guidelines and Policy

This document describes Charles Sturt University's guidelines for the use of External Educational Technologies (EETs) for learning and teaching in the context of existing policies and principles of Charles Sturt University (the University). They are informed by the External Educational Technologies for Learning and Teaching Policy and include advice and helpful hints for staff on the effective use of EETs in learning and teaching to minimise risks and ensure that students will have a positive learning experience.

CSUED conference

CSUEd conference is the CSU’s internal learning and teaching conference. The purpose of this conference is not only to show and tell but also to observe and listen. Together, this will lead to forming and strengthening networks and alliances across disciplines, faculties and campuses.

 

In keeping with CSU's Strategic Plan to provide quality online learning experiences and strive to be the national leader in the provision of high quality professional and practice based education, the 2015 CSUED conference had online teaching and learning as one of its key themes.

 

The online teaching and learning theme examined existing and emerging best practices, policies and pedagogies for sustaining high quality online teaching and learning. Drawing upon the collective work of CSU's CTL, QLT and the CSU learning and teaching models, this theme focused on a broad range of topics to support online teaching and learning.

·         Training/professional development for academic staff, sessional staff, and students

·         Learning design, eAssessment

·         Small group strategies

·         Innovative learning resources

·         Teacher presence

·         Baseline quality indicators

·         Tutors and online moderator skills

·         Student and academic staff support

·         Interaction strategies

·         Alternative workload models for online teaching

·         Simulations and role plays for work-place learning

·         Academic policies, and

·         Use of learning analytics ('Big Data'), and

·         Marketing online courses.

 

Learning Technology forum

Learning Technology Forums are a joint initiative of the Learning Technology Unit and uImagine within the Division of Student Learning. The Forums are held quarterly via video conference across most campuses. The Forums run for 90 minutes and focus on a particular topic related to the use of technologies to support Online, On Campus or Blended Learning and consist of a series of presentations of approximately 15 minutes duration. Presentations, generally by academic or educational support staff, consist of innovative ideas, showcases of learning environments or resources, or reports and reflections on teaching or learning design practice. Presentation slides are made available online through the wikis in the “About Learning Technologies” Interact2 site.

5.evidence:
Centralized LDU support, Service Request System.

The Learning Design Unit currently has a dispersed organisational structure in that many staff including Educational Designers are situated in the Schools.   This model has allowed teaching staff to access the Unit’s services ad hoc, with staff responding to each request.  In 2015, CSU began a process to restructure to, amongst other things, address the university’s market position with concerted efforts to lift enrolments and reduce attrition rates.  It was decided that the university needed to address priority courses and that Learning Design support needed to be more targeted and concentrated. To achieve this, faculty priorities will be supported by two functional teams, a Design Team and a Delivery Team. The Design Team will work with course and subject reviews and projects that address enhancements relating to assessment and online learning innovations. The Delivery team will respond to requests by academics who are teaching. This model of providing ‘just in time’ support using the Division’s Service Request System will allow for more targeted, equitable support for staff who are teaching.

 

Faculty priorities for course and subject review are in line with Curriculum Learning & Teaching sub plan;

 

Pedagogy Templates - pedagogy templates for use by teaching staff (see section 4.3);

 

CSU Learning & Teaching website supports staff by providing comprehensive resources to support the use of technology in learning & teaching.

 

Ongoing Educational Technology support

Rollout of new systems within CSU including Interact2, Adobe Connect and ePortfolio are well supported by both DSL & DIT staff.  Resources are developed that support technical aspects of using the tools with ongoing professional development to support use within learning & teaching.

Online showcase of innovative online learning practices to complement showcase of workplace learning practices at CSU
 

DSL work focusses CSU Curriculum, fostering the CSU signature delivery methods of Practice Based Education, Online Learning and alignment to our Indigenous Education Strategy, assuring best practice in assessment of student work, and their evaluation of our work (via implementation of Student Evaluation Surveys)

Student experience surveys

Evaluating learning and teaching is a key part of enhancing student learning. Seeking and acting upon feedback from students can enable us to better adapt to student learning and students' needs.

To enable such adaptation, our evaluation tools need to be focused on the key elements of the learning process that i) greatly impact on student learning and ii) are within the control of teaching staff to address.  To this end, CSU has developed a Subject Experience Survey (SES) as our tool for formal subject evaluations.

 

The SES gathers feedback on aspects of learning design and delivery that have been shown to be influential on student success, including:

·         Clear learning outcomes aligned to assessment tasks and learning experiences

·         Engaging learning experiences: Assessment tasks and supportive learning activities assist learning

·         Opportunity for collaborative learning experiences

·         Currency of knowledge and skills development

·         Learning enhanced by technology

·         Timely and useful feedback provided

·         Students develop the ability to judge the quality of their own work against standards

·         Visible connection of subject and course(s)

·         Appropriate Workloads (CSU Subject Workload requirements 140-160 hours for all activities per 8 points)

 

 

Smart Learning course design

Smart Learning course design ensures data is gathered to inform the review process including student surveys (See section 4.1).

 

Course Level Surveys /Planning and Audit
Course Performance dashboard provides data on the performance of courses at CSU. The reports cover enrolments, load, progress and attrition, as well as the outcomes of the various quality and engagement related surveys such as the Graduate Destinations, Student Experience Survey and Course Experience Questionnaire.

7.rationale: Evidence of the impact of technology enhanced learning is integrated into continuous improvement planning for courses and programs. It is apparent, but not in a consistent way.
7.evidence:
Analytics & evaluations
CSU is committed to enhancing learning and teaching through the use of data and analytics, such as:

·         student feedback and evaluations;

·         learning analytics;

·         educational intelligence - the analysis of data about learning and teaching practices and standards; and

·         surveying of academic staff on learning and teaching matters.

 

Diverse data and analytics is brought together to improve student learning through the frame of Adaptive Learning and Teaching.

 

Adaptive Learning and Teaching is comprised of three elements:

1.       Personalised learning - using analytics-based technologies to personalise or differentiate learning experiences.

2.       Personalised support - using analytics to support student learning in targeted ways through evidence-based interventions and feedback.

3.       Data-informed practice - using learning and teaching data to inform decision-making, reflective practice in teaching and design, and management of quality standards.

 

An Adaptive Learning and Teaching Community of Practice has been established to support CSU staff seeking to employ or research personalised learning and support, and data-informed practice.

 

Learning Technologies Dashboard

 

This dashboard shows a variety of analytics on some of the learning technologies in use at CSU.

The analytics shown in the dashboard include:

·         Top 5 Web Browsers used to access Interact2

·         Percentage of Desktop, Mobile and Tablet

·         Accesses to Interact2

·         Average Interact2 Session Time and Page Views by Device Type

·         Heatmaps showing when students access Interact2 Subject Sites and CSU Replay

·         Heatmaps showing when staff and students log in to Online Meeting [Adobe Connect] Meetings

·         Unique users of mobile devices within Online Meeting [Adobe Connect]

·         CSU Replay Recordings Methods

·         PRIMO Sessions by Month (PRIMO is the library's search tool)

 

 

 

Academic Compass

Academic Compass is an ongoing program of surveys to explore the needs, expectations and perceptions of CSU's academic staff.  Universities often focus on conducting surveys about their academics. Academic Compass seeks to redress this by providing a survey of academics about issues important to academic practice. The Compass aims to provide a mapping of current issues related to academic practice, in particular learning and teaching, and point the way forward as CSU charts new directions. Results from Academic Compass are provided back to our academic community to spark discussion and debate.  Summary reports from previous surveys are available to all staff.

·         Blackboard features and tools in Interact2 Survey (August 2015)

·         Promotions Survey (July 2015)

·         Learning Environments (virtual spaces) Survey (October 2014)

·         Learning Environments (physical spaces) Survey (October 2014)

·         Student EdTech Survey (September 2014)

 

 

Student EdTech Survey (September 2014)

The Division of Student Learning’s Education Technology Survey explores access, usage and experiences around educational technology among CSU students. The University seeks to better understand how students use technology especially in educational settings. The feedback gained through this survey enables the University to more effectively meet the diverse and changing needs of its students. The report form the survey is available to all staff and is promoted and was run in 2010, 2014 and 2016

 

The Pulse

The Pulse provides a picture of what is happening within CSU with regard to learning technologies and analytics to enhance our knowledge, challenge our thinking and stimulate conversation about the use of technology/analytics in learning and teaching.  The Pulse is published three times a year and each edition explores a particular theme. The statistics and analytics are drawn from a range of sources within CSU including systems reports, surveys and case studies. Trends in Learning Technologies and use of Learning Analytics outside CSU are also highlighted.

 

Smart Learning course design ensures data is gathered to inform the review process including student surveys (See section 4.1).

 

QLT Audit & Initiative

Faculty based, QLT Assessment and Online leads conducted audited subjects and highlighted the need for improvement in engagement in online environment and uptake of the Graduate learning outcomes as identified in subject learning outcomes. These audits have been used to inform priority courses and subjects requiring assistance in 2016.

8.rationale:
There is evidence of examples to support the pedagogical use of technology but apparent only in limited cases on program level.

 

Overall:

 

Initial recommendations for improvement

The followed areas have been identified for improvement;

4.3 The pedagogical application of technology enhanced learning is based on sound educational research and guidelines (including compliance with legal requirements, accessibility, and learning designs) are readily available to all teaching and support staff.

 

The OLM has filled a gap in good practice and as this initiative rolls out across the University a large number of courses/programs will adhere to the research based model. Another gap identified are learning designs. Examples of pedagogically sound learning designs are currently not available at CSU.

 

The following learning design resources are currently in development:

·         active lecture,

·         problem based learning,

·         scenario based learning

·         cooperative learning, and

·         ePortfolios and reflective practice.

 

The development of these learning design resources will encourage the use of research informed teaching practice and allow teaching staff to easily re-use the learning designs in subjects via the use of import/export function in Interact2.

 

Accessibility

Guidelines for the design of Interact2 sites are not readily available and is not evident that any guidelines are followed in design of subjects.

 

4.7.
The pedagogical impact of technology enhanced learning services is regularly evaluated in detail at a course and program level.

The Learning Design unit has been re-focused and rather than school/Faculty based model our emphasis is now on course design model. This new service model will need to be evaluated.

4.9.
Good practice examples advance the pedagogically sound use of technology enhanced learning services in courses and programs.  

Examples of good practice and showcases have been developed to share practice at CSU but a repository that teaching staff could access to provide examples of best practice could be developed.

·         Learning Technology Forums provide an opportunity for academic and sessional teaching staff to share knowledge and practice within courses/programs. These events are held 4 times per year with various sessions targeting specific key themes.

We look at keyword search terms being used by our students, and incorporate these into our FAQ metadata to increase search result relevance.

The Learning Technologies Unit manages the university's online learning environments and provides leadership and support across the university in relation to learning technologies.

  1. Leads the review, selection, implementation and integration of learning technologies, including adaptive learning and teaching systems, in line with research on international, national and local developments.
  2. Develops and contributes to relevant University policies, plans and committees, and builds partnerships, to support the appropriate implementation and use of learning technologies and analytics from a holistic perspective.
  3. Contributes to the professional learning, uptake, appropriate use and support of learning technologies and analytics by teaching staff.
  4. Leads the development and implementation of evidence-based solutions to enable scalable personalised learning and support.
  5. Manages and develops learning technologies that DSL supports.
  6. Leads the appropriate design of virtual, physical and mobile learning environments.
56e23d002761400d3e2716be:

Implementation of an online learning model focused on delivering better online student experiences across a range of key focus areas such as Teacher Presence, Flexible and Adapting Learning and Interactions between students.

Process improvement related to moderation of assessment and ensuring that assessment and marking is performed to agreed standards determined by discipline lead teams.
56e23d002761400d3e2716bf:
Greater engagement with distance students in an online environment, our online learning model seeks to increase student satisfaction when studying from a distance and make their study experiences as rich as if they were to study internally.

Requirements for learning technologies suited to a very diverse discipline portfolio such as CSU is a challenge that we are addressing through greater support for faculty and school led technology initiatives. This is supported by a new policy and process related to new learning technology introduction.

Greater support for workplace learning and associated learning initiatives is a key challenge that we are faced with. This involves ensuring that student progress is correctly tracked and that outside parties (such as those that assess students in a workplace) can interface with technologies in a way that is not an imposition to their work.

    • USQ’s vision includes ‘leadership in physical and digital higher education learning experiences geared to a diverse student constituency’ and education objectives which include, ‘Deploy learning environments that are student-centred, authentic, cooperative and engaging; and supported by an extended range of high quality resources, facilities and technologies.

1.rationale:
There appears to be a strategic alignment with a number of specific plans from the Academic, and Academic Services Divisions to enhance the quality of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL). However, anecdotal evidence suggests they are not well understood by coal face academic staff, not easy to locate or identify.

Relevant strategies include the continued streamlining of virtual learning environments, support for students’ ICT literacies and StudyDesk support for staff and students.

Under the Strategic Plan, the Educational Experience Plan (EEP) is designed to be aspirational, with what we are becoming, communicating important commitments, sparking the imagination, and leading the USQ community to important and practical investments in our educational experience.

Operational Plans encompass ORMP, ICT Strategy/Portfolio of projects and the Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap, all aligning to the strategy. The budget and project process attempts to align strategy with operations. The EEP – Educational Objective (EO) 1 is still in development with no procedure to date.

Key strategies include: continued progress to improve learning content use and re-use, access and management including the eLearning Objects Repository (eLOR); renewal of library systems; recommendation of new systems capability (p 69).

2.rationale:
USQ clearly articulates Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) in Strategic and Operational plans, which points to these activities being Business As Usual (BAU), and therefore budgeted via the normal university budgeting processes.

The Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group reports to the ICT Services Committee, which is a check and balance into ICT Projects, services and strategy.

3.rationale:
There is limited specific policy or procedure around course and program level use of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL), beyond that all courses will use USQ’s Virtual Learning Environment (VLE). The Learning and Teaching Policy has a focus of online learning and pedagogy, and a blended learning model.

No official guidelines exist for TEL, but some are currently in draft form (e.g. StudyDesk Expectations and Good Practice Guidelines). Individual schools devise their own procedures, but this is limited. Information and Communication Technology (ICT) standards are related to service and use, rather than TEL.

    • ‘The approved Virtual Learning Environment will contribute to the personalisation of the Student Learning Journey. All Course offerings will involve use of the University's Virtual Learning Environment.’

4.rationale:
Currently, course and program quality is in pilot mode, and relevant guidelines are being raised for approval by the Senior Deputy Vice-Chancellor (SDVC). As such, it is difficult to provide much evidence of existing integration.

Guidelines in draft, include StudyDesk Expectations and Good Practice Guidelines, but currently, these are not integrated into processes and not well communicated.

Some schools have their own procedures, but this is limited and not well communicated.

5.rationale:
USQ committees include stakeholders from various areas of the university. There is some input from academics, but decisions and changes are decided by the technology, and its limitations.

The flow of information and communication is generally perceived as good. Committee minutes are accessible, and school forums provide an avenue for communication.

6.rationale:
USQ adopts a system of Product Custodians, Sponsors, and Managers which works well. However, these are not centrally publicised or promoted. There is confusion at times, particularly from an academic perspective, as to who is responsible for the technologies they use.

The Academic Services Division (ASD) provides operational management of technologies, and this is communicated through forums such as the IT Governance Structure, academic groups, School forums, and systems operational groups.

0.rationale:
Quality assurance processes are a work in progress with an ad hoc approach to the integration of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL), at both program and course level. Common guidelines, such as the StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form, programs of work via eLearning Development (eLD), program support projects, and Course Health Checks by the faculty, provide some consistency of approach and performance indicators.

Course and program quality is mediated by the Academic Division (AD), with the extent of TEL integration dependent on course and examiner requirements. The AD does have a level of expectation in relation to the services offered by Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services and Learning Environments and Media (LEM).

ICT undertake a staff satisfaction survey (2014 is most recent) to ensure their services are quality checked. The survey also includes questions related to the support of technologies, for a quality check on services provided by LEM. An email address (new.studydesk@usq.edu.au) has been established by LEM, for staff to submit, new ideas, change requests, satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the USQStudyDesk (Moodle).

A traffic light approach is not robust enough and accountability is limited. USQ’s online course environment will be the focus of a Course Quality Framework, and the implementation phase of the A-2, A-1 Program Quality Framework being piloted in 2016. Project Management methodologies for ICT Projects provides a clear focus on quality assurance, but this is not at a program and course level.

1.rationale:
When a new service is proposed, a rigorous evaluation process is applied and usually associated with a formal project. There is a collaborative approach between Academic Services Division (ASD), driven by Scholarly Information and Learning Services (SILS), and the Academic Division (AD), as multiple levels of approvals are required, particularly if the service has the potential to become a ‘core system’. For tools (plugins) associated with a core system, a trial phase and quality checks are instigated by Information and Communication Technology Services (ICT) Services and Learning Environments and Media (LEM). In some instances, limited user testing is undertaken due to time constraints.

The One USQ Experience Project (1UEP), Technology Demonstrator sub-project is identifying and trialling technologies, but this is not a mature process at this time.

ICT and LEM’s Learning Systems and Support (LSS) evaluate systems and support data to drive technology decision-making.
