2.rationale:
Regular scheduled updates and patches on core systems are planned for, and resourced from Business As Usual (BAU). Unless forming part of a project, innovation and major improvements are also resourced from BAU, which can put a strain on various departments. Some improvements tend to be ad hoc, or incremental, but not at a consistent pace.

Although infrastructure improvement is supported, there is often limited resourcing for professional development. It can be difficult to access staff resources with the expertise required, in a timely manner.
2.evidence: • USQ ICT Governance Framework FAQs – http://www.usq.edu.au/ict/pmm/ictgovframeworkfaqs

3.rationale:
The student course evaluation, using the MyOpinion system with limited technology-based questions, is a core component of the quality cycle at USQ. Access to view the course reports is limited (Academics teaching the course, Head of School, Executive Dean, Associate Dean Learning and Teaching, Senior Deputy Vice-Chancellor), so this can pose difficulty for departments to drive change.

Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services provide a client satisfaction survey for each staff and student incident they manage, to analyse and plan for continuous improvement.

A key objective in the Academic Services Division (ASD) business plan is: ‘To support the continuous improvement of learning and teaching outcomes for staff, students and other constituents’. (ORMP) This includes an outcome of improving systems for students studying, and staff teaching online. A link between KPIs in the ORMP business plans and forms of evaluation in this space are not clear.

KPIs exist in relation to performance uptime, however there is room to increase this aspect of our work at USQ. System data and information tends to be accessible across courses only, not programs, schools or faculties. For key support areas such a Learning Systems and Support (LSS), there is limited knowledge and access to reporting tools for the Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) modules.

A formal review of major core systems is scheduled in the Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap. A cross-institutional represented group is assembled to review current usage data. Typically a short satisfaction survey is circulated to gain input from end users.

Those outside of committees rarely see results, unless invited to a school committee to share findings. A ‘climate of protectionism’ is perceived in relation to the inability to access academic course data. There is no systematic dissemination of data with a wider audience.

0.rationale:
The One USQ Experience Project (1UEP) is currently investigating options for a robust system, with Sustainable Business Management and Improvement (SMBI) working on a Learning and Teaching (L&T) Dashboard, although a solution is not imminent. A recently formed USQ analytics group, is working on a framework for the development and use of appropriate data and analytical methods.

Access to data, along with reporting capabilities is more readily available from USQ hosted core systems (e.g. Learning Management System (LMS) – Moodle), and limited access to others (e.g. Blackboard Collaborate Web Conferencing). RightNow (customer relationship management software) data is fed into the LMS and a learning analytics plug in provides data to teachers.

There is an ad hoc approach to data collection, usually when a specific need arises (e.g. lecture capture use, repository item status), and no reporting specialist to facilitate a systematic approach.

1.rationale:
The implementation of Ask USQ for Staff will aid in enhancing communication, but this is not a fully mature system yet. With the current Academic Services Division (ASD) structure, responsibilities and processes are fragmented, e.g. Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services and Learning Systems and Support (LSS).

Responsibilities are clearly outlined in ICT’s Maintenance Schedule, and Products and Services Catalogue, Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group’s (LTSAG) Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap (systems upgrade and decommission), and the Learning Systems and Support (LSS) Services Catalogue. It is less clear in relation to innovation, and there is a lack of flexibility.

Although stakeholder representatives attend committee and relationship meetings, information is not disseminated to all stakeholders. It is felt that processes and responsibilities are clearer within the ASD, as opposed to the Academic Division (AD). The ICT Governance Structure outlines the ICT Strategy Board with its three committees (Portfolio, Services and Standards Committees).

2.rationale:
Although there is no policy defining support and training for staff and students in relation to Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) systems, there are clearly defined responsibilities and processes outlined during orientation activities, StaffEd presentations, School forums, ICT Training, and various USQ sites (e.g. Student Computing, USQStudyDesk Skills, Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services, and Learning Systems and Support (LSS) service catalogues). The platform for self-managed staff support delivery, starts with Ask USQ for Staff, leading into areas of the Staff Development Gateway, Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) and Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS).

In the past, student support with learning and teaching technologies was limited, but in recent years, support has increased substantially with the collaboration of ICT, LSS, Library, and Learning and Teaching Services (LTS). The platform for delivery of such support is Ask USQ, which houses the search and standardised view of the support framework, leading onto materials stored in central repositories.

Identification of contact points remains confusing to staff and students, with numerous specialised support teams across USQ.

The Academic Services Division (ASD) Professional Learning Working Group was established in 2015, to define responsibilities for training in systems, with an aim to align training to the Academic Calendar.

3.rationale:
New services, and some major upgrades are usually delivered via formal projects, and are substantially resourced. USQ dedicates recurrent and strategic funding to Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) systems, with projects such as the Learning Management System (LMS) upgrade resourced with the Structural Adjustment Fund (SAF), Integrated StudyDesk, and the One USQ Connectivity Project (1UCP) – Unified Communication, aligning and supporting USQ’s Video Conference Service.

Resourcing challenges occur for mainstreaming systems after project completion and ongoing maintenance. With a lengthy timeline to decommission systems (mostly due to Queensland archiving rules), this can place a strain on resources for maintenance and support. Opportunities for investigation and extending the use of a product are restricted due to resourcing implications.

4.rationale:
USQ’s investment in the experimentation of new and emerging technologies has been limited. An initiative showing great promise in this space, is the One USQ Experience Project (1UEP), Technology Demonstrators sub-project. The project’s aim is to identify and trial technologies for learning and teaching, each in a limited timeframe. StaffEd presentations provide another arena to showcase ideas.

Requests for system improvement, innovation and new technology can be submitted to the Learning and Teaching Systems Advisory Group (LTSAG). However, there are limited procedures available, so this forum relies on word-of-mouth amongst colleagues. Sector scans and USQ’s Project Management Lifecycle are used to evaluate new technologies. Learning Environments and Media (LEM) maintains the Learning and Teaching Systems Roadmap which incorporates formal review periods.

Some staff have been deterred from pursuing wide acceptance of alternative technologies, due to the time lag involved from initial request to implementation as a core system. It is however, important to have a robust process to mainstream tools to validate compatibility, security and support. eLearning Development (eLD) provide some support to academics in the use of alternative technologies when redeveloping courses.

5.rationale:
Staff are provided with opportunities, and encouraged to attend Professional Development (PD) when available. Some external opportunities may be limited due to budget constraints.

The ICT Training team, in conjunction with Learning Systems and Support (LSS), provide regular training on core systems. Biannual StaffEd presentations are conducted to keep staff abreast of core system updates, and deliver Academic Showcases. Teams, in varying degrees, incorporate PD in their Business As Usual (BAU) activities.

In relation to new and emerging technologies, this tends to be a mix of ad hoc, and planned internal or external activities. A small percentage of staff attend conferences such as MoodleMoot AU, ascilite, Equella Navigate, and EduTECH. A community of practice model exists, where those staff attending a conference are encouraged to present, then return to share their experience with colleagues.

6.rationale:
USQ has mature risk management initiatives, with the ICT Governance Structure, including the ICT Strategy Board and supported by three committees – Information Standards Committee, ICT Services Committee and ICT Portfolio Committee. Reporting is ultimately up to USQ Council.

IT Service Management (ITSM) software, which incorporates the Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) processes, is used by Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services, and Learning Systems and Support (LSS) to manage support incidents. Issues are highlighted through the ICT Service Desk and LSS then escalate to the appropriate team for a resolution as quickly as possible. Further usability improvements and system upgrades are handled by a software ticketing system called Gemini. This allows for proper release management and development cycles to be catered for.

Significant issues are also addressed via ICT Customer Relationship Meetings (CRM).

ICT adopts stringent security protocols around authentication, virus protection, backups, and digital rights management within repositories.

There are numerous paths for staff to access technology support, but a lack of cohesion and clarity about the appropriate path is evident. The intention of the Staff Development Gateway, is to provide an avenue to access Academic Services Division staff support from one location, but this site has not been widely adopted.

Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services and Learning Systems and Support (LSS) have defined processes for support, including escalations, which are communicated, but not always followed.

Mechanisms provided for staff technology support include, ICT, LSS, LTS, Ask USQ for Staff, Staff eLE, PLAS, academic orientation, UConnect, Talk Nerdy (weekly videos), StaffEd presentations, Academic Info Bites (information session) and Learning and Teaching Communique. Communication about some of these pathways is ad hoc between departments and across USQ as a whole.

0.rationale:
There is a strong connection between Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL), and strategic plans and policies which express online learning as a hallmark of the university. The USQ Educational Experience Plan (EEP) principles include USQ’s approach to the use and deployment of technology and information systems. The application of technologies is implicit, with all course offerings involving the use of the Virtual Learning Environment (VLE), Moodle and associated tools (USQStudyDesk). This provides staff and students with the ability to use mobile technologies, communication tools, digital media and assessment tools.

The Associate Deans Learning and Teaching communicate with staff regularly at School forums and via a newsletter. Learning and Teaching Services (LTS) assist teachers to develop and review StudyDesk courses with the aid of eLearning projects, and course enhancement processes that use the StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form, which articulates good practice principles and indicators, including the use of technologies and online student engagement. The One USQ Experience Project (1UEP) outcomes will aid Learning and Teaching service application enhancement.

A key aim of the USQ Strategic plan is ‘leadership in physical and digital higher education learning experiences geared to a diverse student constituency’.

1.rationale:
At the course level, there has been a widespread application of the StudyDesk review criteria and indicators by the Academic Services Division (ASD), and Faculties which has led to some strengthening of the connection between Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) and pedagogy. This is currently applied on a relatively ad hoc basis by Schools, but will become increasingly systematised as the USQ strategic course quality system is enacted over time.

At the program level, there has been some use of the StudyDesk review criteria and indicators as part of re-accreditation and program development activities, but these function only at the course experience level. There is less connection between program design, TEL and online pedagogy. There are however, some good examples of whole-of-program implementation, for example, Bachelor of Midwifery, and the Masters of Project Management.

Learning and Teaching Services (LTS) apply good practice principles, and proactively identify issues for resolution during the review and enhancement of courses and programs as nominated by the Faculties. This review and redevelopment process has not been consistently adopted at either course or program level, and not evident that the recommended 5% course audit is being conducted. There is no approved template or set of expectations, that is enforced, about what is expected on StudyDesk, and pedagogical intent is largely left to the individual.

There is potential for improvement in this space with the A-2, A-1 Program Quality Framework being piloted in 2016, and Course Health Check which will be a systematic trigger for course and program enhancements.

    • Designed to serve as a trigger for required course enhancement based on semester and yearly cycles.
  • StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form – https://lor.usq.edu.au/usq/items/1864d79c-8730-407d-9787-b5f503055c0b/0/Studydesk_Review_2015_3.docx

2.rationale:
The StudyDesk review criteria and indicators, are based on sound educational research, legal guidelines, and accessibility guidelines (including Disability Standards for Education). Design principles and guidelines are promoted via avenues such as professional development and StaffEd presentations, but there is no evidence available as to how they are used. Although guidelines are available, it can be difficult locating them in a timely manner, and some are in need of a review and update.

To manage USQ’s legal obligations in relation to copyright compliance of digital objects, Digital Rights Management (DRM) is employed within USQ’s Equella repositories.

Resources and guidelines are not always evidence-based, but rather a sharing of practice. Sites such as Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) and Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS) provide a platform for staff to share their experiences with learning and teaching practices and technologies.

School Learning and Teaching Coordinators attempts to encourage the participation in communities of practice at the School level, have had limited success. Ad hoc communities exist within Education, Health Sciences, Mathematics and Statistics, Nursing, Law, Business, and Engineering.

The USQ Salon Series and StaffEd presentations provide opportunities for knowledge sharing and conversation with internal and external experts.

4.rationale:
Learning and Teaching Services (LTS) dedicate 1 FTE academic staff and the eLearning Development (eLD) section to the development of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) pedagogies. eLD are upskilling from their previous role to provide greater support to academics in the review and development of their online courses. Ad hoc school-based attempts to improve pedagogical practice are ongoing with limited traction, and there are some communities of practice funded.

The Pro Vice-Chancellor (Scholarly Information and Learning Services) and Executive Director (ADFI) is an advocate for the competitive funding opportunities that are available, such as the 2015 USQ Learning and Teaching Grant (e.g. USQ Open Textbook initiative), and 2016 Open Educational Practice Grant. Projects such as the One USQ Experience Project (1UEP) provide a mechanism for technology development, with some alignment to plans such as the Educational Experience Plan (EEP).

5.rationale:
Sustainability is an explicit focus of eLearning tasks within Learning and Teaching Services (LTS), and component of a criterion in the StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form. Other opportunities to support sustainability of Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL), include the Equella repositories, StaffEd presentations and Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS).

There is support with top-down funding, but there is a lack of direction around expectation and interpretation, so the application of pedagogy is inconsistent. Based largely on the technical ability of individual course examiners, some cases are sustainable and others completely unsustainable.

6.rationale:
The MyOpinion course evaluation collects data on all courses, with some questions in relation to pedagogical impact. However, uptake is varied and specific mention of technology enhanced learning is not undertaken. A review of the MyOpinion questions, and an update of platform is currently being conducted.

eLearning Development (eLD) utilise the StudyDesk Design and Implementation Review Form for course review and development, combined with a log of service for work completed on a StudyDesk. There is limited use of before and after review data at this stage. Ad hoc evaluations of support impact occur incidentally as part of Enrich and Promotion applications.

A Course Health Check and evaluation ‘dashboard’ approach to course evaluation is in its infancy, and yet to demonstrate impact. There has been a reliance on anecdotal evidence, though it is anticipated that the advent of the Course Health Check will improve this.

ICT Training courses for staff are not compulsory, but data collected from these professional development sessions, StaffEd presentations and Talk Nerdy (weekly video quick tips) is used to develop a client needs analysis as part of their Performance Cycle. Staff often self-identify their requirements, and one avenue for this is within the Enrich performance management process.

5.rationale:
USQ does aim to provide flexible staff development options which cater for differing skill levels. Training tends to be Toowoomba centric, via video conferencing or both. Staff development via video conferencing systems, needs to be facilitated well, and this is not always the case.

Professional development programs will usually focus more on technically challenged users, so power users may be overlooked. However, with the introduction of StaffEd, we are now showcasing the more experienced users and how they use the technology in an innovative way with their teaching and learning.

Increased engagement with the Academic Division for the delivery of online and physical induction and orientation programs, is proving to be successful.

Online resources are continually being developed and improved for just-in-time access. Talk Nerdy videos are delivered as short snippets of information. Whereas, Ask USQ for Staff provides more comprehensive how-to information, while Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS) and Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) are respectively focussed on pedagogical and contextual areas. StaffEd presentations are delivered face-to-face at the Toowoomba campus, but also incorporates Zoom for Toowoomba and other campus staff to participate.

Learning Systems and Support (LSS), eLearning Development (eLD), and Information and Communication (ICT) Services accommodate varied skill levels when delivering workshops, training or one-on-one assistance. The Equella repositories manage learning objects, and provides the ability to download objects for use offline.

Technical support is most definitely aligned and responsive, with the support provided by Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Services and Learning Systems and Support (LSS). Media Services support audio, video, multimedia and graphics. The Library’s repository team provide user support for the Equella repository instances. eLearning Development (eLD) provide support for a small percentage of courses being reviewed, and LTS have, in the past, provided a range of education support, but this is lacking in 2016. Sites such as Staff eLearning Environments (eLE) and Personalised Learning for Academic Staff (PLAS) are further support mechanisms.

Zoom, cloud-based video conferencing technology, has recently been adopted by USQ for widespread use, with support from ICT and LSS. The One USQ Experience Project (1UEP), Technology Demonstrator sub-project is identifying and trialling technologies, but this is not a mature process at this time. A working party is being established to evaluate the use of tablets. At times, support of technologies appears to be more reactive than proactive, with expectations ever changing.

0.rationale:
At the beginning of most recent strategic cycle (2014 – 2017) the University of Canberra repositioned itself to focus on consolidating and embedding initiatives and projects that take advantage of opportunities emerging in a globally competitive tertiary environment. The DVCE’s portfolio identifies actions that will reposition the University’s teaching, learning and support efforts to provide students with more access, choice and flexibility in how, when and where they use our services. This repositioning established a new learning and teaching context designed to:

  • develop, implement and embed information and communication technologies that enable more online, distance and flexible learning opportunities that meet the strategic goals of the faculties and the needs of their student markets;
  • provide targeted student support services and academic services online through new initiatives and third party services, using educational analytics to assist in identifying where support is needed and directing students to that support;
  • provide technology infrastructure to better track student interactions through their university lifecycle and to facilitate better information about staff roles through identity management;
  • implement engagement strategies to assist students to engage broadly with the University, other students, and university staff and see themselves as a part of the UC community;
  • reviewing and streamlining policies and procedures to enable the University to become more adaptable and agile in a fast moving environment;
  • support staff as they develop and grow their capability and enthusiasm for innovation in teaching and learning; and
  • ensure quality of the University’s courses through multiple mechanisms including course reaccreditation, timely internal reporting, national benchmarking, and action plans for ongoing improvement.
  • To ensure students have equitable access to technological learning resources and services the University supports their needs through the Student Engagement Directorate. Study Skills is part of the Student Engagement directorate and provides a range of face-to-face and online study help programs for UC and UCC students. These programs include drop-in study help sessions, peer learning programs, interactive online study programs, and in-unit support.

The Study Skills & Study Help drop-in sessions invite students to bring assignments and other work where staff are available to help with:

  • professional and academic writing skills
  • understanding and structuring assessment tasks
  • finding journal articles and other information resources
  • referencing and avoiding plagiarism
  • time management and exam preparation

Through the University’s Digital Strategy we have constructed a map of our ICT ecosystem ‘driven by the convergence of four interdependent trends: social interaction, mobility, cloud, and information. Matched to the highest level outcomes there are four digital KPI’s; in particular KPI3 suggests we remove technology barriers and provide a seamless IT experience on and off campus for all members of the university.’ ITM’s Operational Plan includes five improvement themes: prioritise domestic and international students’ digital experience; enable easy and open access to measurement reporting and analytics; remove barriers to enable secure and easy of university systems when and where required; lead innovation through technology within the university; and create stronger engagement with core university stakeholders; including:

  • Establish a yearly ‘techfest’ to engage with students to help solve University problems in creative ways.
  • Trial the appointment of a service delivery liaison officer within ITM. Each liaison will focus on the three core stakeholders of students, faculties and business units.

While the university has in place some specific student training initiatives, it’s clear the future lies in the creation of an adaptive ecosystem; open and accessible to all. Such a learning environment promotes self-enabling agency built upon agreed themes and principles including cloud first; mobile friendly, proactive posturing, borderless and BYOD:

  • Pull back from detailed hand-holding; provide configuration settings and let users work it out for popular services. Supports flexibility of access, reduces cost and effort, empowers users.
0.evidence: Embedded through rationale

1.rationale:
As identified in other Benchmark responses (BM1) capital expenditure (CAPEX) is the University’s spend on capital assets to create benefit, which includes information and technology systems.  The UC Financial Delegation Policy details the financial authority and delegations that may be exercised by staff of the University.  At the University, recommendations for expenditure related to information and technology systems come through the Information and Technology Advisory Group (ITAG), which reports to the Vice-President (Operations). 

As expenditure relates to the ‘student experience’ business units prioritise spending on Technologically Enhanced Learning against strategic and operational priorities. The overall coordination of resourcing is a managed process. Some components of the existing educational technology infrastructure were put in place as part of the SAFFIRE project.

The core of the existing educational technology infrastructure, the learning management system (LMS - currently under review) has been in place for many years with significant expansion as part of the SAFFIRE project. The university maintains a focus on ongoing budget and technical support for UC’s existing services, and  puts in place processes that continually update, replace and/or add educational technology to enable and support learning and teaching innovation, good quality student learning experiences, and proper administrative management of the business of education. Educational technology infrastructure requires regular review and enhancement to respond to changing and emerging needs of UC and its students.

The University has a reporting process where the educational technology ‘owner’ provides the Learning Environments Advisory Group (LEAG) with information about the educational technology. This information includes, as appropriate and meaningful for each of the technology the following:

  • usage in terms of student numbers;
  • usage in terms of integration of that technology by academics into their teaching practice;
  • usage in terms of its use for provision of UC Open or other community-facing initiatives;
  • budget for licensing, upgrades, enhancements and support;
  • impact of discontinuing the provision of the technology/service;
  • rationale for ongoing funding and support of the technology/service.

LEAG acts as a mechanism to recommend the purchase of educational technologies and provides input into the design of physical learning spaces that will be needed soon, or now, or in the future to enable delivery to new and existing student cohorts. LEAG’s Terms of Reference include formal and informal learning environments, physical and virtual spaces. Purchasing and implementation of educational technology oversee:

  • purchase and implementation of enabling and educational technologies to support the expansion and delivery of flexible learning at UC including for example:
  • developing and implementing a customer relations management system to support a consolidated approach to managing student engagement and support. 
  • implementing an Identity Management System that provides access management, identity and access monitoring, auditing and reporting for accountability and directory services such as identity data centralisation, discovery and reuse.
  • acquiring mobile learning applications to develop a student-friendly mobile platform accessible to both students and staff and that covers mobile corporate services including:
  • enrolment and course progression;
  • PC room availability;
  • integration with LearnOnline;
  • mobile UC search functionality;
  • personalised information based on location.
  • creating a webinar/virtual classroom capability and virtual classrooms to provide:
  • tutorial-size virtual classroom teaching environment
  • softphone capability
  • ability to share screen, desktop and applications
  • lab-style teaching, including online interaction, whiteboard sharing and raising hands to ask questions for students logging in remotely.
  • enhanced lecture-streaming capability including live interaction;
  • persistence of sessions to be replayed afterwards.
  • upgrading Moodle capability including digital resource management and Mahara ePortfolio integration.
  • participation in the conceptualisation of, and decisions around, learning space design and furnishing.

ITAG is an advisory group that advise on information and technology management matters. It is the primary ITM governance body of the University; the composition is designed to ensure University business areas are represented and direct ITM resources and investments which enhance core business, including teaching, research and the student experience. Business cases are submitted for consideration to ITAG. The membership is as follows: 

  • Vice-President (Operations) (Chair)
  • Deputy Vice Chancellor, Education
  • Deputy Vice Chancellor, Research
  • Chair of Services Committee
  • Chair of Corporate Systems Working Group
  • Director, ITM
  • Secretary provided by the Office of the Vice President, Operations

A new Capital Management Process for evaluating technology bids is currently under discussion, which includes the formation of a Capital Planning Expenditure Committee. Membership would include the Vice-President (Operations) (VPO), Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Education) (DVCE), Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Research) (DVCR), Chief Information Officer (CIO), and the Chief Financial Officer (CFO).
1.evidence: embedded in rationale

2.rationale:
At all layers of the University’s strategic and operational activity there are reporting mechanisms in place designed to evaluate an initiative’s effectiveness, efficiency and equity. In the context of Technologically Enhanced Learning initiatives the driving strategies obligate some form of evaluation against key performance indicators.

The University’s Digital Strategy is explicit in its demands for high quality review of resource allocation and service delivery. To contribute to the University’s three principles (education, internationalisation and research) ITM’s operational objectives establish improvement measures under regular review:

  • Prioritise domestic and international student's digital experience through:
  • Improving self-help material available to students relating to IT issues.
  • Increased engagement with the student body through focus groups to better understand their needs and wants.
  • Ensure student facing applications and sites are optimised for mobile devices and slow internet speeds.
  • Enable easy and open access to measurement reporting and analytics through:
  • Successful delivery of the 2015 analytics and reporting projects.
  • Increased focus on internal and vendor relationships pertaining to reporting and analytics.
  • Remove technology barriers to enable secure and easy use of University systems when and where they are required through:
  • Increasing focus on the connections between UC and partner organisations such as Tafe Queensland.
  • Ensure new systems that are deployed provide secure and easy off site access wherever possible.
  • Continuous evolution of the UC Technology Road Map to ensure we are ahead of key technology changes in the industry.

  • Lead innovation through technology within the University through:
  • Remaining open to and seeking our strategic partnerships with industry leaders that may lead to innovative and exiting ways to work and study at UC.
  • Continue to develop and explore a more strategic partnership with our existing partners and suppliers such as Wipro, Microsoft and Intersect.
  • Establish a yearly 'techfest' to engage with students to help solve University problems in creative ways.
  • Stronger engagement with core university stakeholders:
  • Trial the appointment of a service delivery liaison officers within ITM. Each liaison will focus on the three core stakeholder groups, students, faculties and the business units.

 

 

Through the Learning Environment Advisory Group (LEAG) the University has a strategy for ongoing ‘over the horizon’ technology planning and implementation. LEAG’s focus on the future and educational technologies that may have, do have, or will have important uses in higher education, as well as a focus on the implications of the use of this technology for learning space design, and the impacts on broader technology-enabling infrastructure.

LEAG is positioned to evaluate and advise UEC and the DVCE on existing, new and emerging technology that could be used in teaching and learning to innovate and improve student experience and learning outcomes, as well as ongoing implications for learning space design. Further, LEAG takes the position that there should be no assumption made that existing educational technology will continue to be supported if it is superseded by better or more appropriate options. LEAG receives reports from the technology owners and makes recommendations to UEC and the DVCE about existing educational technology.

The aim of LEAG is to ensure that UC develops a ‘pilot and evaluate’ culture, where UC regularly interrogates its own assumptions about the educational technology provided for students’ use.

LEAG provides advice to UEC on the types of learning spaces, learning space design and furnishings required to enable and enhance flexible learning. Under LAG’s Terms of Reference the Committee meets a minimum of four times per year. Through LEAG’s auspices, a rolling three-year learning technology road-map for enterprise eLearning systems will respond to demands arising from more flexible delivery, open units and courses, and new technologies and applications coming onto the market.

Through LEAG, the renewal of policies and procedures are kept at pace with the changing technology environment. Implementation and dissemination processes are standardised to ensure that staff are aware of changes to policy and the implications for them. This is facilitated through:

  • development of standardised implementation processes for implementation of additional educational technologies infrastructure;
  • development of standard implementation processes/staff training/promotion for new educational technologies;
  • regular review of policies and procedures against reality, and against emerging needs.

In the case of large technological expenditures the IT Advisory Group (ITAG) ensures a review of its initiatives is regularly undertaken using project parameters. Elsewhere (under policy – BM1) it was noted that: ITAG is an advisory group that advise on information and technology management matters. It is the primary ITM governance body of the University; the composition is designed to ensure University business areas are represented and direct ITM resources and investments which enhance core business, including teaching, research and the student experience.

 

And further, a new Capital Management Process for evaluating technology bids is currently under discussion, which includes the formation of a Capital Planning Expenditure Committee. Membership would include the Vice-President (Operations) (VPO), Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Education) (DVCE), Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Research) (DVCR), Chief Information Officer (CIO), and the Chief Financial Officer (CFO).

3.rationale:
The University has recently established a cross-area team to coordinate better, more streamlined, solutions to identified systems and data issues impacting on matters of University administration; including student learning. This team is convened by Student Administration and includes staff from Teaching and Learning, ITM, marketing, partnerships and international.  The ADEs are also members of the CAT. All members of CAT are encouraged to make the work of the CAT a priority when required, take direction from the team convener, be co-located together where possible, and be available after hours.

The cross-area team is tasked with the responsibility of:

Identifying and documenting immediate and medium-term solutions to current problems;
Establishing a rapid-response team to deal with student-system issues 24/7;
Provide advice on current governance and corporate processes that adversely affect student experience at UC.
Propose methods, budgets and timelines to address more difficult problems.
Provide regular reports and actions for the DVCE to escalate as required.
Documenting student experience expectations: The Office of the DVC(E) will use comparisons with other universities and student feedback to identify how UC’s processes and systems meet student expectations. This information is used to set KPIs and for the CAT to document progress. The Office of the DVCE will provide this information in regular reports to VCG.

For example, the current architecture of our course and unit website information is less user friendly than other universities. Edith Cowan University, also a Callista university, is an exemplar of what is possible (see http://www.ecu.edu.au/degrees/overview).

Rapid response to problems: The CAT will also be responsible for providing rapid response and resolution of issues before they can impact negatively on the student experience.  Response times should form part of the KPIs.

Timeframes for publication of information: The University should investigate the early publication of course and unit information, and the early announcement of timetabling information.  The CAT will establish timeframes beyond which changes to this information occur only in exceptional circumstances, and only where the overall student experience is enhanced by such changes.

Revised governance arrangements: To ensure the efficient notification of important student information, the Office of the DVC(E) will review the University’s governance arrangements, policy and timelines for the approval of course and unit information.  A revised new course approval process has begun operation, and it is timely to review the processes around approval on other types of course and unit changes.
3.evidence: Evidence embedded in rationale

4.rationale:
The Study Help Moodle site allows students to access online training in a range of study skills including digital literacy skills . It contains a number of self-paced, interactive modules and informative resources to help students with topics such as reading and note-taking, participating in tutorials and lectures, using Moodle, Mahara, Blackboard Collaborate and EndNote, research, database searching, assignment writing including essays, reports, literature reviews and annotated bibliographies, referencing, avoiding plagiarism, English language, mathematics and statistics, time management and exam preparation.

Many of the interactive modules are at introductory level, however there are varying levels of difficulty for some of the technology platforms, such as EndNote and Mahara. The content for the Study Help Moodle site is developed by the Study Skills team who also run a face-to-face drop-in service on weekdays on the library where students can access study skills support tailored to their individual needs from introductory to advanced level. The Study Skills team can also create tailored interactive modules for unit convenors to add to their online unit materials to support the study skills needs of their student cohorts.

In addition to this the peer learning study skills program, the Study Skills Rovers, offer 20 minute one-on-one consultations in a face-to-face drop-in model daily in the library from 10am-6.45pm Mon-Thurs, 10am-5pm Friday and 1-5pm on weekends and public holidays. The Study Skills Rovers are students trained to help their peers with general study and digital literacy skills required to succeed in their studies and can tailor the session to the need of the students from introductory to intermediate level. The Rovers assist with assignment writing, information searching, referencing, Moodle and are specifically trained to offer Mahara support from basic to advanced level.  They also offer this service online through phone and computer consultations on Mondays-Thursdays from 4.30-6.30pm.
4.evidence:
A wide variety of self-help training resources provided as well as face-to-face drop-in services that run for extended hours and on the weekends. 

 

Some training resources include multiple levels (e.g Endnote basics 1 and 2), others are only aimed at an introductory level and advanced training resources do not exist.

5.rationale:
The common first year unit (Foundations of Professional Planning - FPP) aims to help students transition to university and plan for their career through a student centred approach.  The unit helps students connect with the university via common approaches and supportive activities, recognise the relevance of their study and non-curricular activities in professional planning (improves retention and engagement) and plan for their career via a five year plan (leads to better employment outcomes).  The FPP unit is intended to benefit all commencing undergraduate students across the university. During FPP studies, students are introduced to and provided training with technological tools such as Moodle, Mahara, Twitter, etc. They examine the implications of the use of technologies such as social media not only in relation to their academic studies but also on into their professional careers. This ensures students understand the value of ethical use of such technologies, through understanding the long term implications of their digital footprint.

The Assessment Policy and Procedures gives advice to staff in the use of social media for learning purposes. This includes alerting students to the same and ethical use of social media. Unit outlines also give a standard warning text about the use of social media for units/assessment items that require their use. Students are reminded that use of social media is a public domain and that their online behaviour should mimic that of the ethics expected in their face-to-face behaviour. As such, online behaviours deemed to breach student conduct rules will be dealt with in the same manner.
5.evidence: Embedded in rationale

6.rationale:
As already established the University has high-level processes in place for procurement and (LEAG) the ongoing allocation of funds supporting TEL and furthermore determining value for money on the basis of Key Performance Indicators (Digital Strategy). Reporting channels are clearly described and as such maintain regular reporting routines; facilitating communication and review as part of the University’s continuous improvement of student development processes.

Where TEL related programs are under development (or redevelopment) and broadly engage resources and/or stakeholders from across the University the motivation to review and evaluate is embedded in project management strategies, two examples include:

Through the Information Technology Advisory Group (ITAG) digital dashboards for students, staff and the executive are under development. This large and heavily resourced Learner Analytics project has been phased-in over two years and has included extensive forms of review and evaluation as the technology is brought online and socialised.
 
Through the DVCE’s portfolio, a Common First Year Unit (Foundations of professional Planning - FPP) has been developed and implemented over the last three years. FPP represents a very contemporary educational design and initiates first-year students in many of the University’s online learning strategies. To ensure its ongoing improvement this whole of University initiative is comprehensively reviewed through regular scrutiny of a representative steering group working to an explicit set of Terms of Reference.

Smaller sub-projects, operationally managed within Business Units, undergo less formal review and evaluation. In most cases these programs establish their own success criteria, keep their own forms of evidence and adjust as needs be to contextual circumstances. By nature, these small programs have ‘only limited or ad hoc integration’.
6.evidence: Interface is an example of evaluation data being collected and used to inform future planning, Study Help site evaluation and usage data collected and used to guide further resources and program implementation.

7.rationale: Pathways clear and accessible, but staff are not always knowledgeable of the training they can recommend to their students – central communication difficult. Study Help site was designed as a one-stop-shop for online training resources to prevent students needing to access a number of different sites, however not all services that provide training use this site for delivery.
7.evidence: Evidence embedded in rationale

There was a range of responses to this question, reflecting a variation in views depending on the business unit's context and relationship with student learning. Technical alignment and technical integration are sometimes confused in designing and meeting student support expectations. The level of shared and common knowledge is assumed but at critical points the 'unknown' gaps become apparent and can cause significant confusion or delays in response. Our systems make some untested assumptions.

As 'flexible' services are rolled-out, user needs are differentiated and general solutions lose personal relevance. Personalisation has escalated the complexity of knotty problems. The University espouses and aspires to a strong focus on student support at multiple points of need. When problems arise there's a willingness to learn from mistakes and improve future practices; across the system.
